description:
I Love this place! Everything about it was amazing. I wasn't a huge fan of German food because I always thought it was too hearty and fattening, but this place  changed my mind.

With me being half German, I wanted to give my German side some real authentic German food. My friends took me here for my birthday. It was The Best birthday dinner ever. The service was great and the owner is so friendly! 

I had the Schnitzel Vom Schwein- breaded pork loin with mashed potatoes and seasoned vegetables. It was so good I ate All of it. My friends ordered the Rinderroulade- tri-tip stuffed with bacon, pickles and mustard, spatzles and red cabbage. They shared some of it with me and I have to say it was amazing! I love the spatzles. And of course we had to have some German bier to go with the amazing food. 

I definitely recommend this place if you like home style cooking. I can't wait to come back for more. Danke!
author: Edie G.

description:
This is a lovely experience. My mom + mom's side of the family are from Germany. Everything about the ambiance is right and really kind of a unique experience in the SF dining landscape of hipster-esque wood + Edison bulbs and American food with a fusion-y twist. 
The food is authentic and very good. Note: the vegetarian schnitzel is actually schnitzel-type breading of vegetables, I kind of expected that they would be a side. Spaetzle were delicious and not too heavy. (You don't feel gross like you just ate a bowl of Mac n Cheese). I was delighted to see Apfelschorle on the menu. Beers + everything were excellent and servers polite. Next time I want to try the potato pancakes and Rote Grutze. 

Thank you, Christiane Schmidt!
author: Teresa M.

description:
Pretty great German place with a 70s kitschy vibe that more people should know about! Great prices and good service.  

I recommend:

Alsterwasser (half 7up/beer)
Tomato/veggie/ salami soup 
Chicken schnitzel with seasonable veggies
author: Grace P.

description: Delicious authentic German food and great service. This place hit the spot and dessert amazing. Throw that in with some German beers and there's no reason not to love this place. Glad I found it while visiting the city. Now open one up in LA!
author: Nicole K.

description: Warm, small cozy resto with retro hip decor. Love that it's run by a friendly family/couple/tight knit group -- service was great for us though they can get busy so not a good place for the high strung patron. Rich, delicious food is served in hearty portions and comes out pretty quickly. The menu descriptions do not do justice to the tastiness of the food. Lighting could be better -- everything looked a bit gray -- but then I guess that's fitting for a German resto :)
author: Kate A.

description: We had dinner here a few months ago and loved it.  I can't recall the specific items but they were all delicious.  The service was good.  One of the 2 servers were very friendly and helpful.  The interior was a little dark and I had trouble seeing my food, and menu.  I would come here again the next time I'm in the mood for German food.
author: t d.

description:
Gah, what a hidden gem.  I was so shocked when I realized this had been here ~two decades and I am only now finding out about it.

From the food to the atmosphere, I just loved my dinner here.  I really enjoy German food but am so tired of the beer hall shtick and was relieved to see something *different*  Despite the fact that it's a German restaurant, there was something about the decor that made me think Cold War era and the show, The Americans....though, on further reflection, maybe it reminded me of the movie, Atomic Blonde (which is the right country, at least).  Either way, it was something kind of fun and kitschy without being over-the-top.

All the food we ate was excellent and hearty - and perhaps more than we needed.  Two of us shared the potato soup with sausage, the tomato soup with salami, the house cured salmon on fitness bread, some kind of mixed sausage platter, and then the bratwurst entree with mashed potatoes.  I liked everything quite a lot, with the exception of the (1) tomato soup (which was good but not really my style) and (2) the mashed potatoes (which needed more salt and/or gravy of some sort).  I'd like to return and try the schnitzel and the kalter hund dessert :)

Service was friendly and efficient.

I'd definitely return.
author: Tay H.

description:
Such a pleasant meal from beginning to end: friendly service and excellent food!!
Found Walzwerk via Yelp (thanks guys), and we chose it over other German restaurants because they served Andechs on tap (the best bier on the planet, people). The food was spectacular! Potato salad may be some of the best I've ever had, with just the right amount of pickles and onions to compliment the perfectly prepared potatoes. I went 'American tourist' and had the schweinschnitzel for my main course: tender pork, and they did not overdo the breading. More importantly, it was fried in fresh cooking oil--so tasty. Mashed potatoes had a wonderful flavor and consistency. We all had several 1/2 liters of Andechs, which was fresh and so damn good. The meal was rounded out by friendly service, and an owner who obviously loves her restaurant . . . Walzwerk gets an A+, and I can't wait to get back here!!

Cheers!
RS
author: Rich S.

description:
The atmosphere and especially the service are so nice, cozy, and welcoming. 

The food was comforting and well made.
author: Michelle B.

description: The sauerbraten is so delicious. Really liked the stuffed cabbage too. Love the atmosphere. Feels like I'm back in Germany. Service is great and beer list has just the right beers you need.
author: Helen C.

description:
This is my favorite German restaurant in San Francisco. 

The ambiance and decor are completely unique; it makes you feel as if you were transported to a home in Berlin that has the perfect mixture of old and new. The food is delicious and the Owner has always been supremely kind and attentive. I make a point to bring all my friends to eat here at least once so that they can experience what home cooked German food tastes like; not all of us are lucky enough to visit Germany ourselves but this is as close as it gets.
author: Bex L.

description:
Having decided to try a new place in SF tonight we fell on the idea of German.   This was a great find for us.  The potatoes pancakes were fantastic and sausage yummy.   Price to quality is solid and I loved the decor.  

I believe they were trying for a East German motif which I enjoyed.   

Great Saturday night place that's not far from work.
author: Dan Q.

description:
My friend and I came here after an Oktoberfest event on Saturday to end our festivities with some good German food. There's no designated parking lot, so we parked a few blocks away. The restaurant itself is quaint, charming, and totally German-themed with signs, memorabilia, and glass cases of mini-alcohol bottles . It was busy at the time (8:30pm), with only the bars being the open spot to be seated at. There are two bars, with two seats per bar. My friend and I sat down and the waitress brought us some German fitness bread starters. We ordered cheese spatzel to start and a bratwurst plate for the each of us.

The cheese spatzle plate was decent and huge. It came with some cabbage, carrots, and sliced green apples. For around $17, you get a plate with a hefty mound of mashed potatoes, sauerkraut, and a grilled sausage. The meal was heavy but really good. We really enjoyed the ambience --the workers are very kind and attentive.
author: Trang T.

description:
With all the great review we had to try this place. This was my first time trying German food and I wish it would've been a better experience. 

Service: It was ok. The waitress did the bare minimum and just enough. She took our order, brought out the food and came over when we wanted to ask for another drink. She wasn't that friendly.

Food: I had the smoked pork chop with mashed potatoes and veggies. The pork chop was too salty, the mashed potatoes and veggies were very bland. I  also had the potato soup with sausage. None were memorable.
author: Sophia M.

description:
It felt like going to a German grandmother's house. The setting is cozy and casual. Service was prompt and polite. 

Start of with the potato pancakes :) 
The pork loin with mushroom gravy and spaetzle and Sauerbraten were both delicious! Look forward to returning next time I'm in the area
author: Nicole J.

description:
First of all, I'd just like to say that I don't even like German food. Usually it's too meaty for me I don't like sausages and I don't like the flavors used. However, this place is actually different and I really loved it!!! I highly recommend this spot and would want to come back. It's amazing I promise!

Please please get the grapefruit beer if you love fruity beers or ciders. It's this beer that tastes like grapefruit juice with a hint of alcohol I think I can drink 5 of these lol! I took a picture because I wanted to find it when I drink now. It tastes pretty similar to the grapefruit sculpin but much sweeter and definitely less alcohol percentage. I got this while waiting for my food and it is so good!

For a starter they give you an open faced sandwich. I didn't really care for it because the bread is not like American soft bread. It's hard dry bread- not my thing. But what can I say? It was free. 

I decided to order the cheese spatzle because it was one of the highlights on yelp. It's kind of like a less cheesy version of Mac and cheese. I didn't know what spatzle was before ordering this but now I can tell you it's something like gnocchi or pasta. I loved my dish but I loved my friends dishes more! They ordered the jager dish(?) which is breaded pork with the spatzle. The fried pork really reminds me of chicken katsu or tonkatsu (the Japanese dishes) but it has a mushroom gravy sauce all over it and spatzle underneath. You probably won't be able to finish anything because the portion sizes are huge here. I ordered the spatzle and my box to take home was extremely full of pasta. 

Next time I plan to get the breaded chicken with the spatzle underneath with my grapefruit beer and have this for two meals. My total was about $25 for 1 dish and a drink-not bad considering I can get two meals out of it.

I think this might be the only German place I love and actually want to come back to. I would highly recommend it especially if supenkuche is crowded because the food is way better and there is no 45 minute wait. 

Can't wait to come back!!
author: Kelley Y.

description:
What a unique place!  I was attending an event nearby and found this place through Yelp, and I am glad I did!

The decor is East Berlin-themed which is super unique and eclectic, and gives the overall feeling of being industrial, quaint and cozy at the same time.  

True to form, the beers on the menu were all German and were excellent -- I had a hefeweizen that I really enjoyed!  For food, I tried the vegetarian schnitzel which was basically breaded and fried root type vegetables that worked really well in that format -- I think it was kohlrabi, beets and carrots -- served with a really delicious sauce.  The mashed potatoes it was served with were outstanding, too... smooth and buttery and flavorful!  The cucumber salad it came with was delicious, too.

The service was friendly and attentive.  You can tell the owner and folks who work there really love the place.  Prices were reasonable.  I'd come back for sure!
author: Christine G.

description:
Winter is coming. 

To which you should reply: "Ein Bier bitteschön!"

The night air outside might be chilly, but you're sitting in the warm insides of Walzwerk. After downing a cold Franziskaner, settle in and notice your surroundings. It feels very ... industrial doesn't it? with Marx, Engels and Lenin staring back at you, you'll probably feel out of place and maybe a bit uncomfortable. 

Good. Because, when you travel outside of the comforts of your (foodie) home, you should feel like that. In fact, having a dinner at Walzwerk feels like you've traveled back in time to East Germany and that's what owner Christiane is hoping for. 

My Berlin born fiance attests to the authenticity of this place. It is as East German as you can get. We took his dad here who was visiting from Berlin and we went full throttle on ordering several dishes: the uber crispy kartoffelpuffer with chive sour cream and applesauce, schnitzel vom schwein (breaded porkloin with mashed potatoes and veggies), grilled pork and veal bratwurst and the rinderroulade.  Both men had their eyes rolling at the back of their heads while making MMM!! sounds. They took spoonful after spoonful of creamy mash potatoes and stuffed it into their mouths. The MMMeats were all traditionally and expertly prepared. 

I felt proud ordering the Rinderroulade :) My fiance's grandma would make this rich dish in the height of the summer when I visit and it's seriously, the best combination of flavors you'll put in your mouth. The melt in your mouth tri-tip is stuffed with bacon, the delightful crunch of the pickles and tangyness of the mustard. It is soft, crunchy, savory and overall, a wonderful concoction that'll make your belly very happy. Try it. 

I'm so fortunate to have Walzwerk in SF. This is Eastern German cuisine done right.
author: Janice C.

description: Amazing food. German bier on tap. An authentic experience that captures the real East Germany. Ironically it may be the only surviving GDR gastropub in the world. Ten thumbs up!
author: R C.

description:
I've just returned from an exquisite meal here.  I was with a group of two other musicians, and I sought the place out motivated by both a love of German fare and a desire to experience some Ostalgie.  The space is adorned with plenty of memorabilia from the DDR; The Ampelmännchen card on the restroom door was a particular favorite of mine.  

We were seated quickly, and our needs were well attended to.  The bier was excellent, and the food was well-executed.  Service was friendly without being obsequious.  

I chose Sauerbraten and it was excellent- Sometimes it's a dish that somehow manages to be dry despite the sauce, and in this case it was perfectly done and the flavors were spot on.  The bread dumplings were firm but not stodgy, and the red cabbage was well seasoned and had just the right amount of tooth.  My colleagues had similarly excellent experiences with the Schnitzel dishes.  While the food is hearty, and the portions exceedingly generous.  I was able to leave without feeling unwell!  

I regret that I didn't have desert. 

This is a wonderful restaurant, and I will make it a point to return any time I am in the Bay Area.  While of would be helpful to have some experience with German cuisine before you go it is not essential.
author: Jacques C.

description: More of a 3.5.  Definitely a unique restaurant the moment you walk in the door.  The bratwurst was fine, although I'd say that the sauerkraut and mashed potatoes were actually the better parts of the dish.  The salmon with special spaetzle that my girlfriend got was like fried rice, except using spaetzle - pretty interesting.  Will certainly try more of the beer selection next time.
author: Simon L.

description: This is the best German restaurant in town. The food, beer, and desserts are all delicious. The decor is authentic and makes me feel like I'm eating in someone's dining room near Alexanderplatz in Berlin.
author: Nicholas P.

description:
My wife and I stopped here for dinner before theatre in SF.
Great authentic food and nostalgic decor from behind the Iron Curtain in East Germany...my sweetie loves it!
author: Johnny J.

description: Small, cute venue close to Rainbow Grocery, there's a nice selection of unique beers and comfort foods. The owner is super friendly. Good place to warm the belly with traditional fare.
author: Kimberly H.

description: Really authentic restaurant, im a fan of their beer on draft! Personally enjoy the wienerschnitzel! Recommend making a reservation in advanced.
author: Antonio R.

description:
So freaking goooooooood! And with vegetarian options too? I am in love! Had the cheese spaetzle, potato pancakes and light lager. YES! YUM! I loved the decor too.. reminded me of my German grandma's house. 
Can't wait to come back!
author: Joseph C.

description:
Started off with kartoffelpuffer (small potato pancakes with chive sour cream and applesauce). It was good with the chive sour cream and weird with the applesauce. There wasn't enough chives in the sour cream to taste the chives, so it just tasted like regular sour cream. 

For the entree I ordered the schnitzel vom huhn (chicken breast breaded, boiled potatoes and cucumber salad, but replaced boiled potatoes with mashed potatoes) and my boyfriend ordered the jägerschnitzel (porkloin with spätzle and creamy mushroom sauce). I really like the balance of the creamy mashed potatoes with the fried chicken breast. The chicken breast was juicy and tender. The creamy mushroom sauce was really good. I don't remember much of how the porkloin tasted. The highlight of that dish was definitely the sauce. 

Both entrees were really heavy and because of that I think one entree can be shared with two people.
author: Michelle T.

description:
TL;DR It's not a fancy place, but food is great!

Great place for someone who wants to experience authentic yet surprisingly familiar food in low key but stylish place.
Beer: Opt for German on tap - either light or dark lager (I had both :)
Appetizers: Matjes Hering comes along with beer, as well as German style cold cuts delicatessen.
Entree: Pork schnitzel was great, and Rinderroulade even better (a bit sweet garnish).
Note: Dishes come in full size and priced well in-line with food quality.
Service: casual, polite and attentive.

Danke schön!
author: Sergey G.

description:
I don't know much about German cuisine except the word "Hefeweizen" so that's exactly the beer I ordered to pair with my food. But more on that later. My boyfriend brought me to Walzwerk, and we were immediately seated in the nook by the front door. It felt cozy and romantic, complete with votive candles. This place seems good for pairs or even groups. Note that it's only open for dinner.

I decided on the kassler, which is smoked pork chop with mashed potatoes and brussels sprouts. So good and such huge portions! The mustard, of course, completed the whole meal. They have a wide selection of German beers here. I would love to come back again and try more of them, as well as other items on their menu. The spätzle is definitely on my list. The service here seems very hands-off which can be nice, though I remember needing to flag down the waitress multiple times. Anyways, I love this restaurant and would highly recommend it!
author: Stefanie C.

description: Great food and a comfortable oasis on a rainy night. Attentive service, though a little confusing. The third member of our party was arriving late. One server came by to tell us to give her five minutes' notice as that's how long the schnitzel would take. We said, here's your notice -- she's five minutes away. Five minutes later, another server also asked for notice -- this time, 15 minutes, which is how long it would take. We repeated that she was almost here. She arrived soon after, and in fact waited 15 minutes. Ah well. The best laid plans...
author: Carl B.

description:
We were a party of two and once inside the restaurant, we were not greeted with a hello, or a smile, which sadly I thought set the mood for the rest of my experience there. 

The restaurant had great decor with many interesting tings to look at. The service felt rushed and scattered, which I understand, when you have a full restaurant with only two servers working the entire floor. 

I was excited to see so many great reviews on yelp and by word of mouth. We ordered a side of the cucumber salad, which was refreshing and had a good balance of sweet & sour. The Grapefruit Heffenweizen is a delicious treat to savor. 

I ordered the Bratwurst and for being an entree, it was super disappointing. I have cooked authentic home made Brats before and questioned how far ahead of time the sausage was cooked, then sat under the heat lamp for a bit longer? 
It was so shriveled and dry by the time it made it to our table. The mash potatoes were bland and the sauerkraut and mustard were the only decent tasting things on my plate. My partner ordered the Veggie stuffed cabbage roll which they said was very good and it looked that way.
author: Jess M.

description:
One of my favorite German restaurant in the city, features authentic East Germany aesthetics. Both their drinks and entries are amazing. I'm a sucker for sweet alcoholic drinks, so Berliner Weiße is a must every time I go. They also make Radler which is Pilsner + Sprite. For main dish, I love Thüringer Bratwurst. I have heard good things about their Schnitzels as well. To be honest, I don't think you could go wrong with this place, just try everything.

They take reservations if you have 6 or more which is super convenient. I would recommend this place for a friends gathering :)
author: Angel C.

description:
Small restaurant on S Van Ness.  A bit off the beaten track but makes parking a cinch.  

Great beer selection.  Pilsners, wheats , darks and I settled for the gaffel koelsch.  

Has an even greater German food selection.   Last night had the potato pancake.  The one here is made with mashed potato, not grated potato so the texture is slightly unique.  Comes with sour cream and apple sauce.  

Also had the roulade (thin rolled beef) baked in a stew.  Served with red cabbage and spätzle.  Very good and very authentic in my humble opinion.  

For desert tried the special. It was a pear cobbler served with vanilla ice cream.  Also excellent.
author: Marcus K.

description: My favorite German restaurant in the Bay Area. Friendly staff including the two women who own it, authentic kitch decor, and tasty (but heavy as most German food is) food! Love the lightly sparkling German wine too!
author: Jody M.

description:
I crave Walzwerk on a regular basis. I wish I didn't because it's so far for me, and such a tight restaurant that's hard to just walk in. I wish they were on OpenTable. ;)

I love that they have vegetarian offerings. I'm totally a carnivore, but I always want to take my vegetarian friends to unexpected, delightful places, like Walzwerk.

The spaetzle 'n' cheese (as I'm calling it) is amazing. It's paired with 3 cold salads on the side, which go so, so well with it (mouth, salivating).

The other dishes are bold, flavorful and unctuous. I can't wait to try the desserts next. 

Expect to pay $20-30/person.
author: Sarah W.

description:
Several years ago there was someone special in my life who loved me. She really liked this place. We came here once together, I think it was her birthday and her sister joined us. We've long since gone our separate ways. I was a heartless fool and I let her go. But today is her birthday and so I'm thinking of her, and every time I pass by this place on my shopping trips to Rainbow Grocery I think of her, and that night we dined here, and all the times we were together. I'd like to call her up and wish her happy birthday today, but I'm sure a phone call from me wouldn't make her happy and so I'm not going there. I know I should 'move on' but for me there is no moving on, my life is over.

But what do you care about my memories, my heartache and regret? You want to know about the restaurant, of course. Well, I remember liking the food, although to be honest I can't even remember what I ordered from the menu. I was still drinking back in those days, so I really loved the tall pint glasses of great German beer. The fact that I am vegetarian limited my food choices but there were still some very tasty menu items to choose from. I loved the atmosphere, just like someone had turned the ground floor of their home into a restaurant by adding a bar up front and setting up chairs and tables in the adjoining rooms, hanging pictures on the walls, everything very domestic and unpretentious. The wait staff were nice.

But mostly I remember how much my partner loved the food, and her happiness and relish over her favorite dishes, and how wonderful it was to share this fundamental enjoyment of what life offers us, the food we're given from this beautiful earth, prepared with love by fellow humans, served with kindness and simplicity, consumed with gratitude and pleasure in the company of those we love. I miss her so very much. And I will never eat here again because without her it would come with so much grief and sorrow, and I don't belong here, there's just no place for me in this world without her.

So Happy Birthday to the one I loved. May she live a joyous, long and healthy life, and may her cup always be full. Prost!
author: Ferrara P.

description: Great food great time yesterday.  Please let the gentleman I spoke to at the bar from East Germany I found the Trabant model I got in February of 1990
author: Kristian A.

description:
I love this place.
I am originally from northern Italy, and somehow in my region we develop an appreciation for German food (maybe it's because of the climate?), so I really enjoy coming here.
The food is great, I always get the schnitzel, the potato pancakes and the strudel. However I enjoy exploring the menu, especially if I am sharing with others.
The service is great, Christiane is a wonderful host, and even in the very busy nights, when we had to wait to get seated, I never felt ignored.
The ambiance is another good reason to come here, just wonderful, East Berlin themed.
Which is why I found ridiculous when other reviewers have a problem with it, would they have to write home if an Italian restaurant would sport a picture of Columbus, or Julius Cesar? I understand that some of these historical figures are controversial, but they are just part of the decor, you know "Good Bye, Lenin" style.
My favorite comment was from somebody gulping because of the pictures of "German dictators", excuse me? Where exactly did you see German dictators? People are weird.

Anyways if you crave earthy food and a different kind of ambiance, this is your place!
author: Amira T.

description: I loved it here... the Formica, the vibe, the East German memorabilia, the music... it was the complete package... I visited the East a few years after the wall came down and honestly this is close! The food is good proper winter stodge, from herring, schnitzel, potato and great beer... a fantastic experience with good friends around the kitchen table
author: Reg B.

description:
I keep coming back, because it keeps being oh so good!

Great place, great people, great food, great ambiance! :-)

Danke, Christiane, weiter so! :-)
author: Schorschi A.

description:
Always a quality meal here! Nice to find a place near the Victoria Theater that doesn't have too much of a wait and has good food. 

THE WAIT: About 10 minutes for a group of four around 7:45pm on a Wednesday night.

See my photos for additional details.

* Amuse-bouche: Bread, meat, cheese, pickle, radish - 3.5 stars
Nice and simple, but bread was on the dry side. 

APPETIZERS & SALAD
* Gebeizter lachs (house cured salmon w/ horseradish cream, red beet salad, fitness bread) - 3.5 stars
Simple, good, not super memorable. The bread is dry, but the beets are moist. 

ENTREES
* Kassler (smoked pork chop, mashed potatoes, brussels sprouts. $18) - 4 stars
Solid. I wanted a big chunk of protein and that's what I got! The potatoes have chunks - I like the texture. The mustard is crazy sharp, goes great. Sprouts were boiled & flavorless though.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
Very nice restaurant with awesome owners. Will definitely be back!
Food is great and choice of foreign beers is a must.
author: Romain D.

description:
Get there just after they open on weekends, to get good seats. Fills up fast!
Amazing food.
author: John L.

description: Really good and authentic German food! I love the spätzle, and super good schnitzel! Broad variety of beers on tap and in bottles. And finally, there is a good underberg to finish a proper German dinner. :)
author: Tobias R.

description:
What a great place! The staff was very friendly and welcoming (and hilarious).

The food was fantastic! I recommend getting the Kassler vom Grill (smoked pork chop bone in, mashed potatoes & brussels sprouts). It was so tender and flavorful. It was perfect! :)
author: David T.

description:
One of my favorite secret spots in San Francisco. The food, service and ambiance are excellent; it's like dining at someone's home.

The rinderroulade, sauerbraten, vegetarische krautroulade, and jägerschnitzel are delicious!

I've only been a few times, so I'm really going to have change that.
author: Michael B.

description:
Best potato pancakes in SF- moist, flavorful, perfect combo of sweet, salty and refreshing with the apple sauce and sour cream.

The Cheese Spaetzle (Kasespatzel) was another favorite for sure.

I love the nostalgic nod and low key ambience with mix and match plates that make you feel like you're in your aunt's kitchen.
author: Lisa M.

description: I absolutely love this place! My son brought me here a few years ago and I'm now hooked! Great selection of food and beers. The service is fantastic, it really does feel like like your dining in someone's home. The food is very fresh and delicious! So many layers of flavor...cherry sauce on apple and bacon stuffed chicken breast? Omg! Everything on their menu is awesome!
author: Diane G.

description:
This past week-end I had house guests from Brazil. My friend's 14 year old son has been to Germany, has a German language tutor and loves German food. His 19 year old sister got her wish to go to a vegan restaurant in the Mission, so her brother got his wish to have German food. Fortunately I have known about Walzwerk for many years and bicyle past often so it is in the front of my mind. 
Because we were coming  on foot from the  vegan place, we arrived at 9:05 pm.  Restaurant had at least 3 free tables, although as I recall two were rather small. The host in a somewhat brusque manner informed us that they were expecting  some parties and there was no way they could serve us. 
There was no "Let me see if someone is leaving", "Let me see what  we can do", "Would you be willing to share a table", "Can you wait a few  minutes".  Could it be that he was just an employee who preferred  to not have the arduous task of serving dinner to a group of four and was trying to make sure he got out for his hot date as soon as possible after closing time? (which I see from the website is 10 pm) 
I already decided I would never go back, and was chagrined to see tonight from the online menu that I will miss some delicious sounding veggie dishes and the  Radlberger lager, which is one  of my favorites.   
As for our dinner, we were not to be denied, we jumped in my Audi to go to the  new wurst restaurant in downtown  San Mateo, which fortunately is open until midnight. It was great, and friend's 14 year old son was "sehr zufrieden." Wirklich.
author: Roy G.

description:
Tonight was my first time coming here.  It's a very small & eclectic space with mismatching chairs/tables. I found that part to be quite charming & welcoming. 
They only accept reservations for parties of 4 or larger.  We were only a party if 2, but the wait was VERY short!  What I really appreciated was although there was a table for 4 available, and a party of 3 behind us, they didn't skip our place in line to seat the larger party. Instead offering us the larger table. It was VERY much appreciated!!
BOTH of the servers were fantastic!!!  VERY friendly & SUPER accommodating!!  I had asked to swap my 2 sides for 1 different side.  The waiter didn't even bat an eye. 
When the order came, only one of the sides had been swapped out.  It wasn't an issue at all. They simply brought me a side bowl of the correct item. 
I ordered the pork schnitzel & asked to replace the mashed potatoes & veggies for spätzle.  I've traveled to Germany more times than I can count, and this is always my go to dish. It was delicious, and very filling!!
Both of the servers had smiles on their faces & seemed to really enjoy their job. 
It IS a bit loud in there, so be prepared to repeat yourself to whomever you're dining with. 
Parking was surprisingly very easy. In fact, we parked almost directly in front of the restaurant. 
I'll most definitely be coming back for more. The next time I'm craving schnitzel, I know where to go!
author: Reed S.

description:
Service was wunderbar.  Both of our servers were great at explaining the dishes and making everyone feel welcome at this starkly appointed replica of the former East Germany.
From the unadorned light bulbs overhead, to the chipped enamel tables set against dimly painted yellow walls, we felt as if we walked into a time warp of the former Soviet-era.

Both the mood and tone were quite inviting and relaxed.  It's as if you walked into someone's home and sat down for a realistic, home cooked German meal.  I don't think there were 10 tables in the small dining room.

The beer selection is pretty cool and exciting.  We were steered to the bottled Gaffel Kölsch and the draft Weltenburg Helles.  They were delicious!!  German beer---love it!

A small appetizer was immediately brought to the table.  It was made up of thinly sliced, small square bread bottoms with cucumber, sliced radish, sour cream, cheese and a little piece of bratwurst on top.  I was expecting more flavor but didn't get it.

The kartoffelpuffer came next.  We shared these potato pancakes served with a side of sour cream and applesauce.  They were dense and plain tasting--the applesauce was the better choice to kick up the flavor.

I ordered the schnitzel vom schwein and was served a large portion of a breaded, pork cutlet.
The accompanying mashed potatoes were creamy and tasty.  The pork was very good too.
The side vegetables were a fresh mix of squash, carrots and brussel sprouts.

My partner had the hühnerbrust gefüllt mit äpfeln und speck.  This rolled chicken breast was stuffed with bacon, apples and raisins and covered in a white gravy.  What looked like it should offer a-- "wow"--- in flavor,  just didn't bring that much taste.  The accompanying sides were the same as above.  Again, outstanding mashed potatoes.

I'm sorry, but the apfelstrudel dissapointed.  The dough was heavy and rubbery.  I had a hard time getting through it with my fork.  Apple strudels that I have had in the past were crisp, crunchy and full of flavor.  This was not.

We may have played it safe with the dishes we ordered.  Next time we visit, I'd like to experiment with their cabbage and sausage dishes and search for more flavor.

All in all, it was a nice experience and we are so lucky to have all of these choices in SF.
author: Thomas D.

description:
We ordered the Jaeger schnitzel, sauerbraten and the bratwurst entree, along wit the cold plate appetizer.
First of all, the appetizer, the dark beer and the German red wine was good. 

Initially, when we walked in, there were only 2 other tables and the our waitress was pleasant to us. 
Well, unfortunately The food came out cold..which is always such a disappointment after waiting 30 minutes. There was only one server who was seating people and serving them simultaneously. By the time our food came out for the first time, the restaurant was packed. 
After we told our waitress that our food was cold, she picked it up, still pleasant, yet mumbled that it "felt warm" well, the second time the food came out, my Jaeger schnitzel and the mashed potatoes in the Bratwurst dish were still cold. Only the Sauerbraten was hot. 
 
After telling our waitress for the second time that our food came out cold, she yelled at me in front of all the guest and my family that she "couldn't help me" and even had the nerve to complain back to me for "flagging" her down to order beverage and food too many times.
Isn't that your job??? 
I understand it's a busy night and it's not easy to serve everyone, but seriously her attitude was completely uncalled for and very unprofessional to say the least!

My husband was in complete shock and asked to leave.
I left in tears as I was disrespected by the server in front of everyone! She then had the nerve to complain in German loudly about us in front of the guest by the bar, when we were just trying to pay for the food that we did not eat..

Unfortunately, I can't review on the food, because we didn't have a chance to really taste it, but on the service side, I can say that it was a very VERY disturbing experience for me and my family that I did not expect!

We drove 2 hours to go there based on reviews and we will never go back.
author: Monika V.

description:
Had a reservation ahead of time for 5. The restaurant is small, cozy, and noisy. I loved the ambiance as it reminded me of the time I was in Germany. 

Ordered the following items:
hefeweizen draft beer - 0.5L, tasty and worth it.
potato soup with sausage - thick potato base with a sausage. very tasty
bratwurst thüringer art - delicious, but only comes with 1 pork & veal sausage which is quite expensive considering the kassler and rinderroulade are only $1 and $2 respectively more expensive.
kassler -  smoked pork chop looks like a big piece of ham, but tastes like pork chop and has a smoky flavor to it. mashed potatoes seems to be the go to starch for German dishes.
rinderroulade - tri-tip stuffed with bacon was so flavorful. the spätzle was also delicious and not too doughy. 
apfelstrudel - a bit too sweet for my liking, but well made.
kalter hund - layered cake made of butter cookies, chocolate and rum. This was a very unique tasting dessert, dense yet airy at the same time. It is certainly worth a try.

The service here is quick and attentive. I'm definitely coming back for some authentic German food.
author: Edward W.

description:
4.5 STARS 

I have a love and hate relationship with large group dinners.

I love being able to get together with friends who I rarely see these days because of our busy schedules. Seems like everybody and their mama is getting engaged, married, and/or knocked up on FB...except us. We're over here like, "Heeeeeey, look at my furbaby in his OOTD".  *le sigh*

I hate organizing group dinners because finding a reasonably priced restaurant in SF that can accommodate a large group AND have easy street parking is like finding a unicorn. Then, with some restaurants you have to deal with stupid penalty charges if you have flaky friends who don't even bother texting that they can't make it. 

Walzwerk is that unicorn.

The East German menu is carniwhore friendly with large portions at very affordable prices. They have a private room in the back that can accommodate up to 20 people, and finding street parking in this area of the Mission is not impossible. If you have a group of 10+, there's a set dinner: sampling of all the apps and 3 shared entrees for $28 pp which is dirt cheap for SF. Beer and wine only. Reservations accepted for parties 4 or more.

We had less than 10 people so we ordered a bunch of apps, our own entrees, and shared several desserts:

A P P S
*Kartoffelpuffer: Potato pancakes w/ chive sour cream, applesauce ($7): http://bit.ly/1JsqBh4
*Matjes Herring w/ sour cream, apples, onions, pickles, pumpernickel bread ($9): http://bit.ly/1D8XQ7L
*Gebeizter Lachs: House cured salmon, horseradish cream, marinated beets, fitness bread ($9): http://bit.ly/1Ipa1tm

The group favorite was the potato pancakes. Sure, they were just glorified hash browns but they were delicious with the creamy sour cream and nicely tart applesauce. The herring and house cured salmon were standard. We enjoyed the accompanying marinated beets which were slightly pickle-y. Not a fan of German bread because of that grainy texture. 

E N T R E E S
*Jägerschnitzel: Unbreaded porkloin w/ spätzle, creamy mushroom sauce ($16): http://bit.ly/1HYQGSP
*Kassler: Smoked pork chop w/ mashed potatoes, brussels sprouts ($18): http://bit.ly/1ScwCUT

The entrees are the star of Walzwerk's menu. Everybody loved their entrée. They're huge, hearty, and comforting. My Jägerschnitzel (unbreaded) was tender and showered in this sinfully delicious creamy mushroom sauce (great depth of flavor). The spätzle absorbed this yummy sauce which made it even more delightful to enjoy these tiny dumplings. Highly recommended! 

I had a bite of the Kassler which would satisfy any pork chop lover. The thick cut pork shop was surprisingly very tender and moist with a pronounced smokiness. 

D E S S E R T S
*Apfelstrudel: Filo dough filled w/ apples, raisins, nuts & brandy, vanilla ice cream, whipped cream ($7): http://bit.ly/1SL4zH0
*Weekly Special: Bread Pudding w/ caramel sauce, whipped cream ($7): http://bit.ly/1gju9qZ

Desserts were disappointing which is why I'm rounding down my rating. The Apfelstrudel tasted like an undercooked apple pie. Didn't taste any flaky layers from the supposed filo dough and the apples were still hard.

The bread pudding was better than the Apfelstrudel but just ok. We also ordered the Rote Grütze Berry Pudding  (sorry, no pic) which I wouldn't recommend. The "pudding" was watery and very tart. 

It was packed on a Saturday night and there were only two waitresses who rocked it. They were knowledgeable and quick on their feet. They also have their sh*t together in the kitchen as we got all our dishes very timely. 

I've been to Walzwerk before my Yelp days and it's just as good as I remembered it. Next time, I'm going to bring an ACME baguette to sop up all that mushroom gravy deliciousness from the Jägerschnitzel. Shhhh.....
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Had dinner here tonight (Friday). Came in around 5:40, so they'd just opened, and we were the first ones there. We got seats at the front, by the windows. Welcoming staff (owners, right?). Great decor, nice DDR touches.

Nice complimentary bites to start with. We had the great grapefruit beer everyone has been raving about in their Yelp reviews - yep, it is pretty good!

For entrees, we had:

- Jagerschnitzel (unbreaded pork loin with spaetzle, and mushroom sauce). My entrree. Wow, so good. The spaetzle had a nice crust/crunch on them, so they had a nice firmness along with the soft. Mushrooms and sauce were very tasty, as was the pork.
- Schnitzel vom schwein (breaded pork loin with mashed potatoes and vegetables, including Brussels sprouts). Daughter reported the mashed potatoes were very tasty, and the pork looked really good too (to me!). 
- Kassler (smoked pork chop with mashed potatoes and Brussels sprouts). The pork chop was very tender and perfectly cooked. Husband also liked the potatoes very much.

We had for dessert:

- Kalter Hund ("cold dog" - great name) - layered cake with butter cookies, chocolate and rum, served with a little sauce on the side. This was delicious. These types of cakes can be dry, which is why I usually stay away from these, but this was very good, not at all dry.
- Rote Gruze - this was a red berry pudding with raspberries, strawberries and blueberries, made with cream of wheat (!) and vanilla sauce. I was a bit worried with a dessert made with Cream of Wheat, but it was actually very good. Wasn't sure what to think of the texture (a bit grainy), but we enjoyed it very much.

Definitely a good choice for dinner tonight, and will be back!
author: June W.

description: A nice cozy quaint little restaurant that feels like Europe once you are inside.  We used the back room to seat 15 comfortably.  All dishes were delicious.  Service was excellent.  They would split, share, dishes for what we needed and even suggested best way to serve them.  We tried bratwurst, schnitzel, käsespätzle and speck washed down with dark beer.  Will be back to explore more of the menu.  Prost!
author: I Be E.

description: I love Walzwerk. I've been to a few German restaurants in SF and none compare to the authenticity of this place - German owners who still carry the accent, vintage German posters on the walls, German beer, and amazing Bavarian food! I have been to Munich and have eaten Bavarian food and this place hits the spot!
author: Leonora H.

description: Delicious and authentic German food in a cozy setting! Easy to get a seat and service is good. Took my dad here who said it was just like the food his German grandma cooked for him. The best German food you will find in SF.
author: Kelly R.

description: Incredible, authentic German good - I can't speak highly enough about this restaurant. The food is well prepared, flavorful and true to how the dishes are made back in Germany. The staff and owners are fantastic - I can't wait to go back again.
author: Steven M.

description:
Really, really good. I'd never had German food before coming to Walzwerk, so I really had no idea what to expect before walking in. I wound up going with a friend on a Thursday evening for dinner, and surprisingly, it was super full. I would say, make a reservation if you know for sure that you want to come. But even if you're just walking in, the line won't be too long if you're there on a weekday.

Service is great. All the servers are super friendly, patient, and helpful, which is great because the menu has some pretty foreign terms. Wait was somewhat long (15-20min to get our main courses), but our server checked up on us during that time to make sure we had enough water/drinks/etc. Location is pretty sketchy, but if you are with someone else, it shouldn't be a problem walking around.

The food itself is definitely unique but very, very good. My friend and I shared an appetizer and an entree. The matjes herring (basically a potato salad-esque dish with fish instead of potatoes) appetizer was the most interesting of the night. I still can't tell if I liked it or not, but it did present me with such a unique flavor composition that I have never experienced before. I'd say that the flavors of the sauce are really similar to your typical potato salad. The texture of the fish, however, was the most unfamiliar to me. Upon first bite, my friend and I both didn't know if we had actually eaten the fish or if it was something else. We had to try a few more pieces before confirming that it was indeed the fish. Chewy, cold, and didn't remind me of fish meat at all. Not my favorite dish of the night, but still worth a try if you're want to experience new flavors.

I absolutely adored the entree that we ordered - the vegetarische krautroulade, stuffed cabbage with lentils, root veggies, and lots of other good stuff, smothered in a fragrant tomato sauce. The cabbage was infused with the filling and the tomato sauce, so it was really delicious. The stuffing was combined in sort of a mash consistency, and it was just bursting with delicious flavor! All of the many ingredients used complemented each other very well, especially when mixed with the tomato sauce. The serving size is also super large and well worth the $15 that I paid for the dish. I still have half of the dish sitting in my fridge for dinner tonight!

Overall, I was very pleasantly surprised by this restaurant, especially because I had no idea what German food was! I've heard the beers here are superb, so if I do come back, I'll definitely try the drinks and more of the hot foods... and maybe pass on some of the bizarre cold appetizers.
author: Sheila D.

description:
5 Star from the moment we were seated until we left.  Haven't been here in about 3 or 4 years and it's still Fabulous.  Our server, Yahni (sp?) was delightful and she was super busy, taking orders, bussing tables, getting drinks, making change and she NEVER lost her zeal and provided impeccable service. As busy as she was she never faltered on attention to detail and giving us the time we needed to understand a few items on the menu.

Drinks -  3 highly recommended dark, but light beers.

Appetizer - A Special - Sautéed onion on a puff pastry with Sour Cream and a nicely dressed salad.

Entree #1 - was actually 2 appetizers, small potato pancakes with chive sour cream and applesauce, 3 fluffy and not greasy pancakes and house cured salmon with horseradish cream, marinated beets and fitness bread, nicely plated and extremely fresh. My guest was supremely pleased.

Entree #2 - Also a special, which was a Pork Shoulder stuffed with apples and possibly apricots and cheese (can't remember the type of cheese), it may have been ricotta, but not sure with a light gravy on top, served with roasted potatoes and really fresh and crispy green beans. After my 1st bite, I was in Heaven.  Everything was superbly cooked to perfection.

Entree #3 - Sauerbraten marinated beef, mushroom bread dumplings and red cabbage.  Again, superbly cooked and plated.  Mushroom bread dumplings were fluffy and light and the red cabbage had the right amount of "pickling", also a winner with another guest.

Service was very attentive but not overbearing.

Next up... yes... we still had a little room... Dessert.  The gal had overheard it was my Birthday so when she presented me with "another special" of the night a Rhubarb Tart, it came with a Well Wish Birthday Candle.  So sweet of her to remember.  Other party had the filo dough filled with apples, raisins, nuts & brandy, vanilla ice cream and whipped cream.  It didn't appear to be made with Filo dough as it was a lot thicker and not as flaky as I have remembered in the past, but it was still very good.  We all ordered our Ice Cream on the side, which was delicious and honestly seemed homemade.

The whole experience was exceptional, right down to the low key ambience. Very much like you would experience in East Germany.

Extremely good value for the whole meal.
author: Marla B.

description: My go-to now. Definitely authentic eastern German cuisine. Try the soljanka, the cold cut platter, Roulade and Kalter Hund for desert. Satisfied.
author: Kaden I.

description: Great simple food with good size portions and reasonably prices. The service here is grade A!
author: Krystle S.

description: This is my favorite restaurant in the Mission. The decor is simple and eastern Berlin inspired. There is history behind a lot of what is around you. The owner is often there so you can ask about all the digestif bottles on display and she will tell you. Love the herring salad and salmon toasts. I usually fill up on their small plates and end it with an underberg. Very welcoming for large parties as you can have the backroom for a family style party with no extra charge.
author: Lauren A.

description: I really enjoyed my time at Walzwerk. Nice, that they bring German appetizers to the table right away. The waiters were very friendly. The food was like the food in a great restaurant in Germany, or like a home cooked meal by a German mama. Portions are big. We had leftovers that made for a nice meal the next day. The German cheesecake, which was the special of the day, was amazing. I wanted to take some home, but my friend ate it all.
author: Katrin N.

description: Had the Jäger schnitzel and the lamb bean soup. Reminds me of some of the best food I had when I used to live in Germany, it was absolutely mouth-watering good food and everyone at my table was equally happy. Love the DDR decor and the cozy little space, this place is a real find. Our waiter was great as well. Highly recommend.
author: Josephus F.

description:
A friend from Berlin suggested this place for a girls get together dinner. We called and were able to secure ressies for Thurs night 7 pm. Place is cute and seems very authentic (there's a sign on the main door "You are now leaving the US sector" LOL). The service was very friendly and welcoming (nice change from some of the other places in SF). 

They had a great beer selection and we started with a few 0.5L of beer. As we were waiting for one more friend, we ordered 3 apps (house cured salmon, charcuterie plate and a salad). The salad was very average but the salmon and charcuterie plates are must haves especially served with fitness bread (thin dark bread). Their red cabbage is also amazing.

I ordered the jägerschnitzel (porkloin with spätzle and creamy mushroom sauce) as my entree and all the dishes are enormous and very hearty!!! The schnitzel was perfectly thin and flavorful. Also tried my friend's dish (kassler - smoked pork chop with mashed potatoes and brussels sprouts) which was my favorite!! The pork chop was so juicy and tender. 

Overall, very reasonably priced for delicious and hearty comfort food! We ended up catching up over dinner for almost 2.5h and never once did we feel rushed to finish eating and leave. Excited to come back and try some other dishes here that aren't available in other German restaurants!
author: Yin H.

description: I'm not very familiar with German food , but I am familiar with flavor, and food cooked right , and a balance of tastes. Sadly that wasn't what I experienced at Walzwerk. The restaurant is definitely charming with an austere but interesting ambiance. Our hostess and other servers were polite and efficient, and the beer that was recommended was excellent. But the meal itself was uninspiring. I ordered the beef " roulade" with spatzle . The beef was stringy, the spatzle rubbery , and the sauce far too sweet, especially considering the side of red cabbage was sweet too. I know this is supposed to be German "country" food but the appropriate range of flavor and texture just wasn't there. A dining partner ordered the Schnitzel and he ended up salting  it considerably before it began to taste appealing; it was crispy enough though. Overall Walzwerk didn't work for me :P
author: Umar G.

description:
The food was extremely good and authentic! German all the way. 

Nice ambiance. Service is run by two nice women that you can tell care deeply about the restaurant and food.
author: Brian G.

description: Charming space, friendly staff, and delicious food!
author: Kimberly D.

description:
Awesome ambiance, fantastic service, and great concept, though food lagged a little behind expectation. 

The interior feels very cozy and there's a small waiting area for you to relax with one of their many beer offerings. Even though the wait was long on a Saturday night, the waiters courteously made sure we weren't waiting on drink orders and kept us updated on progress.

I ordered the kartoffelpuffer (small potato pancakes with chive sour cream and applesauce) and rinderroulade (tri-tip stuffed with bacon, pickles and mustard, spätzle and red cabbage).

First the potato pancakes - loved the fresh chives on top and the slight char on the pancakes was perfect. Overall though, the pancakes were a little plain, and the apple sauce (which tasted like Motts) didn't enhance it for us. 

Now the tri-tip... . it sounded absolutely delicious, which made the disappointment much worse. The tri-tip itself was wonderfully tender (tasted slow-cooked), but the meat itself didn't have much flavor and relied heavily on an unmemorable sauce on top. The pickle was a soggy cucumber lacking acidic bite and crunch. The bacon-oh woe-didn't add anything but pork fat to the concoction. The spatzle... well, I like spatzle so it was okay. In general though, execution was just lacking. 

Overall loved the concept, but the flavors, unfortunately, just weren't there for me.
author: Daffodil L.

description:
Love this spot! We found Walzerk when we decided we wanted German in the city but did NOT want to wait in massive lines for Suppenkuche. And I'm so glad we did!

Walzwerk has a homey, intimate feel to it. When we got there on Saturday at 7:30pm, there were still a few open tables. We were seated within 5 minutes.

BEER ($6.50 to $9)
[+] comes with its own proper brewery beer glass

POTATO PANCAKES ($7 for 3 pieces)
[+] served with chive sour cream and apple sauce
[+] not a big fan of sour cream but this chive flavor added so much
[-] apple sauce was a bit of a miss for me, tasted a bit bland and lacked texture
[+/-] the potato pancakes were not like hash browns with layers of twisty noodle-like potatoes fried; it was pretty solid but still VERY GOOD. 

SCHNITZEL ($16)
[+] came with a HUGE portion of herbed mashed potatoes
[+] which can be substituted w/ rosemary potatoes at no add'l cost
[+] steamed veggies (kale, brussel sprouts, and string beans) - I know, a bit bland but it was the right balance with the breaded porkloin
[+/-] the entire dish was slightly on the blander side (though it was perfect for me), but there is salt and pepper on the table for you to sprinkle on your food

I would definitely come back here. Parking is easier, the place feels homey, and the food was delicious!
author: Sandy T.

description:
Years later and I still love this place. It's funky in a great way ( creative)  and has delicious comfort food.

 The jagerschnitzle, beef roulade and bratwurst are still among my favorite things to get when the dog bites or the bee stings. The mashed potatoes are perfect for soaking up sauce, and the spaetzle and sauerbraten taste just like my dad's. I'm not such a fan of dumplings ( never have been) but friends who like dumplings seem to like these. Pickled herring? Yum. House cured salmon? More yum.

And then there's beer. Germans know their beer. Get what's on tap. Tell your server what you like and they'll bring you tastes of things and you will be super happy.

Portions are huge, so if you know you're coming for dinner eat sparingly during the day...save your calories and appetite for Walzwek. 

Side Note: Skip dessert. It doesnt stand up to the meal and will leave you feeling let down. I am waiting for them to fix the dessert situation and then five stars. I actually rate my experiences 5 stars because I know not to get dessert, but when I'm out with friends they always insist ( ah my foolish friends who never listen to me.) And then the last thing discussed is the dessert issue and that is not the way to end a stellar meal....so four stars.
author: El B.

description: I went here with a friend a few weeks ago and had a wonderful time. The food is absolutely delicious, the service is off the charts and the drinks are refreshing and delicious. The atmosphere is casual and open, and we didn't feel crowded in at all. It felt like being back in Germany! I had serious Heimweh after leaving that evening. I'll be back soon for sure.
author: Astrohfiziks A.

description:
A superior German restaurant.

I come from Texas where the German restaurants I have tried are mediocre at best.

Walzwerk is certainly better than what I have at home.

Walzwerk is a small place with a small menu.

But the items on the menu are well chosen.

The beer menu has a german grapefruit beer.

One taste of that and I was in love with Walzwerk for the rest of the evening.

But the food easily rose to the quality of the beer.

Two out of the three cabbage dishes were excellent.

I happily chowed down on my kraut and red cabbage.

The vegetarian did not think much of the vegan stuffed cabbage -

which is too much like the tomatoey yuck 

the Jewish ladies in my synagogue

made us eat as children.

Friends don't let friends braise cabbage in tomatoes.

They have them make kraut instead.

The potato soup was to die and go to heaven for.

Their bread is an excellent super heavy grainy rye bread.

Frankly, you can do very well by just ordering bowls of potato soup with rye bread on the side and filling up ... and this is certainly authentically German. 

The cold plate appetizer is probably skippable.

Boring cheeses, boring meats.

A roast stuffed with bacon, pickles and mustard and then braised was a pleasant entree ...

The spaetzel and gravy that came with it were up there with thirteen different kinds of sex.

Mop them all together and you have Immediate, total, happy pleasure.

The sausage eaters were equally happy as well.

(Sausage eating here refers to an entree and not the fourteenth kind of sex.)

Overall, though there is more good stuff than bad stuff on the menu at Walzwerk.

This is definitely a destination to return to.
author: Samuel C.

description: Outstanding experience. Even without a reservation! Beers while waiting for a table. Wonderful food. Cool guy (owner?) giving us the scoop on the beer selection and some free tastes. Cool gal (owner?) giving us dessert recommendations (her grandmother's recipe for her birthday cake was one of our choices - yum yum). Will definitely be back.
author: Suzette C.

description: Been coming here once in a while for 10 years. Always Great food, even better atmosphere. Walzwerk is a great option for purely European food, in the city of plentiful fusion.
author: Anne L.

description: Best German food in SF. The beef roulade is amazing. Also live the cheese spatzle. The ambience has a cozy East German feel to it. Very cool place. Authentic.
author: Zane S.

description:
Walzwerk is probably my favorite German restaurant.  The service is great.  The food is delicious.  The beer is plentiful.

My choice of food items?  Jäger schnitzel.  Freakin scrumptious.  They serve the best spaetzle I have ever had...the pork was also super moist and the gravy was made to perfection.  

On the other hand, try the stuffed chicken.  Holy cow.  It's stuffed with apples and bacon...served with mashed potatoes.  Another best for me...

Prices are a little on the higher end but super worth it for the quality of food.  There aren't a lot of tables but it's cozy...street parking only.  5 stars.
author: Jen W.

description: This place was a delightful find! Food was delicious (I ordered the sauerbraten and it was amazing) and super authentic (approved by a German guest). Staff was super friendly and great service.
author: Lauren H.

description: Very good authentic food and great service! We had a very friendly waitress definitely recommend to anybody. Small place but very easy to park and get seated.
author: Eric H.

description: A no frills German style restaurant that has resisted the recent trends to go upscale and modern, even as the neighborhood around it is getting the gentrification treatment.
author: Thomas C.

description:
Date night for a celebratory Thanksgiving dinner spent here!

This East German themed restaurant, compared to the others that I have been in the city, is much more secluded, cozy and intimate.  Dimly lit, it was homely and perfect for the Thanksgiving spirit.  You can't go wrong with mashed potatoes and their beer.  Maybe their sausages too - I didn't try that the first time around, but I will do when I return to Walzwerk.

They have this small dining area in the front and back area that reminded me of a living room with communal tables as well as tables meant for two.

Daring to be adventurous on food, we decided to go with the starter of the Matjes Herring In Sour Cream rather than the Potato Pancakes.  It was significantly different.  The sourness with the tossed up slices of apples and pickles, is something I have never had together - especially when adding fish to the whole sha-bang.  It was a hit or miss.  For me, I liked it, but too much of it, may be overwhelming to the palate. 

Their Schnitzel, breaded pork loin, should have been more flavored and left a lot more to be desired.  It was on the bland side and their broccoli served up as vegetables, were on the mushy side.  The only ingredient that was good, was the mashed potatoes.  Hence, just good.  No sauce at all.  It was a flop on this dish. 

Next up, the Beef Roulade.  The tri-tip beef was wrapped up with bacon and stuffed with mustard, pickles and onion.  Spatzle and red cabbage were served up on the side.  This entree was sauced up, indeed.  Their Spatzle reminded me of a more textured form of Mac 'n' Cheese.  It was different.  I liked the briniess to the stuffing of the beef.  It was a decent dish.

I had a lovely time here and would be back for a special occasion.
author: Tiffany D.

description: Crazy good hearty food.  Perfect flavors and didn't feel heavy. Will definitely be back!
author: Paul D.

description:
The Vegetarian Schnitzel is a little bit overrated.  It's good, but I was expecting amazingness, and the three or four times I've tried it, I've experienced solidness.  The potato pancakes are really good, especially when das Gegenteil of nackt, so dip them or souse them up.

It smells in here.  That's not a bad thing, but you might feel like it is if you focus too much on it.  If anything, it reminds me of the smell of my high-school chemistry lab.  I think it's just the offgassing of particular plastics and/or laminates that are used in the chairs or tables or other various pieces of old, depressing furniture.  This smell is strongest in the late afternoon near the picture window, but the picture window is also the best place to sit in the late afternoon, and like I always imagine I tell my imaginary children, "Life is all about balancing risks and rewards, kids."

It's not enough to know this is a German restaurant.  That might get you somewhere with the food, but it won't help you put up with the weird furniture and decor, so I'll reiterate what should be obvious to anyone who pays the slightest attention in life:  It is an East German restaurant.  No, East Germany doesn't exist anymore, and no, that's not a bad thing, but in order really to get what's being got at through the placards and posters and menu items and general run-down industrial chic of Walzwerk, you need to know a little something about the history of East Germany, its fall, the alienation of its former citizens even when it was once again a part of Germany, and geography.  I won't bore you with all that, but please don't complain about this place being uncomfortable inside, because that's kind of part of what it's trying to do for authenticity's sake.

I really need to come more often, so I think I'll re-add it to my Taste of the Mission Week rotation this year even though there are still (and always will be) new places to try when the hipsters are frolicking in the Nevada desert.

The owner is cool, in both senses of the word.  She reminds me of a lot of Germans I met in Germany in 1994.
author: John S.

description:
Outstanding place for East German Food.  I am glad San Francisco has German food -- I remember when it was a rare thing.  Now San Francisco has great options.  Just coming back from Berlin I had a hankering for German food and I know that Walzwerk specialises in East German cuisine --I was simply overdue for a visit.  There are all the familiar dishes and I was in the mood for the Schnitzel vom Huhn--most people might expect a large pizza sized Schnitzel.  I like the nice golden brown exterior and moist chicken.  The Schnitzel is served with moist rosemary potatoes and nicely vinegary uber thin cucumber slices.  The meal was completely satisfying and I like the East German approach a style different than say a Bavarian cuisine style.  I love the East German style-- very homey and absolutely delicious.  

I absolutely love the interior design--all DDR inspired--I was seating below Marx, Engels and Lenin and above the door is a picture of Erich Honecker the omni present General Secretary of the Central Committee of the Socialist Unity Party of Germany in his well known 1976 headshot.   Even the salt and pepper shakers are from the DDR period and I took photos of everything on the wall--most cool!  

The service was attentive and I liked the menu offering, the beer selection is everything I needed to get my fix of Berlin and East German beers.  I am so glad there is a place like Walzwerk that is nearby to enjoy outstanding East German food.  

Loved the experience.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description: Loved the Christmas specials and was happy to find very good and not very sweet Glühwein. Will definitely come back for more eastern German fare.
author: Diana C.

description: Tasty food, unique theme, awesome veggie options (I recommend the cabbage rolls), generous portions, and great service.
author: Daniella O.

description: Lovely service, delicious food. Been coming here for a long, long time and still does not disappoint. Their vegetarian schnitzel is the best. Can't say enough about how great this place is.
author: Heather B.

description:
A place very steeped in rustic charm with authentic food and friendly staff. Small, but ever so quaint as a result.

Be sure to ask the staff about the pictures. It was quite educational.
author: Dennis C.

description:
Sauerbraten platter under the watchful eye
of Karl Marx in a austere ambience with wonderful service, very worth it!!!
author: Judith R.

description: What a delight to find this special place in the city.  Unbelievable customer service and the food was so good.  We visited Walzwerk on Saturday Dec 2nd 2017.  We were greeted by the staff who were so friendly and upbeat.  The menu was explained and descriptions of the entries were well described.  The special menu with the duck was a hit.  Seasonal and so so good.  All our items were better then expected.  The servings were on the larger side for San Fransisco restaurants but they are like East Germany and believe in a hearty meal.  The dessert cookies were split with coffee (free refills and good) and so so good.  Will return to try other menu item for sure.  Nothing to complain about here..
author: Tim C.

description: We've been several times and have NEVER had a bad meal. The food is AMAZING, highly recommend the Wienerschnitzel with a side of the mushroom gravy!!!  The staff is friendly and efficient; we are always impressed by how well they handle a crowded dining room and it does get crowded which proves this place earns its following!!!   The vibe is influenced by the DDR era complete with mixed plates, industrial seating and minimalist decor.  It can get a little loud as sounds reverberate off of the concrete walls and floors but go with it and enjoy an amazing beer and meal!!!
author: Nick G.

description: 3.5 stars - We were craving bratwurst and sauerkraut and wanted to be in close proximity to Bi Rite for dessert.  So, we ended up at Walzwerk for dinner.  DH ordered a the bratwurst plate that comes with mashed potatoes and sauerkraut.  I opted to share potato pancakes and a wienerwurst with potato salad with my daughter.  Looking back, this was a lot of potatoes, and I wish I had ordered something different.  Nevertheless, it was all delicious.  DH cleaned his plate, and his only complaint was 1 bratwurst was too small of a portion, especially for $17.  I enjoyed the potato salad and was surprised the pancakes were light and fluffy, not like a typical latke made with shredded potatoes.  The wienerwurst was not notable- tasted like a hot dog.  Service was attentive and quick.  Extra props for an interesting dining room, which transports you to a different time and place - kitschy and cute.  Also loved the selection of beers and offering of spezi- very authentic.
author: Amelia S.

description:
Schmidt's (Walzwerk's larger sister restaurant) is closer to my house (and I love it, too!), but when I'm looking for a more authentic German meal without leaving the neighborhood, this is where I head. 

I first came here shortly after returning from a vacation in Germany and almost forgot I didn't have to butcher some German words to order my food-- the menu is written primarily in German but translated to English secondarily, and though the staff speak English well, most do have an accent.

I love the pickled fish appetizer with a creme fraiche/dill-like sauce, served with pumpernickel bread. It sounds weird (or Danish), but if you like cold fish (I'm looking at you, sushi fans who ended up at a German restaurant), it's a delicious way to start off your meal. 

Some other dishes you have to do a little reading to 'translate' the equivalent-- One time a fried fish special (effectively fish & chips) was written in a way that didn't make the fried part obvious. 

My favorite entree is the non-breaded pork cutlet with mushrooms. It's a whole plate of just mushrooms, a thinly sliced piece of pork, drenched in a gravy-like sauce. It's probably not healthy by any means, but it's one of the few entrees that doesn't have me discreetly unbuttoning my jeans toward the end of the meal. 

Finally, the East German theme is mostly decorative, with some steelcase tables and chairs and photos of previous benevolent leaders. I wouldn't worry about it too much; the beer and food are all over the German map. 

Main room is a bit on the small side with about 6 tables of varying size, but usually not too busy; there's also a back room but I'm not sure how large it is.
author: Krista L.

description: Omg. Best jagerschnitzel outside Germany.. chicken was tender as hell and beef roulade that made love to our tastebuds. Tasty bier and friendly service.
author: Gordon E.

description:
Yum yum yum! I totally felt like I was being transported back into Germany. This eastern-German style restaurant does all of the German things you would expect. From apfelschorle to bratwurst, they have it all! 

Walzwerk, located in the Mission, has a full menu of delicious German items. I had the Greunder Salat and the Jaeger Schnitzel - loved both! They also have a nice selection of German beers. 

The staff at Walzwerk do a great job, working very hard, and it helps that they are German (adding even more to the German vibe). A definite recommendation if you are looking for some comfort food.
author: Aletta B.

description: Had the bratwurst and the jäger schnitzel, but thought they were fairly average. Nothing spectacular about either of these dishes and the bratwurst was a little overcooked (looking a bit wrinkly instead of plump and juicy). Of Suppenkuche, Leopold's, and this place, I think this one ranks the lowest on my German food stops in the city. 3 stars for decent food and generous portions, but won't be coming back too soon.
author: Joanne Y.

description:
Ambiance: 4 stars
Food: 4 stars
Service: 4 stars

Walzwerk pays homage to East Berlin's unique culture. I really liked there were books too, in addition to the very East Berlin furnture. The waitresses also speak German, which is pretty awesome because I have not had anyone to speak German with since I moved back to the States.

I lived in Berlin, so I really appreciated the atmosphere of the restaurant as well as all the art. I was a bit disappointed with the beer selection because there were not many options. I had the Spaten Märzen, which was good, but I wish there was Paulaner because I really miss that!

The menu is not as large as other German restaurants because most German food people think of comes from Bavaria (Bayern) and not Berlin. I ordered the potato cakes (kleine Kartoffelpuffer), which were really good! I also had the bacon-wrapped Thüringer Bratwurst filled with cheese (gefüllt mit Käse). It was good, but I felt the sauerkraut was not on par and the potato tasted a lot different than potatoes I had in Germany. /: However, the Spätzle was really yummy.

The waitress was really nice and attended to us when we needed the attention. It was really refreshing to come to a German restaurant in SF where there was more focus on the food than the beer selection. Finally, a great German restaurant in SF! I would love to come back here again.
author: Kelley L.

description: My wife and I went here for dinner last night. The restaurant is in what looks to be an old residential building -- pretty charming. The two sisters that own/operate the place really make you feel welcome. They poured me a beer while we were standing and waiting for our table, and once we sat they brought me a complimentary one. The food was good and served in big portions. I'll definitely be back.
author: Bobby N.

description: Love this place. We would go here to avoid the long wait at other places. Parking is infinitely easier, the atmosphere is very intimate and the food and service are always lovely. Mmmmmm. Go here.
author: Ash S.

description: Great dinner with friends! Loved the ambiance and staff were very friendly. Food was DELICIOUS. Huge helpings, too. Will definitely come back!
author: Emily K.

description:
Horrible: first it was a hassle trying to put a table together with enough space for all of us, the food I had: chicken was the worst ever eaten, same for my friend who had a shnitzel, then when I mentioned it to the waitress so something could be done she tried to start arguing with me.
Never coming back, there really should be a thumbs down minus star option on here they don't deserve one.|
Unfortunate, it's been over a year since we were here and it completely gone down the drain.
author: s.y. d.

description:
Think of an unlicensed East German restaurant where the waiters have friendly 'tude and you will be tempted to eat so much that after-diner activities are limited to stationary ones. No regrets, though.

Anyone who thinks that German food is just sauerkraut and sausage will enjoy an epiphany: pickles and bread and diner pies and ... well, to much to try and sample in one day (although we gave it a good shot). By the way, the sausage and sauerkraut are fantastic.

Even if you don't have to, visit the bathroom: it is a little museum of Soviet-era consumer products.
author: Richard H.

description:
Much better environment than Suppenkuche! While Suppenkuche is super loud with communal seating, Walzwerk is decidedly quieter and has individual seating, allowing both privacy and the ability to carry a proper conversation.

HIGHLY recommend the rinderroulade ($19) which is tri-tip beef stuffed with bacon, pickles, and mustard, with spätzle and red cabbage on the side. The beef was soooo tender - it reminded me of the meat that crumbles off a perfectly cooked rack of ribs. The ingredients wrapped inside the beef, along with the delicious sauce drizzled on top, made the dish hearty, unique, and just soo delicious!
author: Jeffrey Z.

description:
I wish I could come here everyday, the food is yummm! 

There are a lot of great German restaurants in SF, but I come here for the cozy atmosphere and friendly service - hands down my favorite in the city. 

I've been here a few times - my favorite dishes are the Beef Roulade (tri-tip that comes with Spätzle and the most delish red cabbage), Schnitzel (breaded pork with creamy mash potatoes and steamed veggies), and the very best chicken breast stuffed with apples and bacon covered in a heavenly sundried cherry sauce.
author: Brooke W.

description: Quaint spot with friendly and attentive staff. Cute interior/decor.
author: Yad L.

description:
I'm German and have been here twice now. The food is very good. German cooking can be a little heavy, Isabelle however combines the German tradition with California lifestyle and by that I mean the dishes are delightfully healthy. The decorations are authentic historical socialist East German. The selection of beer is very good and the desserts are a highlight as well. The Apfelstrudel was just like my Austrian grandma made it, which is almost impossible! The dessert wine and digestive made me truly feel at home. Also in true European fashion, your entree doesn't arrive till you're done with your appetizer and the check doesn't till you ask for it!!!
Great restaurant!
author: Oliver P.

description:
