If your in the mood for a charming and unusual dining experience, Walzwerk is a great choice.  Most German food we know in The US is Bavarian.  This is Berlin cuisine and likely different from what you may have experienced.  When you enter the restaurant you time travel to a homey East Berlin apartment circa 1968.  Strangely, the naked light bulb high up on the wall casts a warm and welcoming glow.  Most Americans old enough to remember the Soviet Union think of East Berlin as a prison state.  When speaking to Christiana and Jana, the proprietors,  you come to realize everything is relative.  "Growing up there was pretty wonderful.  It was very nonmaterialistic, there was no thought about money and we were very safe as kids.  Of course, when you got older and wanted to express yourself you ran into problems."  Apparently, with only two state run TV channels you had to get really good at developing your abilities to entertain and engage your friends and family.  These two  women have preserved something increasingly rare these days.  A welcoming and inclusive atmosphere.

It was the first night of their Holiday Menu and I chose The Christmas Goose with red cabbage and dumplings.  Keep in mind a goose is nothing like the enormous breasted agri-business poultry we are too used to here.  The rich, fragrant, falling apart dark meat morsels were succulent and very satisfying.  The portion was just enough to make you want to come back again for more.  They only prepare three geese each evening, so if you would like to try it, best call ahead.  The Märzen beer on tap went very well with this dish.
author: Martin H.

description: This gem of a neighborhood restaurant. We're lucky to have it around the corner from us. I loved the special dessert called Kalter Hunt. Try it!
author: Carlos P.

description: First time here. Ambiance is nice it feels like somewhere in Berlin or Germany. Clean basic chairs and tables. Service was great, server was very helpful. Good in general was a bit pricy. Plates are about $18! The potatoes pancakes are awesome $7. Herring plate was good $$9. Chicken plate was a bit dry even though it had a lot of sauce for $18. Beers were really good $8.5 must try Schheider Weisse if you like sweet! Overall it was ok.
author: Ibelig V.

description:
I want to eat here every day, get really fat, and change my name to Helga. 

Everything about this place is great.
author: Andi R.

description:
Going here is like stepping in a time machine to East Germany, or at least what I imagined East Germany to be back in the Communist era. There are lots of kitchy little touches to make the place feel homey -- little doilies, mismatched forks, glass on top of the table clothes, all very cute.

We waited around 10 minutes before we were seated and they gladly took our Gilt City voucher. We shared the cold cut plate, the schnitzel, the beef roulade and finished off with the apple strudel. The cold cut plate was delicious, especially the different pickles -- red cabbage, regular cabbage, pickle slices and carrots. The meats were really good, too.

For our entrees, I had the roulade and my fiance the schnitzel. The roulade was too salty for my taste and the meat wasn't very tender. I didn't like it very much. The sauce was good on the spatzel, though. The schnitzel is veal and absolutely divine. It was tender and not over seasoned so you could actually taste the meat. It wasn't drenched in sauce either, so it's still crispy and didn't taste oily. A must order!

My favorite part of the night was the apple strudel. They used a heavier crust instead of the filo dough, which I like more. The pastry was flaky and tender and the vanilla ice cream just seals the deal for me.
author: Alice W.

description:
Walzwerk is a cute little hole-in-the wall establishment with delicious German food, just a few blocks away from the main Mission area. In fact, it has arguably the best German/Austrian food I've ever had..? And a variety of imported beer from Europe.

I can here on a Monday night with a group of 6 friends. While there were a couple of smaller tables in the front, they were able to seat us in the back (bigger room for larger parties). The place is quite small, and filled to capacity could probably only seat 30-40 people (if that). Which is nice--it's not so loud or impersonal.

I got to try a few different items, and, again, while I thought it was all very good, I would highly recommend the breaded jäger schnitzel (make sure to ask for it breaded, or double-breaded!). It was very moist, and the accompaniments were perfect for the dish. My mouth is watering as I remember eating this.....
author: Julia N.

description: We have been to Walzwerk multiple times and always in December for Christmas goose.  The food is consistent and hearty.  The atmosphere appears classic iron curtain east German - simple, austere.  We went there for the Christmas goose recently.  The place was packed (it's small), so we waited patiently while drinking gluehwein, had an appetizer at the bar, a few schwarzbier, and shared an Underberg with Christiane and Isabell (owner/hosts).  Once seated, we had our Christmas goose (Yummy) with a glass or two of cab.  Too full to enjoy any dessert.  Both Christiane and Isabell are fun and accommodating in the midst of the organized chaos of running a restaurant.  Look forward to returning again soon.
author: Kai T.

description:
My friend who is visiting from Germany and I came here last nite for the first time and we enjoyed everything about the place. The owners here are so friendly and welcoming.  We would definitely come back.  It is authentic East German food and my friend and I loved it.  The kartoffelpuffer (potato pancakes) were delicious, the Kassler (pork chop and mash potatoes with brussel sprouts) was made just right and tender and the vegetarisch schnitzel was very good.  We shared the kalter hund and it was a simple yet very satisfying dessert. 
Danke Sehr!
author: Tony M.

description: Being a vegetarian I was reluctant to go when a group of my friends were going to Walzwerk, but was I pleasantly surprised. Interesting, creative dishes. Very flavorful - the meat eaters in our group were also extremely happy. The wait staff was fun and helpful too. I've never been that into German food, but this place is fantastic (aren't you glad I didn't say wunderbar?)!
author: J J.

description: The food is amazing, and the portions are HUGE! I had the breaded jager pork schnitzel. The mushroom sauce was bomb. My friends had the chicken schnitzel, chicken breast, and smoked pork chop. They were all amazing! My favorites were the jager pork schnitzel and the chicken schnitzel though. The chicken schnitzel has the perfect amount of breaded crunch, while the chicken meat is a melt-in-your-mouth buttery load of goodness that follows right after. Would highly recommend! They also serve authentic German beers. Expect to pay around $20-$30 per person. The ambiance is also really cool. It's like traveling back in time. The furniture is reminiscent of the mid 1900s.
author: Karen P.

description:
Place is great, the stuffed chicken and veggies is one of the best dishes in SF. The waitresses are always understaffed and overworked. One knows physics pretty well. The place is tiny and doesn't accept reservations so please don't go there so I can get seated faster. Thanks.
This place was 6-stars dope fresh awesome but then they changed all their shit up and GOT RID OF THE FUCKING BORSCH like typical western capitalist hypocrites.
author: Mischa S.

description: We have dear friends that we visit in Germany often.  That said,we just love love love German food.  Never been disappointed here.  Authentic food. I can cook the meals we like at home, but not quite as well and its always a lot of work and cleanup after.  That said, the only thing I think would make this place better would be the addition of LeberKasse, I know it might not be authentic East German, but just sayin.....
author: wes t.

description: First time my husband and I tried German food. So good! I believe this place has really perfected their recipes and dishes. Everything was god quality and melted in your mouth! The was no wait time on a sunday night and the service was awesome. We'll be back!
author: Christina A.

description:
Oh man...this is some excellent, excellent food. I wasn't sure what I was expecting. When I had German food in the past, I thought everything was just sausages, and I'm not a fan of that, but Walzwerk is more than just that. It's a place that's decorated oddly but the service is really top-notch. You're greeted like an old friend and they sit down at your table (if you have room) to take your order right after bringing you a nice little complimentary appetizer. If you speak a little German, they are happy to listen for you and correct you if you're wrong. I told my dad and grandfather about this place since they lived in Austria for a time and often went in to Germany as well. I'll be taking them here soon!

The chicken schnitzel was perfectly cooked. The potatoes that came with it...okay, let me just say that potatoes are usually just the filler and they're easy to just glaze over. These potatoes, though, were amazing. I was in such awe that I actually forced myself to slow down because the food was so good and I just didn't want it to end. Seriously, try the rosemary potatoes. My boyfriend doesn't even like rosemary, but these were seasoned and cooked to perfection that we were quietly fighting over who got more.

Next time, I plan on getting the spaetzle, because spaetzle is delicious. That is all.

Stop reading this and have some Walzwerk AQAP.
author: Robbin A.

description:
If you're in the mood for some unique, flavorful food in a quirky, comfortable setting, this is the place. 

I started with the soljanka (tomato - cabbage soup with salami, bacon & pickles), which was tangy, and delicious, with just the right amount of meat to provide flavor without making the dish too heavy. I've never had tomato soup that included a slice of lemon. But it really melded the flavors together. 

For an entree, I had rinderroulade (tri-tip stuffed with bacon, pickles and mustard, spätzle and red cabbage). The meat was tinder and served in a red gravy. The spätzle was a perfect side, more interesting and flavorful than potatoes. And the cabbage provided just enough vinegary pizzazz to keep the dish interesting. 

The rote grütze (red berry pudding - raspberries, strawberries & blueberries made with cream of wheat and vanilla sauce) was a fitting finale. The berry flavor was strong and refreshing. 

The woman with the German accent who was serving us was very helpful and accommodating. She was obviously very proud of the food, and rightfully so. This is definitely a place I will go back to.
author: Rob P.

description: Very good east German food and beer! A fairly Spartan (DDR) interior can get a little crowded on busy nights. I felt the service was very polite, but a little slow. Then, we were an awkward crowd - one very hard of hearing, one medium and two in the process of recovering from surgery. Since the food and the people are so good, I recommend trying for a weeknight.
author: Peter R.

description:
I recently took some friends to the Walzwerk. As a German I am very critical about German food, but I will say that this place has my endorsement. The place is definitely unique. At the entrance door you are greeted by an original sign from the time when Germany was divided by the Berlin wall saying that you are leaving the american sector. There is a picture of Honecker and figures like Marx, Engels and I believe Lenin have huge portraits on the wall. The atmosphere as well as the ambience is definitely east german. You will find minimalistic furniture and table decor. When it comes to the service and the food the place is really amazing. I had Beef Roulade with Spätzle (traditional german noodles) and Rotkohl (red cabbage). It was really delicious. They also have very original german drinks like Schorle (sparkling juice) and Malzbier. Even if you are vegetarian the Walzwerk offers you a great selection of dishes including a vegetarian Schnitzel. 

In summary I would recommend this place, if you are looking for outstanding food, a great service and a trip back to the past.
author: Dennis K.

description:
I was really disturbed at the giant, respectful portraits of Marx and Lenin on the walls.  Dining under the serene gaze of mass murderers?  How can that be ok?  I guess it is supposed to contribute to the East German vibe but I must say I could not get past it.  I am a student of history.  It was disturbing to me, really off-putting.  I am surprised more reviewers don't mention it.  

Servers cool, decor fine, nice variety of food offering, spaetzle done in a dry style which is not my fave but a lot of restaurants do it, sauerbraten was well received.
author: Monika R.

description:
Walzwerk has been on my list of places to try since I moved here 8 years ago (yikes!) but over time it fell off the list because realistically if I hadn't gone in years I was unlikely to go. It's in this weird location in upper Mission not near anything else so it never came up as a place to go with friends. Finally on v-day some friends suggested dinner here before the power ballads at Roxie. Probably a good idea because no one thinks eastern european when they think romantic and it was no problem to get a reservation for 5.

We ordered the small potato pancakes ($7) and thuringer salad ($8) as shared starters. I didn't try the starters but had some potato pancakes. For the main course I got the jäger schnitzel ($16). All the food was satisfactory but that was about it. I think both Suppenkuche and Leopolds have much better food. I would say that maybe Walzwerk is more like what you might eat at home if you were to visit a german family - nothing fancy. Though that said I think the spätzle I make at home is much better than what I had here. It was kinda overcooked and mushy. Also I prefer smaller spätzle noodles.

Of course Walzwerk has an advantage in not being as crowded or as loud, so you can have a nice conversation over german food. And the portions are very generous. Big enough to split.

Total for shared apps, schnitzel, beer, tax and tip = $35
author: Jean K.

description: Schmeckt sehr gut! Jaeger schnitzel mit spaetzle, salat und bitburger drive! And all the DDR memorabilia, just like home... when I want to go to Berlin but don't have time. Ausgezeichnet!
author: Mandy K.

description:
The saying goes "If there are a lot of Chinese people in the chinese restaurant, its good."  So I assume this applies to all different types of cuisines.  

German culture and cuisine being pretty much a blank page to me, except my being a boxing aficionado, when I think of Germany and the Max Schmeling fights with Joe Louis.  And of course when I was a kid, my fascination with the German made Love Bug Herbie.

So this was my first experience in an authentic German restaurant.  Walking in, I noticed everyone spoke German.  "Thats a good sign!", I thought to myself.  Greeted by my friendly waitress April,  I asked her about the popular dishes.

So I went with Herring in creme sauce.  It was ok.  When I ate it, I thought to myself this is an "old people" dish.  It just had a certain creamy, pickle-y taste I think older folks like.

For my main course I had the Schnitzel.  In a appearance, it reminded me of a hungry man's frozen dinner, but a fresh version.  A big hunk of breaded pork, mash potatoes, and vegetables.  It was a hearty meal, not a small sissy meal by any means.  Excellent entree.  Exactly what I'd want to eat with a beer.

Since I was sitting by the bar I couldn't help but notice the free flowing beer being passed to each customer.  And if i've learned anything from my travels around the earth is that cultures that drink a lot of beer, are also a lot of fun.  So I'll have to add Germany to my places to visit.  If anything can unite the world, it'll be a big hunk of pork, mashed potatoes, and beer.
author: Michael L.

description:
Love the decor, and the food was awesome! I like that they had a decent list of Austrian wines to choose from as well.  Only downsides were that the service was a bit slow and we didn't get the correct dessert that we had ordered, but everything else was so great, we didn't mind so much.

We had the Kartoffelpuffer, die Kartoffelsuppe, der Schnitzel vom schwein, salmon. Apfelstruddel and Kalter Hund. YUM!!

Looking forward to going back soon*
author: CeeLo L.

description: Love this place. It's always a treat as it's possible to make smart, healthy decisions here, but difficult as the rich, creamy yums are hard to resist. So is the beer! Started with their brussel salad, onion soup and potato cakes. Then we ordered the jager schnitzel and bratwursts. The server said "you are very hungry then, as that's a lot of food". Well, yeah buddy. We are. And you better bring on the amuse-bouche cause you know we are obviously hungry experts of this joint.
author: Nicole O.

description: Vegan options were great! After hearing they might not be the best for vegans, I found quite the opposite to be true. Our server showed us the vegan items: we had potato soup (best soup ever!), cucumber salad, cabbage rolls, and potato pancakes with applesauce. This was one of my most favorite meals I have had in SF. They also had a great beer list. Very personal service and welcoming vibe. It's also cozy and wonderfully decorated. We had a reservation and I was glad we did because it was packed. I love this place!
author: Mylie T.

description:
I really like this place but feel as if, again, I ordered the wrong thing! Here's what we had:

Herring appetizer: pretty delicious, though just a touch more sour than it needed to be, IMO. I also ate the lettuce. :P
Goulash special: really great. Sauce was slightly sweet; meat was perfect; spätzle was heavenly; cabbage was scrumptious.
Breaded porkloin: my favorite part of this was the mashed potatoes. The pork itself was good, but when I realized that this is basically katsu, I felt I should have ordered something slightly more unique. Vegetables were also nice and light.

A bit more than I like to pay for an entrée, but a really lovely little spot that I enjoyed and would like to return back to... To order more interesting stuff! :P
author: Shendi X.

description: Pretty decent german food.    The staff is nice, and this place is usually not crazy.   I will definitely go back.
author: Michael E.

description:
This is one of the few restaurants where I will order and eat an appetizer, entree, and dessert. I didn't think I would be able to try German food because most of what I have seen were not vegetarian friendly but this restaurant has a few vegetarian options.

The crispy potato pancakes are sprinkled with chives and comes in a set of three with apple sauce and sour cream. I have tried the vegetarian schnitzel and krautroulade. The portions are big and comes in a pool of delicious sauce. I ended up mixing the mashed potatoes with the sauce. The mashed potatoes had a creamy texture. I am not a fan of beets but the beet schnitzel made a believer out of me. 

I have brought three friends on different occasions to the restaurant. Two of them are total carnivores and said the vegetables were cooked perfectly and complimented the meat. One of them said he actually preferred the vegetables and could have eaten a plate full of it as a meal. He had the breaded pork loin with seasonal vegetables. 

My friend (#2), who lived most of his life in New York, said it was the best restaurant meal he had in the ten years he has lived in California. He had the platter with the assorted meats, cheese, pickles, and cabbage with pumpernickel bread, the pork chops with mashed potatoes and brussel sprouts. He said the pork was cooked perfectly, not overcooked or under cooked. The brussel sprouts were delightful sweet and tender. 

He asked for a recommendation on a beer and enjoyed the one the waitress suggested to him. For dessert, he had the apple strudel with vanilla ice cream. He said it was warm and flakey and the ice cream went well with it. He told me he definitely would like to come back and was happy I took him here for his birthday. 

The last friend had the vegetarian schnitzel. He appreciated the restaurant having vegetarian options and thought the meal was delicious. This was the first time I had the cabbage with rice and lentils. It was very hearty and filling. 

The desserts are memorable, so even I will find some room in my stomach for them. I have gotten the cold dog, red berry pudding, and the special chocolate pudding with vanilla sauce. The chocolate pudding was my favorite. It sounds simple but they made it so rich and decadent.

The restaurant has their standard menu items plus a list of specials which are regularly rotated. Back when I was on a mostly vegetarian, occasional pescetarian diet, I had one of their fish specials. I don't remember the exact type of fish but it came with a lemony sauce and capers with veggies and a starch (either rice or potatoes) on the side. The fish had a semi strong scent but the flavor complimented the sauce and capers. It was really good.

The people who work there, talk to each other (and when German speaking customers show up) in German, which adds to the experience. The walls have pictures and music is playing in the background. Most tables have silver metal chairs except the seats near the window. I don't remember if the stools at the bar are metal. After you are seated, the waitress (a friendly brunette) will bring you water and a complimentary sample of two squares of pumpernickel bread, one veggie option, the other meat. The drink menu is on the table. 

They have a single stall bathroom. One wall has a decor case hanging with German products inside. Oh just a head ups, the bathroom doesn't have seat liners and I haven't seen any since the seven times I have been there. There was always soap and toilet paper, so you don't have to worry about that. Be careful and remember to watch your step coming in and out of the main front door because the steps are steep. There are signs alerting you posted on the door. If you are coming with a group of people, I would recommend calling to reserve a spot because seats can fill up quickly around certain times of the night. For people traveling via Bart, it is only a ten minute walk away (about 15 minute walk for those with chronic pain issues). 

I plan on continuing to come here whenever I am in need of celebrating. I continue to recommend this gem of a place to anyone I know.
author: S A.

description: the best German food in the city, along with a relaxed and realistically German atmosphere, feel like you're in a little brewhaus for the evening, our favorite! We've been there numerous times and it's always amazzzzzzzing. I always order the fried schnitzel with spaetzle and gravy. wouldn't have it any other way.
author: B L.

description: Walzwerk is a dream come true. Truely gemütlich in all its kitschy charm of the Ostalgie (love the shower curtains flanking the front door). We went again last night and spent most of the time talking about how much we adore this place : the cheerful service, the unfaltering food, the cozy awesomeness of this old converted steel mill of a venue. The owners create a spirit and an ambience so unlike the rest of the Mission-- a little slice of Europe that you can feel in the hospitality and can observe as the owners chat with recurring customers. You can taste it in the mushroom sauce,  too.  This place is a sheer delight.
author: David C.

description:
We have been looking for a restaurant like this for about 10 years since our favorite spot changed on the peninsula.

The food is the quality of a five star restaurant -- prepared like my aunt used to cook -- She grew up in Germany and was the best cook ever -- or at least until tonight.

One problem that we have is that my husband is vegetarian, so it's uncomfortable to go to a place where there are one (or no) choices on the menu.  Walzwerk had three outstanding entree choices.  I thought about ordering vegetarian so we could share, but I had to try the rinderroulade.  BEST THING EVER!  Except my husband, who ordered the spatzle with cheese said HIS dinner was actually the best new thing in the world.

We looked around at the other food being served and can't wait to go back and try some of the things we saw.  

I heard they filled up early, and I didn't want to be stuck in Friday traffic, so we made it a point to be there at 5:30 when the opened.  We were greeted with a buttered bread/cucumber/cheese/radish square that was divine.  

The servers were prompt and friendly - and the draft beer was cold and fresh.

I finally found my culinary home!

And the cold-war-era sign on the door saying we were leaving the American Sector reminded us of how fortunate we are to live in a place where we can afford this kind of experience and feel safe and cared for..
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
Wow!

After my first time visiting Walzwerk, and albeit, my very first time tasting German food, I was blown away!

Walzwerk is located on South Van Ness and possesses unassuming exterior, however, walking into the restaurant, I noticed and appreciated to quirky and unique German-esque feel to it. WIth school desks as tables and posters of travel destinations of Germany, I felt like I was dining inside someones quaint but welcoming home. 

We were greeted by the host, who seemed to own Walzwerk, and had mentioned that the dessert we ordered was one of her favorites growing up in Germany. But more of that later.

I ordered Breast of Chicken stuffed with Apples & Bacon (with Sundried Cherry Sauce), Mashed Potatoes, and Seasonal Vegetables ($17) and was in awe that the plate served a great blend of savory and sweet.

He ordered the Jäger Schnitzel (Porkloin) with Spätzle and Creamy Mushrooom Sauce  ($16) which was also delish- but had more of savory feel to it because of the abundance of mushrooms and cream sauce throughout the dish.

For dessert we got Cold Dog (Layered Cake Made of Chocolate, Rum and Butter Cookies)  ($6)- so rich, and if you're a chocolate lover this is a must try!

Overall, a great experience at Walzwerk and so glad that my first time trying German food deemed great results.
author: C M.

description:
That place is my home away from home. 

Today I took my daughter Clarissa to my favorite German restaurant in this city. Clarissa lives in Paris and has not been back in Germany ever since she was discovered on the street in Berlin by a model scout about 10 years ago. Oh, time flies when you walk the runways of the world and put corrupt politicians behind bars as attorney and lawyer. Clarissa does both those things and makes it look so high fashion. 

So, to really show her some good food we went to Walzwerk. The Roulade is amazing. Clarissa agrees. She took a selfie with the plate in hand and tweeted it @karllagerfeld. My Jägerschnitzel was as delicious as always. Those two items are my personal favorites. But the food is overall great. So authentic. The real deal. I will always go here. And highly recommend it.

Walzwerk is grossartig. That's German for outstanding. And Karl just tweeted back. He thinks the Roulade looks haute couture. 

Danke Karl,
Clarissa's Vater
author: Ulrich L.

description: I liked the austere/functional decor invoking a certain kind of ambience and I like the fact that they provide more than one vegetarian main course, but the food itself was good, nothing to rave about. The potato pancakes needed a little salt. And the veggie schnitzel, though the breading was very good, the inside was just plain vegetable. I wish they'd done more like mince vegetables and then make a schnitzel, like a burger patty at The Plant or Roam.
author: Manjesh N.

description: This place is GREAT. The food and the service are excellent. We tried the Kartoffelpuffer, Kartoffelsuppe, salad, Jagerschnitzel, and the Schnitzel vom Huhn. Everything was VERY good. They also have a good selection of German beers, wines, and spirits. Our waitress was attentive, knowledgable, and very nice. We will definitely come back again.
author: Rob L.

description:
This place is uniquely different from Suppenkuche up in the Hayes, and thankfully so. The atmosphere is 1. Hilariously more unique with its East German/Soviet era decorations, 2. Much quieter and down to earth allowing for quality conversation unlike like Suppenkuche's deafening madness, and 3. Has heartier German food that is more flavorful and has much better tasting sauerkraut (*when* the dish has it offered). 

The selection of German beers are superb and extremely tasty (you can never go wrong with the heffeweisens ;-) ).

Because of its calmer, more personable (but eccentric) atmosphere and it's great food, when I want German food Walzwerk is my first pick. 

The only two things they need to do is offer more dishes with sauerkraut and add in beer boots.
author: Art W.

description: There was a child waitress there named Anna and she was delightful and an amazing waitress! The food was excellent too but this waitress made the restaurant 100% more enjoyable!  Anna was super friendly, fast paced and very efficient!
author: Terri S.

description: Love the Bavarian atmosphere and outstanding home cooking.excellent beer with the salami and salad, schnitzel is out of this world.
author: SJ L.

description: First time having German food and it was great. We made reservations for 4 and table was ready which was perfect!!! The wait would of been stupid crazy. The whole place is so cute you will need to see if for yourself. Food omg was great!!
author: Nart T.

description:
Never had German food before, but it tastes awesome! Came here on a Friday night, drove by, and didn't see a line so I didn't bother waiting inside until my friend came. Bad idea! The waiting room is in the middle of the place, so if the doorway is clear... don't be fooled! We ended up waiting 40 minutes. In the meantime, order a beer or something while you're waiting!

Once we were seated, we were starving! Shared the small potato pancakes with chive sour cream and applesauce. It was tasty, not sure if it was because I was starving... but it was the best damn potato ever! No really, had a nice crisp on the outside and the inside was like eating a mash potato. YUMMY! Then I got the Jager Schnitzel.... DROOOOL. It's like sauce overload, but my plate was sauce-free when I was done with it! Very tasty and juicy. The mushrooms gave it a nice taste too. My friend got the bratwurst and I tried a little of it... don't remember much about it, but I remember it being tasty.

Food overall was pretty good. I would definitely come back. Service was okay, they didn't really check on us though... not sure if it was a Friday night or because... they just don't check on people. But I had to flag them down for some more water every now and then. Place is pretty clean, a bit dark. Overall, worth giving a try if you haven't had German food before!
author: Johnson S.

description:
Nope. Came on a wed eve about 8. Walked in and there was an open table. We were not offered that table however. We were asked to take a seat in a dark area in the back and wait 5 minutes. After about 10-15 minutes a group of 3 elderly people came in. We offered them the bench but they declined. The waiter then came by and rudely asked the men at the 2 top of a bar if they would move so the old folks could sit down. This seemed peculiar to me, First, there wasn't enough space. Second, the area they were in wasn't really a waiting area and they were enjoying beverages there. I am all for offering up your seat to the elderly but this was a bit off.

Another 5 minutes passes and the older folks that came in 10 minutes after us are being sat. Ok. Starting to feel annoyed now. A couple minutes later we are guided to a table. Right next to the one we saw when we walked in which is still open after 20 minutes of waiting to be sat. The table we are sat at is one that is SHOVED into a corner, sitting under a hanging plant that caresses me with my every move, so close to a table of 8 that I am literally touching 2 of them. WHY? I had to use the restroom but didn't want to make the awkward journey out of my confined corner to do so, worried that I would disturb the other table. I finally gave in, stood up, that dumb plant made love to my face and then I knocked over my water. Really embarrassing but I feel like I wasn't exactly set up for success. My water was never refilled. I ate my meal never being offered a water refill or another beverage. 

I can understand if a table is reserved but making people wait for a table that sits empty for over an hour and shoving them into the very worst spot while being made to look at the empty table is bad service. I have worked in hospitality for many years and this blew my mind. To boot, the food wasn't anywhere near good enough to make this worthwhile. My chicken was ok, the vegetables were actually great. My boyfriends saurbraten was borderline gross. 

We would advise anyone to take a hard pass. People of SF need to stop paying $20 a plate for this kind of experience.
author: Disco B.

description:
I shall attempt writing this review in German (please forgive grammatical mistakes). English translation will be in second paragraph. 

Dieses Restaurant ist klein aber sehr charmant, und das Essen war sehr lecker. Unsere Kellnerin war eine Amerikanerin und sprach kein Deutsch, aber sie war sehr hilfreich und nett. Ich habe die Lammkoteletts  und ein Schwazbier bestellt. Mein Date (not sure if this is the German word for date) hat das Schnitzel vom Schwein mit Gemüse der Saison und Kartoffelbrei bestellt; es schmeckt auch gut. Also, ich habe vor dem Restaurant einen Parkplatz gefunden. Yay!

The place is small and charming, and the food was really good. Our waitress was really helpful and nice. I had ordered the lamb chops and a dark beer, both which I found tasty, but the lamb may be a tad on the gamey side for people who aren't a huge fan of lamb. Date ordered the schnitzel, which was also really good. 

Also, I found parking right outside the restaurant, so parking shouldn't be an issue (it was a weeknight though, so not sure about weekends).

Edit 7/30/2013: Must order the cheese späztle. It's like mac n cheese times 10. Sie müssen die Käsespätzle bestellen. Lecker lecker!
author: Evelyn C.

description:
I should preface my review by saying that I think I've decided that German food just isn't my favorite kind of food. Don't hate it, but I certainly don't love it, which is strange because I'm very much a meat 'n potatoes kinda person. But with that information in mind, you should also know that I think Suppenküche in Hayes Valley is much better than Walzwerk if you are looking for German cuisine.

But of course, this is a review of Walzwerk, so onto the positives and the negatives! The beverages are good. Nice German beers and ciders. Nothing to complain about there. The portions are large, but you're definitely paying for it; prices are not cheap. But large portions also meant that I had more food that I wasn't a big fan of. The beet soup (which is, of course, just Borsht) is decent; not super flavorful but it was good enough. I got the Beef Roulade for my main course and it was no better than something I could make at home in a crock pot. Plus it was supposed to be stuffed with bacon (yummmmm) but I couldn't distinguish any bacon anywhere on the plate. And the side of spätzle was flavorless and just bleh. To make a long story short, there was so much food leftover that I took it home with me, but I pawned it off on the boyfriend when it came time to consume said leftovers.

The service was pretty terrible also. We waited a solid twenty-five minutes for a server to even acknowledge us and even then she only came over once we flagged her down.

But because I don't like to be a Negative Nancy, I will end on a positive note: the décor there is awesome! The place truly feels like you just plopped down right in the middle of Germany and I think that's fantastic. I definitely think the place is worth a visit, even if I don't think the food is anything to write home about.
author: Stephenie S.

description:
Oh liebstes Walzwerk.

Short preface...I grew up in East-Germany and I got a hunch that this is what they want to replicate. 

The place is like a good old HO restaurant (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Handelsorganisation). There is a bit of tack everywhere, yellowed posters, and scrappy tables (which aren't East-German... the build quality is too good).

The only difference to the HO restaurant is that the food is pretty nice, though some of it isn't as authentic as I remember food in the East. We certainly didn't have salmon.

Other than that, it's perfect.
author: Joe G.

description:
Small cozy dining room. Make reservations to guaranty a table.  

When I got here, I was craving a radler.  They didnt have it on the menu, but they were happy to bring me one anyway (Radler is beer + lemonade).  The hostess/waitress was super nice and happy to make substitutions.

I had a beef roulade, and my partner had the shnitzle.  Both were delicious.  Most plates are served with Spetzle, which is very good.  The red cabage is also very good - noot too sweet or sour with overtones of anise.

Definately will come back next time Im in San Francisco.
author: Theodore T.

description:
Wanted to LOVE IT. I sorta liked it.  We went on a Friday about 7:30pm before a holiday weekend.  There was 1 (big table) ahead of us.  They waited forever!  We also waited forever but were eventually seated. The ladies were nice about it, we sat at the counter for 2.  The (in charge) lady said things like "food was coming out slow that night b/c they have large tables", I don't really understand the logic, but whatever. we waited to order, we WAITED for our food, we waited for our check.  

And ya know what? the food was good, BUT every single thing we got was barely room temp.  The kitchen is literally 4 feet from where were were sitting, and I saw the gals doing lots of chores, I went to the bathroom twice between courses, (yeah it was taking THAT long)  and every time I looked into the kitchen there was barely any food "up" and ready to be delivered.  So it was just kinda baffling to me.  I would say the chicken in the cherry sauce was slightly better than the jagerschnitzel, but what looked delish going by (that we didn't order) was just the regular fried cutlet.

Anyway if the food had been hot after all the waiting I might have gone 4 stars, but didn't seem like there was any excuse to cold food, serving the food from the kitchen to the table is the fastest part--it is taking the order, answering questions, getting the drinks and all that crap that takes the time (and YES I used to waitress so I know what it is like!)
author: Amy W.

description: I really wanted to love this place! Environment is neat, vibe is cool, place was busy. I just didn't feel like the food was up to par. The veggies tasted like they were out of a bag of frozen veggies. Even the pork schnitzel (a classic dish that I would expect them to put a lot of attention towards) wasn't great. Wished for more from this place, thought the beers and atmosphere were awesome.
author: Jen O.

description:
Jager schnitzel...delicious, lots of mushrooms!!!!! 

Goulash...wild boar, need I say more?!? 

Service = friendly. And they refilled the water, like johnny on the spot.

Prices = moderate.

Ambiance = dark, communal tables and cozy.  There's more seating in the back for larger parties.

Decor = nice.  I like the retro posters, and the crazy looking chamber door by the kitchen.  Very industrial looking.
author: Fannie S.

description:
My favorite! Since discovering this place, I've been here several times from my own personal preference and to share with friends visiting me in the city. Nothing fancy and perfectly so. I have yet to visit Germany but coming from a Hungarian family, I've got quite an inclination towards this part hearty/ part acidic palette. I've got nothing but good things to say about this place so here are my favorite meals: 

Jager Schnitzel - Can't go wrong. It's so simple and delicious. Also, its HUGE so unless you want leftovers, feel free to split with someone else and be fully satisfied. They'll even bring the food on separate plates and its still a lot. 

Beef Roulade - The beef is perfectly tender and amazing with the flavors of the mustard, pickles and onions. Spaetzle is heaven as always. 

Chicken Breast stuffed with Apple - I don't know what made this dish so exceptionally good to me, but I was loving it so much more than anticipated. Great blend of rich cream sauce and the subtle, sweet tang of the apple.  Also, the mashed potatoes were the biz! Ate. Every. Bite. 

Rosehip Tea - Simply said, a refreshing drink when you don't feel like having beer. I love this tea because it doesn't have a weird aftertaste. Just perfectly fresh and simple.
author: Amy C.

description:
Delicious comfort food, perfectly prepared. Best trout I have eaten anywhere served with mountains of scrumptious mashed potatoes and al dente vegetables. My companions enjoyed their schnitzel and especially the rinderroulade. Nice selection of German white wines complemented the food.

Attentive service and cozy, homey ambiance. Generous portions are good value. I will return to this intimate, quiet spot to sample more dishes from the tempting menu. An authentic taste of Germany in the Mission district.
author: Melanie W.

description:
First of all, Walzwerk is East German, so it's a little bit different from the typical Germanic restaurants that go beer, brats, and lederhosen. 
 
The crowd is late 20's to 30's, lighting is dim, decor is eclectic, and  the tables are picnic (perfect for small groups). (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ISCijFt3uO4M7yzclSwEuw?select=_0QZGrg91aaiMhh7tQyYYg)

We were in the private back room area and adding authenticity to our ambiance was this group of hipster German girls that only spoke in German. I felt like a tourist in my own city. 

Ordered the sauerbraten with the cheese spatzle and red kraut. Even though it sounds like a overly manly portion, it wasn't so you won't be obesely full with no room for dessert. (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/ISCijFt3uO4M7yzclSwEuw?select=eYPbJOCcu8f7XNCZLQN0XQ)

The "cold dog" layer cake made with cookies was sehr gut, or very good for you English readers.  

What's interesting is that they have beer mixers, so it's half beer and half coke or 7up. Seeing that, I ordered ordered the kristall weizen hoping it would be Cristal and beer mixed together but unfortunately it was not. The location of this place gives enough street cred.
author: Earl G.

description: Very homie place to dine in, casual diner, with really good food.  Big portion i will add !!! The lady was so helpful and very good in serving us.. I will definitely recommend to people who loves food. Worth trying it...
author: Marnie P.

description:
Comforting, tasty, German food with a nice selection of beer = great combination!

I finally made it here one San Francisco winter's night!  It's good to get here early as the front room fills up quickly.  There's a back room with shared tables which work just fine.  Love the decor with lots of retro pictures and knick knacks - fun and festive!  

I had:
*  Small Potato Pancakes with Chive Sour Cream and Applesauce (classically, crispy good, would order this again in a heartbeat)
*  Schnitzel (Breaded Porkloin) with Mashed Potatoes & Seasonal Vegetables (this hit the spot, super tasty, comforting, lovely, and I see on the menu 'All pork dishes on our menu are sustainably and naturally raised' - very cool!)
*  Apple Strudel with Ciao Bella Vanilla Ice Cream (even though I was quite full, I had to try this as apple strudel just sounded so good, and it was!)

Pretty easy to get here by BART and Muni.  I can't wait to come back!  I want to bring my bf here as he has traveled to Germany quite a bit in his day for business.  He would love Walzwerk!  Will be back for sure!
author: Maile N.

description:
Eat spaetzle and drink hearty. And then drink more beer. That should be the name of this place.

I never thought I would love spaetzle as much as I did until I came here. This place can give my other favorite German place, Suppenküche a run for its money. Wow.

Holy moley I love German food and German beer.

Seating is definitely tight, so expect cramped quarters. Make sure to get reservations ahead of time!
author: Andrew M.

description:
Very, very, very good. A wee bit pricy, but you'll be FULL with almost any order. And it's SF - considering how much food they fed us last time, I guess I have to say the prices are more than fair.

I love the Ostdeutsch decor, though I suspect they got the tables from a school district warehouse sale and did not import them from the DDR! Certain types might be put off by the large portraits of Marx, Engels, and Lenin but I certainly don't mind. The genuine DDR trinkets and whatnot made me kind of nostalgic. Some have commented that the service is perhaps a bit langsam, sometimes - well, maybe so. Be patient if they're busy, it's worth the wait.

Like I said, they are very, very good - basically a feast! I'm rather impressed that my city now has so many new(er) restaurants that offer delicious German fare at fair prices. Walzwerk is just about the best of those. If I had a job that burned lots of calories, I'm sure I would go more often. Don't be discouraged by that - those aren't McDonalds calories; every bite is genuinely delicious; absolutely mouthwatering really. OK, now I'm hungry. Will take my GF there for supper and report back!
author: Steven B.

description:
Another birthday creeped up on me, and I had no idea where to fit 20 rowdy Russians. Decided to give a call to the few German places in sf - walzwerk quickly confirmed the party and we were good to go. 

We were sitting in the back room, which reminded me of the dungeon in Harry potter, but German style. It was awesome. 

The food is amazing. The kind that goes in and hugs you from the inside, whispering "it's not bathing suit season quite yet." I especially loved the spatzle and bratwurst. The dessert, chocolate pudding and marzipan, was out of the world. 

The waitresses were two gorgeous German ladies. They quickly understood that this wasn't your normal birthday party, rolled with the punches, joked with us, and solidified the experience. 

Thank you walzwerk!!
author: Maryana S.

description:
The meal at Walzwerk was my first authentic German food experience.  I'd have to say that the restaurant has a very homey/mama's-place decor.  

We ordered the jager schnitzel and sauerbraten.  Both of the dishes were good although I think I liked the jager schnitzel more because of the mushroom sauce it was sitting in.  The sauerbraten came with red cabbage which was really tasty and the meat was super tender.  

Very filling meal and great portions.  I am quite disappointed that I did not get to have any German beer with my meal, but all in all It was a satisfying meal.  I can't say that I love German food, but it wasn't bad for my first time trying.
author: Shirley T.

description:
Great food, excellent beer selection... I think this is my fave German restaurant in SF and would happily return!

Franziskaner Hefeweizen - good stuff! We all enjoyed and thought it went well with our food.

Potato Pancakes - meh, forgettable.

Jager Schnitzel - so good! This and the stuffed chicken breast easily were my favorite dishes!

Beef roulade - tasty, but not as memorable as the jager schnitzel or chcicken breast.

Red berry pudding - didn't care for this dessert at all.

Apple strudel - tasty, but nothing special.
author: Steve L.

description:
Great beer/wine list, friendly staff, huge portions.

There's a semi-private area in back to accommodate larger groups.
author: J C.

description:
Fantastic atmosphere, fantastic flavorful food, fantastic service!!  We will be back!  
Fills up fast.  Be patient, food is made with love!
author: April M.

description:
The spatzel was pretty good.  Mushroom sauce was decent. Pork loin was good in combination with the spatzel.

Service was a bit harried because one person served the whole restaurant!
author: Niniane W.

description:
Random thoughts of Europe came today, and I immediately remembered Walzwerk. Now Walzwerk is a gem hidden in South Van Ness. This place has lots of vintage German decor, and the section behind the bar has a creative decor that makes you feel like you are in an underground tunnel. The food speaks volumes itself. The schnitzel is by far one of the best schnitzel's I've ever had. The vegetables can stand on there own with how amazing they taste. The chef gave me a new appreciation for vegetables, so my compliments to the chef.

The ladies behind the bar are awesome. The food, the service,  the decor and the people itself just draws you in and makes you want to come back. I for one will definitely be back.
author: Evelyn B.

description:
This restaurant is amazing and delightful. I've been recommending it to everyone I know since going for the first time last week in hopes that someone will want to go with me again soon.

I went with a bunch of co-workers so since there was 9 of us, we were able to get most of the entrees on the menu.

My favorites were the Potato Pancakes with Chive Sour Cream and Applesauce and the Jager Schnitzel (Porkloin) with Spätzle and Creamy Mushrooom Sauce. Spatzle is my new favorite food. Its delicious and super yummy in the cream sauce it came in. Comfort food at its best. 

We also got every single dessert on the menu. My favorites were the Red Berry Pudding with Vanilla Sauce and the Cold Dog which is like a thick but not so sweet chocolate cake.

Walzwerk - I'm so glad I found you!!!!!!!!!!! I shall return soon.
author: Cicely T.

description: This place is cozy and it made you feel like you were at grandma house for Sunday dinner. The food was excellent. I will be definitely coming back to try out the menu.
author: Kay S.

description:
You'll never leave Walzwerk (or any German restaurant really) hungry. A recent visit wasn't quite up to earlier standards but it's still probably the best German food in SF.

The herring appetizer is fantastic - the pumpernickel bread is a great contrast with the pickled fish. Both the sauerbraten and the beef roulade were't quite as tender or flavorful as they'd been previously, but they were still very enjoyable.

We're still trying to work out how to have enough room left at the end to try the cold dog!

We consider 2 stars to be an average restaurant so Walzwerk is still highly recommended - just not quite as good on this occasion as in the past.
author: Amy D.

description:
I've been feeling out of sorts of late.  Maybe it's because I haven't reviewed anything in awhile.  So let's remedy my ailment right quick, shall we?

I'm shocked that I haven't reviewed this awesome resto yet!  Last year, my bro and I needed to find something yummy to eat before heading on to the Miyavi concert later that night.  I'd been craving some good German, so naturally I Yelped and found this place, only a few blocks from the 16th Street BART station, and a reasonable walking distance to the gig.  We met up with The Boss and beered and dined.

The dishes are amazing!  I went back recently and had me the jager schnitzel.  Oh my goodness, but that whole plate was heaven on the tongue.  I highly recommend it.  Pair it with the Diesel to wash it all down with.  You won't be sorry.

I think I much prefer sitting at the small bar area and noshing than sitting at one of their few tables.  It seems a much more intimate setting, plus you can flag down the wait staff much more easily that way.  They're a wonderful and very gracious bunch of folks.

Let's go.  I'm hungry.
author: Lorrayne L.

description: Myself and my better half enjoyed our recent Saturday night meal at Walzwerk. I had the Jagerschnitzel and she had the beef sauerbraten and a crepe special for desert. All if it was so good and the service was also on point. The portions are substantial and seem really reasonable for modern day San Francisco. The giant plate of Jagerschnitzel was only $16 which I hear is the average price of toast around town these days. My only complaint is that I was so full afterwards that I went home and immediately passed out from food coma.
author: Wes W.

description:
Excellent German food, served in sizable portions. 
A few good beers on tap and an assortment of bottled beers make up the bar (along with wine, and non alcoholic beverages) - which is is not what makes this a destination (its all about the food). 

The design is kitschy and tries to celebrate (by making light of :) east Germany's socialist past.  The place is relatively small and never gets uncomfortably loud which is a plus.  The menu specifies that chicken and pork are organic and free range when possible - which is definitely nice but makes one wonder about beef and fish sourcing. On the night i was here i got to try the cheesy spaetzle, roasted pork and veggies, and some of their sausage special, all were excellent. Overall a solid German place in the Mission, i look forward to coming back.
author: Oleg H.

description: Came here on my birthday for the first time and fell in love with the atmosphere, food and historic East German decor! Owner Christiane was an uber-server. Had complimentary amuse bouche (German-style canape), dark lager, jagerschnitzel and kalter hund for dessert--all amazing--the "cold dog" cake was especially wonderful and an architectural wonder.  Great value for the money; the overall experience was one-of-a-kind; having been to Germany, totally authentic.  Can't wait to return, looking forward to trying their Christmas goose!
author: Lorin H.

description:
I came here a couple of nights ago with a friend who had never had German food before, and I had never been to Walzwerk, so we were both excited to be there.  

I had seen this place on Bay Area Check Please and was really looking forward to trying it, so rather than taking her to an old reliable German-style restaurant like Suppenkuche, or Austrian restaurant like Leopolds, we decided to go to Walzwerk.

Oops, my bad.

4 stars for the food itself, 1 star for service.

The 2 ladies working that night were friendly, but clearly distracted.  After we sat down, we ordered our beers, our apps, and our entrees.  After a long wait, our entrees arrived.   Um, where were our apps and beer?

It turns out our waitress forgot to put that order in.  Ok fine, they asked if we still wanted them.  We did only because I wanted my friend to try a variety of German flavors, including the traditional potato pancakes and cabbage salad.  And, she had never had German dark lager before, so yes, I told them we still wanted everything.

About 10 minutes later, our salad arrives.  The waitress offers to bring out a couple of clean small plates for us to share the salad, cool...aaaaand no plates ever appear.  At this point, we've just decided to dig into the salad and share the bowl.  

Another 20 minutes go by, we're almost done with our entrees, and the potato pancakes arrive.  Again, she asks if we want small clean plates to share this, and I just say no b/c what's the point now, right?

Finally, I ask if our beers are ever going to come, and the waitress again reacts with surprise because she's forgotten all about them...again.  So we get our beers really as a digestive b/c we're pretty much done eating at this point.   Oh well, I figure they would comp the beers or an app or something because the whole thing was pretty egregious, even though they were nice about it.  But nope!  They charged us for everything!  Even though we could only drink 1/2 of our beers because we were so full.  

The only reason it's not a 1 star review was because the food was tasty, very tasty in fact, my jager schnitzel was delicious.  But given the completely unrepentant attitude of the service here, even if they say "sorry" with a smile, I don't think I would return when I can just go to Suppenkuche or Leopold's instead, both of which are closer to me and have never messed up this badly.  (In fact, once at Leopolds, the wait was so long that the owner felt bad, even though it wasn't his fault, he gave us a free charcuterie platter with our meal...now that's customer service!)
author: Jennifer F.

description:
The food was good, the portions were huge, the service was excellent! 

Last night we stopped in on our way to the theater. We were in bit of a rush, and told the waitress, so all of our food came out super fast! I had the potato pancakes for an appetizer, they were heavenly (but who doesn't like fried mashed potatoes). For entrée, I had the stuffed chicken breast, which was enormous and delicious! 

If in the mood for German food, I'd come back.
author: Stephanie A.

description: We made reservations for my daughter's 25th birthday.  Christine had a private table with flowers and candles ready upon arrival.  Drinks came immediately and our glasses were never left empty.  The service was excellent!  My son Gavan said, "Mom, this food tastes like you made it at home!"  Everyone LOVED their dinner choices with huge portions.  Our family will return for sure!  Thank you everyone at Walzwerk for an evening to remember!
author: Julie F.

description:
Portions were big; food was hearty. Service was fast and waiters were fun, joking around a bit and very friendly.

Beer options were great ;)

Oh and in case you've got a sweet tooth, the dessert options weren't the best
author: Alexi P.

description:
Looking for a place to throw a private party? Look no further! Walzwerk has a private back room, INCREDIBLE family style food with lots of options and an extremely accommodating and cool staff. Every last minute request that I made they accepted easily and made the evening seamless and frankly perfect. 

Oh yea, and the food is outrageously good!!!
author: Zoe K.

description:
We went here based on Yelp reviews and with a restaurant.com certificate.  We called to make reservations and were told they didn't have anything until later in the evening, but if we came in they could probably get us in.  We took a chance and went.  When we arrived we were told the only place they could get us in was the back room.  We asked if there was a difference and we were shown the room.  Other than being a little more sparsely decorated and having some plain tables it wasn't bad.

We placed our drink order and looked over the menus.  They have a decent beer selection, with some difficult to find here choices.  Our beers came first and the others came later.  We ordered a pretty good assortment of appetizers and the Sauerbraten and Jagerschnitzel as mains.  I had the tomato cabbage soup and thought it was pretty good and something different.  The Sauerbraten was good and the beef was pretty tender.  It came with some good potato dumplings and some red cabbage.  The Jagerschnitzel was also pretty good and came with Spatzle and cabbage.

Walzwerk wasn't exactly cheap even with the restaurant.com certificate, but I think it wasn't unreasonable given the food.  My favorite German place in SF is still Suppenkuche, but I'd gladly eat at Walzwerk again sometime.
author: Scott L.

description:
I had a great meal tonight with a dark German Bier, followed by Apfel Strudel. 
I will be back! Danke schon.
author: Michael M.

description:
Walzwerk might be my favorite German restaurant in the US (yes, even beat Leopold's)

On a crisp evening on Van Ness, my travel companion to Frankfurt once upon a time and I decided to transport ourselves back in time through a dining experience not soon to be forgotten. 

The two ladies working that evening were more than cordial, and we ended up dining at the small bar seating next to the kitchen. We were brought out an array of recommendations from the ladies, and each dish came with a story or a memory to match the delicious food presented to us. 

For some reason, German dining is always warm and inviting, but at Walzwerk, the bar is set high.
author: Mike M.

description: So freaking yummy after all these years. I love the quirky vibe, delish and filling food, and radeberger beer. Favorite dish is the jagerschnitzel, pounded pork cutlet with luscious mushroom sauce and spaetzle. Great value too, for the chill vibe and huge portions cooked with love. Yes please.
author: Saana B.

description: Worst service I have ever had in San Francisco. We put the order in as soon as we sat down. And then waited 90 minutes for food. No explanation other than they had a party of 18 ahead of us. We had watched multiple tables that came in after us eat and finish their meal. We were unable to even get the waiters attention. A bummer because I used to love this place and brought someone there from out of town to check it out.
author: Chris G.

description:
1st time here. Small location, but got seats at the bar right away (Thursday night 6pm, with a German Film Fest happening down the street). Delightful, authentic, hole-in-the-wall East German setting + food. 
Best creamed herring (Matjes Hering) I may have ever have had the pleasure of consuming, along with some delicious spatzle with house-smoked salmon and a fresh veg slaw from the specials menu. Husband also very much enjoyed his beef entree (a special version of the Sauerbraten, I think), but said he would have found it excellent had he swapped his baby redskins for spatzle --seriously, it's really, really good spatzle. Lovely owners/staff, also very good German beer on draft. 
My only regret was having to eat so quickly to get to a class, rather than getting to linger, enjoying a few more drinks and savoring each bite. Absolutely will return!
author: Anna L.

description:
Massive portions! Delicious food!

Just... make sure you sit in the front dining area. The back feels a little bit like a homey-er extension of a barrenly metal East German jail.
author: Kylie F.

description: Amazing food. I had the tri-tip and it was really good. Looking forward to trying other things on the menu soon.
author: Al Y.

description:
Nom nom nom. Good beer and good food. And you know it's European when it's hard to get a glass of water. 
I don't remember which beer I had; it was an amber ale. The marinated beef entree was delicious. It was hearty and yummy. While we were inside, it felt as though we had stepped out of SF into Europe for a few hours. Service was prompt and slightly friendly. 

I'd recommend it!
author: Sneha P.

description:
Loved the food & atmosphere!  The service was great and the decor was unique!  What a gem!  I especially loved the apple strudel!  I just wish it was easier to find parking, but it is SF after all. 
I ordered the fish (trout) with potatoes & cabbage and a glass of Riesling. Excellent choice!  Can't wait to return.
author: Pat C.

description:
One of my favorite restaurants of all time. Funky, comfortable decor, good attentive service, and all kinds of delicious pork products...I usually get the jager schnitzel, which comes with a generous serving of spaetzel, which is a little piece of heaven.
The spaetzel ( you gotta get it with cheese) is perfectly cooked, some crispy bits, and totally worth the carb splurge. I'm usually too full to order dessert, but I've had the Cold Dog cake once, and it was quite delicious. The location is a little out of the way from the main drag in the Mission, but totally worth it.
author: Sherry K.

description:
It was my Mom's birthday and she loves going to the city. She wanted me to pick a place out so I right away went to yelp and thought about what type of food I wanted. We have a German heritage and I thought I would scope out some German restaurants. I found Walzwerk and took a look at the menu and pictures. I called and left a voicemail for a reservation and received a call back to confirm  

The place is in the mission and can easily e passed over. It's quaint, homey, and the servers were very nice. I ordered a delicious hefenweizen that came in a huge glass. Then I ordered the veal schnitzel special which was awesome. What impressed me was the veggies and mashed potatoes. Some of the best I've ever had. 

Funny thing was my dad spoke German back in the day and my mom was kidding with the waitress that he was still fluent. The waitress started rattling of German and we just don't know enough.

Overall, it was a great find. I highly recommend it to anyone who wants a cozy restaurant with awesome food. 

Auf weirdersehen!
author: R H.

description:
Willkommen, mein freund, in der DDR.

This restaurant is a step into the past, with pictures of the great minds behind the CCCP on the walls, German newspaper headlines about Washington in the "toiletten", and large glasses of beer. The only change this restaurant has from the old days, is the friendly hostesses here.

The service was great. We were able to get a table without reservation: although we had to eat between 6:45-8:00. So they are able to fit people in with no problem.

The pickled herring was a nice start to the meal. Not too sharp, not too fishy. Just the right amount of flavor for your mouth to be happy, and not overwhelmed.

The beef roulade was spectacular and juicy. The meat was juicy, The cabbage was sharp and fresh, and the softy-yet-crispy spätzle complimented both.

Finishing off the meal was a kalter hund. The spread had an attractive sugar-syrup to dip your chocolate cake into. The presentation on this alone was well put together.

All over, I would definitely suggest this to anyone looking to try good German food. It's not too harsh for newbies, and the delicious meat isn't too spicy or sharp, but definitely not bland.

Try it at least once. But remember to bring your papers.
author: Amal C.

description: I love German food, and I love this restaurant. Where else can you get spaetzle and sauerbraten? Yum, yum, yum.
author: Lineka D.

description:
A friend recommended Walzwerk to us and we couldn't be more pleased. Terrific German comfort food. Walzwerk manages to evoke the esthetic of Communist bloc East Germany while giving it a sense of slightly tongue in cheek nostalgic funkiness.

The beer menu was very good. My husband enjoyed his schnitzel and I, my apple and dried cherry stuffed chicken. The side vegetables, often a forgotten overcooked item in many restaurants, were done to perfection here. We finished our meal off with the dessert special, a pear cobbler with vanilla ice cream.

The service was friendly and attentive and the atmosphere was relaxing and cozy. If I lived in SF I'd come here all the time and I'd be as big as a house.
author: Susan W.

description: Potato pancakes were yum. One order with 3 pancakes was enough for the three of us to share.  Jäger schnitzel was yum yum. If you want the schnitzel breaded - you have ask for it. It doesn't come breaded. Hearty sauce but not too creamy either. Apple strudel was to die for with a scoop of vanilla ice cream.  Street parking is far and few between but it's worth a visit. The place is small but was able to get a table without waiting on a Tuesday evening.  I don't think this is the type of meal I'd have every night but good comfort food for when you want a hearty meal.
author: Linda K.

description:
My roomie took me here for a bday dindin and I was impressed by everything we ate!  The potato cakes and herring appetizers were delish!  The beef roulade was to die for and the beef short ribs were some of the best I've ever had.  The schnitzel could have used a sauce, but to me, everything should have a sauce on it!  The rhubarb cobbler was amazing and the beer showed me why Germans do it best!!!  Anyone who knows me knows that I am obsessed with Trumer Pils and the Radeberger really showed me why those geniuses in Berkely decided to craft their beer after German Pils!  The service was also great and I loved the recycled 1960's school desks and chairs they used for furniture!  This place was a treat!!!

Tip** When you're done with your meal, get a shot of the Underberg and tell me how you feel the next day!  Teehee!!!
author: Brandy B.

description:
This place is adorable!  It had been on my list of "to go" places forever, however I just got around to it.  

Things to note:  The service is great, the ambiance is precious, and the food is good.
author: Vanessa L.

description: Super yummy German food in the city. The service was good and friendly. The atmosphere is small and cozy. I definitely like this place more than suppenkuche.
author: Vanessa H.

description:
Everything (food and beer) was tasty. And place was cozy and casual. 

Went with party of 10 and surprise, they take reservations and have small private room in the back. I think that's really good for dinner parties. 

Schnitzel (Breaded Porkloin) with Mashed Potatoes & Seasonal Vegetables: Not bad. Pork breaded well and pork was tender. However, it was a little dry towards the end even with the lemon. I am not going to complain too much about it since it was a big piece and it was fried. So overall, this dish was good.

Jäger Schnitzel (Porkloin) with Spätzle and Creamy Mushrooom Sauce: Very saucy and tasty. Definitely, if you are not looking for something fried, order this. I was very impressed how soft their pork loin came out to be.

Grilled Thüringer Bratwurst served with Mashed Potatoes & Sauerkraut: I think I was expecting a bigger piece of Bratwurst, but what came out was a longer version of the American Breakfast Sausage. I am willing to re-try, but it wouldn't be on top of my list.

Garlic Roast Pork with Potatoes and Vegetables: Conflicting! My husband's and other party attendee's pork dish was tender and done perfectly. However, other dinner party attendee said his pork was dry. And from what I could see. It was truly rock hard dry. So chances are 33% totally dry and 66% chance of moist pork. I guess if it is a bit dry, you might want to tell the waitress. It is suppose to be tender and moist. What happen? Too long off the stove?

Sauerbraten (Marinated Beef) with Potato Dumplings and Braised Red Cabbage: Pretty tasty, Beef tenderized and moist. I defintely would like to go and try a full dish of this.

Overall, this place has a nice family casual dining feel. People are super nice there and the whole feel of the place just works for it. I definitely recommend trying this place. The place, the food, and the beer-It just works!!!
author: Janice T.

description: Tasty, filling, German food in satisfying quantities (even a few vegetarian options). The atmosphere is low-key but with a certain spartan, practical elegance. Staff is friendly but no-nonsense. One of my favorite little places to bring out-of-town guests!
author: squeak s.

description: Awesome awesome place!!! Very cool atmosphere with lots of vintage decorations and trinkets. The staff is super friendly and attentive. The menu has an authentic feel to it and they don't get mad when you try to order because everything is in German. The food was extremely well put together and cooked. You will definitely leave full and satisfied. The food is very hearty and delicately seasoned. A must try place.
author: Maximillian S.

description: This took me right back to being in Germany.  It felt like a true experience and not like an American version of what it's like.  The chicken dish with a cherry sauce was amazing.
author: Kevin K.

description:
I've been here twice. The first time, I had a great experience. I brought two friends here tonight who were visiting from out of town. One was craving German, and my first choice place with a funner, noisier atmosphere was an hour wait so we went here. I walked in to put my name on the list while they were looking for parking. I told the server I had three people but she rolled her eyes at me when my party wasn't all here yet. The main room was full so when they arrived, we were seated in the back where we were ignored most of the meal. After already putting in our order, I later wanted to add the potato pancakes, but the server didn't come by to check up on us or refill our water. The wait for our food took a long time, and our schnitzel arrived black/burnt, hard, and very dry. There was a lot of breading and not much pork - quite disappointing compared to my first visit. When we got the bill, we found out they charged us $1 extra for substituting one of the mashed potatoes with spatzle (a minimal charge but I wasn't charged this during my first visit when I had the same dish). 

My first visit was 9p on a Friday night. I called to check on availability, and the person who answered said it's a slow night. My boyfriend and I arrived and found that it was pretty busy. They did have two seats at the bar or a small table available in the back room which was occupied by a large party, so we decided to wait for a table in the main dining room. We had a different server that night who was nice and to let us first sit at the bar to order food while we waited. The bar counter had fun East German memorabilia to look at. We got the potato pancakes with sourcream and apple sauce which were the best I've had (granted I was very hungry). It was a bit of a wait for a table to open up, but that was fine since our friend was stuck in traffic. We ended up getting a cozy window table. The atmosphere was nice with the candlelight in our own little corner nook. We shared the roast pork with roasted potatoes, chicken breast stuffed with apples and bacon that came with mashed potatoes, and the schnitzel with spatzle (substituting the mashed potatoes). I liked the schnitzel (adding lemon), the roasted potatoes, and the roast pork. The chicken apple was dry and bland. We bumped into a friend who was seated in the backroom and said she wasn't too impressed with the place because her schnitzel was dry. We thought the food was good, and were quite stuffed having no room for dessert although the menu was tempting.
author: Diana B.

description:
So good. SO good.

Never had a meal I didn't like here. Recently had the salmon with mashed 'taters and beets, and it was just phenomenal. A REAL portion of salmon, not a tablespoon on a huge plate with a smear of potato residue or something. A good, hearty meal at a very reasonable price. And the chicken with bacon/apples over mashed 'taters is just an incredible meal. Good potato cakes, too.

Compared to the German restaurant alternative in Hayes Valley, I much prefer Walzwerk. The other is more "highbrow" German food, but still enjoyable. Walzwerk is more Eastern German, thus less Westernized and much heartier. More "home cooking" kinda German food. Great atmosphere, nice collection of Eastern Bloc kitsch. Including the same salt-and-pepper we once had when I was a kid. Nostalgia. :) Friendly staff, and always worth it if you have to wait. At least they have some photo albums and beverages to entertain you during your wait!
author: Zann G.

description:
Fun and funky place with great beers and really good food.  
A friend of mine LOVES this place (he's German) and had bought a Living Social voucher for Walzwerk he couldn't use so he gave it to me.  The place has a shabby-chic East German appeal and the waitresses really work hard to get everyone seated and served. The food was great and very filling so you may want to resist over-ordering (or not).  The beer selection alone is worth stopping in for.
Be prepared - they get busy at dinner and so you may have to wait but the staff does everything they can to make their guests comfortable.
Nice find and I'll be back.......
author: Jay A.

description: It was a pleasant dinner as the seats were comfortable. We ordered the tomato soup, potatoes pancakes, cured salmon and a rouladen. The potato pancake was best as it crispy outside and there are lemon and dill to enhance the flavor. The tomato soup was too sour for our liking. The presentation of rouladen wasn't very good as the dark red source was over everything. But it still tasted pretty good.
author: Roger Y.

description:
Delicious German food, nicely executed traditional dishes. Love the fresh green salads to offset the saucy meats.

Tonight's waitress was great, seemed like they were short-staffed, and she handled the service smoothly and efficiently.
author: Mark P.

description:
I was surprised to find a moderately sized party of German people waiting to be seated.  So the staff don't chomp at the bit to welcome you into the restaurant or ask you how many are in your party, but I feel like that is part of the Walzwerk experience, just as much as learning to cut in "line" and demand "service" at a bakery in Chinatown.  After reading many reviews regarding the friendliness of the servers, I was expecting to be spat on and given mad dog faces, but they exhibited German efficiency with smiles on their faces.

I'd say their food is well-executed comfort basics: meat, carb, veggie.  The marinated beef had nice flavor but was a little tough.  I mean, I guess that's what I get for not sticking with their wursts and schnitzels.  The braised red cabbage was really good though and the potato dumpling was perfect to mop up the juice/sauce left on the plate.

The cold dog really is exactly as they describe it - rum and butter cookies layered in fudgy/ganoche-y chocolate in the appearance of cake.  It's a little dense and dry to gobble up on its own, but it came with a raspberry (?) drizzle to break up the richness, which was again, mopped up completely.

I like that it's casual enough that you feel like you're going to a distant relative's house, where they'll feed you but not dote on you or ask you a million invasive questions about your life, but it's nice enough that the lighting is warm, the noise level is moderate, and you don't order at the counter and bring a number back to your table.
author: Jenn C.

description:
I went there with three friends on a Thursday Night. Made reservations, quickly seated by a very nice/cool server. She offered great suggestions and was very helpful with our beer selections. 

I had the Sauerbraten (braised beef) with red cabbage and potato dumplings. While I didn't really care for the dumplings, the beef and cabbage were amazing! This paired perfectly with light amber beer (forgot name) that I ordered. Come hungry, because the portions are huge. 

The other big hit at our table was the awesome potato pancakes as an appetizer and the Jager Schniztel (porkloing with creamy mushroom sauce). OMG! that dish was so rich and creamy with perfectly cooked loin. 

Overall, an awesome place for excellent comfort style food (bring appetite), great selection of beer, and good service. 

I will definitely be back!
author: E M.

description:
I joined a group of friends at Walzwerk and I have to be honest, I wasn't sure what to expect. In addition, I am not a huge meat eater so I wasn't overly excited about being here. Wow, was I pleasantly surprised!

True: small, cozy, friendly, family run, great wine/beer...all of those things. But the food was incredible!

I ordered the vegetarian schnitzel which was breaded beets and carrots served on top of this interesting spinach sauce, w/mashed potatoes and cucumber salad. Oh my gosh, oh my gosh, oh my gosh! 

Because I was with a group, I was able to sample the potato pancakes and the apple strudel, which quite simply were to die for.
