If someone recommends Walzwerk, GO! I almost missed out on experiencing a true hidden gem.
author: Gina G.

description:
I went here for a Friday dinner date. We arrived at 730 and had to wait for ~10 minutes. (I tried to make a reservation the night before, but they only do reservations for 4+ people.)

The hostess / waitress was super nice and a bit endearing.

We ordered two appetizers: 1) salmon with pumpernickel bread, horseradish, and beets and 2) potato pancakes with chive sour cream and applesauce. The salmon was fresh, cool, and super thinly sliced. I don't like pumpernickel because it's so dry, but the salmon paired nicely with the potato pancakes. The beets tasted home-cooked.

The Aventinus Doppelbock beer was amazing. The waitress helped us pick it.

For mains, I had the jäger schnitzel with spätzle and creamy mushroom sauce, and she had the vegetarian cabbage roll with mashed potatoes. Both dishes were amazing. Mine was obviously much richer and probably much more unhealthy. Hers tasted fresh but had enough savoriness to taste a little salty at times.

We had no room for dessert. Overall, excellent food.

The decor of the place is really interesting too. I think they're going for an East German cafe in the 80's. There were pictures of Marx, Engels, and Lenin on the wall. The ambiance is very cozy.

The only less-than-ideal part of the evening was that the two of us sat at a fairly wide 4-person table. It would been much nicer to sit at a more intimate table because we're both a bit soft-spoken.

In any case, I'll definitely eat here again.
author: Max H.

description: This is a strange and wonderful little restaurant serving tasty food, great drinks and weirdness. Order the grapefruit beer!
author: A D.

description:
I use to frequent this place when I lived in SF.  Love the place, great people, good service, and I love the food and prices.

Michael.
author: Michael G.

description:
The food is very good and the service is friendly and fast. We had a mix up and actually ordered our food from Doordash. We never received our order and the Doordash did refund us the money because they delivered to the wrong place. 

We ended up going out to the restaurant and had a good time. They took very good care of us and the food is authentic. We were treated to an order potato pancakes because they heard about the mix up. It wasn't their fault and they actually made it screw up a positive for us. We will be back!
author: michelle b.

description: Best Pork Chop EVER! Had a great time celebrating Wife's birthday. Servers are great and personable and food is the BEST! Only issue was pork chop advertised with brussel sprouts and expected to get plate of sprouts only to find one sprout split in two with other delectable veggies, but disappointed not more sprouts.
author: Michael S.

description: AWESOME! True German food and a restaurant with ambiance. Enormous portions. Well priced. Friendly service. A unique experience. Can't wait to go back!
author: Rob R.

description: This has been on my list a long time. I have been curious about "East German" cuisine. My friend and I had the Daily Special and Schweinebraten respectively. For starters the potato pancakes. Hearty portions and good food. Best of all the restaurant was quiet with just a few tables and quiet customers so you could actually talk. Will return in the future to sample other dishes.
author: Matthias L.

description: Great German food, excellent beer, awesome ambiance, friendly service, and rarely a wait. I'll be back!
author: Cory D.

description: SO GERMAN! Great food, great beer. Love it.
author: Tasha D.

description:
How have I now reviewed this place yet!

I've been here dozens of times and it's one of my family's favorites.

The beer selection is also as you would expect at any German restaurant. (Franziskaner or Schneider Weisse for me)

My favorites on the menu which I order every time:

Matjes Herring in Sour Cream with Apples, Onions and Pickles, served with Pumpernickel Bread (appetizer)

Small Potato Pancakes with Chive Sour Cream and Applesauce (app)

Option 1: Jäger Schnitzel (Porkloin) with Spätzle and Creamy Mushrooom Sauce

Option 2: Breast of Chicken stuffed with Apples & Bacon (with Sundried Cherry Sauce), Mashed Potatoes, and Seasonal Vegetables

Apple Strudel with Ciao Bella Vanilla Ice Cream

And they have Underberg, you might need one of these tasty herbal digestives before you roll out the front door.
author: Mike V.

description:
By far best German food in SF! I came here with a friend for dinner on Sunday and didn't know what to expect because I've been to suppenkuche and that place is more of a beer place than German food place. I was pleasantly surprised by the cozy ambiance, great attentive staff and AMAZING food! 

I got the chicken schnitzel with mashed potatoes. It makes my mouth water just writing about it. This place has a smaller selection of draft beers (I believe 5?) than other places I've but they are all good!

Another thing to keep in mind is parking- this should just be a known in SF but you will have to find street parking and it may be difficult at times so just account extra time for that. Overall, if you are trying to get amazing food and a nice beer. This is the place for you!
author: Ranna K.

description:
We had a groupon to come here and were in the mood for a crunchy, tasty sausage and have always wanted to try this place so came on a whim on a friday night.
Overall we were very disappointed and will not be coming soon.I can see if you like beer, maybe but the food was just not that great. The flavors were there but the portions were just like, really?!

The place is small, dark and a bit dingy with little nats flying around the bar areas. - first yuck.

The servers are nice but they looked a bit greasy and dirty- like they needed a clean scrubbin or something or needed to wash their hands. Ya know, the type that looks like they just got back from a week at burning man or something?? Yuck #2.

onto the food-

I got the highly recommended bratwurst plate- it was literally a ginormous plate of mashed potatoes with another huge ginormous heaping of saurekraut + a teeny tiny probably 4 inch bratwurst. For $16 I'd assume they would at least double down on the  sausage and i found myself having to ration my eeny weeny sausage to eat with my extra large heaping of potatoes and sauerkraut. + the sausage wasnt even that great, I think a home grilled aidele's sausage would have been more satisfying!! At the end of my meal I had about 75% of my mashed potatoes left and 35% of sauerkraut left on my plate. I dont like wasting food but theres only so much potatoes you can eat in one sitting. The potatoes just tasted like regular home made potatoes and the sauerkraut had a good kick to it but there was just WAY too much compared to the sausage on the plate. 

The hubby had the roasted pork dish, again the flavors were on point, but the roasted pork was this small piece of meat with sauce on top, again piled with another humungo dish of --yep you bet, more potatoes! but this time in roasted form and a side of bland veggies.

We finished off with their berry smoothie ish like yogurt dessert. Yuck #3. It was like a semi melted yogurt smoothie thing with berries that I made at home and left sitting out. Nothing worth the $8 price tag. In fact I'd pay $8 not to eat it again!

Upon leaving, the hubby turned to me and said "If i had to eat this crap everyday to be with Heidi Klum, I'd have to dump her right away". LOL!!

Yuck yuck yuck- except for if you like beer i guess!
author: Petri Y.

description:
2 stars for atmosphere! Not crowded or loud. It was a sigh of relief to dine at such a quiet, humble restaurant. My friend described it well as having a "cottage" feel. Relaxing, cozy, unassuming. Random German trinkets, posters, and photos from the window.....to the wall! (Sorry, I had to say it). Also, I was diggin' the strange black and white photographs of Marx and other old German men with beards. 

1 star for good service. Our waitress was extremely friendly, helpful, and understanding of our lack of German beer and cuisine knowledge. 

1 star for good food, and *bonus points for VEGETARIAN OPTIONS! The potato pancakes were good, but my friend prefers the ones at Suppenkuche (I'd have to try Suppenkuche again to compare). Their MASHED POTATOS were HELLA good. Tried both the vegetarian schnitzel and vegetarian roulade. The schnieztel was breaded vegetables (turnip, YAMS, and beets), kind of like a "German tempura." The roulade was a cabbage roll filled with rice and vegetables. I equally liked both, depends on what kind of dish you're in the mood for. 
 
Overall, I really enjoyed our time here. The decision between Walzwerk and Suppenkuche really depends on the ambiance you're going for---if you're looking for a fun, lively, younger and perhaps trendier location, then go with Suppenkuche (also better for larger groups as there is a LOT more seating and larger tables). If you're looking for a quieter, quainter location, then definitely go for Walzwerk. =)
author: Diane G.

description: Unfortunately I don't remember too many details about the food, other than it definitely made my mouth water. I felt like this was a true German restaurant - the inside decor definitely had many little kitschy and national pride things, but I truly felt like I was taken back to my high school German classroom. Now if only they passed out chocolate right before exams..
author: Kris I.

description:
GOT GERMAN FOOD? YA! AND IT'S DELICIOUS MINUS THE PLANE RIDE! 

Thanks to the lack of communication by Schmidt's closure for private event on Sunday evening, we came to Walzwerk instead and had a great German dinner. By far, the best German food I had in SF.

We walked in with no reservation and the place was packed on a Sunday night at 8pm. We got lucky as a table just opened up and we got seated immediately. There were 3 of us so we decided to order everythign to share family style. We ordered:

1. SMALL POTATO PANCAKES WITH CHIVE SOUR CREAM AND APPLESAUCE. 

WOW! Best potato pancakes I've ever had. The outter layer is crispy, but in the inside is creamy and fluffy. The chive sour cream is a great match and it really brings out the flavor of the potatoes. 

2. SOLJANKA (TOMATO - CABAGE SOUP WITH SALAMI, BACON & 
PICKLES)

I ordered this because I love soup. This is a little too sour for my taste bud, but friends and family know that I can't really take anything too sour. But the broth is very hearty, very flavorful. It has a strong tomatoes flavors and the salami and bacons are salty, which makes the soup so appetizing. 

We ordered 3 entrees and shared them family style:

3. GRILLED THÜRINGER BRATWURST SERVED WITH MASHED POTATOES & SAUERKRAUT

Wow! I love Bratwurst and this one is dynamite. The sausage casing is seared to crispy and so flavorful. The meat mixture is great. Mashed potatoes are so creamy and the sauerkraut is nicely marinated, but still retained a good slightly crunchy texture of the cabbage. If you haven't have fresh sauerkraut (no, not the bottled stuff you get from the supermarket for your BBQ dogs), you have to try these sauerkraut. You will never eat the bottled stuff ever again. 

4. SAUERBRATEN (MARINATED BEEF) WITH POTATO DUMPLINGS AND BRAISED RED CABBAGE

I thought this dish was only ok for me mainly because it was a little sour, but the beef slices were very tender and you can cut it with a folk. It has great flavors and the sauce is very hearty. The potato dumplings (German's version of the Italian's gnocchi) were so fluffy and covered in creamy sauce. 

5. SCHNITZEL (BREADED PORKLOIN) WITH MASHED POTATOES & 
STEWED GREEN BEANS

The Schnitzel (German version of the Japanese tontatsu or pork cutlet) has a very thin breading on the outside layer, but fried to perfect golden brown and crispy and the meat is still moist on the inside. The green beans were heavenly. 

6. APPLE STRUDEL WITH VANILLA ICE CREAM

Great puff pastry and the stuffing was apples, some nuts and I think raisins? It was all good and came out nice and hot.

Total bill $120 for the 3 of us including tax and tips for all the food above, 3 beers and 2 apple scholes (really delicious apple juice). Not bad at all and more importantly we all had a great meal and our half German friend really enjoyed his dinner. Everything was well made, very authentic (yes, we speak from experience of dining in Germany) and our server, Francis was super nice and very helpful when it comes to helping us decide on which beer to order from their very extensive all German beer menu. 

The moral of my story is -- sometimes a backup plan can turn out to be better than the original plan. 

Yes, we'll be back definitely. Danke!
author: Gourmet Princessa L.

description:
What a gem! Super friendly staff, great beer selection and wonderful food. And not to forget the funky East German décor. 

Breaded Schnitzel with mashed potatos seems a bit strange to me, so I tried the beef roulade with Spätzle and red cabbage. Wow! The meat was melting in my mouth and the Spätzle were perfect. 

I'll definite y be back!
author: Alexa W.

description:
Came here with a party of six for a friend's birthday. First of all, everything about this place screams "East Germany" from the moment you enter the restaurant even to the very last moment where you shut the door behind you; the instant you set foot into the restaurant you'll be surrounded by rustic post-war propaganda posters from around the DDR, and also by your standard hof-style wooden "picnic" tables and homey seatings... 

On to the food and brew: as usual I was the first to arrive, so while waiting for my fellow diners to arrive, I decided to start the night off right with an erdinger kristallweizen. The erdinger was a perfect match with my sauerbraten which, as other yelpers have pointed out, wasn't so sauer, but was still a rare treat for a germanophile such as myself. The highlight of my dish wasn't the braten itself but the potato dumplings--I wish I could order a whole bucket of these and swim in a bathtub full of them. 

My second pair-up of the evening was the draft radeberger (the only other place I've seen that has this outside of Germany was this awesome German Pub in the Chaoyang district in Beijing and Suppenküche) and a piece of Jägerschnitzel I stole from the fellow diner to the right--the creamy mushroom sauce and the radeberger literally coagulated into some yummy fluid  sensation in my mouth, which put me into a 5-minute mini food coma.

This restaurant really deserves five stars, but the nature of Eastern German cuisine sorta takes away that last star; even though the food (and beer) at Walzwerk is awesome, you're basically paying top-dollar for really good comfort food.
author: Scott S.

description:
I love the food here -- my Mom's German so it tasted just like home.  And as the other reviewers mentioned -- it has a very good selection of beer.  

Also, I love the decor -- it's very East Berlin -- pre-wall coming down.  I lived in West Berlin during that time -- it was like a time warp for me to come into this restaurant -- Absolutely loved it -- although I can see why others might think its a bit quirky.

The only reason that I didn't give them 5 stars is that I went here through a Groupon offering.  There were just two of us.  I paid with the voucher -- and was ready to pay the amount over the voucher -- when I noticed they had added in the tip already (even though we weren't a party of 6 or more) -- plus on the credit card receipt, they had added the line for an additional tip.  

I own a small business in the City -- and understand that some customers screw you over by not leaving a tip on the full amount.  But to include it on the bill -- plus to ask for even more tip on the credit card slip -- for a party of 2 -- I thought that was a bit too much.  

Sorry Walzwerk -- Just not cool!
author: Anneliese G.

description:
I thought this place had a really fun East German inspired atmosphere (fun now that people don't actually HAVE to live in Eest Germany!).
The food was really good! The spatzle was amazing and I had the jaeger schnitzel and it was tasty too. My favorite dish there was the cured salmon appetizer. That was excellent.
I will definitely be back to sample more of their great German draught beers too!
author: M G.

description:
"You are leaving the American Sector"

When I think industrial, goth, avant-garde, and enigmatic, I think Germany.

I wanted to visit Walzwerk for quite some time now. The opportunity never came. It's specifically hard to define German good to someone who hasn't had it when I haven't been to Germany myself. But for me it's the beer and the flavors that make you feel full though not bloated. Oh, and I always thought German was one of the most romantic languages (I hate the sound of French) so if I have the chance to hear people speaking German next to me, I will take it.

So, we arrived here and sat by the window. I liked that little altar and the beer menu at all times framed. They were out of Köstritzer, so I got Radeberger and my dinner companion got Weltenburg Helles. I would normally get Franziskaner as it is my favorite beer but not this time.

We got our drinks fast.  For starters, we got the potatoe pancakes and a sausage with more potatoes (?) Anyway, Those potatoe pancakes were mathematically perfectly round, and the sausage was also great. We were tasting each other's drink's, food. This is a place where you definitely want to share.

We talked and talked and talked. Again, keep in mind "You are leaving the American Sector." This isn't Starbucks where your waiter smiles like an idiot and asks about your day. This isn't a place where you take priority. This is European style. You either like it, or not. They don't care. If you want to be spoiled, go to Burger King or grow up! In fact, I wish more places were real and not fake about their "customer service."

However; when you have a beer, and you're in a nice place, well, it's worth the wait. I think they must have been backed up in the kitchen as neither tables had any food. Not a single person seemed to be really concerned with this. I know I wasn't. I ordered the "Breast of Chicken stuffed with Apples & Bacon (with Sundried Cherry Sauce), Mashed Potatoes, and Seasonal Vegetables."  He got something with red cabbage. I forget what exactly.

//Beware: Almost all entrees are pork. Probably not vegetarian options but check first. Menu at the window or online. 

By the time we got our dinner. I wasn't even really hungry anymore! Don't you hate it when that happens? I got a to go box and had lunch and dinner for the next day!

But, yes, the bill was rather steep. We paid almost $100. I'm not saying the food wasn't worth it, or the beers. In fact, if there's a place where I'd spend $100 for dinner, it would have to be German or one of my favorite spots in the city. 

The bathroom has this weird gallery full of German hygiene trinkets. Interesting. Also, portraits of Marx....no....La Vey! Tell me that is NOT La Vey's face on the wall, dare you to! And if it is, I have now drank with La Vey and stayed at his residence! 

Oh, and that logo...it looks pretty similar to Kink.com's logo :) If you don't agree, dare you to come whip me!
author: Alexia R.

description:
I was looking for somewhere unique, reasonable priced, and tasty to have dinner with my friend visiting from Boston, and this place definitely fit the bill. 

The Rundown:
Apfelschorle: i love apple cider and this was the perfect pairing for all the dishes. a good non-alcoholic choice.
Potato Pancakes-- MUST try this! applesauce is such a great pairing and it wasn't heavy at all.
Jäger Schnitzel-- pork is soooo tender and the mushroom sauce is just heavenly. I would definitely get this again.
Beef Roulade-- this entree is on the heavier side because the beef and sauce is very flavorful (vinegar based). The beef wasn't dry at all and although the dish is on the sweet side, it was overall well-balanced.

Our servers were very friendly and fast. We got seated immediately even though all the tables were filled. Since it was just the two of us we sat at the small bar area in the middle of the restaurant where there are couches... it was very cute and intimate and feels like you're in someone's home. The entrees took a little bit to get to our table but i just assume that's because it's an authentic German restaurant (and that's what happened when i was in Germany). I will definitely come back to try other things on the menu and drink some beers!
author: Melody C.

description:
I have to admit, when I first think of German food, images of bratwursts and sauerkraut with generous pints/boots of beer come to mind (or at least, that's what they have at Oktoberfest).  Suffice to say, I was glad to see so much more was to be had.  But first and foremost,  I have to say, the Potato Pancake is AWESOME.  Since we had such a large group, we got multiple orders of it, and these babies were flying off the table.  Granted, these are just glorified hash browns, but I LOVE hash browns!

As for our entrees, we obviously got ourselves an order of Bratwurst with Mashed Potatoes and Saurkra and it was a mighty hefty serving.  The potatoes were rather bland though (that's what garlic mashed will do to you), but I loved the bratwursts.  You imagine bratwursts tasting almost the same everywhere, but I certainly liked this one more than anything I've had before.  

We also ordered a plate of the Chicken stuffed with Apple and Bacon as well as the Jager Schnitzel (Porkloin with Cream of Mushroom sauce).  They were both just okay, but I thought the Schnitzel was the better of the two for me, even if a couple of my friends didn't really care much for it.  It loosely reminds me of a dish I had as I was growing up, so maybe that's why I liked it better than them.  As for the Chicken, it was a bit of a miss for me.  The dish sounded so good on the menu, but it was a little meh for me, which is disappointing because it seemed like it would be so good!   The Cheese Spatzle was not bad, and it went well with the chicken and pork entrees (it's almost like rice!), but eating too much of it starts to get kind of gross. 

One knock on the place is that while they can accommodate groups, you may want to keep it below a group of 15 or so.  Our group was about that size (probably larger) and we were seated in a room at the back of the restaurant.  It was a smaller sized room, and so we really had to work to squeeze in at one long table.  We got it done, but it wasn't the most comfortable fit.  The service was friendly and attentive though (helped being in the back since we were right by the kitchen), and they rotated around to help our table instead of just one person managing all of us.  In any case, I'd want to come back to get more hash browns!
author: Mike L.

description:
Wait, we are in East Germany now?

After getting seated at a nice table in the back room, I looked all the pre-unification memorabilia, interesting. Not that I can tell the difference between east and west German food, I like the simple home feeling of the place.

Now back to the food, just like the place, taste home made. Not a lot of veggies, but nothing on the heavy side.

The potato pancakes were yummy!

Beer selection, average for a German place, but that still means 10 on tap, and another 10 amongst the bottle selection.

I like this place, easy going, relax, and just good enjoyable home style German meal.
author: Alice C.

description:
Came here for dinner, i love how small and homey the restaurant felt, as if i was at someone's grandmother's home with a combination of industrial like decor which was cool.

My friend ordered the Fish special which was really good, very buttery and moist.

I had the Jäger Schnitzel which was really yummy, it really felt like a home cooked meal and hit the spot perfectly, i love the mushroom sauce on top of the pork. I would come here again.
author: Darnell L.

description:
YUMMY! Great alternative to Suppenkuche w/o the wait! 

I got the Brat with mashed potatoes and sauerkrat and the portions were huge! The brat was a little bit salty, but the spicy mustard tastes great with it. Also, make sure to get the potatoe pancakes with sour cream and apple sauce! The sour cream tastes great with it! :)

I think I'd rather go here instead of Suppenkuche for the following reasons:

1) Parking is EASIER
2) Small inside, but no wait
3) Portions are a little bit bigger
4) Staff is SUPER SUPER Friendly
5) Cute Homey Decor

Yay!! I'm a fan! :)
author: Jo L.

description:
If you are looking for a little warm, comfy, authentic "grandma's kitchen" sort of place in the middle of the city.. this is it! When my roommate and I lived downtown we were here constantly. I think they might still recognize us, hah..

The mashed potatoes are to DIE for. The stuffed pork is superb. The stuffed chicken is equally so. It's comfort food to the max! You won't regret it.
author: Adrianne M.

description: In my opinion there are 2 legit german places in sf, I think this is the best one.  jaeger schnitzel with spaetzle.  Dang gina!
author: christopher h.

description:
Minus one star for NEVER ONCE refilling my water over a 45 minute time period in which I ate AMPLE sauerkraut. Anyways...

The food here is SOOOOOO good. I had the Stuffed Chicken Breast and my bf had the bratwursts with sauerkraut. Both were unbelievably delicious. They were served with a very thick luxurious heap of mash potatoes.

The chicken breast itself was a bit dry but the stuffing was pure tear-inducing deliciousness (bacon, apple, raisins?, creme, tears of God). The sauerkraut was sooooo good (I have a thing for vinegar.) I don't remeber much about the bratwursts other than it was meaty. 

I'm still waiting for my water though....I like water.
author: Glenda L.

description: After moving here from Germany, Walzwerk became my favorite place for german food and beer. I prefer it over Suppenküche due to the cuter more intimate atmosphere and the food is very good and the dish sizes huge! Christiane and Viola are sweethearts
author: Daniel C.

description:
A good selection of German beers on tap, and in the bottle.

I had an excellent meal, normal German fare, authentic. I enjoyed talking to the owner, and the staff.  High quality German food, friendly service, totally enjoyable.
author: Nemo O.

description: To our amazing waitress, she took care of us for 4 years, delivered amazing service and exceptional food. We will miss her, and wish her the best in Seattle with her boyfriend where she will embark on her new journey.
author: Guillermo C.

description:
Pros- good beer, cool stuff on the walls, big portions, great mashed potatoes.
Cons- cold food, bad services, no reservations, not an enjoyable experience. 
Overall: Do not go.

I have family coming into town next month and want to find a great restaurant to take them to. So I decided to try this place as a potential spot to bring them because the menu looked great. I was REALLY hoping to like this place and had been waiting all week to go. Not only was I unimpressed, I was very disappointed. 

From the moment we walked in things went down hill. 

This place does not take reservations for less than 8 people, which is fine. When we got there the server told us the wait would be an hour for two people. This place is VERY small (only about 8 or 9 tables total) with only four seats at the bar (which were all full), so we went and got a drink and came back 45 minutes later. When we got there we were told that our table had been given away 20 minutes ago, and we would have to wait another hour. We were shocked. After deciding to go somewhere else, the gave us a table. We were really exciting and sat down and looking forward to the awesome food!

The same server came to take our drink order, I started by saying I wanted water and she turned and walked away. We asked her to wait because we also wanted to order other drinks. At this moment it became clear, this place is like that soup restaurant on Seinfeld (which sucks for a sit down place): You must know exactly what you want and bark it out very quickly--you do not ask questions about the menu or ask for suggestions. The server acted like you are more of a nuisance than a customer.  My boyfriend barely got the words out "I would like an amber..." and she was gone again. 


When she came back we quickly gave our orders without asking any questions or for any suggestions.

When the food finally arrived it looked great but was cold. Not just "not hot", it was cold--like it had been sitting out for 15 minutes (although, the center of my mashed potatoes were warm and that part tasted great).  By this point, we gave up trying to take pleasure in this experience and just wanted to leave.  It was not enjoyable to be there. No one ever came back to ask how our food was or if we needed anything and, honestly, with such a rude server I did not want to chance grabbing her attention and sending my food back to be warmed, anyway. I ended up putting my whole meal in a to-go box to take home and heat up. I end-up finally eating my meal at home at 11pm. 

The service was really bad and the food just was not worth it.  Not only am I not bringing my family here next month, I would never recommend to anyone. There are so many amazing restaurants in this city that have awesome food and friendly staff; there is no point in wasting your time or money on this place.
author: Casey P.

description:
The food was properly German in the most exotic sense. Meat, cream and potato heavy. Gluten-free vegans should abstain.

The ambiance was right...International style modernism mixed with the right amount of post-WWII pop culture memorabilia. The lighting was good and its intoxicatingly cosy inside. 


The service was personable and timely. Our waitress was patient and cheerful for tri-lingual table.

Their house wine was the only thing to be desired.

I will def. be back. You should go...went with party of 9 and it was just right!
author: Hilde L.

description:
Once you approach Walzwerk's heavy door you are informed that by passing through said door you're leaving the safe zone of SF gastronomical delights (or something like that...)

Inside, Walzwerk is very low key, which lends a very casual feel.  We were given the option of sitting immediately in the back or waiting for a table in the front.  Not knowing what the difference was, we went with sitting down right away.  Which was a mistake - the back had three tables, one with LOUD, drunk tourists (how did they find this place?) and another with a baby.  As in, the baby was on top of the table.  Interesting.

Another problem I'm blaming on the back room is the service - it was just not there.  Every time a waitress wandered into the back room we flagged her down, but it almost seemed like they forgot people were in the back room at all.

Contrasting with the stark decor, everything on the menu seemed a few dollars too expensive for what it actually was.  We ordered the potato pancake that Yelp is so fond of - $7 for three glorified hash browns.  For my main dish I had the beef roulade which had a great, tasty description but the taste left something to be desired.  I think what really threw me off was the warm, melty pickles in the roulade.  Now I know - pickles are have to be crunchy!  The red cabbage and spaetzle were good, but they're supposed to be sides, not the main event.

For dessert we went with the apple strudel - so classic.  This was definitely the high point of the meal.  It was just a normal, classic strudel, but it helped wash down the strange roulade aftertaste.
author: Cathy Y.

description:
I came to Walzwerk on a Tuesday night. The ambiance is very unique. It's funky and cool with posters, unique chairs, etc. The dining area is full when we arrived (6.30 pm), so my friend and I decided to sit at the bar. 

Once seated, we're greeted by the server who brought us amuse bouche (bread with gruyere or salami). Our server is so nice and friendly that she let me try a few beers before ordering. My pick was schwarzbier which is a German dark lager beer. 

I got the trout special which comes with green beans, brussels sprout and mashed potatoes (which I substituted with spatzle for $2 extra). The trout is topped with sliced almonds. My friend's jager schnitzel with creamy mushroom sauce was so delicious. The plate looks almost like he licked everything off the plate.

Walzwerk is definitely fun for a group of friends or even a date night. :)
author: Saran R.

description:
don't hate me but the food was meh. i guess this is my first time trying german food so i didn't know what to expect. almost everything on the menu was pork based- i love me some bacon but that that's just too much porky for my taste. 

the saving grace for walzwerk were the delicious apple strudel dessert and the awesome staff- they were incredibly friendly and sweet. i had a huge group and they were able to accommodate all of us. they even had a small room in the back for more privacy. another thing i liked about this place was that the menu is written out in german and there were random east german items that decorated the restaurant- it really makes you feel like you just teleported to berlin or dresden.
author: The Hangry Chef O.

description: Small, little whole in the wall kinda place with great food! Had the jager schnitzel, hubby had the regular schnitzel, German beer with a tiny bottle of Underberg to help the good ol' digestive system. You just have to experience it for yourselves.
author: Marian L.

description:
From the moment you walk in the door it's like your going into an East German Steel Workers Dining Hall.  Which on the surface may sound tacky but when is matched perfectly with authentic East German food and most importantly authentic German Beer on draft makes for a great combination.  Christiane the owner is hustling hard to serve most of the customers and while the service is warm it is slow which in my mind is more than made up for by the quality of hearty food and drink.    

I was definitely a huge fan of the Herring appetizer with is made with apples and cream and the overwhelming size and authenticity of the jägerschnitzel which is suprisingly hard to find in SF.  A must try restaurant which is definitely worth the long wait.  The only downside from the long wait for food was the heat because as the restaurant gets to capacity it rises to about 80 degrees F which only adds to the DDR steel worker atmosphere.
author: Alejandro L.

description:
always a delight.
Great food. Mellow and lovely service. 
great environment. 
They pulled out a gluten free menu for my friend. 
!!
author: slow c.

description:
The food is excellent.
They could however greet customers when they walk in with a hearty Guten Abend or good evening and a smile. Also, there needs to be traditional German music playing to create a festive atmosphere. It was too quiet during dinner.
The waitresses were very attentive, fast and helpful.
Again, the main course was amazing, authentic and very filling! Very original, too!!!
author: Marshall M.

description:
Don't go here for dinner if you have a time-sensitive engagement later that evening. Luckily, I didn't. The industrial decor and drunk servers threw me back to the Cold War. Well, except for the Hispanic cooks who occasionally entered the tiny, loud, and crowded dining area to serve food while the drunk German waitress mingled with guests and dropped plates on the ground as she stumbled about. 

Essentially, no one who works here gives a fuck. And you shouldn't either. You get seated when it's time to get seated. You get waited on when they think it's time for you to get waited on. The food is rich, simple, unique. Out of this world danktastic? Hardly. The herring appetizer was my favorite dish, by far. Sure, there were moments when we witnessed disgruntled guests stand and leave after waiting several minutes for one of the two waitresses, most likely a sober one, to acknowledge them. Clearly understaffed, yes, but I believe this is all part of the experience. I'll give this place another try soon.
author: Scott G.

description:
I've been a big fan of Walzwerk for a while now, but recently decided to have a party there for 18 people! 

The service was great and the food fantastic.  

If planning a party this is your place, they give you all of their appetizers on the menu and 3 entrees served family style for only $25 per person.  We ordered the Bratwurst, Jaeger Spaetzel (sorry about the spelling), and the stuffed chicken.  I highly recommend all three, and there was more than enough food to go around.  My boyfriend and I went there weeks before to try things on the menu for the party and the waitress was extremely helpful and gave excellent recommendations.

In addition to that we had the entire room to ourselves so we could talk and not be drowned out by a busy restaurant.  

Bottom line, this is a great place to throw a party or have a dinner for two.
author: Nicole A.

description: Delicious authentic German food without the crazy crowd and wait. Friendly staff.
author: Ian W.

description:
I AM A HAPPY GIRL!

I have finally found a go-to German joint that takes reservations and happily fed us with good food and drinks (without a ridiculous wait, crazy crowds, and super bad parking)!

I was able to get a reservation for a party of 6 on a Friday night only a few days before.  We walked right in.  Sat down.  Ordered and proceeded to have a great time.

The place is a small space, so I can see the wait being a bit long if you just walked on in.  Definitely make the reservations, folks!

YUM:
- Breast of Chicken stuffed with Apples & Bacon (with Sundried Cherry Sauce), Mashed Potatoes, and Seasonal Vegetables- most of us were lured by the chicken and bacon.  It was good, but not as amazing as...
- Grilled Thüringer Bratwurst served with Mashed Potatoes & Sauerkraut- the brat is sooooooooooo delish!

Just OK:
- Small Potato Pancakes with Chive Sour Cream and Applesauce

I also discovered a love for Diesel- beer and coke.  Brilliant!  Great choice of beers as well.

Parking was actually easy for all of us (3 cars all parked within a block).  

Will definitely come back!
author: Christine K.

description:
I used to live in Germany and I frequently miss German. 

Me and a native born German friend checked this place out. I had the chicken breast stuffed with apples and bacon and mashed potatoes. So beyond delicious. It was like coming home. 

It's a very small place, but worth the visit.
author: Kim J.

description:
bomb bomb bomb!

god i felt like i was in deutschland! 

If you like German food and you haven't had any in a long time, you need to stop by this place, it was absolutely fantastic, it is so so so small, they have amazing beer and amazing food. The Spetzle was fantastic!

I wish i lived in SF, i would eat here all the time! 

Prost!
author: Skyler W.

description:
Seriously great. I've been here several times and it blows my mind that two gals can keep a jamming front of the house rolling every time. Last time I was there we used a Bloomspot on the last night of the coupon, I have no problem paying full price here, and as a result there was a bit of a wait, but a wait with beer it is hardly that. Some people were being turned away because they didn't plan ahead, so don't let any of those reviews sway you because I'm sure they are out there.
Two words: pickled herring, every time a must. Once we had some leftover and I woke the next morning excited to eat it. Other classics like the jäger schnitzel and sauerbraten are some of my favorites. Be sure to finish your night with an Underberg,  and get a round for the gals too, they earned it.
author: john s.

description:
When I think of the perfect model for a successful restaurant, this is it. The decor, floor plan, plates, glasses, salt and pepper shakers, and well, even the waiters are German.  Walking through the front door of this place is like walking into an alternate dimension. After entering from an odd block, it's like a secret German expatriate hideout. 

The food is fantastic. Jagersnitzel that will blow your mind time and time again. Spaetzle that is too much to deal with. Even pickled herring in what looks like tartar sauce? Okay Walzwerk, I'll eat it. Wash it down with a beer mixed with Coke? Why not? By the time they've charmed the pants off of you to fit more food into your ever expanding stomach, you start to wonder how you ever got into this predicament. 

If there is ever a place to lose your mind and go hog wild, this is it. I'd go so far as to say it's my favorite restaurant in San Francisco, and one of my favorites overall in the quality of experiences I've had there. Christmastime Gluwhein and cookies is a must for anyone looking to live in their lifetimes. The service is great, and while it's not technically perfect (you might wait or get the wrong thing,) like I said, it's beyond charming. If this place ever closes down, I will buy the property and encase it in glass, preserving it like Lenin himself. 

Walzwerk, I left my heart in East Germany, and I'm coming home to you.
author: Evan C.

description:
Had dinner here the other night. I would say the food is a solid 3.5, but the service is so friendly and the ambiance so interesting, I have to boost my rating up to a 4. It's a small space, but it was just my friend and me, so we were able to sit at the bar (which actually enhanced my experience because we were able to chat with the servers, who I found to be lovely people). In summary:

1) We started with the house cured salmon--I would say that the salmon was pretty good, though the bread it came on ("fitness bread") tasted like it came straight from East Germany...in the 80s. I would probably pass on this if I had the opportunity to come back. 

2) Upon the recommendation of our waitress, I had the jager schnitzel (porkloin with THE MOST DELICIOUS PASTA and mushroom sauce). The sauce looked really heavy when the dish arrived, but the whole dish was extremely flavorful and I ended up eating far more of it than I would have expected. If I was rating solely on this dish and the service, I would have given this place 5 stars, easily. I would absolutely come back just to eat this again.

3) Upon the recommendation of our waitress, my friend had the chicken stuffed with bacon, in cherry sauce. I had some, and I have to say this was really good, but not a show stopper like the jager schnitzel. The mashed potatoes were especially good, however.

4) For dessert, we ordered the apple strudel. We devoured that as well, despite being totally full. There's something about the classic apple pie and vanilla ice cream combo that gets me every time. In this rendition, I really appreciated how the "crust" of strudel was thin and light and the apples weren't totally soggy. Well done!

Overall, a very cool place--I'm looking forward to my next visit!
author: Nora G.

description:
My friend and I bought a Living Social deal to try out this German restaurant. There's no nearby garage so we ended up with street parking on a Sunday night.

If you didn't know it was there, you could have missed it. The place is small with German decor/posters. It's a bit dark though and they have simple table decor. The atmosphere is intimate. There were only two waitresses but at least the turn around time was better than a previous dinner outing with my husband.

For our deal, we got one appetizer, two entrees and one dessert. Since my husband doesn't like fish, we choose house cured salmon with horseradish cream & marinated beets. My friend got the herring in sour cream with apples, onions, pickles, served with pumpernickel bread. Both we interesting dishes.

For entrees, we each had different dishes but I think it would have been better if the couples shared the food. The entrees were big so I had to eat half in order to make room for dessert. I had the garlic roast pork with vegetables and potatoes. With the sauce, it was good but when I brought the other half home without the sauce, it was pretty dry.

For dessert, we got the red berry pudding and my friend got the strawberry tart. All good desserts. The pudding wasn't sweet.

I'm glad that my friend and I bought the deal. It was our way to try out new restaurants that we wouldn't know about.
author: Jenn D.

description:
Delicious food, with a nice "home-cooked" feel to it. I tasted the jager schnitzel and the stuffed chicken, both great. They also have a good selection of German beers on tap, which added a nice touch.

The decor is a little odd --- like a WW2-era bunker filled with used furniture and war-themed posters on the wall. Office chairs, mis-matched plates and cutlery... They were playing ACDC at a low volume throughout the dinner. Unique to say the least, but the ambiance somehow added to the experience. It really felt like I was having dinner at somebody's home.
author: Laurent L.

description:
I can't believe I've lived in SF for 11 years and never knew about this place! Awesome cozy and retro atmosphere, incredible bar and strong local following and yes, rich hearty Deutche fare: just a treat.

They assured us it wouldn't be crowded at 7 (and don't take reservations for 2 anyway) but we still had to wait; while an inconvenience, it's certainly a good sign (particularly because this place looks a bit seedy from the outside). I got a tasty Riesling and my BF got his trademark Pilsner (here, a Radeberger) and these completely did the trick. We wound up sharing a table with a great couple (he ordered in German) and appreciated the Marx, Engels & Lenin decor while we munched on our potato pancake ("latke" for yours truly) appetizers: not too greasy, chunky with real potatoes and just enough to tide us over until the main course came.

My BF *loved* his schnitzel though I thought it looked a bit like a cheap chicken fried steak. My bratwurst was fine - tasty but hardly the huge footer I'd envisioned. Both plates came with very tasty veggies, and his with mashed potatoes, mine with spicy good sauerkraut.

Sum: the ambiance, drinks, appetizers and service all get high marks*...the actual main dishes get medium marks*. But overall a memorable dining experience I'd repeat. 

* or DMs
author: Diane B.

description:
We arrived at 9:20 pm on a Saturday night. The restaurant advertises that it is open until 10 pm.  There was one table free. The host told us that because it was slow, they had closed early and would not be serving any more customers. We were momentarily speechless. She sneered and turned away.

Having spent years working at restaurants, I appreciate that it's a real drag when customers show up just before closing and want service. But with 40 minutes to go? 

I have enjoyed Walzwerk, and while the food and service has slipped since the original owners left, it had been OK till now. At this point, I wouldn't bother with it.
author: TIm a.

description: The Jäger Schnitzel (Porkloin) is delicious! I like it!
author: Arnaud H.

description: Love Walzwerk. Came here a while back with my mom and I remember it being good but I honestly didn't remember HOW good. We asked to taste the amber beer and our server was happy to oblige. We ordered the amber beer and the dark lager. Both beers were EXCELLENT. I loved the dark lager, I could have drank 5 of them lol. It was similar to a Guiness with smokey coffee notes and slight bitterness but waaaay more flavorful and more effervescent and crisp than a Guiness. So great. We ordered the stuffed chicken breast and the schnitzel and asked for spaetzle instead of mashed potatoes on one of the plates. Both plates also came with a side of mixed veggies. Everything was outstanding. The schnitzel is light and crispy tender, the spaetzle was so flavorful, I wish I knew how they prepare it. The mashed potatoes were decadent and smooth. The chicken was moist and flavorful in itself but filled with bacon and dried cherries and onions and covered in this delicious, slightly sweet and creamy sauce. One of the best meals I've had in a very long time. We literally finished every single scrap of food on the plates. Amazing food, great service, delicious beers and a cute, kitschy atmosphere. Must go, can't wait to go back.
author: Emma H.

description:
Awesome food! Any food I tried :)

We had lots of food.. some that I recall:

Small Potato Pancakes with Chive Sour Cream and Applesauce
Jäger Schnitzel
Sauerbraten 
Breast of Chicken stuffed with Apples & Bacon
Beef Roulade
author: I B.

description:
**This review is written as a mostly vegetarian, if i was not it woudl be 3-4 stars.

It's a German restaurant so I know it is going to be mostly meat and potatoes. However, the vegetarian options were pretty basic.  Aka - when they said breaded vegetables on mashed potatoes, i did not think I would get breaded potatoes on mashed potatoes. 

The stuffed chicken I had a bite of was great (bacon stuffed and cannot be ordered without bacon).  

Beer on tap is great!  Ambiance is well lit, real basic room.  Authentic s&p shakers and wall art is members of the German club.
author: Sarah G.

description:
Food: They brought out an amuse bouche! It was rye bread with radishes and cheese/sausage, but still. Nice! Entree: heaping portions of potato, enough meat for 2 meals, and boiled and (kinda tasteless) vegetables. I almost wanted to dock more points for that, because come on. Fresh or flavorful at least produce should be like a basic thing in SF. Maybe I am way too in this bubble though. Heavy, cream everything. Potato pancakes were yummy!

Atmosphere: A lot smaller and more rinky-dink than I thought based on the website (which is so shiny and graphic designer-y!) Has some 70s office chairs that aren't very comfortable and reclaimed office tables.

Service: Really, really nice. My friend doesn't like beer so the waitress brought her a taste of a beer/sprite mix that she liked. I just don't think many SF places would bother, right? Also didn't hassle us about splitting the check on four cards even though I HATED that when I was a waitress.

Anyway: filling and comforting food, casual atmosphere, really nice people.
author: Miranda E.

description:
After seeing Walzwerk on Check, Please! Bay Area, my partner insisted on going there. I've never had German food before and figured it was worth a try.

Having worked for a (crazy) German lady in the past, I'm quite familiar with their aggressive, short demeanor. That prepared me to not take it personal when the hostess/waitress greeted me coldly. I asked for a table for two and she responded: "I don't have anything!" What a warm greeting! Usually, this would be a trigger for my inner biatch to come out, but in this case I considered it part of the "theme" of the restaurant. 

The food was good, although the vegetarian options are limited. I had the cheese spaetzle and my partner had the vegetarian roulade. The spaetzle was good and I loved the sides of pickled veggies. It was a weird combination but tasted very good together. The mashed potatoes served with my partners roulade were like crack! 

For dessert we had the special of the day which was schokoladenpudding. Can you guess what that is? Chocolate pudding. Not very German, but tasty. 

Overall, we had a good experience although it's a bit pricey, especially for vegetarian entrees.
author: Joshua C.

description: Walzerk is German food heaven!!  I've been here many times and love it every single time! All of the food I've tried is absolutely delicious! My favorite are the Wiener schnitzel and the Jaeger schnitzel, so amazing! The spaetzel  is cooked perfectly and the butter lettuce is simple but so damn good!! The place itself is really cute, it kind if feels like you're in someone's home and the service is nice without being overbearing. The food is priced very well since the food is super delicious and the portions are huge. Walzwerk is absolutely delicious!!
author: Michi R.

description:
4.5 stars.

Walzwerk is one of the few restaurants that live up to the 650+ (omg!) glowing reviews.

I went last night with the boyfriend to try out some delicious German cuisine. We arrived at 9:15, had drinks in our hand by 9:45, then a table by 10, which is, according to Yelp, closing time for them. Despite that, the restaurant was extremely busy, people were still enjoying each others company and hardly any bills were given (which explains why it took us so long to find a darn table). So this place, understandably, is quite the Popular Patty! 

My God, make reservations. Don't do what we did and think, "Oh, it'll have died down by 9 on a Friday night." BZZZ. WRONG. FAIL. END OF THE LINE FOR YOU, MISS. We stood there like assholes for the majority of the time we were there because everyone else (probably) called in ahead.

My boyfriend drank the Franziskaner Hefeweizen ($6) all night, and I the infamous Diesel ($4) - a funky concoction of beer and Coke. The only beer I really drink is during Oktoberfest, so take my opinion with a grain of salt but.. the Diesel was ridiculously good. I mean, it's effing hilarious how my mind was blown taking that first sip. Try the Diesel. 

Eventually we got our food. It did not disappoint. The boyfriend ordered the Bratwurst ($15) and I tried the fish special they had going on ($19). Was it worth the wait? Heck yes. By 10 PM, we were ravenous and heavy German food is just the answer. We both got mashed potatoes, which were so good. It was just the right amount of creamy and soft. His bratwurst, I'm told, was delicious as well as the sauerkraut that came with it. Mine, the fish, was super good too! It was a perfect combination of crispy and tender at all the right places. Might have been a tad too salty but the lemon sauce that was drizzled all over it and the green bean vegetables were soo good. If you're reading this review while they still have that fish special (that I cannot spell/pronounce or even fathom to attempt), please try it.

The building itself is tiny. Sooo small. I wish it were bigger. But it's pretty awesomely decorated with a picture of Karl Marx, Vladimir Lenin and some guy who looks like Rutherford B. Hayes. (Who is he!) ETA: I am told he is Freddy Engels, Karl's buddy.

There were only two waitresses at the time we were there. Both were extremely friendly and helpful. One took pity on us lowly newbies and offered to serve us drinks. (THANK YOU.) Later, the other asked a couple patrons if they would give up their table for us while they sat in the couch. (DOUBLE THANKS.) They were super kind, super generous. I feel like an ass coming back to the restaurant to question my itemized bill, when everything was actually on the straight and narrow. 

This review is getting almost TL;DR so I'll stop now. Walzwerk is awesome. This is going to be my new favorite German restaurant that I'll use and abuse every time I'm in SF. (Too bad I'm in SoCal!)

P.S. - They don't take AmEx!
author: Tiffany W.

description: Started with potato pancake. Yum. Schnitzel was fantastic with spatzel and mushroom gravy. Bratwurst with REAL mashed potatoes and sauerkraut was good as well. Highly recommend for authentic German food.
author: Julia M.

description:
As a person who goes to a German butcher pretty much every weekend, I had to check this place out, since after all, it was his recommendation. In a sleepy part of the Mission, it was a great stop before hitting a show down at Slim's. My butcher pointed out that this place is specifically an East German restaurant, and the stuff that I was used to eating was going to be slightly different here. Indeed it was.

The decor is eclectic with cool East German referential art. We were sat in the front room near the bar without hesitation. I got the trip tip roulade with bacon and  pickles, with red cabbage. They happily substituted the cheese spaetzle special from another dish for me from the normal spaetzle. So awesome. Cabbage has a bit of clove in it and nice sweetness. The roulade was super tasty and had a nice sauce to round everything out. Being a stout drinker it was also good to see that they had Schwarzbier or "black beer". Lovers of German food will appreciate the subtle differences you'd find here from most other German establishments in the bay area. Definitely a great find.
author: Kim N.

description:
My friends live just around the corner in the ghetto and we randomly hopped into this cozy place last night. Service was a bit spotty but it was just I think two people serving 5-6 tables. 

On to the more important things:

FOOD
- I had the classic schnitzel with mashed potatoes and seasonal veggies (buttery carrots and peas) and LOVED IT. The seasoning is not complex, but the meat was well prepared and I thought it was good. Fattyness...but GOOD!
- My friend had the meatloaf special with mash and veggies and that was yummy too! I don't even like meatloaf but there's was tasty and had a good texture.
- Other friend had the jager schnitzel which I wasn't a big fan of because 1) I dont like heavy cream 2) I didn't like the mushy rice type that that was underneath. SO if you like cream etc you might like it! 

We also had the potato pancakes to start. YUM!

I tried the red beet soup, and it was a lot of beets - even for a hardcore beet lover. hahaha. It was hot though (I was scared it was gazpacho-esque) and I thought it tasted good. Not for everyone.

BEER
- Pear Cider. Yum
- My friend had diesel (beer and coke) and the other mixed drink with beer and sprite. They were interesting. But didn't taste especially delicious. 

Overall the place was cozy and fun. I thought the food was pretty good and decently priced. Would go again.
author: Liz T.

description:
What a dumb restaurant and bad service.

We were celebrating one of our friend''s birthday so we brought our own wines.
First the waitress brought us different size of wine glasses.and the she just left the corkscrew on the table and never offered to open  the wines.or poured our wines

The food was average and the coffee was very bad /weak. taste like a instant coffee.
the apple strudel taste like from the frozen box.

By the end when we were ready to pay and find out from our check , they charged us $10.00 for corkage fees/bottle..
 
Very disappointed and will never go back
author: Benny B.

description:
This place is tiny!

Come early, make reservations or expect to wait.  We were seated within 10 minutes because there was a reservation that no showed.  Our group ended up sharing a table with a senior couple.  Because of this, we were able to listen to an impromptu lecture on Jack Koeppler.  Our elderly dining companions really made our night and we enjoyed their stories, bantering, and history lessons.  Although I did politely decline the offer of their 37 yr old unemployed son.

Food was great.  Janelle and I had the jager schnitzel and I also tried the beef roulade.  Portions are pretty big but I managed to wipe my plate clean (of course).  Only minor gripe I have is that I feel their prices are slightly high.  For the type of food, ingredients, and preparation... I feel like most plates should have been a little less.  I'm not complaining though because it really was delicious.
author: Hoa T.

description:
Omg, I love this place.  The beer was excellent and strong, the food was tasty and not at all cloying, like German food can be.  

We had potato pancakes to start, which are not at all like latkes, more like mashed potatoes formed into a patty.  Yum delish with apple sauce and sour cream.  They have 3 veggie entrees to choose from.  I had the cabbage roulade, which was just perfect.  Savory and hearty but not at all greasy.  Great environment to drink and shoot the shit.  Yeah.  Avoid the back room if you can.

Just wished they gave us more water.  So german of them to serve beer in place of water.  

Also, check them out on restaurant.com for gift certificates on the cheap.
author: Teresa Z.

description:
Hands down my favorite German restaurant in the Bay Area, and I'm a huge Germanophile. When people think of German food, they're actually thinking of Bavarian food. Walzwerk is the rest of the nation. You can get Bavarian fare like schnitzel und so weiter, but for anything else, there's no place like Walzwerk. The food is awesome, the service is very German, which is to say, they're actually from Germany and they don't care to be your best friend, just straight efficient service. 

Tip: Do check out the bathroom. Die DDR lebt wieder... in 10m2! (That's German for check out all the East German stuff!)
author: Joe C.

description: Love this place - one of my go-to's in SF. Delicious food, great pricepoint; personal, friendly and entertaining staff/owner.
author: sarita g.

description:
My companion arrived at 6:30 on a Saturday night; I was running late making my way from Sacramento.  He was told that the wait would be fifty minutes.  It was perfect because I was struggling with traffic and it bought me some time.  By 7:40, the wait had turned into fifteen minutes.  I parked, met up and stood with my companion there in the restaurant for another forty five minutes.  

We were both starving by the time we were seated.  The food was hearty, but none if it really stood out for me.    Maybe it was just that I was still bitter about the wait.  When we were done, it took a while for the waitress to notice and bring the check.  As interested as I was in trying authentic German cuisine, I think I was over it before even being seated.
author: Carol Y.

description:
These are a few of my favorite (German) things:

Foot-tall Radeberger beer, spicy mustard and cold cut plate, cute waiters with accents, bratwurst with kraut, potato pancakes, the lamb rack special, red berry pudding, giant pictures of Marx. 

I love me some veggie-heavy Californian food, but when I feel an urge for meat and potatoes, Walzwerk is the place to be. (Nonetheless, there are tasty vegan options for the meatless.)
author: Monica S.

description: Best Jager Schnitzel I've ever had so far. Homey feeling when eating dinner.. Yunmy desserts!!!! I shall return to try other entrees
author: Dimples P.

description: This place is amazing! Best German food I have ever enjoyed! The herring is not to be missed and the sauerbraten is sooo delicious. Great job on the red cabbage too! Server was really competent and super pleasant.
author: Mary M.

description:
Let me preface this by saying I am picky about my German food.  Mostly because I am German. And my German grandmother can beat all your German grandmothers in a cooking contest any day of the week.  If you have a German grandmother.

Went to Leopold's and Walzwerk within a short period of time and both are good for different reasons, but Walzwerk is where I'll return first.  Here's why:

The food was tasty--options, even for people who don't eat pork, beef or meat in general (this is important to the girl I drag to German restaurants with me).

The staff is German, and though initially apprehensive that I speak German, engaged in a great conversation and came outside to say goodbye to me as I left.

The decor is unique and makes for a great experience.

The wait can be long, and the service not the greatest (this is probably because the restaurant is nearly always packed and there is one waitress).  If you have time to enjoy your food, this is where you should go.
author: Marvin P.

description: The food was Great!  The decor is like a hole in the wall cafe.  The service was almost non-existent and it was freezing in there.  They might not have a heater or they don't use it.   I had to give a 3 star.  5 Star for the food, 1 star for the service and 1 star for the freezing cold atmosphere.  I will go back because the food is good and maybe they were having a bad service day.
author: Darren W.

description:
They have a huge private room for a large party! This place gets busy so fast and I have to say the food is great.  Service was ok.  I think they have may been short staffed because the waitress wouldn't check on us too often.

Since it was such a large party, we had a fixed menu.  We had the schnitzel with mushroom gravy, stuffed chicken, bratwurst with sauerkraut, mashed potatoes, spatzle, roasted vegatables, potato pancakes, coleslaw, beet salad, and smoked salmon.  That was ALOT of food!  The germans sure know how to feed an army!  

But I love the decor of the restaurant.  Its very homely in the sense where all the dishes, utensils, tables, chairs, etc didnt match.

You will definitely leave here stuffed like you just came back from your mother's house and highly intoxicated from all the great beers!
author: Gina S.

description:
I love this place. The people are so nice, the food is great and the atmosphere is fun. I wish they had more beers on tap, but that's about my only complaint. 

I have been here multiple times, now, including with a very large group, for which we got the entire back room. Coming here with a small group is fun and intimate, and provides you with great food and beer. I have to say that coming here with a great big group was a lot of fun though.

That was really great. I booked about 2 weeks in advance and was told that the max number of people for that room is 18. For dinner, it's $25/pp without dessert, and $28/pp with dessert. For my 18 person party, I got to order 3 main dishes, and then it came out family style. They give you all the appetizers and then a mountain of the rest. The appetizers were potato cakes (sooo good), smoked salmon, herring salad (surprisingly good) and some cabbage salad. For the main dishes, we got the Beef Roulade, Bratwurst and the Veggie Schnitzel. With it came mashed potatoes, spaetzle (my fav) and sauerkraut. It was more food than we could possibly hope to eat, but we made a good dent in it, I think. The food was great, the service was happy and the entire party was a hit. 

Although there aren't too many beers on tap, the ones that are on tap are very good. I always get the Pils, and for $5, it's a good drink to have cradling in your soon-to-be-tired arm. 

If you like heavy foods with strong (good) smells and beer, this is definitely the place to go!
author: Mariko F.

description: We had the schnitzel and brussel sprouts salad. I wasn't a huge fan of the brussel sprouts as it lacked flavor and dressing. I did love their mash potatoes. Their schnitzel is pretty good but I wouldn't say it's the best. My bf loves them and asks me to give them 4 stars so hey why not ?
author: Jennie C.

description:
the food is fine but wow the service is painfully slow.  took 30 minutes from when we came in to have the waitress come take our order, and another 35 before we got our food.

seems like it was a busier than usual night for them, but I definitely won't be coming here again when actually hungry.
author: S. M.

description:
A very authentic German spot.

I was feeling the German love right when we got in. My friend and I were still waiting for the rest of our party to arrive, so our German waitress sat us down to order some drinks.

I ordered the Köstritzer Schwarzbier (dark lager beer). It's a thick beer with a full, chocolatey flavor. Zee Germans know how to make their beer. SO GOOD.

My friend wanted something light so she ordered the Diesel (half beer - half coke). I never thought to mix beer & coke but it tastes delicious! They mixed the coke with a light pilsner so you can still taste the sweet soda flavor but also experience the hoppy beer taste. It blends well. Again, SO GOOD.

We both had a long work day so those drinks hit the spot. I started feeling it. She started feeling it. The next time I come here, I'm ordering more beer.

Once our friends arrived, we got seated in a nice little area in the back. It was time to make our German food decision. We ordered an appetizer to share and our own dish to devour. 

| The Appetizer | 
Small Potato Pancakes with Chive Sour Cream and Applesauce
- Small serving but warm & deliciously light. The sour cream dip makes it a little heavier, but I really enjoyed the applesauce dip. Both dips come on the side.

| My Dish |
Grilled Thüringer Bratwurst served w/ Mashed Potatoes & Sauerkraut
- I thought the bratwursts would be bigger. However the brats were very tasty and rich with flavor. I'm a fan of tangy things, so I'm glad they put a good amount of sauerkraut. The mashed potatoes were the best part of the meal. I smeared them all over my brats & mixed them in with my sauerkraut to get that tangy-meaty-starchy flavor of food filling goodness.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Having grown up in Berlin and having just recently moved back (A friend of mine thought it would be funny to take me me to a German restaurant a day after i came back to SF) I have been to Suppenküche and wasn't thoroughly impressed, so I was keen to check out Walzwerk. Automatic Stars for having a pic of Erich Honecker, nothing like some DDR nostaligia! Beerwise, proper half liters like one would get in Germany, and the food was pretty good. I wish they had more Junge Pioniere (Seid bereit!) deco to really encapsulate the experience. Maybe they did, and i just did not notice cause of marathon drinking the night before and minor jetlag. Minus some points for not having fritz cola and for a northern (east) german style restaurant...Spätzle where's the Currywurst or Eisbein? These minor things can be overlooked because...Hey they have Rote Grütze and Bionade.


I ended up getting Spätzle ha.
author: Dennis G.

description:
I LOVE this place. I love the atmosphere, I love love love the food. It really does not get much better than this... The people that work there could be a little nicer but to be honest I go for the delicious meal. 
I always find a reason to come here. LOVE!
author: Corinne W.

description:
Ze Germans are coming!
Ze Germans are cooking!
Ze Germans are brewing!
Ze Germans are baking adorable chocolate deserts?

A friend recently planned a night of German eating for three of us with German last names*. Despite our somewhat common heritage, if you put us side-by-side, we couldn't look any more different. The joke would begin "a Jew, an Aryan and a Hapa all walk into a bar..." and it would end with "...and that's why they call it a hot brat!"

Anyway. I regress.

As we discussed our somewhat-overlapping ethnic backgrounds and somewhat-overlapping experiences in either Ohio, LA or Hawaii, we ordered a few beers and sampled the potato pancakes. Although not what I grew up on (and a great observation made by The Aryan who pointed out they weren't called latkes), they were still flavorful and slightly crisp (just how I like them). With apple sauce and sour cream on the side, it was almost like having my Bubbe's** cooking. 

I was about to order the bratwurst, but changed my mind at the last minute and ordered the meat special of the day: a pork and beef meatloaf. Having ordered something similar from Suppenküche, I wanted to be able to compare. While I think I liked the other one better (mostly because it was WRAPPED IN BACON), my stomach was quite pleased with the choice I made. It came with a huge helping of mashed potatoes and peas. 

Some people consider their comfort food to be mac n' cheese. Others would insist on pig's feet. Mine is meatloaf. Meaty, ketchupy meatloaf. And after leaving Walzwerk, I was quite comfy*** in my black hoodie as I walked home to my Biergarten and drank amongst the stars****.


________
*I'll give you a hint: mine is a color
**Bubbe = grandma (for all you gentiles)
***Nice way of saying "I could see your gut sticking out you fucking fat ass"
****I watched Hoarders and passed out in 10 minutes. Maybe 7.
author: Jared S.

description: The waitresses were very friendly and helpful and spoke German to us for fun.. Food was tasty and restaurant was clean but could use some more Bavarian decor.   A very nice evening!!!!
author: Trish H.

description:
I had the garlic pork with potatoes and vegetables.  It was very well prepared with a delicious gravy, tender pork, and hearty, soft potatoes.  It didn't "wow" me, but I think that's because this dish has it's natural limitations.  I give it a 3-star rating.

My friend had the schnitzel.  I tried a bit and it was amazing!  Maybe I'm a sucker for fried food, but his dish was definitely better than mine.  4 stars.  

The atmosphere and the service were great.  The staff was very friendly and attentive (but not overly so).  The ambiance was very traditional German (the bathroom even had old-style German products in the medicine cabinet - nice touch I thought), great lighting for the space, and we didn't have to wait for a spot on a Sunday night. 5 stars.  

And, of course, great beer!  I would definitely go again.
author: Bryce B.

description: Went to Walzwerk about two weeks ago and loved their food!!!  I went with my friend from Cologne, Germany.  She enjoyed their food as well.  The atmosphere is very utilitarian, but go for their food!  We had the potato pancakes and sausage, bread and cheese plate as appetizers.  For my entrée, I had their pork schnitzel with mashed potates [THE BEST I'VE EVER HAD] and I substituted the veggies with their cucumber salad.  All was delicious!!!  I want to go back again!!!!
author: Stephanie A.

description: I would really take this place over one of the other SF German restaurants, Suppenkuche or Schmidt's, anyday.  It's a lot quieter and much more intimate than those options, I don't have to sit with strangers at a family style table, and I really do feel like I get my money's worth here.  I'm happy with everything on the menu and my only qualms would be that they haven't taken reservations in the past (though the seem to now), they close a bit early for my taste, and the cheese spatlze isn't offered as a side dish (but I think that if I asked for it in place of the plain spatlze on the side that they'd accommodate).  Additionally the charm of the East German decorations can't be beat by those other restaurants, so this is my go to for German food in the city.
author: William C.

description:
yum yum yum yum yum! I honestly fantasize about going to this place. It's that good. Better food than that I had in Berlin, well, better than all but one restaurant I tired in Berlin. 

I have been here countless times. With a colourful array of friends, all of whom have left satiated in both their hearts and their bellies. 

There is always a wait and it is always worth it (and I really hate waiting in restaurants). The beer on tap is well chosen and nice and cool. Man I wish they had a beer garden. And the servers (yes they are often times killer busy and thus can't be the friendliest) really are fun sweethearts. 

I love this place and my heart pains a little knowing that some day, one day all things come to an end and I know that a piece of me will die alone with them. Alas! seeing as how great and popular they are I don't foresee that happening anytime soon.
author: Jason L.

description:
I've been to Walzwerk three times. I kept thinking it would get better...but it didn't. 

I love the decor, wooden benches, family style sitting and the kitsch music memorabilia in the bathroom. 

However, I feel the service is always slow and often cold. The food is good but should be about half the price. I feel like I'm paying for the ambiance which is ok, but surely there has to be a better German restaurant around.
author: Dianne N.

description: I've been going to this restaurant since I was a child and I have to say it's still as good as it was then. I really enjoy the stuffed chicken breast glazed with a cherry sauce, mashed potatoes or potato patties, and steamed vegetables. The ambiance is cool it's the industrial side of Germany so they have very authentic and cool decorations. The staff alone is awesome they are all very nice and really inviting. The owner is also a very nice lady. The chef Medardo is really nice even came out to the table to see if we enjoyed everything. I would recommend this place but be sure to try and reserve and leave your home on time and I would say take public transportation parking is definitely hard in this area but overall you'll enjoy the experience.
author: Ivette A.

description:
5 stars for delivering on what they promise: authentic and well-prepared East German food. Being from East Berlin, this place offers me a little piece of home.

(If you don't like it, your problem is really more about East German cuisine - fair enough - than about this place.)

+ Hilarious and over-the-top socialist deco
+ Warm and friendly service
+ Generous portions

-  Sloooooow service
author: Janett R.

description:
This place is a little over priced for what you get.

I went with the Grilled Thüringer Bratwurst. It comes with mashed potatoes, Sauerkraut, and mustard. The mustard was great!

The waitress was kind enough to let me substitute cooked veggies for the mashed potatoes.

It is a funny little space with teacher desks and little kitchen tables close together to sit at. The desk we ate at had a drawer, but nothing was in it. It was hot and muggy inside.
author: Antony H.

description:
This is a cute East German restaurant serving traditional homestyle comfort food, just a few blocks away from Poc Chuc. It only has 7 odd  shape tables in their front dining room (and 3 tables in their private room in the back). The tiny bar area consists of just 2 stools and a small loveseat. It fills up quickly, so making a reservation might be a smart idea. Plan ahead: make a reservation, or come in early (by 5:30pm) or dine later (8-9pm).

It's really warm indoors, so I'd advise to wear layered clothing if cold outside.

They give u a sample (one each) of the pumpernickel & wheat bread with salami & cheese topped with half a cherry tomato, as an amuse buche.

The potato pancakes appetizer ($6) are not to be missed. U get 3 small, thick and delicate hockey puck-like potato cakes with 2 sauces in tins: one with a homestyle apple sauce (love it!) and sour cream with chives in the other. Truly delicious! Yum-yum-yum!!

This week's specials included: a green beans and lamb soup, grilled salmon with a lemon caper sauce plus boiled potatoes and asparagus, stuffed pork loin with red cabbage and spatzle, homestyle apple pie w/whipped cream for dessert.

I ordered the salmon ($16.50). Perfectly grilled, rich and moist, with a rich, creamy and tangy (from lemon) caper sauce. The boiled potatoes were fully cooked, but with a firm texture (might be a German variety). The asparagus were just right.

I also like their Schnitzel ($15), better than Schroeder's version. They have a vegetarian "Schnitzel", but we've not tried that yet. In general, the food is rich and portions are generous, so expect to feel satisfied with fewer dishes. It's comfort food, don't expect a fancy plate presentation.

Beverages available include: Radeberger Pilsner (popular), Hefeweizen, Weltenburg Amber & Helles. Mixed drinks: Alsterwasser (half beer/ half 7up), Diesel (half beer/ half coke), Spezi (half coke/ half 7up). Juices, sodas and wines.

Located on South Van Ness avenue between 14th and 15th streets, so it's still within walking distance (3 blocks) of the 16th & Mission BART station.

My next stop: Schnitzelhaus, to compare which one is better.

Here are some helpful basic German phrases:

ja = yes
nein = no
bitte = please
danke = thanks or thank you
vielen dank = thank you very much
bitte = you're welcome
entschuldigung sie bitte = excuse me
wie geht es dir? = how are you?
mir geht es gut, danke = I'm fine, thanks
kostlich = delicious
guten abend = good evening
