guten nacht = good night
auf wiedersehen = good bye
sprechen sie Englisch = do you speak English?
wo befindet sich die Toilette, bitte = where is the toilet, please?
author: Luis C.

description:
Wanted to like it. Really did. But was told an hour wait. That hour wait turned into two hours, with the waitress constantly telling us "five minutes" so we wouldn't leave. The people in line ahead of us were on their desert by the time we got sat. Wanted to enjoy it after that...

The food was a bit bland, there was nothing to speak of  with my mashed potatoes or on my schnitzel, definitely not like anything I have had in Eastern Germany...very bland and greasy. 

Even better, since they sat us so late and wanted to close they started  BLASTING AC/DC to get everyone out of the restaurant, which by then I would have been happy to comply with if the waitress wouldn't have been sitting down having a nice chat with her friends at the next table....which meant that I felt completely forgotten. 

I'm sorry, but for almost $90 for a meal for two...this SUCKED.  I won't be back, and can't understand what all the hype is about.
author: Danielle L.

description:
First visit...

Authentic German food..great selection.  Be prepared to wait
if you go on a weekend unless you have a party of four or more
and then you can make reservations.

Go for the food (after all, isn't that what this is all about?)...not
for the ambiance.  The place certainly has old world flavor and
cuisine with authentic knickknacks and decorations but it is on 
the small side and rather noisy.

Great waitstaff.  Taking in account how busy they were, they did
a great job.  Plan on making this the highlight of your evening instead
of just a dinner before a movie or a show.  I started with a bowl of
the nightly soup special, a butter squash cream.  Very large bowl..
hot and tasty.  I had the potato pancakes with sour cream as an
appetizer...very good.  The entree was Sauerbraten (Marinated Beef) with Potato Dumplings and Braised Red Cabbage.  I appreciated that
the different courses were served in a timely manner and not all
stacked up together.

Bottom line.. I will return!!
author: Dale N.

description:
My roommate said: You know, Walzwek is Eastern German?

Me: What does that mean?

Him: It's about 85% less fun than Suppenkuche in its Bavarian style.

Hmmm. I was having second thoughts about choosing Walzwek for a big, fun group dinner (Suppenkuche was booked, and we had a hankering for German). But I went ahead with it anyway...

It's true, Walzwek is quieter, more austere and less boisterous than Suppenkuche. The art/posters on the walls definitely gives a sense of a kitschy East German influence, but it's certainly not devoid of personality. The food is GREAT. I had the jagershnitzel, and everyone at the table had entree envy. Pork loin covered in a creamy, gravy-like mushroom sauce. Pure heaven. And with spaetzle - yum! As appetizer, we had the potato pancakes which are more appropriately named mashed potato pancakes - also incredibly yummy.

The food and beer came out quickly. The restaurant is relatively small - just one small front room and one small back room. We were a boisterous group of 8, and I think people with us in the back room may have been annoyed by us. 

Great food, but it's probably not a good place for a loud big group.
author: Wendy L.

description: This is kind of my favorite restaurant in the Bay. Funny, huh, a German place! The food is great, the beer is great, but it's the atmosphere that's the best feature. It's cozy, not too loud, with awesome Commie decor (Marx and Engels giant beards stoke the appetite? - plus check out the back room), and the staff is killer. The owner is a firecracker with a cool sense of humor. Vibe-y!
author: Dan N.

description:
Since my two good friends are male and on the never ending search/explore run of finding neat eats in the city when I visit, I was somewhat fraught with trepidation, only because the menu seemed a bit stark, blunt, and plain, and delivered with typical Eastern European charm:

Soups
Appetizers
Entrees
Desserts

Even more charming, was the waitress, who was swooping around carrying two pints of beer in each hand, without a smile on her face.  Although, the larger body figures made my big Asian butt feel right at home.

Since this was my first time, I decided to go the traditional route.  We bypassed the appetizers because they seemed a bit of a distraction (Matjes Herring in Sour Cream) or Cabbage Soup (Um, I don't think so,  I've tried that diet before) so I ordered the Schnitzel with their house mashed potatoes and brussel sprouts ($14.00).

What I received, was this huge platter consisting of the schnitzel (looked like chicken fried steak to me.....) lying on a thick huge bed of mashed potatoes and flanked by a bunch of large steamed brussel sprouts.  The menu does not lie, I got exactly what I ordered.

The Schnitzel, was surprisingly good, a bit thin, but juicy on the inside, with a crunch outer layer.  The brussel sprouts reminded me of eating miniature little cabbages, but I could only consume so much of the future sulfuric consequences.  I could only eat 1/3 of my plate, it was too much food. Forget about the hefeweizen, I handled about 1/8 of it before my friend finished it off for me. 

We bypassed dessert, since I felt like I had just consumed a gut bomb......I would be able to retreat in hibernation, and emerge hungry a month later.

Service is prompt, but rather lacking in creating a friendly ambiance, but we were not expecting that anyways (friends have been to Germany, so they've warned me beforehand) and the food was thick, heavy, robust, and uninventive.  But I'm not disappointed. That base layering was exactly what I needed before we headed into the Mission to hit the crawl scene.

Prices here are average, not expensive for city standards: $5-7 for appetizers, dinner entrees from $11-15, and dessert at $5 each.
author: Miika M.

description: Food excellent.  good selection of German favorites (Bratwurst, schnitzel).  Service good and prices reasonable.  Decor interesting with alot of East German signs and paintings.  Good experience.  I will be back
author: Michael G.

description:
Thanks to Trubates, I was able to try this place out with $20 off, which helps because this place is pretty pricey.  

Took my roommate here for our quality "beefers time" and the whole time, she kept saying we were going back to our roots (both of us went to high school in American schools in Germany).  Personally I didn't start expanding my palette until recently so when I lived in Germany, I can count on one hand the number of times I had a schntizel or any other authentic German food. I was the kind of person who was excited when we finally found a McDonalds. But that's besides the point.

First overall impression: this place is SMALL. Went there early on a Thursday evening at 6PM so we didn't have to wait at all but I can see this place getting packed really quickly on the weekends.

The atmosphere is quaint and very...East German-like for lack of a better adjective. It made the whole experience very authentic so I didn't mind.  It was pretty quiet in there and every time I laughed, I felt everyone's eyes on me.

The food.  OMG the food.  It was AWESOME.  So awesome that I want to go back in time and slap my 16-year-old self for never taking advantage of the German food that was right in front of me for years.  We had the following:

Beer: Roomie had the Radeberger Pilsner and I had the Franziskaner Hefeweizen. My hef was hoppier than regular hef but it was good and tasty.  

Potato pancakes: it was like a hashbrown on steroids but sooo good.  Didn't really like it with the apple sauce since it was cold but I did like it by itself.  I't was crispy on the outside and super hot and fluffy on the inside.  

Schnitzel (Breaded Porkloin) with Mashed Potatoes & Seasonal Vegetables: This was my entree and it was very good.  Squeezed the whole lemon wedge on it for that extra zing and it enhanced the taste tremendously.

Jäger Schnitzel (Porkloin) with Spätzle and Creamy Mushrooom Sauce: This was my roomie's entree.  Good thing I waited until I was halfway through my own schnitzel before having a bite of her's. The creamy mushroom sauce was PERFECT with the pork.  It was sooooo good.  We ended up trading halfway through our entrees because I loved the sauce so much and she could swish the breaded porkloin with the sauce that came with the spatzle.

How I know that the food was GREAT: I ate it all (with some mashed potatoes left over) and I didn't notice that we didn't get water because I didn't need it to wash anything down.

Even if its a bit more expensive than what I personally prefer, I would come back here if the occasion fit.  Or if I find another deal online.   Ended up paying a total of $40 out of pocket.  THANK YOU TRUBATES FOR THE $20 FOR $40 WORTH OF FOOD/DRINKS DEAL :)

Random other notes: street parking isn't bad on that side of the Mission. And they only take reservations for parties more than 4.
author: Alyssa S.

description:
WALZWERK
This very authentic German restaurant is located on South Van Ness in San Francisco, and does a great job of conjuring images of East Germany through its decor of numerous East German icons, dark interior, and stein upon stein of beer on every table. The serving staff was very friendly and made our visit here quite pleasant. While we waited for our table, we looked at East German cookbooks to see what cuisines were popular back at the Fatherland.

Small Potato Pancakes with Chive Sour Cream and Applesauce: B+ (thick and fluffy, but a bit bland).

Breast of Chicken stuffed with Apples & Bacon (with Sundried Cherry Sauce), Mashed Potatoes, and Seasonal Vegetables: A (tasty chicken with the sweetness of the berries and sauce were a delight!)

Beef Roulade (Tri-Tip Stuffed with Bacon, Pickles, Mustard & Onions) with Spätzle and Red Cabbage: B (a bit dry, but when eaten with all the stuffings, it's quite flavorful. The Spatzle (pasta) was excellent and the red cabbage lent a healthy side to the otherwise meaty dish)

Because of the long wait, we got some breaded appetizer and red berry pudding dessert on house! Now, that's some German hospitality! All in all, Walzwerk is an excellent place to come to if you're looking to dry some German cuisine; many entrees and German beers to fill your pallete. Once you enter Walzwerk, you truly are "Leaving the American Sector" as the sign says outside the restaurant door. You will walk away with your belly stuffed! Highly recommended!
author: Stanley C.

description:
Just walked in with a couple of friends. It has a very German atmosphere (big sturdy tables, flimsy chairs, small interior), and the hostess/waiter both speak German.

Food was great -- we had a matjes herring appetizer, and it was fantastic. Sour but very tasty, great to start off the meal. I had the sauerbraten as the main course -- the sauce is a bit too sour for me, but I loved the red cabbage. I kinda regretted my choice when I saw the mister's jägerschnitzel! It was lathered in a rich mushroom cream sauce and he really liked it.

Gooseberry cake is the dessert. The gooseberries, meh, a bit funky, but personally I don't like them very much to begin with. The cake more than made up for it. It's not too sweet, just hit the right spot, like how European sweets are supposed to be, and it's served with a *non-sweetened* whipped cream! Nice! If you have the American kind of sweet tooth (i.e. you like loads of sugar), the desserts here might not be for you.

Of course, they have German beer there, and they serve it by the half litre like they do in Europe :)

This is definitely a gem in a otherwise sketchy neighbourhood.
author: Alice C.

description: I love mushrooms I Love speckle is that what you call it little dough pasta.  I got the Jagger schnitzel and it was yum yum yum. We started with the potato pancakes and I was expecting crispy round thin yummyness.  Nope! It was I'm guessing left over mashed potatoes shaped into pancakes them pan fried on each side..meh nothing exciting. It was a cute cozy place. I might go back and try the cabbage rolls.
author: Karen T.

description:
My boyfriend and I arrived when the doors opened at 5:30 on a Saturday night and were promptly seated.  However, by the time we left around 6:30 or so, the small lounge area near the bar was packed with people waiting to be seated.  Reservations are a good idea, but getting there early is an even better one.

The service was incredibly friendly and attentive and the food was plentiful and piping hot. Even when the restaurant got busier, people still seemed to be receiving prompt service.  Also, I'd written "Thank you for a wonderful birthday dinner!" on top of our receipt and our waiter even dashed outside as we were leaving to wish me a happy birthday!

Our dinner cost just under $60, but that included a huge bowl of soup (plenty for two people), 4 pints of Hefeweizen, 2 entrées, and a 20% tip.  We left full, content, and with plans to return. 

Walzwerk is just two blocks away from the 16th/Mission BART station and at least two MUNI stops (49 & 14). Photos of our visit, including our meals (Jäger Schnitzel and Schnitzel), can be seen in the photos section.
author: Katrina J.

description:
I didn't know that a restaurant with an East German motif could serve such tasty food. My friend and I went there (he was originally from Hamburg) and I was expecting to be fed heaping portions of glutonous-pork/potato-based hauptgang and washed down with some Dresden Radeberger Pilsner. My expectations were correct, but it was flavorful-- but bring a sleeping bag to have a nap in after such a big meal. 

I started with the small tasty potato pancakes because I was hungry. Wrong move with the Raderberger, because now I'm starting to get filled. After more Pilsners and I decided to stay with generic-German food by ordering Sauerbraten with potato dumplings and braised red cabbage. If you're a vegan, go home. This marinated beef was spicier than what I expected from Erich Hanocker's Deutsche Demokratische Republik, or GDR or East Germany. Potato dumpling and red cabbage squirted their juices well (with flavorful combination) in my mouth. I'm not versed enough to compare tasty squirts of this Sauerbraten against say, the Rhineland or Swabbian versions, but who cares? Hefeweizen bitte!! 

Oh yeah, did I mention GDR? Yes, the place does look like a stoic cafeteria fit for your finest people's machinists. I have to admit that after a few rounds of Hefeweizen, Wallenburg and more Radeberger, the wall portraits of Marx, Engles and other protectors of workers' paradise started to talk to this capitalist. I'm not sure I saw Lenin's portrait (he was my favorite Beatle, or is that Lenon?), but the food and beer will compel me to come back.
author: Reyz A.

description:
It has kind of a sterile decor, but the servers were warm and friendly.  I had expected a wait, which is why I sent Tintin and his friend there first, while I was at a work function.  Unfortunately for me, there were plenty of tables and they just had to wait an hour for me.  

The servers were nice enough to liquor them up with some Fernet, which is one of the few alcoholic things Tintin likes.  I got a salmon and spaetzle dish that was enormous.  I could not eat much at the time, after a couple of big beers, but it was delicious the next day. Tintin's stuffed chicken was also great, and I am not a fan of things stuffed into meats.  Next time I will be getting the schnitzel.  

Good selection of beers, great service and hearty comfort food will probably bring me back this fall.
author: Seong P.

description:
Dear Suppenkuche,

Please forgive me. I have been seeing another German restaurant. It only happened once. I enjoyed the herring and sour cream immensely, I'm sorry to say, but the jagerschnitzel can't compare to yours, my dear. You are my favorite of all time, but I might need to step back and see Walzwerk every now and again. 

I hope you'll understand. 

XOXO,

Eliza
author: Eli B.

description:
The food was really good but the service was terrible. There was one frazzled waitress for the entire restaurant. She was doing the best she could under the circumstances but she literally looked like she was going out of her mind and I just felt sorry for her. If they added one more gal, the place would have been running like a well-oiled machine.

Nevertheless, she took to time to answer all of our inane questions about which beers and dishes she liked best. We ordered two huge, creamy Franziskaner hefs (my current favorite beer) and a meat and cheese plate to start off, which was super good and hearty. The rye bread, cold cuts and cheese I loved. Then we shared a giant plate of the chicken breast stuffed with apples and bacon, sundried cherry sauce, mashed potatoes and veggies. The chicken was luscious and not overpowered by the bacon. The apples and sundried cherries added the perfect combination of tartness and sweetness, while the mashed potatoes, absorbing all the chicken and cherry juices made a nice bed for the rest of the food and beer in my belly. 

We walked all the way back to my house on 30th and Mission to digest but couldn't help but feel like all that comfort food kept me warm on the way home. Note: part of the bathroom wall was decorated with old German record sleeves from the 60s, which I loved!
author: Laura M.

description:
SHANDY!  What an awesome thing for non beery-beer lovers!  The 2 options here are dark beer mixed with coke and light beer mixed with sprite; both of which are amazing!

I'm probably not the best judge of German food, as my experience now has expanded to a whopping 4-5 restaurants ever, but the food was really tasty and the servers were extremely friendly.  Per recommendation, I went with the bacon stuffed beef and the lovely gf went with the jager shnitzel (pork loin in a mushroom sauce).  We ended up switching plates since hers appealed to my palate a lot more.  Overall, both plates were delicious and hearty, but I guess nothing that completely blew me away.  For dessert, we had the apple strudel with ice cream.  Honestly, I could have gone without the nuts in the strudel and the crust could have been flakier/tastier.  

All in all, it was a delightful meal in a very random area (and old school decor).  Given that the staff were all German (sounding at least), it seems pretty authentic.  Definitely will have to try Leopold's to compare now that I've set the German standard in the city.
author: Jeff N.

description:
I love schnitzel, and I love it even more after washing it down with a really good Franziskaner.  Well, maybe that's really what my boyfriend did but I wish I had been that bold!  My favorite part about this place was definitely the decor, which included images and icons from communist East Germany.  Totally cool!

Walzwerk is one of those totally unpretentious cool places where you can throw back some good beer and eat some good grub with all of your friends.  Refreshingly unpretentious, Walzwerk represents a unique and authentic East German food (think meat and potatoes) experience with a laid back atmosphere, where you feel like you should know everyone in the building, and their mother.  And, from the look of it, there are definitely some regulars there who are on a first name basis with the German blond who waited on us.

Dinner is served family style or with individual meal options at formica or wood tables reminiscent of your local cafeteria 20 years ago.   We opted to sit at the cozy little bar since there were no tables available, and got some great German wine recommendations and a little German language lesson from our super sweet  waitress!  

We tried the Small Potato Pancakes with Chive Sour Cream and Applesauce to start, which were served hot and crispy.  The b/f ordered the Matjes Herring in Sour Cream with Apples, Onions and Pickles as well, which I could only handle a few bites of as it was pretty strong.  
And, I'd definitely go back just for the Chicken stuffed with Apples & Bacon with Sundried Cherry Sauce!
author: Jacquie L.

description:
You have to know that there is no boot here.  It's like high class German digs - the biggest mug they have is a 0.5L.

Even though I was disappointed there was no boot, it was a fantastic restaurant.  And no it's not "high class" but it's miles from the screaming, dark, chaos of some of the other German holes in the walls around here. There's no drunk idiots dancing on the tables spilling beer out of a boot here and no beer wenches carrying 10 steins prancing around.

Food was great - the potato cakes were great.  Order early so you can enjoy them with the cold beer!  I had some of the shortribs and beef roulade.  Both were fantastic.  The shortribs were a little fatty, but the sauce was to die for.  The roulade was good meat, but the sauce was a little skimpy. The spatzle was better than most I've had - but it was a little on the well-done side, so if you like yours all powdery and mushy then this wasn't it.  There was even a little crisp to some of them, like they fried it up to finish it.  And of course, I love the purple cabbage thing.

Our server said she doesn't recommend the schnitzel anymore so I don't know how it is, but one of my friends had the veg schnitzel and said it was really good.

The restaurant is small and crowded so the wait might be long, and there's not much else to do right around there.  Service ranged from rude and rushed to really polite and humorous. Guess that's what happens when it's so crowded.

It was too clean for me to think I was actually at a German dive, but that's not always a bad thing.
author: Traci H.

description:
Picture this.  Saturday night, 8pm, I'm storming out of a restaurant with 10 friends in tow, expecting, insanely, to find another place in this crowded city for a huge party.  With awesome food and drinks, of course.

And would you believe that place was Walzwerk?

Despite being packed, they took all ten of us, gave us a private room to boot, and made our haphazard night led by this horrible grumpster a fabulous time.  

I've never had German food before, but after this, I definitely will again.
author: The Grumpster J.

description: I went here with friends when visiting SF and really enjoyed it. It is a small eatery and pretty plainly decorated (but it is in East German theme so fitting). I had the Sauerbraten (Marinated Beef) with Potato Dumplings and Braised Red Cabbage. It was delicious. All of us were happy with our food selections. I had a hefe here to drink and it was the best hefe I have ever drunk! So tasty! They also had interesting drinks, part soda and part beer. We were not trying to be that authentic lol. It was a little pricy but worth it, I am glad we went!
author: Brigid P.

description: The best mashed potatoes I've ever had. It's black magic how they got all that butter and cream in those taters. Was very happy with the schnitzel.
author: Heather R.

description:
I was introduced to this place when a friend of mine had his birthday dinner here.  Eighteen of us piled into the backroom for a family style dinner that sampled basically everything on the menu.  

Appetizers were potato pancakes with apple sauce and sour cream, and they were just like grandma used to make: crispy on the outside and warm and squishy on the inside.  The cabbage salad was, well, cabbage salad.  And the plate of bread, cheese and sliced meat was pretty good.

The Schnitzel was thin with a really tasty mushroom cream sauce.  The mashed potatos were lump-free and properly spiced.  My favorite was the apple and bacon-stuffed chicken breast which had a sweet and creamy cherry sauce on top.  

And the thing that made me really happy?  The "Cold Dog" dessert.  Do not skip this.  It's a nice portion size (not too big) and worth every penny.

The beer selection was pretty good too.  :)

And the waitresses kindly put up with our drunken revelry and kept us well feed and watered throughout the night.  Would highly recommend this place for any occasion.
author: Jorf D.

description:
I came here twice, both times with a party of three, both times with a $50 gift certificate (thanks, Restaurant.com!).  As expected, each time we came out fuller than we ought to have been.

Personally, I enjoyed the appetizers more than the main courses.  I really liked the pickled herring, which, by the way, I had no idea was a thing.  It tasted...kind of exactly how I expect pickled fish to taste.  I also loved the tomato-cabbage soup...perfectly sour and yes, appetizing.  The potato pancakes were good, but nothing special.

I had the sauerbraten (marinated beef) with potato dumplings and braised red cabbage, which was pretty good, if not spectacular.  A friend had the beef roulade (tri-tip stuffed with bacon, pickles, mustard & onions), which sounded like a meal and half (and it was).  It was like a baby turducken - layers upon layers of meat attack until you surrender and/or pack it up to resume the battle later.  The schnitzel (breaded porkloin) tasted kind of like Japanese tonkatsu - take that how you will.

Both times I've come to this place, it's been really full.  They have a tiny waiting area, and it can get a little cramped in there.  However, this is nothing a few good German beers on tap cannot cure.

Three stars because when it comes down to it, I don't think I would return if I don't have a gift certificate for this place.  It's good, but not amazing.
author: jon y.

description:
This is a great authentic German restaurant.

We've been here a few times and the food is delicious. I find many dishes, that you would usually only find in Germany itself. I was very surprised to also find 'Kalter Hund' which is a dessert and definitely worth a try.

The staff is super friendly too. Just make sure to come early or get reservations. Not surprising - it usually gets busy :)
author: Isa T.

description:
Awesome little place! Stepping into this restaurant is like walking across the threshold into Germany! The atmosphere was very inviting and the servers made sure we felt comfortable throughout! 

We enjoyed the Sauerbraten (beef) with potato dumplings and red cabbage. And Schnitzel (breaded fried pork) with potatoes & steamed vegetables. Both were GOOD HEARTY COUNTRY STYLE MEALS.

The Sauerbraten ($18) is as the word suggests = sour. Hence, very appetizing. The potato dumplings are unique! Its not the texture of a whole-boiled potato. But rather, a little more chewy and flavorful. I believe there was bread incorporated in there. 

The Schnitzel ($16) was good. I liked that it was not too dry as meat tend to be, when fried. It was nicely moist and tender. Cold German beer ($6) to wash all the GOOD STUFF down! Excellent!

Finally, we shared a nice little dessert- Red Berry Pudding ($6) which is FANTASTIC. Soft, creamy texture of berries enveloping your taste buds and you would wish this meal never ends.  

A fantastic experience if you would like to dine in charming Germany, minus the crazy-airfare.
author: Pancakes D.

description:
The host was nice and helped us picked a German wine to accompany our dinner. It was interesting we went ahead and a few that many reviewers ordered to share. 

It's a very small restaurant about 10-15 tables with mix match chairs and tables for all seating....once you enter the restaurant the doorway was covered with the thick plastic curtains similar to the one you'll walk into a large freezing room where pigs are hung to keep cold. It was creative I thought.
author: Linh D.

description:
The tomato soup was good but I obviously ordered the wrong entree- the
garlic roast pork.
It consisted of raw garlic inserted into folds in the meat, the flavor of which did not transmit, a very thin tasteless gravy and rock hard new potatoes and brussel sprouts. The service was rather haphazard and we were near the door, where the chilly SF wind breezed in when people came in. At one point one of the waitresses actually  propped the door open to my horror.
author: Josephine G.

description:
Finding beauty in the stark...

I had a significant birthday this year, and guess where I asked Mom and Dad to take me for my celebratory dinner?

Good guess.

Great beer, great food, great wait staff (be warned though -- they don't humor you and at first you think they might kick your ass but it's all German love).
author: Zin M.

description:
I lived in eastern Germany for a year as an exchange student and coming here was like falling back into the robust, flour covered arms of my baker Gastmutter (host mother). Everything from the small flower vases to the plastic butter dishes and even the bathroom soap dispenser (Florena!) was so authentic and real I thought I would cry. To me it was clear that every single item of Walzwerk's interior decoration had been consciously and lovingly placed to replicate eastern Germany's ongoing reminiscence of those pre-unification days of the DDR, and to proudly display the region's renowned honest and no-nonsense work ethic.

And the food! Everything was just as delicious, hearty and filling as I remembered. My host mother's clucking and second (and often fourth) servings of her wunderbar old fashioned home cooked meals made me gain upwards of 10 pounds in my first month in Saxony alone (ach du Scheisse!), and by the way I was salivating over Walzwerk's simple menu I thought it might be possible to beat that record in one night.

I went to Walzwerk with my family, who is not well versed in the cuisine of this area and consequently found some of the listed dishes a bit odd. Kloesse (boiled dumplings made of shredded potatoes), for example, are a favorite of mine because they bring back memories of my Erzgebergische Weihnachten (traditional Erzgeberg Christmas). This may taste bland to those not accustomed to it. Other foods, like the Schweinebraten and the thueringer Wurst, were a hit. As for drinks, don't limit yourself to the usual German beer: try the Diesel (beer mixed with cola) and Apfelschorle (apple juice with mineral water), which are good enough to have come straight out of a Biergarten in Dresden.

Eating here is as authentic as it gets. Don't pass it up!

P.S. For any of you who are interested, Walzwerk is pronounced VAL-TSVERK.
author: Kalyani Y.

description:
Great alternative to suppenkuche if you want awesome German without the wait and commotion, its even walking distance if you need a back up (thats how i was introduced to it).

the food is delicious and they have good beer, its a very simple and fills you up if you are craving German food.
author: Barbara C.

description:
This place is absolutely amazing! For one it's owned and manged by a woman from East Germany (where I was born and raised) and second of all she has a lot of popular  and traditional East German dishes on the  menu which made me feel like back hom again. 

Cons - Place is very small and gets packed quick so be prepared to wait a while but I promise it's worth it.

Pros - Awesome food, great beers, good ambience (not too noise and not too quiet), good price, and overall very German experience.
author: Heidi K.

description:
Why is it so cozy in Walzwerk? 
Why have I never had a beer and coke before?
Why does it take forever to get a seat?
Why are these tables and chairs so rustic and quaint?
Why is this beef so sour?
Why is the pork schnitzel so good?
Why do I feel like this server is my German mother?
Why is this bill so ridiculously expensive?
author: Aron L.

description:
They probably don't need a positive review from me because I got there just at opening and by the time I left the place was completely full.

Nevertheless, I am solidly on the side of those who like it.  My meal of pork schnitzel with mashed yellow potatoes (Yukon golds?) and Brussels sprouts, preceded by  soup and followed by apple strudel reminded me of something my grandma might have served me if I had a grandma who was a darned good German cook.  

The soup, whose spelling I forget, was very good.  It was a vinegary, meaty broth containing chunks of sausage and bits of kraut with a dollop of sour cream and accompanied by some excellent brown bread with nuts.

Somebody here said the schnitzel was dry--indeed it is if by dry you mean amazingly free of grease in spite of being obviously pan  fried (as it should be) rather than deep fried.  The piece of meat itself was tender and utterly free of fat and/or gristle.  The potatoes were quite tasty and clearly hand mashed (because of the occasional unmashed chunks in them)--maybe a hint of garlic?  And the Brussels sprouts blew me away--I like 'em but I realize the average American probably doesn't and I don't think I've ever been served them in a restaurant before.

Even the vanilla ice cream that came with the strudel may have been house made.

I accompanied all this with a draft Spaten Amber which was something of a random choice that turned out, by luck, to have been wonderfully fortuitous.

The atmosphere is appropriate for the theme--kind of east block workers' haven kind of thing with salvaged tables and unmatched china and utensils.  Maybe they chose the theme so they could get away with that--I  don't know.  But it worked for me.  I went for the food, not the atmosphere, and wasn't disappointed.  But I knocked one star off because some people might be (and because it's hard to be perfect).
author: B. T.

description:
I enjoyed the Sauerbrauten; this hearty dish  was flavorful,  filling and tastey. They filled half of my plate with deelicious cooked red cabbage. Also, it came with two humongous potato balls about 3 inches round; they appear to be made of finely shredded potatoes somehow formed into a 3 inch ball, then deep fried in oil.  Interesting way to serve potatoes. Taste: eh, ok. Next time I'll try  the mashed potatoes. 

  My friend had the bratwurst and said it was good : only one bratwurst is served. If you are a big eater, you might ask for two. It also came with mashed potatos. The quality of the food is 4 stars, however, the cheap tables are too faux E. Germany.
Dinner for two was $38 , it's kinda spendy for what you get. 

  Decor: low rent, blah;  cool minimalist music, low key place; not rowdy like the other German/Austrian place on 9th/Folsom.

 Location: sketchy during the day. Night time: Ladies have your friends drop you off at the door.
  If you drive a fancy car, you will worry. They sat us down to a dirty table; however , the waiter came by in a minute and looked upset it was not cleaned.
Customer service: crummy.
author: Bert K.

description: The food was really nice. I also love the ambience with the candles...I could defninely go back to eat here, nice German food.
author: Ali E.

description:
The breast of chicken stuffed with apples and bacon with sundried cherry sauce was AMAZING. Even leftover the next day (the portions are huge).

All my companions were very happy with their meals (many had the jagerschnitzel) and we left sated and impressed. I want to go back, but maybe it's not such a bad thing that it's far away... my arteries thank me!

Also, we used a restaurants.com coupon and had no hassles with it. Parking is also not difficult, thankfully.
author: Emily M.

description:
I'll never forget coming here when I was pregnant with #1.  The waiter asked when I was due, and when I told him I was due right then and there (it was true!), his jaw nearly dropped to the floor, and he skittered about nervously the rest of the night.  That'll teach him!  =)

That random encounter aside, I do appreciate the great decor and food here.  Who wouldn't appreciate chowing down surrounded by old East German shampoo bottles, cans of Penaten, and random canned food containers?  Great, dark breads, crunchy slaws, and yummy schnitzel fill the menu.  Cozy atmosphere, too.  A great experience all around.
author: Lisa W.

description:
I first saw this restaurant on 'Bay Area Check Please'  (public TV)- which by the way is a fantastic resource  for finding new places to eat. Secret wish: make it 'SF Check Please'...city dwellers rarely find little use for an inexpensive Indian take out place in Walnut Creek - anyway...

Anyway...Walzwerk - it's hearty! It reminds me of nights eating at home when I was a kid. No frills and you won't walk hungry. The food is good (note the term: good). I guess what I would describe (since I am no expert) as typical middle class German! I had the Chicken Breast stuffed with Apples and Bacon with mashed potatoes. I was told this is one of their best dishes. It was good, but after it arrived (and my first few tastes...maybe it needed a dash of salt or pepper) I was secretly looking over at the schnitzel. Of course, I tasted that as well....which was fine as well. Hope you can sense my ambivalence... 

For me, I would come back, but you are going to see me visiting their sister restaurant, Schmidt's more often...its at 20th and Folsom (little nicer part of town) and a little more upscale...which is perfect for a snob like me - and I have always had a great time there.
author: Jason P.

description:
I'm a big fan of knockin' back boots of beer at Suppenkuche, but if you're looking for a quieter, more intimate authentic German restaurant, Walzwerk is wunderbar!

From the staff to customers, you might wonder if you stumbled across a portal to Germany on South Van Ness. Beer, potato pancakes, sausage, shnitzel, gravy... prepare to pass out on the couch when you get home.
author: Stephanie P.

description:
I had a good experience here. I have eaten at all the German restaurants in the city and I would rank this pretty high.

I had the herring appetizer. I find that actual germans/austrians don't like this - but I love it. I buy from the grocery store to eat at  home... although I am neither german nor austrian.

For the entree I had the Sauerbraten and tried the Roulade - both were tasty and the dumplings were different than I have had before. Potato vs bread based. The spetzle served with the Roulade was fantastic.

One thing to note - the place is not big and they will only seat your party at the appropriately sized table. That is if you are a party of two - don't expect to be seated even if you see a big table free - because it is meant for a party of 4... saw this happen to a couple of people, but they did not seem to mind.
author: Angelito R.

description:
It is really, really German in here.

From the decor to the menu, to the staff: all Germany, all the time. That said, I do like German food (it's beer and schnitzel, come on!), so this was a good choice for dinner.

To drink, I had BIER (Radeberger pilsner). When I wasn't having beer, we split a bottle or two of a red wine called blaufränkisch, which I only very (very) recently discovered. And then I had more Radeberger.

To eat, I went with schnitzel (a breaded porkloin) with nice mashed potatoes and plenty of veggies. It was really, really good, but I dig these kinds of meals. You're not overwhelmed with too many choices (from the menu to the drinks), but I liked that about the place, too.

On the expensive side, but that might have been due to the drinks. $40 a pop, I think it was. Not for every day, and definitely not for every meal-mood, but damn good.
author: Tara R.

description:
Expensive and the food is mediocre (and I'm not saying that just because it is German).  People on here say it tastes homemade, but that's just because you could easily make their food at home.    

The staff (and owners, I think) are unnecessarily rude.  I understand that it's part of their gimmick that they are an East German restaurant and German service usually sucks.  I've worked as a server many years and while I'm usually lenient, these people sucked a lot.  They push you to order quickly and to not ask questions because they want to turn your table over.  In general they seem extremely put out by your presence.    

They were embarrassing another table of people who were simply enjoying themselves and laughing.  But if you want your restaurant to not be oppressively loud then maybe you shouldn't have concrete floors (in the back).  

Will not be back.  Better food elsewhere with less aggravation.
author: John M.

description:
It's nice for once to eat somewhere that's not either:
1) California fusion
2) Small plates
3) Asian

Not that I don't like either of those three, but it can get a little "par for the course" after a while. The garic pork loin was excellent, and my brother's goose, which I sampled, was pretty good too. and the beer was of course great. I'd recommend trying to get a reservation if you can, because it's not a very large place. Cozy, though, and the decor is interesting. Will have to come back for der schnitzel.
author: Tom H.

description:
I lived in Germany for several years so I'd like to consider myself and expert on German food...not difficult really, German food is pretty straight forward.  But this places does it well.   

I had the schnitzel with spaetzle and my friend had the Jaegerschnitzel and both were very good.  Hot and crispy but not at all greasy and the spaetzle was perfect.  We ordered the kalter hund for desert to go.  It looked really yummy but I never got the chance to taste it as I left it at my friends house.  

Some people mentioned a problem with the staff, they were courteous and attentive to us but I could see a little tension behind the scenes.  

Regardless, it didn't effect our service or food so we'll be back.
author: Dave O.

description:
Walzwerk is a little piece of Thuringia in the Mission.

Other reviews just don't get it. It's Ostologie at its best!  It's like walking through the Flohmarkt at Boxhagener Strasse on Sunday while peddling your roommate's really awful Erick Hoenecker posters he's too lazy to sell himself to make the rent.

That being said -- the only better food of it's kind I can think of that I'm familiar with is at the corner of Dunckerstrasse and Stargarder Strasse in Prenzlauer Berg in Berlin.  I had many happy meals at the Thüringer Eck and Walzwerk reminds me of good days of yore.

P.S. - If you don't get it you obviously have never lived in the wonderland that was Berlin in the last decade.  It's East German kitsch with good German soul food.  That's the key to understanding this place.
author: Jana T.

description:
Having only been to Suppenkuche (and loving it) I had been meaning to try Walzwurk, which is much closer to my house, for some authentic German food (and beer).  Finally did, and I am sad it took me so long.  It's a pretty cozy place, but has a very cool Eastern German feel inside.  We were lucky to grab an immediate seat at the bar on a Saturday night before the people started rolling in and were subsequently told there would be a long wait.  

Great German beers on tap (Schwarzbier ,mmmm), and oh the food.  I cannot ever get enough Sauerbraten (roasted beef with dumplings and red cabbage).  We also got the schnitzel with Spaetzle.  Oh Spaetzle.  You are so delicious.  Such good food, great beer, good service, and since it was pouring rain outside, a pretty ideal spot to be to stay warm and dry.  

Loved Walzwurk and we will definitely be back.
author: Sean H.

description:
I love German food, but it's tough to find German restaurant food that isn't laden with gluten. The Germans love their breaded things, their spaetzle and their gravies. I've also been looking for something with less of a line out the door than Suppenkuchen which, though good, is always a long wait. 

Still, we tried Walzwerk because a few items on the menu looked promising. Loved the sign on the door that said "You are now leaving the American sector," because in some ways you really are. The decor inside is kitschy East German, but also very casual. The hostesses are also German, and very friendly and helpful. One helped me choose a red wine to sip as we checked out the menu, and the other helped me find something on the menu I could actually eat!

I had the house-cured salmon with pickled beets and horseradish cream (no bread for me) -- yum. I also snitched some of my date's sour cream herring with pickles and apples, and it too was amazing. 

For dinner, I had the garlic pork loin, which was good but overcooked. They covered it with a yummy tomato sauce (one of the only gluten-free sauces they make), and had a big pile of tasty greens and some mashed potatoes on the side. The taters were TDF. I don't want to know how much butter and cream were in them. 

Alas, no dessert for me, but I'll definitely be back the next time I have a hankering for German food. It'll happen.
author: Beth W.

description:
I ordered the SAUERBRATEN, which was really flavorful at first, but then became more and more difficult to eat because it was WAY to sweet for an entree.  My cousin ordered the JAGER SCHNITZEL, which was covered in a delicious creamy mushroom sauce.  I would come back and order the jager schnitzel.  
We had a restaurant.com coupon that we presented before ordering, but they forgot to apply it to our check, which caused for a lot of confusion.  We had to remind them of it and ask for the revised check.  Not too happy about that....
author: rose h.

description:
Went there for dinner on a weekday. I like the home feeling it gives you when you walk in! It's definitely different from Suppenkuche which feels more festive & weekend-ish. Spending a night here on a quiet weekday chitchating with friends is perfect. 
I ordered a special - pork sausage wrapped with bacon :) I tasted very delicious!! It wasn't too salty and greasiness was just right consider it's German food. Mashes potato that came with it had a very nice silky texture. I imagine they put cream and butter in it but it didn't fill your stomach immediately like other buttery food does.
For desert, I ordered a pear crumble cake with Vanilla ice cream. I never had a pear cake so it was something new to me. I like the light sweetness in the pear pairing with crumbles. The only thing was the put chocolate sauce on it which totally overrode the lightness of the dessert. I would recommend people to ask for it without the chocolate sauce.

For drink, I had a dark beer. That night I was looking for something rich and thick to drink. This dark beer wasn't the one but it wasn't bad neither.

Overall, I love this place! I would go back !
author: Mel C.

description:
The last two times at Walzwerk didn't go so well so I haven't been back for a while but I've been craving their schnitzel so I'll probably be back soon.

When I find something I like in a restaurant I'm likely to order it over and over. Ever since the second or third time I've come here I've ordered the Jager schnitzel. The second to last time I came here they made me Saurbraten instead and when I pointed it out the owner just said something like, "you'll like this". It was OK but not what I wanted, and whether I liked it or not isn't the issue.

The last time I was here I met some people for dinner and the food was good as usual but the service was terrible. We were done eating and waiting for the check while the owner was sitting at a table chatting with a friend. After a while she noticed that we were done and she said, "you aren't in a hurry".

I have to knock them down a star for all that but I can't write them off entirely.
author: Manny F.

description:
My experience with German cuisine starts at bierocks and ends with Johsonville brats! So, needless to say, I was flying BLIND on this culinary adventure! The decor of the place was a little bizarre. Cold, metal tables and chairs, but touched up with little flower center pieces and tea-light candles. The server (whom I never got a name) was fantastic! I told her I'd never been in before and was pretty much lost! She pointed out the jägerschnitzel and one other dish (which I can't remember the name, which is of course, the one I ordered!) I ended up getting the marinated beef with potato dumplings and cabbage with soljaka soup to start and the darker lager in draft. The beer was great! Right temperature, just enough carbonation and great webbing on the glass...i wanted a boot though:-( only got 16 oz. But the soup was AMAZING!! I have to learn that recipe...

The main course was good! Not an over the top experience, but good enough that I'd come back and try something else. 

After dinner, i ordered a bottle of the Spaten Optimator...yeah...I love beer....I love REALLY GOOD beer...this was heavenly...it was so good in fact...

...i ordered apple strudel! I didn't want to leave! 

All in all, a very pleasant experience and one i hope i can duplicate in LA.
author: John W.

description:
Whenever I'm missing Germany, this place is GREAT! 
Solid food. best beer selection. Getting a lil pricey but its SF.
If you don't like it please don't go cause you are just getting in my way.
Go join the tourists at one of the Bavarian restaurants!
author: darrel w.

description:
Food, environment, and very polite waiter and waitress deserve 4.5 stars if they did not charge 18% tip for two people on the bill.  I mean it was not a suggestion. Tip was a part of our bill. It was odd since I was so impressed by food and people working there, that I could not give less than 20% tip but...


Beside this last point surprise, the environment was great as well as foods. Especially my food, roasted pork,  was very good. It was tasty and was not heavy.  My wife's food, a daily special with fish, was also delicious  but a little bit oily. The foods were ready after 40 minutes , a little bit late for our taste(-0.5 star here).  And beer, sure, it was a German shop.
author: Alireza R.

description:
Good potato pancakes and veg Schnitzel. Everyone at the table loved the herring and ate it up like mad.

More laid back than Suppenkuche and not as loud. Great beer selection as well.
author: Jessica P.

description:
I'm berserk for Walzwerk. Really, the entrees were big portioned and incredibly comforting/delicious. BF and I ordered the: 1) Breast of Chicken stuffed with Apples & Bacon (with Sundried Cherry Sauce), Mashed Potatoes, and Seasonal Vegetables $17-the chicken was very moist + uniquely flavored sauce, 2) Jäger Schnitzel (Porkloin) with Spätzle and Creamy Mushrooom Sauce, $16-omg, creamy, comforting. Overall, it was damn good.

Quick tip: Parking was plentiful, portions were great, staff was friendly.
author: Johanna P.

description:
Took a friend here for her birthday and we were a small party. We ordered the potato cakes, schnitzel, the sauerbraten, garlic roast pork, and an apple strudel. Must disagree with my fellow Yelpers here and say the schnitzel was my least favorite of the three. It was dry and tasted a bit like Katsu. The garlic roast pork on the other hand was sooo good! Very tender and juicy. The potato cakes also lived up to its hype. As others have said, it's German comfort food and I could've easily mistaken this kind of food to be something from a cafe if I didn't purposely search Yelp for this. 

Ok so I only wanted the strudel after watching Inglorious Basterds. Unfortunately it didn't come with a nice cold glass of milk, but it had ice cream on the side. Eh good enough I guess. It tasted like a pastry and had different kinds of nuts in it. 

My only complaint is that the food took kind of long to get to us, not sure if it was because there was a party of 8 ahead of us, but thank goodness we had each others' company so we hardly noticed it. 

I would come back again.
author: Anita W.

description:
Maybe we went on a bad day? It just didnt do it for me....

Came with a few friends bc we heard this was a good place to go to get some good German food. I was excited because I had never had German food before and I was ready to be germanfied. The decor was strange and funny. I felt like I was in some bunker.

We got the potato cakes. Pretty good. We asked for ketchup and the waiter was not amused. He found some ketchup and told us to not tell anybody. Oops.

Got the schnitzel. I'm not sure what warranted the high price tag.....was this imported straight from Germany? Is it made from the finest schnitzel a piece of currency with Andrew Jackson can buy? Not sure. 

Tried someone's entree and it was this meat dish with potato and this really strange sour sauce. I didnt like it but I'm guessing this is a staple of german food that I just dont care for. But again, I didnt really understand why it was so expensive.

Anyways, maybe I shouldve done some more research but then thats just too much work for food.
author: Young L.

description:
Ok I've been a few times.  German beer fans must stop here! The food here is very solid and good value for German food.  Is any  food expected to be cheap except Chinese or maybe Indian?  Schnitzel is probably the most popular dish for the uninitiated.  The golosh was a miss, but the pork tenderloin stuffed with apples is delish.  Would give the place four stars for having good German beer on tap!  Decor is definitely Kitschy with a 70's flair. You eat of what could only be classified as military grade steel desks and chairs. So go there and give a toast to Friedrich Engel and the Communist that have come and gone.  

Eastbay people need to check out my review of BJ's Cafe in Concord if you like this place.
author: Stephen I.

description: The service is outstanding and the food is truly authentic. Great beer selection to pair with light appetizers or a great meal. The ambiance and authentic decor really compliment the whole experience.
author: Juan G.

description:
Walzwerk is at least twelve kinds of awesome. Let's see: 

1) Beer
2) Drinks consisting of beer + carbonated beverages
3) The ability to handle an eight person reservation with efficiency, charm, and spot-on timely seating
4) A cozy environment perfect for a lovely meal with friends
5) At the same time, an intimate and dimly lit atmosphere that makes it excellent for a date
6) An atmosphere intimate and dimly lit enough to soften its industrial decor
7) Industrial decor
8) Really excellent potato pancakes
9) Kasespätzle (mac and cheese, essentially) to die for
10) A fantastic chocolate dessert called a "cold dog"
11) Excellent service
12) A name as delicious as the food

Notes: 

1) I am vegetarian, but I've eaten here with carnivore types and heard only positive feedback from them about the food.

2) I think they only take reservations for large groups

3) I have no idea whether the food is "authentic", nor do I generally believe Yelp reviewers who claim they can make this assessment. I just know that Walzwerk is yummy. 

4) I don't remember seeing any kids there, but it strikes me as the kind of place that would welcome children.
author: Janna M.

description:
Maybe its just me but I'm not a huge fan of the 'sharing tables' business.  We get there and there are probably 8? tables and people are splitting a table of 6 between 3 parties of 2.  it gets really awkward for the party in the middle seats.  I know its probably some cultural difference that I'm not aware of since suppenkuche does the exact same thing but I like my personal space.  That, and I hate it when the couple sitting next to me cannot hold a decent conversation so they spend an entire dinner eavesdropping on my convo.  

The drinks were awesome.   I got this funky looking elderberry german soda and quite honestly, it tasted very german.  Take whatever you want from that.

The food was also good.  I got the porkloin with Spätzle and Creamy Mushrooom Sauce.  zomg was it flavorful.  I think I have a slight eroticism towards spatzle.  its a perfect blend of asian noodle-textured doughyness and european styled pasta.  It tastes so great especially with the cream sauce.  I thought the porkloin was going to be tough and overcooked with the sauce masking it but the pork was very flavorful and was well cooked, slightly under.  

I would definitely come back here even though its in sort of a shady portion of van ness.  ill be sure to bring my taser next time.
author: Paran Y.

description: Favorite German food. I'm German and knew what I'm talking about! Last time we went it was a little different,  maybe they changed the chef.  But still the best Jaegerschnitzel in town. East Berlin theme.
author: Hendrik G.

description: Food was very good but service was slow ( over two hours for dinner). One waitress was working her xxx off while the other ran around on circles. Both rude and we had to ask for everything.  Won't go back.
author: Marvelous Margaret M.

description:
This place is good, solid German food, but I think what I like the most about it is the cozy, friendly atmosphere. I had a schnitzel with a mushroom sauce and spaetzle and it was pretty good. 

Definitely worth a trip, but not the greatest. I'd say, worse than Suppenkuche, better than Schmidts (even though I think they're the same owner?). But if you're looking for a nice, quiet cozy German meal, this is your spot.
author: Abbey S.

description:
As a German living in the East Bay, coming to SF to get my fix of good German draft beer with authentic German food is important. I had heard good things about this Eastern German Restaurant and was eager to go with a couple of friends. 

First of all, let me be upfront about why my rating is so bad: BAD service. The food was decent enough. And for somebody who grew up in Germany and knows that in comparison to the US, most restaurants in Germany really lack any service attitude, I thought it is actually not possible for me to write a bad review about a restaurant, only based on the bad service. That was, until I visited this place with friends. The waitresses were rude to a point I was seriously embarrassed in front of my American friends and was trying to defuse the situation with jokes. Some friends didn't even dare to order another beer as they feared they would just be sneered at. 

The highlight of the evening was that two people came 30 minutes later to our dinner. We were a party of 5 before, were all in the middle of the dinner and one of us left, so basically they would just have had to accomodate one person more. When they arrived the waitresses seemed upset insisting that "you cannot add more and more people to the dinner as the evening goes on". After I assured here that this was the only change of the evening, the two new arrivals tried to order food, only to be told "no you cannot order something, since we now need your table". That was basically a verbal slap in the face. 

I still left a 20% tip at the end of the night but was basically also willing to leave much less. One thing is for sure: this was the last time I went to this place under the current management.
author: M. Y.

description:
Yeah, I pretty much heart this place! It's one of my favorite restaurants in the city. I may be just a bit biased because I am German. Or maybe that makes me an expert? ;-)
The food is always good - no matter what I order. I love the 'Rinderolade'. The beef is as tender as it should be. The 'Kaesespaetzle' are fantastic every time. I cannot get enough of the 'Reibekuchen'. Make sure to leave some space in your tummy for the 'Rote Gruetze'. When my family visits from Germany, we always come here. They say the food is almost better than in Germany. Ha. ;-) Guten Appetit!
author: Kristina T.

description:
Best restaurant experience I've had in my US travels all summer.  The food was delicious.  Three friends and shared schnitzel, sauerbraten, stuffed chicken breast, and bratwurst.  All were outstanding.  I don't know how they prepare the mashed potatoes, but they were the best I've ever had.  The sauerkraut and another cabbage dish were incredible.

We actually started with the cold cut plate and potato pancakes, both of which were excellent.  For dessert, we shared the cold dog (layered chocolate cake with butter cookies) and schockoladenvanillapudding (not how it's spelled; I just can't remember), a wonderful chocolate pudding with vanilla sauce).

This was well worth the 20 to 30-min. wait.  The staff was so attentive and playful.  Two of the servers chatted with us when the rush died down.  They were both very friendly and fun.

Did I mention the amazing sauerkraut?  I'll be hitting this place whenever I visit the City from now on!
author: Marcello L.

description:
In the world of San Francisco German cuisine, Leopolds is greater than Suppenkuche, which is greater than Walzwerk.  

Compared to Leopolds and Suppenkuche - Walzwerk's atmosphere is way mellow.  It skips over the raucous-ness of Suppenkuche, and the welcoming hearty-ness of Leopolds.  Instead, you might feel like you've time warped back to East Germany as you walk into a comparatively-quiet, dimly lit, small space with era and culture appropriate historical art, trinkets, and decorations. 

The restaurant is small - maybe 6 tables out front and three in the back with a long narrow hallway connecting the front and back.  Next to the hallway, there's a mini seating area where you can wait for a table and also their tiny bar which I think had two stools.  Like Suppenkuche and Leopolds, Walzwerk also does communal seating.

Food: 
1) House salad - uses butter lettuce and a vinegar dressing = soo good and perfect size for two to share as an appetizer
2) Bratwurst - There were heaping mounds of creamy, buttery mashed potatoes and a lot of really good sauerkraut, but it comes with only one sausage.  It wasn't proportional and the quantity wasn't worth the price.  I feel like you need at least two sausages if it's going to be served as an entree.  That said, it tasted good - so I guess if the price doesn't bother you and one bratwurst is enough for you, then this dish could be great.
3) Beef roulade - it was good to try once especially if you're down for something heavy.  The beef is stuffed with bacon, pickles, onions, and mustard; it comes with red cabbage and spaetzle.  
4) For dessert we shared the strawberry raspberry pudding - really disappointing. It's frozen berries with some sort of vanilla sauce on top  - not impressive. 

If you want German food and a mellow evening, this place could be better than Leopolds and Suppenkuche.  It provides a more intimate space than the other two and the decor/atmosphere make you feel like you are eating out of an East Berlin kitchen.  But for me, Walzwerk's food does not compare to it's competitors.  If I'm in the area and the mood is right, maybe I'll give it another shot - but I can't see myself returning in the near future.
author: Kimya P.

description:
We went here for a birthday dinner last Saturday and I must say that I was quite impressed with Walzwerk. It's quite small inside but they may have an extra dining area in the back (not sure). The decor is somewhat minimal but quaint. 
The food was excellent and definitely one of those places where you can go for comfort food. Friendly service and a menu that is quite diverse. So if you like meat, they've got a chicken dish (excellent) and pork dish (comfort food indeed). But if you're looking for something more vegetarian, they also have that for your own choosing.

Now, when it comes to wine and beer. All you beer enthusiasts out there will definitely like this place because of their wide array of beer selection.

Additionally, parking wasn't that bad on a Saturday night despite having only street parking as an option. We found parking not too far from the restaurant.

So on a cold evening, if you're craving for some nice German comfort food. This is the place to go.
author: Chad B.

description: Solid German food, but not anything that will blow your mind away. Especially after you've had the real deal in Germany. But nonetheless, solid food when you're craving some schnitzel and potato cakes. Try the Jäger Schnitzel if you'd prefer a cream of mushroom type sauce over your schnitzel.
author: Angela S.

description:
In today's economy, you think any restaurant owner would be pleased to have customers waiting for the door to open for business! We (party of 4) got a less than warm welcome!  But hey!... This is an East German style restaurant with pictures of the Fathers of Communism adorning their wall.

BEVERAGES: Spaten Optimator and  Bionade-Holunder 

APPETIZERS: Potato pancakes and Matjes Herring in sour cream w/apples, onions, pickles w/pumpernickel bread. 

DINNER: Grilled Thuringer Bratswurst w/mash potato & sauerkraut.    
Jager Schnitzel (porkloin) w/Spatzle & creamy mushroom sauce.
Breast of Chicken w/apple & bacon w/mash potato & seasonal vegetables.

DESSERT: Cold Dog (Layered cake made of chocolate, rum & butter cookies. Apple Strudel w/Ciao Bella Vanilla Ice Cream.

All-in-all, with the exception of the Chicken and potato pancakes, there was very little to be impressed with. One star for the food. Another for the service.

As the multilingual warning sign said on the outside door... that "you are leaving the American Sector" to the eastern block tchotchkes and décor. So we were warned!
author: Edward H.

description: Food was good, nice to see some Eastern European staples on the menu. The place is decorated in communist-era theme. Service was good. The place is small and gets packed after 6pm, so come before or after 8pm.
author: Patricia L.

description:
Half of the group got there on time for the reservations, while the other half arrived 15 minutes late.  While waiting for the other half, they were rushing us and asking when the rest will arrive.  It took forever for our server to take our orders and to bring out our food, drinks, and utensils.  I asked for a soda and waited a long time for it and had to ask for it a second time.  

Portions were huge.  I had the stuffed chicken and I thought it was really good in the beginning, maybe cause I was hungry.  But after awhile, I changed my mind.  The chicken was pretty dry, but thank goodness the sauce that came with it was good, because it really needed it.  I tried some schnitzel and that was good... really does taste like chicken katsu.  The potato pancakes were okay.

It was my first time having German food and I enjoyed it for the most part.  But the service here is really slow.
author: Kat E.

description: Best German food in the city - hands down.  Upon first impressions, service can seem frazzled and uninterested - but once you get to know them they are lovely ladies.  :)  Potatoe pancakes with sour cream and applesauce are devine.  My husband loves all the beer choices and speediness in refilling his stein!
author: Tanya F.

description:
Have lived a couple blocks away for 9 years but finally checked it out a couple weeks ago. After hearing the raves for so long I really thought it would be something special.
Meh.
It wasn't. I got chicken --dry, though the sauce was good and pretty much saved the dish--and subbed in spaetzle, because I love spaetzle. This spaetzle tasted like it had been set on the back of the stove overnight. Rubbery, dessicated, and without seasoning. Isn't this a German restaurant? What's up with serving spaetzle not fit for prisoners?

Then we asked for a recommendation for dessert. Our waiter, who was very eager to please and commodious, highly recommended the special: black forest cake. So we got it. Blech! It clearly had been frozen and defrosted, and not in a good way. It was dry and stale on the edges and wasn't worth the calories. 

Basically, I would've been embarrassed to serve food like this. It's probably a 2 star but because of the hype, we were especially disappointed and I'm downgrading.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
*  This place serves the best potato pancakes I have ever tasted.  They're thick, fluffy, salted perfectly, and melt in your mouth at the precise rate.

* Walzwerk also serves Christmas Goose during the holiday season.  While fatty, the goose has to be one of the most flavorful meats I've tasted.  It's like the dark meat of turkey, but thicker and richer.

* They also serve Kstritzer Schwarzbier from the tap in its own special glass.  It's a dark, cold, thick lager - perfect for a cold winter's night.

*Their Spaetzle is thick, chewy and full of buttery flavor. Another friend claims that their mashed potatoes rule. But I did not enjoy the potato dumpling served with my otherwise wonderful Christmas Goose dinner. Not even the perfectly seasoned Goose gravy could salvage its lack of flavor or mushy texture.

* And I love the sleeves of old 45s tacked on to the bathroom walls.

I can't wait to return.
author: Matthew L.

description:
ummm...yummers! This place rocks. Only a short wait for a table in this hipster restaurant where the awesomely European waiter sat with us to take our order. It really does feel like your oma's sitting room with the little knit doilies on the table. Excellent food (totally recommend the beef stroganoff. Be prepared to be full, reaaaaaaallllly full.

All four of us agreed, it's better than Suppenkuche which we love.

Beers for the boys, a sweet wine for me and all the schnitzel you can shake a stick at.
author: Nikki M.

description:
Hast du ein Bären Hunger?  Besuchen dich Walzwerk.

I picked the place and my friends said "but I thought you do vegetarian"...
No worries.  Beet soup, Spaetzle, cabbage roulade.  Try those but not the vegetarian schnitzel... it made my friend unhappy and he called it skimpy.  But I had to finish half of his beer.  They only serve it in rocket ship size.  Es war zu gross fur mein freund.  

My food was flavored just right.  Mashed potatoes and cabbage stuffed with rice and peas, helped out with herbs, sour cream and tangy sauce that brought it together.  Not salty, spicy, or greasy and still satisfying in a healthy way.

Call ahead.  They're small.  Great for conversations.  Interesting decor- portraits of lenin, marx, and neitzche (beard party!), vintage signs and german pop music.  Nice service from enthusiastic people.
author: Pat L.

description:
This place is pretty cool and certainly original in a lot of ways. The food is good, and the East German specialties are probably the only ones of their kind within a 500 mile radius.

Decor is baren, but that's part of its charm. Though, in all honesty, I felt like they could have gone further to make it look more "authentic" considering it's their whole mantra. The bathroom actually shows some of this potential.

Aside from that, it's nice that you can order beers while you wait. And the waiters are extremely nice, even if they are a bit forgetful.

Overall, 4-stars... but I feel like it the food could be a little better.
author: Slava P.

description:
Walzwerk is my favorite place in the city.
Here you won;t find servers pretending to be your friend or anything else that can be defined as cookie cutter or superficial. Instead you will be served by real people who serve real good food and drink.

Not one dish on the menu is marginal and the daily specials are well crafted fresh plates. 

As a small restaurant on some weekdays they may only have one server on which can slow things down but this is the type of place that deserves a slow enjoyable feast with friends or family.
author: Eric F.

description:
If you're like me and have never tried authentic German food, GO HERE. It will blow your mind away and make you wonder why you never tried it before this! The place is so small and cute, my boyfriend and I were lucky enough to sit at the window table. Everything about this place from the wall decor to the fresh flowers on the table to the mis-matched plates is to die for. But of course, what really won me over was the food. 

Everyone gets started off with a salami and cheese on some type of bread. It was pretty good. We got the potato pancakes to share, they were so delicious! I could have eaten them all. The sour cream and chives as well as the applesauce were excellent compliments to the starch of the potatoes. For the main dish, I got the chicken stuffed with apples and bacon. The chicken was so moist and it came with the most delicious sun dried cherry sauce. The mashed potatoes and the green beans were also great. For desert, we ate the classic apple strudel with ice cream. The strudel was so flaky and it went so well with the creamy ice cream. 

This was a great place and I will definitely be making another visit soon.
author: Khanh C.

description:
Slightly embarrassed that I've lived up the street for 8 years and JUST tried this place last night...well, good things are worth the wait.

The food:  amazing and filling and oh-so-tasty!  (they had a spinach salad with warm bacon in a vinagrette for a special app! yummy!) 
Potato pancakes with sour cream and applesauce?  Hella GOOD.

The beer:  SO GOOD!!

So happy we wandered in there for a change of pace for dinner last night.  Tuesday night = no wait.  Excellent.

Can't wait to go back and try more!!
author: diana p.

description:
FOOD =  The small potato pancakes with chive sour cream and applesauce ($6) is good, but one of our potato pancakes was almost burnt on the outside.  If you like hashbrowns, you should like this.  Interesting flavors when you have both the chive sour cream with applesauce on top.

The Breast of Chicken stuffed with Apples & Bacon (with Sundried Cherry Sauce), Mashed Potatoes, and Seasonal Vegetables ($15) was good and a favorite at our table.  The chicken was not dry and it had a lot of sweet flavor around it because of the sundried cherries/sauce.

My husband had the Beef Roulade (Tri-Tip Stuffed with Bacon, Pickles, Mustard & Onions) with Spätzle and Red Cabbage ($15) and that was good, too.. the beef and bacon together was yummy.

Someone else ordered the halibut special which was an almond and sage crusted halibut with potatoes and asparagus.  For $21, I would think they would do something different with the potatoes because it was basically just boiled.  The halibut was good, but nothing super exciting.

Another person ordered the Schnitzel (Breaded Porkloin) with Mashed Potatoes & Seasonal Vegetables ($15) which I was a fan of because I like pork.  It seems huge, but it's because the schnitzel is big and thin--it was yummy and probably my favorite of all the dishes.

PAYMENT/PRICING = We all paid in cash, but I'm sure debit/credit is acceptable.  I'd say we all had good portions on our plates that made it almost entirely worth the money.

PARKING = Street/metered parking.

SERVICE = The ladies were nice.  

Before you enter, there's a sign on the door that says something like, "You are now leaving America..."  It's not a super lively atmosphere, but they do a nice job of putting a lot of German flavor on the walls.
author: Doreen M.

description:
I love this find in the City.  The food is very good and the beer is even better!  They import all of their beer from Germany and I am told that only a couple places on the west coast carry the beers they carry.  There is one beer I think it was called Schwarzbier.  It is very dark, almost black in color.  The bartender explained something about fire roasting the malt until it is dark.  This dark malt give the beer a hint of a coffee flavor.  I am not all too knowledgeable in beer processes, so some of this may be slightly wrong... but freaking drink it and you slowly decide you really don't care how it gets into your glass, just as long as it gets there!! 
The food I have tried and really like are:

Potato Pancake appetizers (awesome with the applesauce believe it or not)

Jäger Schnitzel (and no... there is no Jägermeister in it... at least I don't think.  I had a lot of beer, so who can tell, right?)

Sauerbraten

Apple Strudel with Ciao Bella Vanilla Ice Cream for dessert

There was one dinner item that I was not fond of and it was the Beef Roulade.  It is made with tri-tip and I just felt that the tri-tip was not a good choice of meat to roast.  I like my tri-tip cooked or grilled like a steak at medium rare.  It's worth a shot, though if you like well done tri-tip.
author: Thomas O.

description:
Walzwerk was a good experience. I have not had the chance to taste much German food, but it had a great flavor. I ordered the schnitzel with mushroom sauce. The food had a very pleasant taste and was more than plentiful. The meat was perfectly cooked and moist -- which can be somewhat hard to do with thin slice of pork. For an appetizer we had the mashed potato pancakes which were incredible. They were perfectly cooked with just the right amount of spices added. I wish I had room for dessert.

The service was very good. The waitress was knowledgeable of the menu and was able to explain it well. She was able to help me choose a beer based upon my likes and dislikes as well.
author: Pierce B.

description: Tasty German food. Love this spot! Great staff too
author: Tina F.

description:
Yumm Yummmm Yummmmmmmmmm!!!

I can't wait to go back here, it was soooo good!  And I love how they decorated the place.  I went with my friend and we shared the potato pancake with sour cream and apple sauce.  I never would have thought apples and potatoes would mix, but damn they do!  I ordered the pork and veal sausage with sauerkraut and mashed potatoes. It was so delish! I also ordered an organic soda and it was pretty good, a lot less sweet than American sodas.  My friend ordered the trip tip with these fried dough like things and beets. His tri tip was simply unforgettable!!!  To top everything off, the service was amazing. I cannot understand why anyone would give this place less than 5 stars!
author: Raquel C.

description: I LOVED the Cold War atmosphere! The service was wonderful and offered samples of the beers when I couldn't make up my mind. The food was delicious and preiswert.
author: Mary H.

description:
Delicious delicious delicious. 

My roommates and I sampled the potato pancakes first which were soft and flavorful with a slightly crispy exterior. Abseloutely melt in your mouth with the apple sauce and sour cream.  

For a meal i would suggest the chicken breast stuffed with apple and bacon. (although i tried my roommates' dishes and they were awesome as well!) The chicken comes with cooked cherries around it (which i was skeptical of at first) and the combination of all the sweet and all the savory drenched in a light cream sauce is like having desert and dinner all at once! (I am sure some seratonin was released from my brain after taking the first bite.) It comes with a side of mashed potatoes and vegetables cooked to perfection. 

Of course they have a nice beer selection as well. The lighting and atmosphere is calming and the vintage posters and pictures of philosophers and the like are kind of satirical . Staring at Marx made my meal a bit unsettling but nevertheless, it was overall a good experience. I will be back!
author: Katie D.

description:
Oh Walzwerk, I love you so hard.

It's not just because German is a gorgeously violent language.  Pickled herring with sour cream and cold dark German bread sounds disgusting and tastes delicious.  Bonus, there is SO freaking much of it for nine dollars.

Everything is quite tasty except your desserts which are awful.  I mean embarassingly terrible...but Poppy is typically quite inebriated on your fabulous selection of flavorful alcoholic beverages and couldn't possibly care less at that point.
author: Poppy C.

description:
I happened upon this place by happy accident.  I had intended to go to another German place somewhere around Folsom and 20th (I think?) but didn't know the name, so after a quick Yelp consult I assumed this was my intended destination and moseyed over.

This place deserves 5 stars for ambience.  From the street (cold, windy, industrial, even a touch desolate), Walzwerk offers a glimpse through its windows of muted light, frothy amber beers and abundant plates.
