Inside, the 6 or 7 tables were full so we sat at the tiny bar to wait with a brew, peruse the bilingual menu and take in the decor - mostly kitsch.  The European staff are casual and relaxed - sometimes a little inattentive, but very friendly and I was so charmed by the ambience I didn't mind waiting.  There is nothing pretentious or even hip about Walzwerk.  It didn't even feel much like San Francisco - and certainly not the Mission.

The food was solid, both in quality and in nature.  The potato pancakes were delicious, the beet soup a touch salty for my taste, the sauerbraten and schnitzel were both good.  The ice tea is rosehip, not black, and was very tasty.  Food plus beer definitely has a soporific effect which is not bad at all on a chilly fall night, especially if the stumbling distance between table and bed is not too far.
author: Jane F.

description:
I was first intrigued when they described themselves as East German, not simply German food. Upon entering we instantly started to understand what they mean. It feels as if you're eating in someones home, very homey, but great service as well. 

While completely packed they were great to accommodate and ensure we enjoyed our time. Even while slammed with tables in true European fashion, when we asked about their wines, they brought out 5 for us to sample before selecting one. 

From ordering our drinks it only got better, the food was spot on for authentic food, in particular the Spätzle was great. Though everything our party of four had was great. There's nothing that could have made the quality of our time and food much more enjoyable, we will be sure to make it back as soon as possible
author: Craig K.

description:
Had a great birthday dinner here a couple weeks ago.  Had a group of 10 people so we got the back room to ourselves which was perfect since we were probably fairly loud and would have been annoying to any other nearby diners. 

The food was great - highly recommend the Sauerbraten and the potato pancakes.  Contrary to some other reviews - we also had good service and no issues with waiting for seating. 

Also highly recommend a round of Underberg post-dinner to kick-off the digestion.  It's basically the German version of Fernet, but it didn't seem to make everyone cringe as much as Fernet does.
author: Josh B.

description: Well... I hate being blamed for all the douchebagery of the world when you aren't satisfied with a dish.... And the lovely woman that was serving that night so tastefully and tactfully both apologized for my dissatisfaction yet lumped me into this category of "people who complain to get free stuff" that I was just blown away.  This woman needs to star in her own line of bondage and sadomasochism videos because I really loved the fact that she lumped me Into this category because I felt the need to defend myself from the mass amounts of douchebagery in this city... Which I can't blame her in the least... She even talked of posting to yelp as a place for people to have no voice...people who are tired of their existence and have nowhere to turn... Well... I have plenty of places to turn and plenty of good restaurants to go to so how about next time don't serve me a soggy very neutrally beige piece of meat covered with sauce served way too soon to even be considered to be fresh by the most drunk of a person(even though she tried to elude to that's why I didn't like it). I'm partially to blame but she first said she was sorry I didn't like it but then offered up the fact that people try to get free shit by complaining and that for me was free game from there on..... I didn't say one disrespectful word... Just voiced my opinion...  Which gave me a glimpse into the state of her world... Which I completely accept and love and will definitely go back sometime I am not the last customer ten minutes before they close.  I was craving jäger schnitzel and the mushroom gravy was amazing.... It was just covering an obviously precooked textureless lump.  I have plenty of outlets and do creative work for a living... So the diagnosis  to complain on yelp for having nothing else to do doesn't really apply.... I just wanted a nicely fresh fried piece of pork.... Has anyone in this kitchen ever heard of the Maillard reaction?  It's pretty handy with cutlets of meat.  I'm sorry there are so many douche bags that frequent the upstanding establishments of San Francisco that as soon as someone has an opinion it becomes a thing to be looked down upon....  I work hard for a living and see the division of labor and classes every day.... But don't try to make someone feel bad for not liking your food.... Even though it definitely was the most tactful and classy way to be told this I have ever experienced. I said I was at a poker game and had a couple drinks so that immediately was the reason I was "acting in such a fashion" :)
author: Chris T.

description:
Einfach super Geil!  Das Essen hat's gut geschmacht, die Kellnerin waren lustig und schnell (und heiss).   

One of the best times I've ever had at a German restaurant...and the decoration, makes me feel like I am back in East Berlin (but a bit kitchier)!

go there go there go there go there go there

Spaetzle was GREAT!
author: Matt V.

description:
Good place for some authentic German fare and beers. 

Food: I ordered the Sauerbraten (basically marinated beef or a pot roast-esque dish) which comes with potato dumplings and red cabbage. The beef was tasty but the potato dumplings were bland or strangely seasoned because it did not go well with the beef. The red cabbage was ok. My date had their special that night: bacon wrapped Hefeweizen bratwurst with a cheese filling. The sides were mashed potatoes and sauerkraut. He said his dish was great.

Service: Our waitress completely forgot to put in our order!! You could tell she was the only one working the small restaurant but we had been waiting long enough to watch another table seated at the same time as us finish their food. She also didn't bother to come back to fill our glasses or ask how we were doing. Also, I've experienced waiters offering some sort of apology appetizer or drink for doing the mistake she did. Nothing was done just that our food would be expedited (which is expected since she forgot to put in our order.)

Would much rather go to Suppenkuche for German if I were ever in the mood.
author: Klaus t.

description: Get your German fix here. Good coleslaw and potato pancakes. They have schnitzel and bratwurst and sauerkraut. It's a small place so make reservations or prepare to wait.
author: Oanh N.

description: Okay place to me. Just the customers wont get up even if they finish eating and paid the check. So, be prepare to wait even though they see you are waiting for  their tables.
author: David W.

description:
Great beer list. Great food. Really random ambiance -- kind of dusty and full of character. 

I had the spatzle- which was amazing, highly recommended vegetarian option.
author: Rena B.

description: LOVE IT! As a German I can tell you it's authentic. Also seeing the East German decoration puts quite a smile on my face :)
author: Ingo R.

description: I had my 40th birthday party here in the back room. We squeezed 20 people in there and had a great meal (family style)and a great time. My partner and I are both vegetarian, which would seem not to be an obvious choice but we have been coming here for years for the vegetarian schnitzel and the vegetarian cabbage rolls. Although I have never tried them, their meat dishes were a big hit with our party and from what I have seen also with everyone else. I know there are already tons of reviews for Walzwerk, but I just wanted to say that they made my 40th a lot of fun.
author: Eric F.

description: Super dense potato pancakes unlike any I've ever had. Hockey disk sized rounds of mashed potato, herbs and cheese. Delicious. The vegetarian schnitzel was divine, I was super jealous of my BF for ordering it. Crispy flavorful breading on veggies, and the variety! Their mashed potatoes and green spinach? puree was pure magic. You cannot go wrong here.
author: Cori W.

description: We didn't even get to eat here so I'm not rating the food. We had a reservation at 6pm. We got there at 6pm. They said it would be 5-10 minutes for a table. Our 2 friends with a baby showed up separately. Then they took a another party of 4 ahead of us and when asked why they seated them ahead of us, some lady (not american) told us in a condescending russian accent "I don't know what to tell you people. They came, there was an empty table, your party wasn't all here, we gave it to them. Sorry, I don't know what to tell you, besides, I don't think we have a kiddie chair for your son" Very rude. Nice reviews on here about the food but we will never know. One experience can ruin everything. Zero desire to try again. Hope others have a better experience
author: Chris Y.

description:
Dark, candlelit, and pitchers of beer.
Terrible waitress. "what's wrong with vegetarian?"
Spilling beer.
Yummy chicken with bacon? and apples? 
Mashed potatoes and cheese spaetzel.
Insert spaetzel dance here.
Good conversation and good people.

I'm here again, check it!
author: Lauren S.

description: Between the communist art on the walls and the underwhelming food I'll not be returning. When you put a man on the wall who murdered 60 million people, you might as well throw Hitler up there too. Seriously, the food was bad. Breading on the pork had no seasoning, and was overcooked. The soups were heavy handed on the salt. Dessert was luke warm and had raw dough. I had a hankering for German, but next time I'll be going elsewhere, as the bay has much better German offerings. When you strive towards the ideals of men they worship on their walls, it's no wonder they have a mediocre offering.
author: Brian K.

description: For a christmas work dinner from my german employers. Fun experience, complete with vile herbacious digestif in little bottles afterwards. Good dinner. Home style food. First exposure to spaetzel and herring, with grapefruit hefeweizen (fun).  Yum.
author: Micah J.

description: First off, I love this place.  However Google said it was open today (Sunday) and it was not.  Only realized this after standing in front of place for 15 min, wondering why there was no activity inside; then read sign saying it was closed on Sundays.  Hopefully someone can get that inaccurate info fixed.
author: Matt H.

description:
Great food.
Don't forget to try the deserts!
author: Scott N.

description:
I remember the first time my friend went to Walzwerk. He text messaged me in a craze about the authentically surly staff, the great food and huge portions, and the cool place it was in. Being that I was never one to deprive myself of being looked down upon by ornery Germans, I knew I had to go see for myself what it was all about. 

Walzwerk is all about East Germany, or the former East Germany, I guess. The menu offers very homey country-style German dishes that fall more on the side of comfort food than exotic, but that's totally great. Schnitzels, wursts and other delights of the German kind come out of their kitchen and it's all wonderful. I had the stuffed chicken breast which came out covered in this homestyle gravy with dried cherries on top, offered with wonderful fresh asparagus and mashed potatoes on the side. I should clarify that I did not actually live in East Germany, but I can safely say that this is as authentic as it gets in San Francisco. Another delight was that they have Franziskaner on draft, along with an impressive list of other beers. 

The restaurant itself is outfitted in a very efficient, communist-type style with simple tables and chairs, plants with East German flags hanging out of them and some kitschy art on the walls. The wait staff is efficient, friendly, but short, and that seemed pretty authentic to me too (the waitress was neither impressed, nor concerned with my friend who tried to speak German with her). The prices are super reasonable and portions are enormous, so go with an appetite. This is a new discovery in San Francisco that I will look forward to returning to.
author: Justin S.

description: Great experience and I love the homey feel. All the silverware, plates, glasses are unmatched sets. The interior has been painted over 10 or more times which really makes it feel like it's been around forever. The service here was what separates this place apart. They comped us a dessert after they asked us to move to a smaller table when a larger party showed up. Great experience, hard to find good german food just about anywhere.
author: Richard S.

description: Enjoyed a very good bratwurst with spaetzle, an orange-ginger bionade, and a strudel.  The compact size of the restaurant, industrial East German theme, and at least 2 large tables full of German-speaking visitors (when I went anyway) complete its unique atmosphere.  Even casual fans of the film Good Bye Lenin will enjoy the decor.  If you want to avoid a wait, perhaps visit right around the time it opens because it gets packed in the hour that follows.  The food was very good overall and I hope to return sometime.  I don't know why German food isn't bigger in the U.S.  It's just so damn delicious.
author: Nathan M.

description:
German food has a reputation for being heavy, but Walzwerk's cuisine displays a very attuned sensibility.  Beet soup highlighted the naturally sweet taste of beets with a very light hand towards seasoning; unfussy, simple, refreshing, and delicious, it was the most enjoyable aspect of my meal that evening.  Vegetarian roulade was hearty, but not heavy - it featured sweet cabbage surrounding what looked like black lentils with a well-rounded tomato sauce accompanied by a mound of rich, creamy mashed potatoes (not so healthy).  Only mediocre aspect were the potato pancakes - they were a little thick and bland, could have been seared more.

As some others have mentioned, service is not the hallmark of this dining institution.  Server was brusque and rolled her eyes at us on more than one occasion (we asked a few questions and hesitated a little before ordering), but I'm not here to be courted.  The food came out promptly and was cooked well... good enough for me.
author: Ana L.

description:
Great food--I mean really great food.  The sauce on the jagerschnitzel was wonderful.  I wanted to ask the waiter to bring we a bowl and let me drink it.

My husband and I talked about what a wonderful time we had--it was definitely a "date night."

The next time my work folks are coming out to the city, we're going to eat here.

Very intimate.  Really cool.  The owner (I think it was) was wearing a black outfit with converse.  She came by our table a few times to ask if everything was all right.  HELL YES!

Thank God we got there at 5:45 on a Sunday.  There lots of people coming in after us.  

Families come in here to eat too.
author: Priscilla L.

description: Thick heavy food that goes into your stomach and gives it a hug from the inside. The winner was beef roulade. The other two entrees (sauerbraten and I forget the other one we ordered) had an overpowering vinegar-based gravy that made sauerkraut redundant. Potato dumplings though. I wish I could roll around on a pile of potato dumplings.
author: Will R.

description:
So I'd heard good things about Walzwerk and decided it would be a great place to host a going away dinner for a friend.  

The staff were very clear with me that they could only seat nine of us, and really I didn't expect everyone to be able to show up anyway, so I wasn't worried.  Only seven people had confirmed.  But then -- uh, oh -- thirteen people arrived for dinner.  Walzwerk was not happy.

But you know what?  They rose to the occasion.  The food was spectacular, and the service was polite and efficient (even when they were clearly a little frustrated with us for taking over their space) and we all had a great time.

Danke, Walzwerk, for making our parting dinner a memorable one.  And also for the great beer.  Five stars.
author: Jeremy R.

description: Went to Walzwerk last night. I had the Garlic Roast Pork with Spätzle and my husband and "The Frau" both had the Jäger Schnitzel (Porkloin) with Spätzle and Creamy Mushrooom Sauce. The food was hearty and authentic (according to The Frau) and the selection of draft beer was excellent as well. For dessert we shared a Cold Dog: Layered Cake Made of Chocolate, Rum and Butter Cookies. The place is very small, really a "hole in the whole" with authentic, wholesome food. I've had Weiner Schnitzel in the past and wanted to try something different. But next time, I'm just going to have order it - looked so good!
author: Dorothy W.

description:
Ok, so I was staying in a hotel in Mission for a week and when browsing Yelp for restaurants in the vicinity I found this. Me being German I was curious and had to check this place out, especially after reading the positive reviews. And I did not get  disappointed. 

I've been to quite few so-called German restaurants outside Germany and they usually serve horrible food that hasn't got anything to do with the real stuff, the focus tends to be on selling beer. Walzwerk is different. The Jaegerschnitzel was the best I'd had in a long time, very decent indeed. The sauce was excellent and a nice contrast to the usual 'out of a bucket sauce'. 

Another, very pleasant, difference to your usual German place is the decor. While normally it's all about the Lederhosen and Bavarian theme Walzwerk is full of East German socialist memorabilia which gives it a slightly quirky and stylish touch...stark contrast to the usual Oooompapa ambiente. Service was good and the dessert (Stachelbeerkuchen) appeared to be homemade. All in all an easy recommendation and I'll definitely be back on my next visit to the Bay Area.
author: Lars R.

description:
Nice place, though it's a little "hole-in-the-wall" at the edge of the Mission district. The owners also cook and run the place. The restaurant has alot of cold-war era decorations with an east-German flair.

Sadly, I cannot remember the name of the soup that I had, but it was delicious. A tomato base with red cabbage and sausage topped with a dollop of sour cream. It may sound odd, bit if you like red cabbage at all you'll love this. I'm definitely taking my family back there in the future.
author: Jeff D.

description:
My favorite German food place in the city. Love the intimate atmosphere (reminds me of being in some German back-alley... in a good way) and the food is always delicious!

Plus, they have some good vegetarian options.
author: K. C.

description: This is a funky little place off the beaten path of the "vibrant Valencia corridor". All the better. Cozy space meets cozy food. Been here 3 times, and enjoyed the food, beer, desserts and service every time.
author: Ryan V.

description:
Very simple, clean, traditional German food, well executed and served by cute and friendly Germans!  Walzwerk has no pretentious attitude and the environment is very relaxed and even a little funny as you may be seated with some strangers (who, in our case, wound up making out (with tongue) during most our meal causing much embarrassment and funny looks -- entertaining cuz it's usually me making the scene)!

Anyway, I had the Sauerbrauten, which is marinated beef (YUM) with red cabbage and potato dumplings!  Probably the best I've ever had of it's kind -- my buddy had the fried pork cutlet which definitely wasn't as good as my dish-- he'd probably only give 4 stars.   I loved the cabbage, so yummy!  And dessert was pretty damn good too -- not too sweet, just right.  

I'd definitely go back so that my friends can get a taste of real german food.  I enjoyed my experience much more than the time I went to Suppenkuche (which was, I admit, many years ago now)
author: Marty E.

description:
I love this place. I rarely feel like going out and eating German food. I prefer cooking it myself. But it is such a fun place to take friends and share some of my childhood. 
I love all the artifacts. It is like traveling back in time and feeling home where I am not. I always have a good time here, great conversations over yummy beer, and of course, yummy, feel good German food. 

Seid bereit, immer bereit!
author: Kristin K.

description:
The food at Walzwerk is awesome, it is my German friend's favorite place to eat in San Francisco. Our table ordered a little of everything and it was all great. I ordered an entree, beer and appetizer which added up to $28. The beer selection is wonderful. 

While the food is definitely on the comfort side, it's served with a sort of "fine dining" twist reflected in the presentation, limited menu and price. I wish you could choose your own sides like the place I used to go back home, but this just isn't that kind of restaurant. 

They would have had five stars except our service was a bit lackluster. We had a reservation at 8 and weren't seated until quite some time later and our server was pretty cold. We weren't asked if we wanted more beers and we waited quite some time for our check even though there were other people waiting for a table. 

I wouldn't go here with a group larger than 4 or you will be pretty cramped. It was packed on a Wednesday night, so reservations are probably a good idea. Will definitely be back often.
author: Beth D.

description:
So I'm sitting at Walzwerk, admiring all the German decor, when the waitress shows up, and hands out the menu, which was written in German.

I don't speak German very well.  Basically, the only words I picked up were "schnitzel", "bratwurst", "apfelmus" and "salat".  So Walzwerk, I see you're trying to either trick me into learning more German or completely confuse me into getting something totally random and weird (for all I know).

Thats when I was told to flip over the menu to the English side.

Oh.  Duh.  /smacks self on forehead.

Quaint and cute space, delicious food, great service, I must say, I'm a fan.  I will be back, next time with 45% more German fluency!
author: Erika C.

description:
What is it about German food that is so comforting??? Whenever I eat here I feel so damn good and sleep so well.

Walzwerk should have little mattresses under the tables so diners could curl up for a nap after a meal. 

Heh.
author: zoe b.

description:
Gooooood stuff.  Shared the potato pancakes.  Pretty good, but next time I know to save space for my main entree.  The pancakes are lightly fried and served with sour cream with chives and applesauce.  

Per the recommendation of another review, I ordered the Jager Schnitzel, but breaded, with a creamy mushroom sauce and spatzle.  Yeah baby.  

Hubby had the regular breaded schnitzel with mashed potatoes and peas.  Make sure you squirt on that lemon juice - it makes the pork loin sing.  

No room for dessert.  Enough leftovers for another meal.  Yeah, we'll be back.
author: Denise M.

description: Positively charming little east germen joint with a solid menu of delicious fare. This is a very small spot, so you may want to call ahead to see if thery are booked.
author: Mo A.

description:
My first visit to this cozy east-german restaurant left me with mixed feelings.  On the plus side, the food itself was excellent.  I started with the Soljanka, a hearty tomato and cabbage soup with bits of bacon and salami.  It was relatively simple but still so flavorful.  For my entree, I tried the grilled Thuringer Bratwurst with some boiled potatoes, sauerkraut, and a delicious spicy mustard - also a home run.  There were also a bunch of authentic german beers on the menu.  The Schwarzbier and the Hefewiezen were both tasty and very reasonably priced.  

Unfortunately, my group was a bit disappointed with the surprisingly long lag between our appetizer and our entree.  Also, after we had finished eating our dinners, we found out that there had been a Specials Menu that our server had never given us.

Four stars for the food, and maybe 2.5 for the service this time around.  We'll chalk it up to a busy Saturday night, and hopefully we'll have better luck next time we visit.
author: Tim N.

description: This place is like a German hole in the wall.  The Potato Pancakes  is a must to try.  There Schnitzel and Beet soup  is very good. Quick tip if you are a part less that two arrive early,the wait can be an hour or more.
author: Joan T.

description: This is my 2nd favourite place for a hearty meal after the incomparable Bobo's. When I don't feel like dropping a lot of dough, the stuffed chicken breast with a German draught beer hits the spot. The portions are so large, I never finish it - but that's fine as that means tasty leftovers for the next day. Yum!
author: Guy A.

description: What a cool place! This is an eastern Germany restaurant with lots of Marx and propaganda posters. It's particularly great if you're into meat and homey food but if you're a vegetarian like me there are pretty limited options. I ordered the egg noodles which were fantastic! Also, I highly highly recommend their Hefeweizen beer, it was phenomenal!
author: Marina S.

description:
Mitch: Wow. Cheese. Is that you?
Dean Pritchard: Hello, Mitch. Bernard. I see you guys haven't changed much.
Beanie: Who's this guy?
Mitch: Beanie, you remember Cheese, Rodney's kid brother?
Dean Pritchard: Actually, my name's not Cheese anymore. It's Gordon Pritchard.
Beanie: Oh yeah. Cheeeeeese. Yeah, didn't we lock you in a dumpster one time?
Dean Pritchard: Yea, I got out.
Beanie: Cool man. Good. Glad you did. 

For some reason, Old School came to mind when I was going to write this review...why? Well, because I got the delicious cheese spatzle...

It was awesome! 

We were with a big group, 14 or 15 if I remember correctly, and they were able to give us a reservation at 8pm, or the same day! I was seriously impressed once I got to the place and saw how limited their space was.  I loved everything about the decor, throwbacks to the Cold War and Eastern Germany were great, and the table we sat in had drawers full of fun things to look at.

All in all, I loved it. The mulled wine, the potato cakes, shnitzel/spatzle and the service were all tops!
author: Kristin E.

description:
OMGOMGOMGOMG!
Dudes.  I have found the ULTIMATE WINTER COMFORT FOOD.
Get the jager schnitzel (pork that's like, pan fried) which comes with spatzle and mushroom cream sauce ALL PILED ON TOP OF EACH OTHER.
HOWEVER, substitute the jager schnitzel for the regular schnitzel (pork that's pounded and breaded; this is TASTY).
The combination is brilliant.  It's delicious spatzle underneath a crunchy and flavorful pork patty topped with DELICIOUS mushroom sauce.  
So so so good!
Get this if you want to gain like, 289,203,909 calories (and damn worth it!).
author: Meh M.

description: I thought it was better than the food we had in Germany. All our dishes, the cabbage roulade, beef roulade and mushroom based pork loin were excellent and each had a distinctive gravy. Great pickled beets and spatzel
author: Patrick K.

description:
"An Ode to AHB"...

My ex of ten years was a Germanophile. As in... 

-- Majored in German language and literature in college
-- Spoke fluent German
-- Went to school in Germany
-- Worked for a German company (ThyssenKrupp -- the mother of all German companies; the one that financed all Germany's wars; like, "HEIL, KRUPP!")
-- Frequently chose to spontaneously slip into the German language even though I speak not one word of it, obviously to illustrate that there ARE some things I don't know everything about

Anyway, I have a lot of memories of Germany, and things German. Our last moment together as pseudo-husband and wife was on a train platform in a hayfield in Frechen, Germany, outside Koln (put that in a bittersweet romantic film, why dontcha!). 

Every minute I spent in Walzwerk, I was thinking of my days in Germany. Of my days in Berlin: in Kreuzberg, especially. And, of my times with Andrew. 

Which means I will never, ever, EVER come here again. 

But... There's one thing about Walzwerk that was very UN-German.

They special-made me vegan roulades. And I'm pretty sure that would never, EVER happen in Germany. Not even in Kreuzberg.

Four stars for both the authentic, and the not-so-authentic.
author: Lisa T.

description:
I had two years of German in high school... but I can't tell you what dish I had... I can say my dinner was sehr gut - Wunderbar!  My German/Austrian freund from Munchen recommended Walzwerk when he was here on his last visit from SD. 
By 6pm, the place was bustling; they had to seat us in the quaint back room of the converted house... but we loved it.  The waitress we had was German - I know because I made Kai order for us in Deutsch- she was super attentive and sehr schon.  We order a pitcher of beer and it came with cute little glasses that were once mustard jars (Kai recognized these jars - which he said are used for Kinderbier back home!).  There were lots of other cute trinkets from deutschland that are stashed in various places - super charming!
Once we got our food, I was very pleased! I had to admit, I was afraid I'd get the fake authentic German food I've experienced in other spots I've been before.  The flavors were complex and rich in the chicken dish I had - I loved the tasty beef from Shauna's plate too. We all shared and enjoyed. 
But what did my REAL German freund Kai think?
Well, his sister is a German chef...  he said it was pretty good. 
I thought the total experience was excellent and I'm definitely a fan.
author: Micaela H.

description:
Forget the food (though it is delicious)
Forget the beer (though it is plenty)

Give me the waiter! 

What a hottie. Friendly, effervescent, and sporting an accent that takes me all the way back to my salad days in Berlin. 

Ich liebe.
author: Eric S.

description:
I came back again for a Schnitzel. It was Good, but my Boyfriend's Jagerschnitzel and Spatzel was extra yummy and delicious. So far my favorite. The Spatzel was cooked with a pleasant mouth feel and the mushroom sauce was really delicious.
They got me in and out the door in under one hour because they knew I had a time restraint. Very respectful and attentive service.
author: Kimberley M.

description:
This is what the best restaurants in the world look like. My sister will disagree, understanding a different ken of the elite cuisine scene. But for me, it comes down to a style, a great ambiance (doesn't have to be swanky, it can be hip, stylish, or interesting,) and amazingly delicious, healthy food. A great drink selection is also required. While we have never had a glass of wine at Walzwerk, it's only because their beer is so excellent. 

I just like saying it. Use the "v" sound instead of "w." Say it with me. "Walzwerk. Walzwerk. Walzwerk." Delicious.

East German food that is great for vegetarians. What? Say What? Walzwerk. Say it.

We got there, no reservation, at 6 on saturday. She looked at us, said, "no way." Totally booked for the night. We offered to eat in their awesome little nook like bar area. She said, "I'll tell you what. That table is open until 7. What do you think?" 

We took it. Ordered adroitly. Food came. We scarfed. Finished our beers, Franziskaners and Schwarzbiers. Veggie Schnitzel. What? You said veggie? What? Say What? Walzwerk. Say it! Walwerk. 

Great latkes. Tried the special asparagus soup. Awesome. Jessica tasted mint in it. Mashed Potatoes were simple and delicious. Spaetzle was delicious. Life was good. 

We left the table with a minute to spare. Sated. Ready for a happy evening no matter what. It was only 7 o'clock. 

Walzerk. No exclamation point needed.
author: micah f.

description:
Köstlich! (delicious!) 

Walzwerk is A-W-E-S-O-M-E! It's a great place to go after watching a movie on a cold day. They have tons of drinks, beer, and beer mixes (such as half beer half 7up that my boyfriend will not like me admitting that he ordered since it's not exactly that manly but he secretly enjoyed it). 

The restaurant is really small, but it's cozy and everyone that works there is friendly. The server that always helps us is hilarious and I feel as if his name should be Hans if it isn't already. 

As for the food, it tastes so good and they give massive portions. I have a soft spot for the jager schnitzel and spatzel so I don't usually order anything else. We also had the stuffed chicken dish with apples and veggies which was good also! I don't think there is anything here that isn't good!

It sounds weird but once you try it, you'll definitely get German cravings every month.
author: Maureen B.

description: Loved it. Cosy little restaurant with lots of potato-ey dishes. Everything looks and tastes yum. All the vegetarian stuff on our table was pretty awesome. Had a yummy cheesecake for dessert. Definitely going to return here for the potato pancakes and the cheesecake!
author: Aditya M.

description: Came here on a quiet evening looking to satiate my appetite for German cuisine.  Great selection of beers.  The apple strudel was excellent.  Bar tender was German (more interestingly, from the East).  Looking forward to coming here again.  Parking can be a bit of a hassle, as usual.
author: Nancy W.

description:
We had an enjoyable dinner at Walzwek. I've only been to a German restaurant once previously (the now closed Schnitzelhaus that was plagued with bad service in its last year.) I don't know too much about German food and was interested in trying this place. 

The jaeger schnitzel was tasty. The thinly sliced pork loin was breaded and cooked until tender and then smothered in a generous serving of mushroom gravy and served on a bed of fresh potato spaetzle (small noodles). Everything else I sampled was also delicious. My friend's chicken, stuffed with apples and bacon, was the right balance of savory and sweet. The portions were huge. I think there was a vegetarian option on the menu, but honestly I couldn't tell you. 

The place feels like a converted one-bedroom flat -- small but cozy, a mismatch of tables and chairs, retro German posters and album covers and other tschotskies decorate the walls. The waitstaff is friendly and attentive. The drink menu is mainly centered around a good variety of beer.
author: Joel A.

description:
Looking up the word "hearty" in the dictionary may bring up a photo of Walzwerk. I highly recommend being very hungry when you have dinner here.

We went in not knowing what to expect, and came out totally comforted by the wide range of fullfilling foods and beer. And what a fun spot with friends, we only wish we had more people to share it with.

Started out with the Potato Pancakes with sourcream and applesauce.
Then ventured to 2 different specials; the cheese Spatzel and Salmon (really delicious with the vegetables and 2 different cabbages) and the trout dish. 

I can't wait for my our next dinner here, already have my eyes on that Beefe Roulade, Schnitzel and the different Bratwursts.

It can be a bit crowded and we were lucky enough to get a table within a half hour. Next time we'll plan on going early, which will then give us enough time to enjoy the food even more.
author: Mickey A.

description: This restaurant has the worst staff in the city. Not only did one of them scream at me but no one else working intervened. No one said sorry. No one took money off my order. Horrible horrible absolutely horrible. Never ever go here. I was so disturbed by this service that I had to write two reviews. I know have a bad taste in my mouth for german food because of that woman.
author: Ana V.

description: Been there twice and scored parking close by.  The food is a bit different from my other experience with German food at Suppenkuche, but still very good.  Had the Jaeger Schnitzel and a couple Kostritzers.  Very good.  The second time I went there was to have couple of Kostrizers.  Very good service, food, prices and not very loud at all.
author: D M.

description:
We usually go to Schnitzelhaus; but, last Friday, they stopped taking names at 8:15.  We like Schnitzelhaus and have never had problems getting a table - but it was Friday...oh well.  We moved on to Suppenkuche in Hayes Valley.  Horrible attitudes there!  I asked whether we could be seated at all that night.  The completely distracted and angry host snapped back:  "I'm not taking any names right now but if you want, you can come back in 20 minutes to see if I am."  No, thanks...I don't need to give you my money that badly.

Last stop was Walzwerk.  Food is good and service is even better!  The staff at Walzwerk make the experience completely worthwhile.  I loved that they had vegan options and enjoyed trying a different regional take on German food.

I will definitely be back.
author: Tone C.

description:
I have little to add to my prior review.  However, I went to Walzwerk last night with Poe, and we both had the jaegerschnitzel and 2 German beers, and it was fantastic.  I ate all of mine and 1/3 of hers (the jaegerschnitzel, perverts!  Get your mind out the gutter), and I was so gloriously stuffed, I had no choice but to go out for more beers.

I love Walzwerk.  Totally love the place.  I love eating my jaegerschitzel beneath giant posters of Marx, Stalin, and Lenin.  Mostly I just love their jaegerschnitzel.  I'd probably eat it beneath any poster at all.
author: Joe C.

description:
I went here with a bunch of guys from Germany for my birthday and they all said it was very authentic East German in terms of decor and food. It wasn't gourmet German food, just very good food like you'd have at your family's house for a holiday.  We were a big group and they did a good job accommodating us. Although their neighbors are kinda close so if you get too rambunctious you'll get shushed.

Favorite stuff on the menu:

Spätzle
Potato Pancakes
Herring stuff

Clearly I don't speak German but I'll eat the hell out of Walzwerk's food. Although the pork was kinda dry which I've heard from other people who have eaten there so probably best to avoid. They also have digestiv stuff called underberg. This stuff is horrible, don't let your friends convince you to drink it or, like in my case, 5 of them. *shudder
author: rob. l.

description:
It's a little East Village, a lot East Berlin.

In my book, Walzwerk is the coolest restaurant in San Francisco.

When you walk in, there is a definite buzz to the place - people are engrossed in conversation, food is coming out on steaming hot plates, and drinks are going down at a rapid clip.  There are no kitten heels or cosmos in sight.  The decor is a delightful hodgepodge of all things German, from propoganda posters to kitchy accessories.  Tables are mix and match, just like the eclectic clientele who loyally keep the restaurant busy every night.

First, start with one of their many delicious beers - my husband likes the Optimator, while I prefer the amber.  You can't go wrong with a Weisse beer on a summer day - I can't think of anything more refreshing.

For appetizers, the potato pancakes are wonderful - thick and hearty, with sour cream and applesauce on the side.  Big enough to share, if you're feeling generous.  

The house-cured salmon is also lovely, with triangles of brown bread and a big bowl of beets on the side.

The soljanka soup is a real treat - a mix of pickled vegetables in a nice broth with bits of sausage thrown in - warms you up instantly and has a sour/savory flavor that is unique and very tasty.

For dinner, be sure to check the specials menu, because you can't go wrong with one of the fresh fish or pork selections.

Favorites from the regular menu include:  Jaeger Schnitzel with Creamy Mushroom Sauce, Sauerbraten (Marinated Beef), Breast of Chicken stuffed with Apples & Bacon, Roast Pork.    If sausages are your thing, of course there is a great selection of those as well.

**Vegetarians please note:  the Vegitarian Schnitzel is really good - a must-try!**

Desserts:  Love the Cold Dog - layers and layers of cake & chocolate - almost a cross between a cake & a cookie, and the Apple Strudel is very good, too.  Again, there are usually specials such as cheesecake and chocolate pudding - all excellent.

Even if you don't think you like German food, give Walzwerk a try.  In its very straightforward approach to both its service and its cuisine, it is sure to charm you.
author: Liz S.

description:
Great food and service. Perfect for a date or a casual hangout. Another one of The Mission's gems. Try the potato soup! 

Overheard a guest call the fare "soul food for the white kids." 

See for yourself.
author: Ashley K.

description:
Are you facing a harsh East German winter? Would you like to induce a food coma so deep that you hibernate through months of bleakness and awaken when it's lederhosen weather again? Walzwerk is your place. 

Dining here was a milestone in my history of dining out for these reasons: 
1. I have never been so full after a meal, and
2. They serve the best mashed potatoes I have ever tasted.

The food is hearty and heavy and surprisingly vegetarian-friendly. The vegetables in my vegetarian schnitzel were a little tough, but they were bathed in a creamy, delicious pea sauce and accompanied by the anything-but-dull mashed potatoes. They were complex, with hints of lemon and butter and garlic and some kind of sweetness. Add a melt-in-your-mouth consistency and there you have it---potato perfection. 

The decor is folksy East German kitchen, which fits, because the place is barely bigger than a kitchen.  The Massive Attack album that played throughout dinner? Didn't fit so much. The service was efficient but not overly friendly. Great selection of beer served in big steins (mine was chipped, but I guess it made it seem more like someone's mom's kitchen.)

A hidden benefit of eating here? You won't be hungry for another 24 hours.  Add beer to your bountiful meal and you'll be down for the count.
author: Tamara B.

description:
Step through the iron curtain (Walzwerk's front door) and arrive magically back in time to East Germany, the DDR. You may ask yourself, why would one step back in time to a land of socialists who lived a meager existence under a harsh regime? To a time when the Stazi invoked fear, and East German women swimmers were systematically juiced on steroids. Because Walzwerk is the opposite of the dreary iron curtain East Germany days of old. 

Walzwerk has a fun atmosphere, great service, and very enjoyable food. As you walk through door your eyes will be drawn to the fun East German paraphernalia placed around the restaurant, and you will be greeted by a very friendly German waitress. This was my first trip to Walzwerk, so I decided to try one of their specials - a pork loin wrapped with bacon around the outside, and served with mashed potatoes. Like most German food, this was heavy, but good. Food probably a 3.5, but the experience and uniqueness of this place deserves an extra 1/2 star. Overall, a very pleasant experience.
author: Gregory C.

description:
Im German and I live in LA. Im also not going to b!t@h about the location. Ive eaten here and suppenkuche several times, which is also good. 

The place has a special barren WW2 German bomber hanger charm. The food is good, and the beer selection is good. Its not the "best ever" but I certainly enjoy it. Def worth the visit if youre wanting gutes essen.
author: Eric A.

description:
My bet for best German in this town, and the atmosphere is much more personal. It's run by two sisters, who also work the room, and you can tell they have a deep passion for their food and their customers.

The potato pancakes are perfect, with a dollop of sour cream and apples sauce on the side. For entrees, the shnitzels are a must try, and the vegetarian one (according to my friends I've eaten here with) is really something special. Someway say sausages? Another specialty done right.

It's a tight space, but there is a small bar and lounge to wait for your reservation. Oh, of course you'll have some fine German brew to keep you occupied.
author: Nish N.

description:
Yelp was right on:
- totally authentic, fresh, delicious
- large portions
- not a lot for non-mammal-eaters but there's the veggie schnitzel, always a good fish special (tonight: rainbow trout stuffed w/ spinach), apps - smoked salmon, pickled herring w/ creamy dill sauce, potato latkes which are mashed vs grated, etc.
- spaetzel is caramelized sauteed
- more limited beer menu but good ones
- not as bustling/social as Suppenkuche but nice, simple Eastern Block design/vibe. :)
- very friendly Deutscher staff
author: Melanie C.

description:
IT'S OST-ERRIFIC!

I don't know why I like German food so much. (I'm Jewish, after all!)  

But I've been to Munich and just last year, Berlin, and I just have to say: German food is awesome!

OK, it isn't terribly diverse.  There's a lot of meat and carbs.  Vegetables are sauerkraut and... sauerkraut.

Walzwerk reminded me how much I enjoy it, all in a nicely DDR-styled restaurant in a nicely DDR-styled part of the Mission (i.e., industrial South Van Ness).

The two things I tried were great: The Jager Schnitzel (breaded/fried pork cutlet) in a mushroom sauce on spatzle, and a surprisingly tender and flavorful beef roulade, which came with spatzle and red cabbage sauerkraut.  The sauerkraut was especially good, mildly sweet with a carraway flavor, bringing back memories of Berlin.  

I'd definitely go back.  Now if anyone can find a source of schweinhaxn in this area, I'd be set.

PS The Weltenberg Amber beer will knock you on your butt if you're a lightweight like me.

PPS  I'll be a little sad when they phase out incandescent bulbs, because this is the kind of place that should be lit by bare, low-wattage lightbulbs.

PPPS Yeah, I know, Ashkenazi Jewish food is just German and Polish food without the pork.
author: Daniel S.

description:
I was a Teutonic knight in a former life so Walzwerk beckons to something strong in my DNA.  I like the feeling of the place and the East German decor; makes me keep checking over my shoulder for Stasi informants in bad moustaches.  Walzwerk is definitely something different and should be lauded for this.

I haven't found another place where you can find a Berliner Weisse (mit Gruen or Rot) in SF  (update: Suppenkuche also has the Berliner Weisse).  It's basically a somewhat sourish beer with a shot of woodruff or raspberry.  Google "Berliner Weisse" for a more thorough explanation on the drink.  If you go here, you should definitely try one.  

The one thing that soured me a bit on this place was when, before my first visit, we tried to make reservations for 6.  We were told that they do take reservations but wanted to keep some tables open for walk-ins.  

Um, ok.

We still went and had a good time although we had to wait 45 min. for a table and that was annoying.  I don't know if it was a miscommunication but it seems like an odd way to handle things.  

On the grand scale, however, I've seen much, much stranger things during my time living in Germany but I'll save those for when Yelp Deutschland goes live.
author: Steve B.

description:
most mouth watering, home-cooked, intoxicating, orgasmic food ever. stuffed tri-tip with orgasm sauce on top and my girlfriend got stuffed chicken with cherry sauce. damn this place is good.
doesn't take reservations for parties less than 4 and get there around 5-530 to get a seat. 
this is a must try in the city.
author: Daniel C.

description:
First off, I must say that you cannot enjoy a German meal if you are having the worst allergies of your life (aka dripping faucet).  Flavors are what make the food interesting.

Second, I was worried initially that I wasn't going to get a fully balanced meal (I recall an earlier German meal where I felt stuffed with meat), but here at Walzwerk, they really balance the meat with vegetables and carbs.

You must try the spaetzle.  I personally am an melted cheese hater.  However, there is only a hint of cheese that adds to the flavor.

Try the cold dog for dessert.  It's not meat, trust me.

Walzwerk also sponsored the closing reception for the German Film Festival.  And I must say, those servers even as tired as they were...are always constantly cheery.  Not to the line of insane, mind you.  They are truly not American.  During my last meal at Walzwerk, our server said, "Bon Appetit" after bringing us our dishes.  Isn't that French?  But regardless, the service was rather good.

I have stopped being adventurous in German meat.  My friends however really like their dishes.  I ordered the americanized dishes--Christmas goose and breast of chicken.  They both had a nice German twist, adding fruit.

Cannot comment on the alcohol, but my friends really enjoyed it.  The non-alcoholic drinks are rather interesting although plain.  Half-7up and half-coke was one drink that was interesting.

The restaurant is nicely decorated with German paraphernalia.  Prices are reasonable.  Most dishes are around $14.

You need to be slightly adventurous to come here.  They can be accommodating of large groups--there's a big room in the back for larger tables.  But I will always love the spaetzle.
author: Jenn N.

description:
I will give it a 4.5 stars. The waiters speak German and know the items well (there arent many choices on the menu anyways). I would recommend anything they recommend. The roast goose with cranberry sauce just tastes so amazing! They also offers good beet soup, and the mash potatoes, soooooooo yummy. 

The restaurant only has something between 7-8 tables so it offers a degree of coziness and privacy. There are also lovely East German posters hanging on the wall. Great restaurant in a quiet part of SF overall.
author: Carrie S.

description:
The vegetarian schnitzel was quite good although I was particular taken over by the "sides" (browned cauliflowers w/ cheese and creamy mash potatoes).  

The potato pancakes appetizer was perfectly browned but at the same time moist.  The only bad thing with it is that there were only 3 very small cakes ;-)

I am definitely heading back for the vegetarian cabbage roulade.  And oh, btw, my friends couldn't stop talking about their regular schnitzel either.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
Came here last Friday for dinner with a couple of my college pals.  We were looking for a warm, cozy place with good, filling food and drinks (a la Suppenkuche, but with better parking options) to do a little catch up session.  Walzwerk partly delivered, but in other aspects, we were a bit disappointed.  

Let's start with the environs.  Not as cute and cozy as Suppenkuche (I love the little back room/nook area at Suppenkuche!), but not terrible either.  This is a East German restaurant, and given the rather non-descript block on S. Van Ness where it's located, the slightly industrial decor fit in quite nicely, actually.  3 stars.

Next, the food.  We shared the matjes herring appetizer (pickled herring in sour cream w/ apples, onions, pickles, and served w/ pumpernickel bread) - very good and tasted surprisingly un-fishy.  The garlic roast pork w/ potatoes & vegetables entree - also quite tasty.  4 stars.

The BEST thing about this place is the beer.  For those who like a medium-bodied beer, get the Kostritzer Schwarzbier.  It looks heavy like a stout, but tastes like an amber.  The Franziskaner Hefeweizen is a good choice, too, if you're looking for something refreshing.  4 stars.

The WORST thing about this place is the service.  I realize it was a Friday night and they have limited seating.  However, please try not to make it too-too obvious that you're trying to kick us out.  Restaurants hoping to have returning clients let their clients take their time eating, even when there are other people waiting for a table.  Stopping by every 15 mins to ask to clear our plates is annoying, but not exceedingly rude.  Stopping by to say: "You're welcome to stay if you order dessert, otherwise I'm going to have to kick you out" is discourteous and highly offensive.  Following up with: "I know I'll get a bad tip, but I don't care" just adds further insult.  1 star.

Average total for Walzwerk: 3 stars
author: Annie W.

description:
Walzwerk was one of the more stereotypical SF dining experiences I've had in a while: a tiny place on a mostly non-commercial block serving obscure cuisine that attracts far more people than it can serve.

With 4 people you can make a reservation, which turned out to be a good call for Friday night.  Even so, we could only get one for 8:00, so I was mighty hungry already, and while we were seated fairly quickly, I think there was a mix-up because they didn't take our order for like 20 minutes.  Or maybe the kitchen was backed up?  Even so, they should have taken our drink orders, that at least would have helped me from going into a low-blood-sugar coma.

But all was forgiven when the food finally came.  This is comfort cuisine of the highest order, and is quite reminiscent of classic Americana dishes.  Like spaetzle, probably the best incarnation ever of mac & cheese.  Or the mushroom-gravy goodness of the jager schnitzel.  Or the stuffed chicken with cherries and the most mouth-watering mashed potatoes.

Equally mind-blowing are the drinks.  I tried the Diesel (half beer half coke), and, considering it sounds like it'd be gross, it's amazingly good.  I think I'll have to start offering it at cocktail parties.  Unfortunately, the slow service didn't leave us with time for dessert, which is too bad because I was really curious about the "cold dog".

So Walwerk may not be the most convenient place to eat in town, but with German your options are pretty limited, and the food here is easily worth it.  And at least it's easier to get a table here than at Suppenkuche (where you need 6 to get a reservation and multi-hour waits are the norm on weekends).
author: Wes M.

description:
I went here yrs ago and wasn't that into it... but I've changed my mind.

Went with a big group last night and sat in the back room. The family style servings and atmosphere felt like a German Thanksgiving. There was sooo much food. There must have been 10 take out boxes we left with,
The beer, mashed potatoes, spaetzle, veggies, chicken, shnitzel- all delish. I'm not sure how hard it was to get the reservation in the back room, but it was perfect for privacy.
I love Suppenkuche, but I'm bringing this into the German rotation.
author: Nicole L.

description:
I STILL haven't shut up about how good this food was. (I love sauerkraut!) The beef roulade was not nearly as good as homemade I've had but the jagerschnitzel was phenomenal! The gluhwein was very nice, though I should've saved it for dessert. Speaking of which, the apfelstrudel is lovely as was the Christmas Plate of cookies (but you MUST have coffee with the latter!) (I love sauerkraut!) The service is typical German-- no extra pleasantries to speak of. 

Yesterday I called and left a message requesting a reservation for four for this evening and I received a call back saying they were SO full and there's no way they could spare a table. (I love sauerkraut!) I had no idea how small this place actually is, but we walked in and were seated immediately (and there was at least one additional available table!) So even if they claim reservations are unavailable, you might want to take your chances. They sure made a lot of money from my willingness to do so!

It was perhaps the most unhealthy meal I've eaten in a very VERY long time, but boy was it worth it! I felt right at home with all these tall beautiful German women. Oh, and I love sauerkraut. I would marry it if I could.
author: Jen S.

description:
I've had the pleasure to know many a German in my travels.  Their food tends to be like their sense of humor; sour and very dry. But I'm generalizing, I know.

Walzwerk is exactly what it's intended to be, hearty East German chow for mission hipsters...and I'm learning to hate mission hipsters more and more every day.  Grow up, fools.

Anyway, at least the food is authentic (as far as I can tell) and the wait staff is super nice, and tall!! Holy cow, I've never seen such tall people in my life. 

+1 star --- Huge portraits of Karl Marx and Frederick Engels adorn the walls. I loves me some good bourgeoisie hating propaganda. Ain't no bitch going to control John T's means of production and exchange.

Vier Sterne.
author: John T.

description:
I was a little excited about coming to this place.  I have a German brother-in-law ("the BIL") and of all the menus I've seen from the various German places around town, this menu had the most dishes that the BIL has cooked for my family.  My sister and her family have since moved far away and I don't get to come over to their German meals anymore, so this made me think of them.

I ordered the jager schnitzel.  The boyfriend ordered the sauerbraten.  The BIL has made both dishes multiple times, in fact every Christmas we have sauerbraten as our Christmas meal.  That's right every year for the past 11 years for Christmas my Viet family would gather around a table and eat sauerbraten.  Anyhow, our dishes came out and mine was fantastic, but there wasn't that much.  I gobbled that thing up quickly.  I rarely finish my meal.  I'm also never the first person to finish my meal.  I not only finished my meal first but I ate it all.  There's something off here.  The saurebraten didn't really taste like the BIL (or his mom's, who came over from Germany one year for Xmas and cooked it for us).  It was a bit more tomatoey than what I'm used to.  I'm not sure what's "more authentic" but since both the BIL has the thickest German accent that after 11 years I still sometimes have trouble understanding him, and his mother who still lives in Germany's didn't quite taste like this I'm going to go with them.  That's fine though, it was still fine tasting, although the dish could have used more kartoffelkloesse (potato dumplings, see, I know what I'm talking about here!)  They only gave the boyfriend 2, which is definitely not enough starch for this beef dish.

While the food was pretty good (although again, portions were woefully small) what makes me not want to come back here was the service.  I get it, it was busy, and there's only 2 of you...but when we ask you to get us our bill and you don't and then proceed to avoid all eye contact with us until the other waitress feels bad and comes over with it, there's a problem.  We waited 20 minutes before we even asked the bill, and then waited another 10 minutes before we got it.  Absolutely unacceptable.  The BIL and his mother would be embarrassed if they knew about this.
author: Quynh-An P.

description:
So, I recently went here for the first time with the family to celebrate my 40th birthday...while turning 40 is a whole 'nother story, this review's all about Walzwerk...

First off, I enjoyed the best jagerschnitzel (on a bed of spatzle) of my life there...I came in hungry and scarfed that meal down like it done me wrong! The spezi I enjoyed with my meal was made with coke and sprite (as opposed to orangina), and was not nearly as good as the one they serve up at other German restaurants, but it was still good.

The decor of the restaurant was cool, and I totally dug the spartan look and feel of the dining room and tables. The bathroom and back area of the restaurant is adorned with some interesting German memorabilia, and the little bar area is pretty sweet!

I give this place four stars (as opposed to five) for two reasons:

- It is a 'no frills' type of restaurant...you do not get a salad or bread with your meal (unlike other German restaurants).

- Since I was starving I ordered a salad before my meal, but the staff forgot about my order and I had to ask for it again...while I was eating my meal. This wouldn't be a s big of a deal if the restaurant was full and the staff was busy, but the restaurant was practically empty.

Despite these shortcomings, I would totally go back here again, but Suppenkuche still holds the spot as my favorite German restaurant in the city.
author: Art D.

description:
My experience  was akin to Omid T's.  Though due to my southern upbringing, I was taken aback by some  of the...ur...German hospitalities.  

Me: "Hi I'm waiting to meet my fr...."

German waitress: "She isn't eya. You.  Vait over zere."  (points her finger over to a dark, scary unlit nook.)

So sat I did in that scary nook by myself until my friend rescued me. And then we sat down for ordering.

Me: "Do you have any recommendations?"

GW: "You vill haf dee chicken, ya"

Me: "uhhh...I was thinking of something other than chi..."

GW: "You vill haf dee chicken"

Me: "Okay" (cowering)

The food all in all was pretty good (with our chicken, we ordered the cabbage salad and spaetzle), but I'm not so accustomed to eastern German food.  A little too heavy for me.  Next time, I will have to try the potato pancake and vegetarian schnitzel.  

I will be firm.  I will be firm.  I will be firm.
author: Melissa S.

description:
Overrated and past its prime, just like communism itself.

The service is authentically European, which is not a compliment.  There is no reason to feel guilty for leaving a European-style tip here (ie: 0-10%).

It does win points for ambiance (very authentic East Berlin) and making decent, but not great, German food.  Schnitzelhaus and Suppenkuche are both far superior.
author: Doctor L.

description:
Four words: GO TO SUPPENKUCHE INSTEAD.

There was only one server on that Monday night that we went so she asked us to help set up the table w/ her. Weird? Just a little considering we called in for a reservation for 10 so she should have had it ready for us upon our arrival.

Anyway, the food was mediocre. Chicken was dry, spatzel was okay, beef was okay. Overall, it was just OKAY. Their potato pancakes were pretty delicious though, I must give that 5 stars. But everything else was OKAY. 

Suppenkuche is 10 times better. It's on the corner of Hayes and Laguna. Go there instead! :)
author: Heidi C.

description:
Love love love this place.  Great Shnitzel. Great drinks. Great cozy, cute decor. Wonderful, attractive, attentive and sweet staff.  It's like walking into Eastern Germany.

Go here. You'll eat your schnitzel and like it!
author: Matthew R.

description:
I can't rave enough about this place! Before I went there, the only German restaurant I had been to was Suppenkuche and no doubt it was good but expensive...but after having dined at Walzwerk...I'm now an official Walzwerk fan!

My experience was all positive! Not too long of a wait (unlike Suppenkuche) got seated in about 10-15 minutes on a Friday night without reservation...totally cool!

When my buddy and I got seated...we got the best seat in the house...sitting at the bar, eating, drinking and watching all the behind the scene waitstaff action and conversation which provided us with hours of fun and delight.

Back to the food...AMAZING! I'm always a sucker for grilled pork chops and that was on the today's specials menu and naturally I ordered it. The pork chops were cooked to perfection...tender, juicy, and packed with wonderful flavors topped with some homemade apple-cherry (I think) sauce. The dish also came with steamed green beans and potatoes. Every bite I took was just orgasmic...I think I may have freaked my buddy out a little when I made those oohs and aahs noises while I was enjoying my food. 

Oh before the main course, we ordered an appetizer and some delicious beer. We had the Herring in Sour Cream with all the goodies and served with Pumpernickel Bread. We didn't know what to expect as neither of us had it before but WOW...it was GOOD! Creamy and yummy!

As far as the beer is concerned...I am usually a lightweight but as the saying goes...when in Rome do as the Romans do...similarly when in a German restaurant do as the Germans do...I ordered myself a beer...a tall glass of Radeberger Pilsner. It was almost as tall as my torso and it was 0.5 liter. Low and behold, this lightweight (i.e. me) downed it completely...though it took me a couple of hours to do so.

Last but not least, the service was excellent! The waitstaff was attentive, friendly and fun! And the menu items were reasonably priced.

I can't wait to go back and have myself a plate of Schnitzel with Mashed Potatoes & Seasonal Vegetables (that's what my buddy ordered and I had tasted it and it was also very good!)
author: Jen L.

description:
Wow - amazing German food. 

The potato pancakes - YES! Crispy on the outside, hot and mealy on the inside, with sour cream, chives, and apple sauce. 

Beef roulade - tri tip with pickles, bacon, and onions - served with red cabbage and spatzle. YUM! The tri tip was a little tough (hard to chew and cut) but the flavor was amazing.

Thuringer Bratwurst with sauerkraut and mashed potatoes - a bite of the three combined while dipped in the mustard is so delightful to the senses. 

Schnitzel (made with pork) - I tried a bite of my friend's - it was so light on the palate, yet fried, yet tender - yikes! So good!

I love the decor, the tiny venue (in the middle of a rather dirty neighborhood, but I digress), and the beers (the hefe on tap is light and delicious).

Must..eat..more!
author: Katherine P.

description: Food is ok but service is extremely slow and unattentive. Waited 35 minutes for food and had to ask for check twice. Decor is fun and super kitschy- bare light bulbs, red hue, Lenin portrait on the wall (by design, East Berlin themed). Acoustics are poor - you can't really have a conversation without consciously elevating your voice. But adds to the feel of the place. Worth a try for the experience if not the food.
author: Gavin T.

description:
Tom nailed it.  You come here because it's unlike everywhere else.  Because German food will NEVER become popular, ever.  Because Sex in the City types do not say, "Let's go to that schnitzel haus, and then we can go to my place."   

And that's cool.  

Other reasons to love it: it's owned by two East German ladies.  Incredible collection of E. German knickknacks -- of which some asshole ripped off at some point -- and a cool crowd of German dudes talking in low voices, perhaps planning something, something nefarious, as they cradle good beers.

The green -- I call it "Mentos" -- beer: you try it, you don't love it, but you must say you tried it.    It's another definitive SF spot.
author: ed y.

description:
Not much to add to the 246 reviews before me except to re-affirm the majority. 

Cozy if not a bit cramped quarters with a good range of German dishes (not just schnitzel and wurst). Staff was very warm and accommodating (the true testing being dealing with our children bouncing off the walls). 

Koestritzer black beer is a must to try. I was impressed that they even had a good selection of German and Austrian red wines: you don't see that around very often.

Much better than Suppenkuche by a long shot.
author: David P.

description: I wasn't overly impressed.  Everyone I was with loved their meals but I thought between the service and food the experience was just okay.  The roulade was a bit tough and I gotta be honest I like my South American mother's version of it better.  The potato pancake was excellent I must say.  I felt like while the waitress was really nice we were a bit neglected.  We were there at opening time too.  I hate to say it but suppenkuche is more of my cup of tea.  I would try it again though.  Might have been an off night.
author: Kirsten M.

description:
Having spent time in my youth having a wonderful german restaurant down the hill from my house I have been spoiled by good german food.  In Seattle we found absolutely none of it, including in a town called little bavaria.

We were pleased to see San Francisco had many german establishments that seemed to get good reviews.  First we ate at Suppenkuche, which was great and then we ate at Walzwerk which was also great for a whole different set of reasons.

Suppenkuche is the "hot-spot" for german food in the city (read: full of pretentious, noisy, annoying people). We liken Walzwerk to more of a homey intimate location where equally delicious food is served.

We had pickled herring (in the sour cream dressing with pickles, apples, and onions).  ALso potato pancakes, jagerschnitzel and one of their specials (honey-beer braised short ribs with butternut squash puree and mashed potatoes).

It was all very delicious, it was more akin to what you'd find in a common country german home, as opposed to Suppenkuche more beer pub upscale world.

It's also quite a bit cheaper that Suppenkuche.  Overall a great dining experience for an intimate night out with a significant other or a small friend gathering (didn't look like they could make a table for more than 6 easily).
author: Josh I.

description: Yum! You just got try it. This sure beats the routine of hitting up some joint on Valencia & 16th. And save room for dessert! They're only 5 bucks!!! What a Sweeeeet Deal!
author: Lisa R.

description:
Wunderschön!

I took my friends out to dinner the other night and was blow away by this charming, inviting place. The staff here are amazing, the inside of the building is cozy, like a family kitchen. They have a decent selection of german beers and the food...well it's amazing. We tried:
Potato Pancakes
Trout
Two kinds of Schnitzel
and strudel for dessert 

I personally ate the schnitzel and I ate everything on my plate. It was a lot of food but I couldn't stop. If I still lived in the city, I would be here all the time, it's just what I love about dining in here. It's cozy, perfect place to bring family or friends, everyone is happy and the food is amazing! Don't miss out on this place. Get here!
author: Erik U.

description:
Bf and I showed up promptly at 5:30, when dinner starts. The friendly waitress gave us a window table, probably the best seats, because it's a small restaurant, and kind of dingy the further in you go. (Interesting decor, too--look for the pictures of Marx, Engels, and Lenin on the wall.)

They started us off with an amuse-bouche that seemed to be thin slices of cucumber and sausage and cream cheese on pumpernickel. Good drinks, as everyone has mentioned--we went with the amber and the diesel. The entrees impressed me, as I'd had a bad impression of German food. Yelpers seem to like the jager schnitzel and the chicken breast, so we got those. I see on the menu that the schnitzel is supposed to come with a mushroom sauce, but there wasn't any, which struck us as odd at the time because it was a very dry meal (there were mashed potatoes on the side, also sauceless, still delicious but evidently they could have been more delicious). It tasted fine, but I'm taking off a star for this pretty egregious omission. I loved the chicken though, which did come with sauce.

Finished off the meal with the red berry pudding, which struck the right balance between fruit-ily tart and sweet. We used a $25 coupon from restaurant.com, which brought the total to $37. I wish I could give this place 4 stars, but nobody should have to eat so much dry meat and potatoes.
author: Angela X.

description:
Well, I've been wanting to check out Walzwerk for like seven years and all i can say is that it was worth the long delay although I'm kicking myself for not having tried it out sooner.  The best German food that I've had although the other stuff I've had has been in Germany (as a snotty high schooler), Columbus, GA (also in high school) and Suppenkuche here in SF.

Anyhow the food, staff and decor at Walzwerk is all top notch.  It can get crowded but that's for a reason.  I had dinner with my friend Jeanene there last night and ran into my friend Joshua who recommended the Jager Schnitzel which I had and was delish.  The potato cakes (forgot the correct name) were a great starter and we also shared some butternut squash soup.  All around amazing food, served by authentic (we checked the tags) Germans, and of course great beers to compliment it all.

Overall it's one of my favorite restaurants in SF after one visit and there will surely be more!
author: Gene X.

description:
Great food, great dining experience, and it won't break the bank.  I went here with a group of seven friends and the service's excellence was only surpassed by the food.  Arriving late with my partner we ordered one dish to split between us.  Without us asking they were kind enough to split the dish in half - very sweet!

I had the Schnitzel, as it was my first time, but tried my friend's Jäger Schnitzel which I will definitely get when I return.  The desserts were also well worth it.  People tell me it's very authentic German.  I can't say whether that is true, but who cares!  The food is amazing.

Highly recommended!!!!!
author: Niki B.

description:
Although one might be scared by walking into what may be a building with a few relics left of the DDR, we were warmly welcomed (well, as warmly as form East Germans can welcome people) by the people who run the restaurant.  Looking around you see bits and pieces that were obviously brought over from East Germany.  My favorite being the DDR Kuch Buch and the signs saying "You are now leaving the American Sector."    Reminded me of that horrible Anthony Edward film, "Gotcha".   But I digress....

Wait was quoted at 45 minutes(as there was a private party in the back room) but we were able to order beer/wine from the bar and wait.  We were only waiting about 20 minutes when a 5-top opened and were told that we could sit immediately if we didn't mind sharing.  Why not, it's so HB Haus-esque! :-P

Started off with potato pancakes (traditionally served with sour cream and applesauce) and had the chicken stuffed with apples and onions, served with mashed potatoes and steamed vegetables.  Service was good and efficient (so German!) and the food was excellent.  Very much comfort food.  The people who were running the restaurant were also very friendly!

Prices were decent, definitely cheaper than Suppenkuche and the food was just as good!

Looking forward to coming back to this place! Jawohl!!
author: Melanie N.

description:
I want to give this place five stars but it's been pointed out to me that I give a lot of places five stars, and it might be ruining my credibility. What can I say? I like things. 

This was a find born of Yelp searching and a desire to see and experience new places, and I'm glad I found it. From the second I walked in I felt like this place was something special. That comes from authentic (sounding) Germans working there, a young staff who all seemed to have a stake in the business, not just a job, and from the location - we sat in the former living room of a converted house. With a nice table by the window great for watching the crowds roll in, this made for a pleasant evening. 

Our food - a crusted fish on my date's part, and apple and bacon stuffed chicken was good if not great, and ridiculously ample portions, hence my willingness to take it down a star. Definitely a meat and potatoes based menu. They had a reasonably impressive beer selection for such a small space, but overall it was more about the ambiance and workers than it was about the food itself. Thoroughly enjoyed and I will be back.
author: Ian M.

description:
Probably as dang authentic as you're going to get, Walzwerk is delicious and easier to get into than Suppenkuche. 

Now, granted, I was there on a Tuesday at roughly 5:30 with my friend Mike, but it was all around satisfying and beat the winter chills away with a heavy spike tipped bat. I had a craving for rib-sticking comfort food, and nobody really does that better than the Germans. 

First up, a little amuse of rye bread topped with salumi...I don't know what the German word for cold cuts is, and a light cheese w/ some veg. Mmmm...good start. 

Onto potato pancake appetizer-which is more than enough for a small meal for the less ravenous of the people out there. Three 3" diameter, hockey pucks of mashed potato-crispy on the outside, squashy on in the inside-with chives, sour cream and applesauce. 

Then the main event, for me at least, JAGERSCHNIZEL. 

Crispy fried pork loin. Breaded, seasoned, crispy, delicious. But wait, it gets better...paired with a mushroom cream sauce and SPAEZTLE. Little dumplings of fluffy joy. And the best part? Some of the spaeztle had been fried in butter prior to being added to the cream sauce. So they were crispy fluffy joy buttons. Yes, it's a heart attack waiting to happen. Give me a friggin break, I'm all of 28. I can handle it. Plus, when again in my lifetime am I going to get to fully enjoy the delights of this kind of food? don't hate. 

Mike gets the sauerbraten-of which all is quite good, but i cannot stop taking little nibbles of his sweet braised cabbage-which seems to have cinnamon spice and possibly apples or onions added to it. It's like dessert cabbage. 

We split the apple tart. Round it out with an order of Elderberry soda and coke (by the way, they also do beer mixed with coke, which must be a European thing). Neither of us drink beer so we cannot attest to the accuracy of the beer/wine list. We waddle out the door, fully and completely satiated, into the darkness of night. Check out the back room for the kitche and posters.
author: Alexis W.

description:
They have vegetarian schnitzel here. While I am practically the bloodthirstiest carnivore I know, I find the vegetarian schnitzel thing pretty impressive. 

We tried to go to Ritespot last night (evidently Patrick M. got cruised TWICE on his walk over there, once with the classiest pickup line of all time: "You got a pretty little mouth") but it was closed. Thank goodness, or I would still have never had Walzwerk's jagerschnitzel (a king amongst schnitzels--it comes bathed in a mushroom sauce). I didn't even make it through half of the enormous serving, though this may have had more to do with my ferocious, and unintentional, all-coffee-all-the-time regimen. 

Anyway, to sum up Walzwerk: delicious food, typical prices ($25 with tax and tip for the huge jagerschnitzel and a delicious amber beer), less crowded than Suppenkuche, and a lot like eating in someone's grandma's kitchen.
author: J N.

description:
The food was pretty good here. Especially the main course: excellent jager schnitzel and sauerbraten. The potato pancakes were too doughy for my taste and the beet soup was very average. It could have used some embellishment. But I suppose that's part of the charm of this place: it's stripped down East German asceticism. Great German beer on tap. 

But the service left a lot to be desired. In fact the service just sucked, some of the worst I've had in this town. There's just this  "Oh, I guess I'll serve you" too-cool for school vibe among the wait staff. If you're in the club, you're cool, if you're not, whatever. They brought a beer to our table almost 15 minutes after we asked for it and no apologies. That wasn't cool. 

If I had to pick between Walzwerk and Suppenkuche, I'd pick the later one. Better service, better appetizers, about equal on the main courses. Actually, no, Suppenkuche makes the best spatzle I've ever had.
author: Andy S.

description: Not a place I could get very excited about.
author: Miriam W.

description:
Four stars with the caveat of all four stars being German. Die sterne, okay?

A sign on the door warns you that you're leaving the United States, and that's about right. The first thing I saw upon entering was Bitburger, as in the German beer. It made me feel instantly at home. And this despite the fact that I'm not exactly a Germanophile.
