The beer menu isn't extensive. A pilsner here, a hefeweizen there. A couple of wines. But the drinks hit the spot, about half on tap, half in bottle.

The soups, salads, and appetizers feature a lot of beet, which is my new obsession, so that was nice. Several pork dishes for entrees, including a schnitzel or two, a bratwurst, a chicken dish, one with beef. Most dishes come with at least potatoes of some sort.

Okay, stop.

There's no way I can do justice to this restaurant by writing that they serve meat and potatoes. No way. What I meant to say, but couldn't, is that the food is delicious, well-prepared if not imaginative.

The atmosphere and service were down-to-earth, and that's refreshing. Why does regional food have to be all hoity-toity, anyway?

Another thing I LOVE about Walzwerk is the cost. I found it affordable. Entrees ran in the $12-15, which maybe I didn't mind paying because this was my only meal today.

I'd go back (partly because it's so close) several times a year.
author: Jeff H.

description:
I was in SF for the weekend and my boyfriend and his brother looooove German food. So we decided to check out Walzwerk. The decor was a little severe sometimes (huge picture of Lenin staring at you while you eat) but I understand that's what they're going for with the East German vibe. It definitely feels like you are in Communist DDR circa 1980. 

To eat, I had the schnitzel which came with mashed potatoes and veggies. My boyfriend had bratwurst and his brother had the chicken breast stuffed with apples and bacon. The schnitzel was huge! It covered practically the whole plate. It wasn't burnt though, or too oily and had a nice crunch to it. I did like the bratwurst a little better though, and might get that next time. Washed it all down with a Franizkaner Hef and then a Helles. Not too bad. The hef was a little too sweet, but the lemon came through nice. 

One last note: the night we went, service was really slow. It took a long time for us to get our food. Almost an hour. I'm not sure if it's understaffing in the kitchen, or the large party in the back room or the table of 8 sitting across the room from us, but it definitely got our attention.
author: Jenna H.

description:
I grew up in Southern Indiana (don't tell anyone!). That part of the country has a rich German heritage, so I feel like I've eaten some great German food in my day. Walzwerks has great German food! Hell, Walzwerks has great FOOD - period.
There is nowhere better to go on a chilly fall or winter night to warm up your insides.
My personal fave is the saurbraten. Tender and served with the the best red cabbage I have had since I was a little tyke. The stuffed chicken is also good. The potato pancakes are a must have, as well as the herring in sour cream (if you're into that sort of thing, and I am).
Thumbs up also for the Schnitzel and the good selection of German wines. And we even got an amuse bouche!
Love it!
author: Jamie M.

description: Took a date here and was very impressed with the food, so much so that I didn't really want to share my dinner at all (I had the stuffed chicken and it was effing scrumptious).  I also dug the east german/communist-era thing going on with the decor, it made me feel like I was really in the right place for the food I was having.  I liked that the space is on the smaller side (aka cozy for dates), but it did take a while to get a table, which was really the only downside.  I'd recommend making reservations or going later when some of the tables clear out.
author: Ali C.

description:
I wish I lived closer to this place, the atmosphere is the best part, it's like some friendly Germans moved into your house and started cooking for you.  

Went on a Wednesday night and it was relatively quiet at first but gradually I was surrounded by the soothing sounds of German conversation.  The Oktoberfest on tap was amazingly smooth and perfectly complemented the pickled herring and split pea soup appetizers.  I ordered one of the specials, Rostbraedel, which was roasted pork with new potatos, veggies, and sauteed onions.  The flavors were great though the meat was a little overcooked and dryish.  However the brussel sprouts, carrots, and onions provided enough moisture and flavor and the potatos were cooked just right.  My friend had the stuffed chicken which was much more tender and flavored with tasty bacon.  The spaetzle that came with it was good but inferior to Suppenkueche's.

I was stuffed halfway through my entree and actually woke up the next morning still pretty full.  I give it 4 stars for the simple hearty food and the servers who are really nice and accommodating.

Update: 1/23/08
Went back recently and the Spaetzle quality has improved,  I think they sauteed mine in butter, it was all rich, browned and yummy.
author: KC S.

description:
The advantage of dining with several people: you get to try a few different things.

An excellent place to literally pig out: The schnitzel is awesome, breaded just right, large, and comes draped over a mountain of mashed taters and steamed veggies. Its counterpart, the Jager schnitzel is just as good, this smothered in mushrooms and gravy and spatzle. The stuffed chicken stuffed with apples, bacon, and cherry sauce (yes, it had whole cherries) is really good as well, though we couldn't detect any bacon. The garlic roast pork was very tasty.

The free appetizers of little hors d'oeuvres (little squares of bread with cheese and meat or cucumber) were a nice start. But the potato pancakes here are quite possibly the greatest ever, trumping even any  Jewish deli. For dessert, the Cold Dog is pretty decadent: a layer "cake" made of butter cookies soaked in rum and frosted with chocolate. A fine choice of beers on tap (had the Köstritzer and the seasonal Oktoberfest amber). The curious Alterwasser is half beer, half 7up, and tasted pretty close to cider. Its counterpart, the Diesel, is half beer, half Coke (didn't care for that one).

Love the decor here, even in the bathroom. Old cold war era commie artifacts. Friendly, attentive service. I'd suggest reservations, to avoid the long-ass waits that some people had to endure. We all agreed Walzwerk is definitely worth coming back to. And our bellies lived happily ever after. The end.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
Dang, this place rocks!  I mean veggie German food??  Fan-fricken-tastic!  There were a bunch of us so we got to try a good amount of the menu.  The carnivores of the group certainly enjoyed their meals and I can definitely vouch for the deliciousness of the vegetarian "schnitzel".  I would describe it as a sort of German tempura... but served with creamy mashed potatoes.  That might not be doing the dish justice - it is very, very tasty.  My partner had the cabbage rolls and loved them... though it was so filling that she ended up bringing one of the rolls home for lunch.

I had the alsterwasser (half beer and half 7-up) and it was super tasty.  But, I want to have one of those giant Radeberger Pilsners that I saw the other table consuming next time.

Oh, and the desserts were delicious too... especially the Cold Dog and the Strudel!
author: Lisa W.

description:
We came here for a friend's birthday and it was amazing! Come in a group of 10 or more and opt for their $25/person family style meal that includes every appetizer and three main entrees off the menu. We got the Mushroom Jäger Schnitzel, the Sauerbraten and the Veggie Cabbage Roulade with spätzle, red cabbage, mashed potatoes and green peas. We washed it all down with a few pitchers of beer and our waiter was so amazing that he gave everyone in our whole group a free shot of schnapps at the end of the meal. (If you come in a group, be sure to call ahead for a reservation)

Come for the food, stay for the beer and take in the scenery. In the back room, where they sat our group, there was random decor all shipped over from Germany. One of our tables was actually an old desk built to withstand an air raid. Inside, we found old German books, including a 10-year reunion yearbook.
author: Anna R.

description:
German comfort food-vegetarians welcome!

I go for the VEGETARIAN SCHNITZEL (only place in town).
Slices of beat, squash, turnips, rutabagas and other veggies are coated in bread crumbs and lightly fried. Piled on top of a "plate-lick-able" pile of mashed potatoes & spinach gravy, the schnitzel fills me up with comfort food satisfaction.  Top if off with a blonde, German beer and my evening is complete.

Bonus: excellent East German decor.
author: Shelley S.

description:
Great little homy place. Went there during Gay Pride and got there just as it opened. Good thing too, it got busy! 

Great food, not Bavarian, which most people expect when they hear "German". East German owners, DDR memorabilia on the walls, friendly staff, but with the typical slightly rash German flaire. I'm German, I have no problem with that. :)

A+
author: E D.

description:
We came here for my birthday dinner after a recommendation from my aunt. Plus I was in the mood for something different. Plus it's close to the Homestead.

We called from the bar. There were 8 of us so we had a bit of a wait so they told us to come in 30 minutes.

Now, "we called from the bar" can mean a lot of things. In our case it meant each of the 8+ people had already bought me a drink and I was wearing a white, furry, bedazzled tiara. This may or may not have affect my perception of the place, but I don't think so. It's not uncommon that we visit the bar.

Anyway, we showed up a little late but - at least from what I saw - no worries. Our table in the cozy back room was waiting for us.

At first I didn't understand the sterile kitsch, but my "German" friend explained the east-German thing. As a Russian, I was elated. While I wasn't raised in communism, I still felt cozier all of a sudden.

The woman who was our waitress - who we were informed was one of the owners - was sassy and sweet. Drink orders, done. The collection of glasses in which the drinks came alone was worth getting a round. The German sparkling wine was nice.

We ordered some appies and they were fantastic. She even gave us some extra since there were so many of us. The salmon was delish.

On to the main course. The main thing that stood out to me, and what I was also told by my aunt, were the portions. You get a lot of food - something that I find is sometimes hard to find for "cool" mission restaurants in this price range. The food was great, too. I haven't had much German food, but I was pleased - and so was everyone else. And the vegetarian schnitzel won over my veggie friend.

Dinner was done, more drinks, and lots of conversation later, the waitress then brought out a special birthday surprise. The German equivalent of apple pie a la mode with a lovely little candle. It was dandy! I loved it also because the same woman called me the "queen" earlier when I decided that "I should stick with the bubbly" out-loud.

Anyway, I also appreciated that there was no rush to get us out the door. We were the last ones out but never felt hurried or unwelcome. While the place may be fashioned after East Germany, it had a definite euro-trash feel. Any restaurant that allows you to enjoy food and the company of your friends is a-OK in my book. And if the food's good and the beer and wine selection decent, even better!
author: Greg Z.

description:
I am German, I lived in Germany, I grew up eating German food.

The snitzel here is delicious!!!!

Hearty servings, heavy food and perfect on a rainy day.  

Drink beer, eat food and be merry.
author: Inga B.

description:
Walzwerk rocks. They were able to accommodate my large birthday party crowd on short notice, and provide us with individual selections. Everything was delicious--hell, I even liked the cabbage, and I hate cooked cabbage. Particular stand-outs according to the group were the cheese spaetzle, the stuffed chicken breast, the potato pancakes, and the schnitzel. The proprietress, Isabell, was great; she handled everything with consideration and aplomb. Definitely a place to visit again.

[Edit, nearly a year later:] My first impression keeps getting confirmed. Walzwerk rocks. Have been back a few times, and each time the food is great. It's definitely popular with the Mission hipster set, so it can be crowded and the wait long--get reservations! Also, that flavor to the ice tea that's terribly familiar but you can't quite place because it seems like it should be something tropical but damn it, what the hell is it? Apple.
author: Alberto Y.

description:
This is one of the best finds in San Francisco.  The food is abundant and delicious, the wait staff and owner ( Emma Peel move over ) are sweet and funny, and the decor will make you long for The Old Country.
To the previous reviewer who only gave two stars - you must have your waiter confused with someone else, you kept using "she" when referring to one of our favorite waiters in the city  (are you a former cast member of "Boys in the Band"?).    Anyone who would toss that racist Adolph comment in to a review should be banned from every German restaurant in the city.  Do you understand how hard the Germans have worked to move beyond those dark times and that horrible stereotype?  You should be ashamed of yourself.
author: Edward A.

description: I've been here two times for dinner, and both experiences have been rock solid.  Whenever you're craving some good mashed potatoes and anything cabbage, Walzwerk is your place to go.  Don't forget to drink some of the awesome beers they have too.
author: Carol S.

description: I've been coming here for years, but this is the first time I reserved the back room for my birthday party. Warning: the restaurant claims it can seat up to 18, but 16 was extremely tight (woe to the latecomers who get the worst seats).  Parties over 10 are family style, so you start with a full selection of their appetizers: potato pancakes with applesauce and sour cream (the best!), creamy herring (interesting but we wouldn't order on our own), shredded carrot, smoked salmon, beets, and choice of three entrees. We picked the sausage and saurerkraut, the schnitzel with kugel and mushroom, and roast pork. yes, three pig meats but good each in their own way. Dessert was a strudel and berry pudding and vanilla ice cream.
author: Vanessa H.

description:
Half way through the best German meal I've ever had outside Germany, my brother finds a secret drawer in the dinner table. In it we find, Mensche - a German board game ("Be a Mensche!"), a guide to fixing motorcycles, and The German Student's Guide to Politics. 

All interesting finds, especially the Student Guide which tells you how the USA has bigger bombs than the USSR's, that Communism may not be such a bad thing, and various odd diagrams of things like the size of the atomic bomb. Needless to say, this alone gives the restaurant 5 stars for 'enlightenment'. Couple this with beer and you've got a 10 star rating (if only). Great bratwurst and unbelievable mashed potatoes. Go here (but try to make a reservation).
author: Ali L.

description:
I just think that the folks over at Walzwerk might be skating a bit on their menu. The beer selection was adequate, but that's really no great feat for a restaraunt. I would expect some more typically East German Beers offered. 

I was a bit taken back by our waiters baffled look when i asked if they carried bread dumplings rather than the inferior potato dumplings carried on the menu...he had no idea what i was talking about! The schweinbraten was tasty, but unspectacular and the schnitzel was rather average. the blaukraut was tasty, though.

I think you'd do much better to seek out Speisekammer, in Alameda.
author: Steven C.

description:
Love Walzwerk.

First of all this is a specifically East German restaurant and I almost feel like I'm in East Germany when I go here. It's on South Van Ness which is some mild eeriness to begin with and then the ambiance is kind of bohemian neo-retro-proletarian with old school space heaters and what I think are formica chairs. Definitely reminds me of when I visited East Berlin in '98.

Second of all the food is AWESOME. I highly recommend the jaeger schnitzel (pork loin) with spaetzle (egg noodle dumplings) and mushroom cream sauce. SO GOOD. As you would expect they have decent beers on tap, I like the Franziskaner.

Finally the prices are pretty reasonable and the service is entertaining, if not the fastest. They will also take reservations for groups. Definitely recommend it!
author: Teo W.

description:
This was my second return to Walzwerk and although I had the Jagerschnitzel before which was very enjoyable - I really loved the stuffed chicken that was covered in a delicious rich cream sauce. The mashed potatoes were authentic and just the right thick consistency that I like. An excellent beer list at this place. The chef is very friendly and apparently able to apply his skills to food you wouldn't normally think of as delicious. I will definitely be returning here if I can get a seat.

And if you get a chance, get the cold dog for dessert. Let me warn you though, it will be difficult to save room for it. But it's definitely worth the effort. Finish out everything with a bottle of bitters - trust me, you will thank me a couple of hours after the meal. East German food is filling and gets you the most bang for the buck.
author: Adrian J.

description:
Walzwerk has gone down the drain. Service was extremely shoddy - bordering on rude - while the decor is not what it used to be. The food is passable but nothing to write home about. Especially at those prices. 

Its one thing to bring a former Communist East German flavor to San Francisco - its another to bring the rude attitude that used to prevail in those days. I should know, I used to live in the very area of the country thats serves as the motive of this place.

And no I am not suggesting that the service personnel should "pretend to be your friend".  As a paying customer I simply expect  to be greeted, addressed and served. Nothing fancy just normal friendly service. And contrary to popular misconceptions, Germans can be friendly and real. 

Luckily we live in a free market society in which I can vote with pocketbook and bestow my patronage on other, more service oriented establishments. 

If you have no expectations and want to waste some $$ on a semi-authentic experience down to dealing with varying incarnations of  "Frau Farbissina" then you may want to try Walzwerk, I for one am very disappointed with the place and will never recommend it again to anyone.
author: Privacy R.

description:
Dude, I got food-sick at this place.  

Enough to say I am not going there again.  

Russian atmosphere? Damn cheap I say.  I remember everything, even the super-cute matchbox size dial-face Wecker (alarm clock), so I actually did not want to remind myself of it.   Walls are bare. 

But let's get back to the food.  The damn Hefeweizen I got there (some German kind, it wasn't Widmer, Pyramid, Paulaner..) tasted bad .. sour or something like that.  That was the first bad thing that got my attention--WEIRD? OLD beer?       Second thing:  the guy next to me ordered a plate of herring (the fish in the cream.)  I tried 2 little fishes.   Gee, half an hour later I feel sick in the stomach .    Not too bad, but the mixture of the sour beer and the something fishy taste in my stomach, as if there is revolution inside  was  .. NOT good!    I ordered something else vegetarian there too, don't remember what it was, but I'm sure it wasn't the reason for my being sick.  

The server guy was also preppy.  This happened I think a year ago.
author: Jordan G.

description: Gave them a second try tonight, and am happy to report that service and food were both fantastic. Our beers came almost immediately, appetizers in 10 minutes, entrees 10 minutes later, and the quality of each was excellent. The sauce that came with the spaetzle was so good that we almost cried. 5 stars! We'll be back!
author: Ramon E.

description:
If you love german restaurants that are not a total shit show you will love this place.

If you love beer you will love this place.

If you love schnitzel you will love this place.

If you love nostalgic decor you will love this place.

If you love foreign eastern bloc nostalgic decor you will seriously love this place.

If you like really cool german staff who are friendly and efficient you will love this place.

If you are like me and love things like pickled herring, then you will love this place.

If  you love not to feel like you just consumed a hogsworth of schnitzel and beer and you love digestifs you will love that they have bittburger to order and its not on the menu.
author: Andrea S.

description:
Fan-friggin-tastic!

Came here for a birthday party in the back room, and pretty much tried everything on the menu, and it was all spectacular!  Not only that, but the waiter was sharp and he was hilarious.  Even though we were a big party, the food came out quick and it was all hot and amazing.  Beer flows freely (they're German, duh) and its all yummy.

One of the coolest parts was when we ordered one of every desert, and the waiter brought out each one individually, and sang happy birthday every time he came in all over again!!  After the check, we all got little German night caps too.  This place ROCKS.
author: Dave G.

description:
That "tough" East German schtick has just crossed the line of demarcation!  Walzwerk screwed up my boyfriend's birthday reservation, blamed me for it,  and promised to call back to see what they can do but never did, forcing our party of 8 to make last-minute changes to our birthday plans on a Saturday night!  

Here's the story: A week before my boyfriend's birthday, I left a message with Walzwerk to reserve a table of 8 for 7:30 pm on a Saturday.  The next day, "Hilda" (Hilga?) of Walzwerk called me back, leaving me a voicemail, to confirm with the same exact details.  I saved the voicemail.

At 6:35 pm of the Saturday night of my boyfriend's birthday dinner at Walzwerk, an irate female employee (sounded like Hilda/Hilga), said, "[My name], why aren't you here?"  She claimed that we were supposed to be there at 6 pm.  Given the voicemail confirmation, the mix-up was clearly on their end, which she refused to acknowledge.  Instead, she said, "Well, what do you expect me to do?  I can't hold it!"  I asked, "What do you expect me to do... it's a birthday party in less than an hour!"  Said she would call me back to see what she could do.  And, did she?  No, of course not!

I get it.  Mix-ups happen, but to not admit to your mistakes and shift the blame, with or without the attitude she gave me, is simply insulting, disrespectful and unethical. And, then to not call me back after "seeing what she could do," just doubles the lie.  Suppenkuche was more than happy to accommodate us despite of a busy Saturday night for them.  My loyal friends and I choose to do business with those who have integrity, which the staff at Walzwerk clearly lack.  Hopefully, Walzwerk goes the way of the Berlin Wall!
author: Jay B.

description: My boyfriend and I chose the place almost arbitrarily; I'd just finished the marathon that day and wanted to go somewhere with hearty food and good beer. We had no trouble finding the place and there was only a five-minute wait for a table. The portions were generous, and the red cabbage was sweet and spiced to perfection. Wish I had room for dessert. We'll definitely stop in again if we're in town.
author: Jade L.

description:
karl marx? check
friedrich engels? check
v.i. lenin? check
40w incandescent on bachelite socket? check
radeberger on tap? check
soy salami cold cuts plate? check
2 great types of schnitzel (jager and wiener)? check
what more would a thirsty/hungry east-european forty-something need?
oh yes, a discount coupon... Check that too on restaurant.com ($5 for $30)
yey DDR!
author: Vlad G.

description:
Ah the delight of Lenin looking down on you as you eat your schnitzel and spaetzle is an experience you shouldn't miss. 

The waitstaff speak German and English in varying amounts and treat you with the kind of dismissive disdain that only a German accent can express properly. It's not personal, it's just how they interact with everyone. It's quite charming, actually. 

Pretty cozy. Ja, zer gut.
author: Melinda K.

description:
I haven't had East German cuisine since... well... East Germany became history almost exactly 20 years ago. And then in the U.S.? Impossible!

Walzwerk is as close as it gets! Whatever is lacking in taste - and that's pretty negligible to begin with - I attribute to differing food sources. 

Soljanka I thought I'd never be able to eat again. But here it is: Delicious! Thueringer Bratwurst mit Sauerkraut and Kartoffelbrei: Delicious! And Kalter Hund? Ditto!

Ostdeutsches Essen beim Klassenfeind? Hell yeah! Keep this place in business! I love it! Love it! Love it!
author: Marco K.

description:
Best German restaurant in San Francisco!
(And I've eaten at ALL of them!) Great service, intimate-"Ost-funk" setting. 
Save room for dessert!
author: Lars L.

description:
It was going to be a three star occasion but i upped it due to the friendly and personable staff.

if a seat is available they will actually sit at your table to take your order. i love that, it's so creepy.

"intimate" setting (its small) for me the food was so-so but that is more a reflection of my taste than a reflection of good presentation or quality.  generous portions generous prices

beer.
author: kiki b.

description:
Best German food ever -- and NOT BAVARIAN.

Definitely a local spot.  There was one German guy at the counter getting drunk.  His wife called the bar to find him -- obviously he's been there regularly.  

Schnitzel -- very good, light.
Chicken Stuffed with bacon in a cream sauce -- very nice.
Beer -- great.  They have no boots or liter steins, or 5 liter steins, like some Bavarian type places we've been to.  But they serve pitchers.  The beer is very good quality stuff you can't get at supermarkets.  
Decor -- East German memorabilia.

We'll definitely be back.

(S)
author: M.S. C.

description:
You have to try to Sauerbraten, but order with Spaetzle instead. One of the best meals in town. The owners and all the waiters/waitresses are so friendly, in an East German kind of way. 
This place is GREAT, much better than the other German spots. Love love love the industrial style and all the decorations. 

Back room good for large groups.
author: Rhubarb M.

description:
The food is FAB!  The wait is too long.

Parking was pretty easy on the street, but you still might need some luck.  I came with one friend (german haha) on a weekend, and to keep it short, she was amazed and elated about all of it.  In case you were wondering, yes we were the girls that kept taking pics, and probably over your shoulder while you were eating.  

We ordered the sausage and stuffed chicken breast.  The portions were huge and very succulent, epecially the stuffed chicken breast.  It came with mashed potatoes and steamed veggies.  also had a soup that tasted like gazpacho(sp)  and drinks that were half sprite half coke.  just wish they didnt run out of the dessert cake.

I felt like overall, it's definitely a good vibe for something new and authentic.  But i'm not used to their culture of waiting soo long for seating and services.  
-j
author: Janice's A.

description: Amazing. Great food, great service. Potato pancakes aren't to be missed. House cured salmon was great. The stuffed chicken was relish as was the jäger schnitzel. Make a res on a busy night as the place only has about 7 tables
author: Jay T.

description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants.  Every inch of the place is decorated to give the feel of a hip, German, countryside restaurant.  There always seems to be a wait, but you wait in a fascinating-looking area and drink great German beer!
The food is amazing.  I am vegetarian and there are several, high-quality options for me.  My favorite is the vegetarian schnitzle- cauliflower, carrot, and some strangely refreshing squash excellently breaded and fried over mashed potatoes (I substituted spaetzle) and a green sauce.  It's beautiful too.  The potato pancakes are great, but Suppenkuche's are better.  I had not an inch of room left for dessert, but I bet it's good too.
author: Melissa W.

description:
I finally got to check this place out last night. The place itself is uber hip with the cute plastic orange and white table settings, funky art and retro metal tables, etc. I half expect Dieter from Saturday Night Live to come out in his black turtle-neck and look down his nose through his wire frame glasses at the dinner guests. I especially loved that they were playing Depeche Mode's greatest hits the entire time we were there! But instead of Dieter, a typically tall blond woman appeared at our table saying something to us with a very strong German accent, which we deciphered as a request for drink orders. No doubt, the beer was ser goot! But the food??? I've had better.

For German food I much prefer Suppenkuche or Speisekammer (in Alameda), but the restaurant environment at these places aren't as funky and artsy....I'd say even stuffy at times. So I would come back here for the "cool" factor; the music, environment, beer and cool German waitstaff.
author: Alotta F.

description:
I really like this place, although it does lack one point of authenticity - german service is very brusk and unhelpful. The last time I came to eat here our waiter was downright *friendly* and even paused to harrass the girl I was with about not eating enough.

The food is great and un-frilly, sauerbraten is served with potato dumplings (Kartoffelkloesse) and red cabbage - delicious.
The beer selection is not broad, but its all good.
author: Tom S.

description:
I'd give it about a 3.5, depending on what you get.

Small little German joint located in no man's land. Outside is typical SF vagrant + hipster scene. Inside, just hipsters. I had no idea hipsters enjoyed German food so much.

This place is a cross between what Id consider a pretty authentic European cafe mixed with kitsch-Americana. There is something warm and easy and familiar (and dangerous) about sitting in the tiny ambient room drinking huge glasses of German beer at $4-5 bucks a pop.

The menu is concise--couple of snitzels, saurbraten, sausage--it covers all the bases. It also features risky items like herring in sour cream (very pickle-y, but I like pickled herring), cabbage soup with bacon, and plum puffs for dessert.

The Saurbraten reminded me of a vinegar-y pot roast, which was good, but the  Jäger Schnitzel with the crispy not-too-doughy schnitzels, was the favorite dish of the night.

To top it all off--the 2 friendly ladies that work there seem to be authentically German as well (not gimmacky -dressed-in-liederhosen-German). 

Downside is that the room is very small, overrun w/people w/creative shaggy haircuts, and can get very loud. If you don't come early, you'll probably be waiting around and staring at other people eat their schnitzel.
author: Sabine S.

description:
Great, super authentic East German food with fabulous DDR decor. Makes me miss all the *real* German food I should have had while I was visiting Berlin (why must you be so cheap, doner kebap?! whyyyy!?!?).

The staff is really attentive and friendly, even though they're often very busy. It's not a very big restaurant, so there's a good chance you'll have to wait for your table. But this can be useful! You'll build up enough of an appetite to consume a hearty plate of food as big as your post-consumption guilt of eating too much. Oops.

Mashed potatoes and schnitzel to die for, great beverages (although they've stopped having Berliner Weisse, sadly), really tasty applesauce and spatzle. Also, unlike most of my dining experiences in Germany, THE MEALS CONTAIN GREEN THINGS!!! So fret not, kiddies, you'll still get vegetables with your dinner - no scurvy for you!

BONUS: the cook looks a bit like Jude Law. Ohhh yeah.
author: Jenn C.

description:
Oh. My. God. That pudding is good!

When I asked the waiter what he recommended for dessert, and he said chocolate pudding, I couldn't help but scoff and think J-E-L-L-O and bad Bill Cosby commercials. But, man, that tattooed german fellow was right: the chocolate pudding is a must-order after dinner at Walzwerk.

And then there's dinner. The theme for the food is, well, meat. The special last night was pork chop stuffed with...wait for it... sausage. Yes, that's right, meat stuffed with more meat. And that wasn't even the only incarnation of meat-stuffed meat at our table--I had chicken stuffed with bacon. The food is good in a hearty way--the mashed potatoes with my chicken were off the hook. 

Oh, and they have GREAT beer, which comes in all shapes of steins and glasses, depending on what you've ordered, which makes the meal seem that much more festive. All in all, a good time.

Just, please, even though you're full, order a chocolate pudding for the table to share.
author: David K.

description:
Took old man M out here for his 132nd birthday and had a grand old time.  Carefully selected German ales and lagers are happily served in the correct glassware at the correct temperature.  There's something magical about washing down Jägerschnitzel und Käsespätzle with a half liter of Köstritzer, and you bet your expanding ass that Walzwerk gets it all right.

Excellent grub and suds aside, they've done a great job with the decor.  The place has a grimy industrial feel, no doubt meant to evoke visions of the East German proletariat life of the 70s and 80s.  You half expect Erich Honecker to be sitting next to you, quaffing Berliner-Weisse.  The service is similarly Germanic - a bit robotic, but fundamentally able.  Not so sure about the kitchen, as it took forever for them to fill our orders.

The quibbles are minor considering that for $60, we got away with six beers, two entrees, and a dessert, all of which were uniformly splendid.  Walzwerk did right by us.  So schmeckt Berlin!
author: Susuk L.

description:
I swear I'm on a string of good reviews because I typically do not enter places without consulting Yelp, it pretty much makes my life a little easier.

Walzwerk has enough reviews. I just like telling people they serve a pint with half pilsner - half seven up and its KILLER. Its like beer for kids, or beer newbs like me who can't get over the bitterness... Ohh and the food is delicious too.
author: kate r.

description: Having visited East Berlin for a day in 1963, after passing through Checkpoint Charlie, I  recognized at once the plain surroundings of the Stalin era at Walzwerk. While no picture of Stalin graces the walls, there is Marx, Engels and Lenin. DDR President Walther Ulbricht is also missing. The food was hearty and very much German homestyle, with portions the size the young East German steelworker on a big poster on the back wall would have appreciated. Obviously a popular place with its following, Walwerk hosted a lively crowd the night I was there, and features some nice German beers on draft.
author: Peter P.

description:
goot times!  I veely enchoyed dis plaz.  Das foot vas speck-tacular, as vas da dekor unt da two vimen owners runnink da joint.

We loved the look, feel and comfort of the place.  Very small though the space is well used.  The decor theme (East German) is obvious while remaining cosy, casual and subtle.  The two women owners running the place are wonderful; friendly and courteous while moving at the speed of light.

Beer selection is good enough.  I had the pils and friends had the special dark and hefeweizen  (I detected cloves and fruit flavor in the heff...not my style) but the pilsner was very good.

We shared mass quantities of the potato appetizer.  Not your typical latke, but more like a lightly pan seared mash potato consistency.  Each order had three thick 'patties', served with apple sauce and sour cream;  yum yum.  A meal in itself. 

I had the bratwurst, served with great kraut and the best mashed potatoes I ever had  (I can only guess what the put in it for flavoring and creaminess).  Excellent!  My friends had the jager schnitzel and sauerbraten; and everything was equally goot.

We also shared the pickle soup; which was tomato based with pickle slices, onions, bacon, sausage and more in it.  It was good, but the pickle flavor was a bit overbearing.  

It does get a bit loud inside, but not too loud for conversation.  Prices are fair for the city.  So go cross Checkpoint Charlie and have fun!

Good stuff!!
author: Mark M.

description:
Oh - the food is really really good, and very authentic.  The rinderroulade (Beef roulade) and the solianka soup were really good.  The cold dog dessert was awesome too.  They have an ok selection of German beer.

What is costing a star is the agonizingly slow service.  It took 40 minutes for a table, and what was worse - about 45 minutes for the food to come out after we were finally seated.  Hmm.... I would go for the food but try to get there as soon as they open...
author: S C.

description:
The short: authentic/reliable food, funky/ethnic decor, authentic/dedicated staff.

The long:

Every time I go to this place the tables are full, the waitresses are busy, the food is delicious, and I leave happy and full.

I don't know much about what constitutes authentic german/slav food- but if my Polish boyfriend and my German friend are at all correct, this place is authentic, nevermind awesome.  

The waitresses are also super hot and personable when the place isn't packed.  They always try to chat with customers- especially if you try to throw some german at them.

Recommended.
author: Cameo W.

description:
Good food, if a little foreign to my palate. They have a very good selection of beer here, and the service is great. Its one of those places where the waitress sits down at your table to take your order - an interesting touch.

We started with an (included) appetizer of fitness bread. Not exactly my cup of tea, but well done. Mine had salami and some other toppings on it, but there was a vegetarian one as well.

I ordered the dumplings with Schnitzel. The dumplings were quite tasty, and the sauerkraut was also pretty tasty. The schnitzel was very good. As I mentioned before, it was foreign to my taste buds, but I can recognize the inherent quality of the food. The portions were pretty large - I left with a large takeout box.

It came to about $20 per person for an entree and a beer (if you come here, you need to drink). Well worth it.
author: Dana L.

description: This place is a trip. Great food, excellent atmosphere. Most importantly its like a time machine. When you walk into this restaurant you take a step back into East Germany (DDR). everything from the menu to the decor screams Communism. There are posters of old propaganda and communist leaders all over the walls. Its an excellent overall experience.
author: Greg N.

description:
When I have a need for beer and starch, this is the spot! I usually get the schnitzel, but our waiter said the stuffed cauliflower (special that day) was delicious (with eyes rolling back as he said that). Sold!!  The cauliflower was indeed awesome, and I usually hate cauliflower.  It was "stuffed" with ground beef and pork paired with mashed potatoes. Wash that back with a heffy or two...perfect.

Perfect dinner....up until three minutes after I paid the check.  My friend and I still had half a heffy each, our waiter ask us if we could finish our beer in the "lounge" so that people could sit.  "Say what?!"  I'm not mad at the waiter, cuz he was super nice and he did turn me onto the cauliflower. But if I had to wait 20 minutes for a table, those people could wait 5 more minutes. Good thing we're both alcoholics. We pounded those beers and peaced out.
author: Ezduzit S.

description:
My daughter ordered the sauerbraten beef entree and the lychee bionade soda. I ordered the stuffed chicken entree and a non alcoholic maltz beverage called Kaiserdom( I was curious about this drink but after 2 sips,I realized that I didn't like it).  We were served our beverages first and it took awhile for the food to arrive because the place was busy. The waitresses were very kind and apologetic about the wait.  One of the waitresses even noticed that I didn't drink my beverage and asked me if I liked it or not.  I was honest and told her that I really found the drink to be way to sweet for my taste and I didn't care for the flavor either. She also admitted that she did not like it and offered to replace it with another drink. I thought that was very nice of her but I declined and said that I would stick with the water. Eventually, the food arrived and everything was delicious.
I had even ordered an entree to go for my husband and this is where they lose the 2 other stars....
I had requested the pork schnitzel entree as a "to go" item when we ordered our entrees and it was given to us at the same time our food had arrived.  Since the schnitzel was all boxed up and wrapped, I didn't even give it a second thought to look at the product since the food on our plates looked great.  Well, when i arrived home and opened up the box, I was very surprised and disappointed to see that they had "overcooked" the schnitzel because the breading looked very charred! My husband was surprised that they would even serve something that looked like it had been burnt.  I felt so bad that I offered to remove the breading and salvage the meat and put it in a sandwich but he was already hungry and tried to eat some of the schnitzel .  The mashed potatoes and mixed vegetables were fine but the cook probably was too busy to pay attention to frying the pork schnitzel.  Next time, I will make sure to peek at  the "to go" item before I leave the restaurant!!
author: Amelia C.

description:
Excellent beers! Hostesses were very accomodating, offering suggestions and giving us tasters. The smoked salmon in the appetizer wasn't the tastiest I've had, but the special lamb chop entree was amazing!    

Hip interior...I've never had dinner in the company of Trotsky, Lenin AND Marx before.

Ask for the spicy mustard on the side.
author: Priya S.

description:
One of my new favorites in SF.  I have recently befriended one of the staff, but would visit quite happily when he isn't there, as the food is crazy filling, very good, and quickly made.  I LOVE the herring app, potato pancakes, and house smoked salmon.  I've had pork twice, and needless to say will probably have it again - whether it's on the regular menu, or the specials, just perfectly prepared.  

The bratwurst is pretty good, I stole a few bites from the gal across the table.  

And the Cold Dog.  Perfect way to end a filling hearty meal of East German deliciousness. 

Plenty of great beers, and I really like the non-alc apple drink.
author: Lindsay B.

description:
Can I say.... OMG!
Was starving and my boyfriend told me of a delicious german resturant some where in the middle of no where and it was worth the wait. HE WAS RIGHT!  

The service was extremely friendly, and quick the food was divine (Rainbow trout, Grilled Schnitzel, pork meatballs and plum pastry) YES WE HAD 3 entrees! Its soo hard to decide.  

According to my bf, the beers on tap and the select is pretty great. 

MUST TRY: Pork Meat balls! They are accompanied with steamed carrots and delicious mash potatoes (SO SMOOTH!) 

Just to warn you its a pretty small place so it get's crowded fast! You might end up sharing a table! Its completely worth it!
author: Jac J.

description:
When we moved to the Mission, we didn't expect to find a neighborhood East German restaurant. We are so glad we did. Reservations recommended for groups of 4 or more, Wednesday through Sunday. (Apologies for any spelling mistakes below)

It's best enjoyed as a six course restaurant.
1. Beer 
2. complimentary sushi-like pumpernickle and deli  crudite (so good!)
3. App. I love the pickled herring in sourcream  (a meal in itself, really). It's kind of an acquired taste, admittedly. Smoked salmon with beet salad, potato pancakes also excellent options.
4. Second beer
5. Entree. The fish special is always good. For regular vegetarian entrees, the stuffed cabbage is my favorite. So good. Could split -- generous portion includes mound of mashed potatoes. Cheese spatzle also tasty. Vegetarian schnitzle and noodles was disappointing, but maybe they've improved it.
6. Dessert. Always good. I like the chocolate cake best. 

For meat eaters, Nick always orders meat, and never complains.
author: Ian H.

description:
it's so good. My first time, was at my friend's Bday dinner, and they handled the large group with grace and fed us like we were their long-lost cousins. The second time, was just me and my girlfriend, right after Italy defeated Germany in the World Cup (I'm Italian, my girlfriend German), so the mood was maybe a bit subdued, but the food...oooooooohhhh, and the beer, aaahhhhhhh....and then the most amazing plum cake....omgod, I have to have some now.
Go there with all your friends. Watch "Goodbye Lenin" to get in the mood.
author: Renu C.

description:
I love, love, love German food, loved Spaetzel before it was fasionable, and my wife and I knew we were made from each other when finding we each owned a Spaetzel maker and Schnitzel/Spaetzel was our favorite food.  We used to think Suppenkuche was the bomb.   (even though you can't hear yourself talking to someone 3 inches away from you, I digress.)  

But then the waiter at the Matterhorn (decent fondue place on Van Ness, I digress..) turned us on to Wazwerk as the areas best Spaetzel, hands down.  

He was right.

Get the Weinerschnitzel (no time for sweating the spelling here) and substitute the whatever with Spaetzel.   You will not be disappointed.  Can't talk to the rest of the menu, never had anything else.

Decor is fantastic.  Bathroom filled with East German artifacts. 

Parking is a little dicey as far as the neighborhood - be careful.

But don't miss it!
author: Scott R.

description:
I considered giving 4 stars, because last time I went my friend was sorely disappointed in the salmon special he ordered.  It was really small but he said it was delicious, but really this is the best German food I've had in the city so the fifth star remains.  

I recommend the jagershnitzel.  I dream about it and crave it at least once a week.
author: Rion S.

description:
It was between familiar Schnitzelhaus that has lively entertainment and trying a new place.  The last time at Schnitzelhaus, the waitress danced on the table.  I however, opted for the second.  And it was to our surprise that this place was excellent.  

Potato Pancakes - delicious, great starter appetizer
Chicken Schnitzel - favorite dish of the night:  light, crispy, delicious
Mash Potatoes - whatever is in them, it's melts in your mouth
Thüringer Bratwurst w/ Sauerkraut - tasty and flavorful 
Apple Strudel with Ciao Bella Vanilla Ice Cream - yummy!!

I'm not a fan of beer but their wheat beer, Franziskaner Hefeweizen was very good and I'd have it again...
author: Jeannine L.

description:
If the German restaurants in San Francisco could be aligned with beloved German characters from American film and TV, Walzwerk would definitely be the Mike Myers character "Dieter" from SNL.

Basically, instead of rosy-cheeked hospitality and warm fuzzy wooden tables, you're greeted by a gaggle of east berliner euro-hipsters with attitudes to match-- it almost warrants really bad techno music.  Ain't no lederhosen up in this bitch, this isn't the jolly Bavarian Hofbrauhaus re-creation you've come to know and love at places like Schntzelhaus and Suppenkuche.

It's AWESOME.  It's got everything you want in terms of a delicious, pork-and-starch-fueled menu of classic German fare.  It's got a ton of fabulous beer.  It's got strudel!

It's just a lot COOLER than most other German places. It definitely plays hardball with the other German spots in town-- it's just a totally different style of restaurant.  Eat here!!
author: Laura F.

description:
Oh my gosh...this place rocks! We had a large crowd, got great service, had multiple toasts, brought our own birthday cake in. But best of all, the food is amazing. Hands down the best German meal I've had in San Francisco.
Inexpensive, friendly, and ole fashioned home cooking.

I just wished my German friends cooked for me. Just once!!
author: E.Mo. ..

description:
This place was good (and I'm not just saying that to get a $3 credit on Trubates.) The restaurant itself is basically a bottom floor, SF flat. We were there on one of those rare, warm SF days. Definitely ask for the back room on days like that; it's cooler and you get to look out on the backyard instead of S. Van Ness. 
The food is rich, hearty, and you get plenty of it. I think I was able to finish less than half of my entree of bacon, onion, mustard, and pickle, stuffed tri tip, spatzle, and braised cabbage. I boxed it up and it kept perfectly. My date got the fish special with mashed potatoes and he literally licked the plate clean. 
While the food was good, my favorite part was the music. They were playing old skool MJ, and Miss Janet, some George Michael, and Queen. It added this quirky, fun ambiance to the place. Mind you, this is an authentically German joint. So the Germans who are waiting on you will be "very German," as my companion mentioned when the waiter didn't want to engage him in banter. They are frank, curt, and efficient, but also courteous and prompt. They were kind and replaced my sparkling wine without any eye rolling when I said it was flat. And they didn't bat an eye when we started dancing in the back room. I mean, we were slow dancing to George Michael, because we're nerds. If we would have been break dancing or something they may have said something. Altogether? 3.75 stars out of 5. But I have unreasonably high standards when it comes to restaurants.
author: Summer T.

description:
Truly delicious food! The goulash was unbelievable--HUGE portion, delicate chunks of pork, big pieces of veggies, and the broth! Just wonderful. I couldn't stop picking at the deliciously buttery spatezel as I was waiting for my to-go box.

But, guilty meat eaters, never fear! Walzwerk uses pork from natural, free-range farms! Hoooray! And it shows in the taste of those lil' piggies...

Perfect cute lil' place for out-of-towners. I called in 20 minutes early, telling them I was bringing a party of 6 & our table was ready when we walked in the door!
author: Caitlin M.

description:
I don't think I've been here and not heard German-speaking patrons, always a good sign of a place that offers 'ethnic' food. Me, I love Walzwerk  - it's one of my favorite places to eat in SF. I'd knock off one star, as the food isn't consistently stellar, sometimes it's just good, which ain't a bad thing, but I am a picky so-and-so. But I added one star for them being so accomodating...one night they had Weiner Schnitzel, but were offering it with mash & veg - I like mine with Ksesptzle & Gurkensalat and it was no problem to substitute. Sweet :)

Make sure you try the Soljanka soup - it's heavenly.
author: Dan L.

description: The food is at once both authentic and comforting.  The space, the warm  service create with or without intention, a strong sense of gemütlichkeit.  I only wish the Restaurant's square footage were greater.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
So this place is very cute, it fills up fast so you need to get there early, 7 pm is an optimal time and don't worry about getting there when the crowd gets there, its a much nicer ambiance when only half the restaurant is full. The pictures of their restaurant do it NO justice, I thought at first it was going to be stark and dreary and dark, but it was very romantic and cozy. 

Typical European service, slow and relaxed, must require adjusting to the typical American speed and agility...so go with people you like!!

Food, was great, homemade red cabbage AMAZING, better than many places I've been to in Germany. Spaetzle, could be drizzled with more sauce and they'd be perfect, but definitely homemade and good! Basically, if you haven't had a good piece of meat in a while, come here, it'll satisfy your craving!

Staff, friendly and all german-speaking, so I was able to bust out mine which was very fun and gave it a more authentic feel.

Overall, worth checking out!
author: Tina D.

description:
- 1 star: We were quoted a wait of 45 minutes: "oh, that table is just waiting for their dessert now" when they were actually just finishing their meal and hadn't even looked at the dessert menu yet. Total wait time wound up being 1 and 1/2 hrs. Sometimes restaurant staff have no control over whether their wait time is accurate, but in this case they did, and they gave us misinformation!

+1 star: Some of the best soup I have ever had in my life, When my friends ordered a soup that contained pickles and sausages I was skeptical, but it was the best part of our meal. I want to learn how to make it myself!

+1 star: Really cute waiter. "Du bist suss".

-1 star: Pretty lengthy wait time between courses although the place was emptying out. Disaster in the kitchen perhaps? Maybe the waiter was sobbing in the back: "I am married but I am in love with the fraulein at table 3...."

-1 star: One of my pieces of beef tasted like dirty socks but I ate it anyway because I was so hungry.

+1 star: Addictive schnitzel. I'd never had it before and couldn't stop sampling my friend's flat breaded pork. Yummmm.....

We're at 0 stars due to cancelling out but Walzwerk is much better than that so I'll give it 3 stars as an average rating.
author: Stephanie S.

description: Give me sauerkraut, mashed potatoes, bratwurst and a pint of Spaten for less than 20$ and I'll give you five stars.  DELICIOUS!  I grew up on German cuisine and have been jonesin' for some brats since my move to SF.  This seriously hit the spot.  I'll be back...   again and again.  and again.
author: Selina I.

description:
The owners of Walzwerk must have come over to American from East Germany on a tanker ship because that's the only conceivable way that they could have gotten all the East German trinkets, decor, and paraphernalia that are crammed into their restaurant over here. Even the soap in the bathroom is authentic. And everything is arranged perfectly. Probably my favorite restaurant interior design in SF.

The staff reminded me of the Nihilists in The Big Lebowski, which is not to say that the service was anything but excellent. Tall, slim, German and dressed in black from head-to-toe, the servers might believe only in Nothingness, but they were still gruffly friendly and, surprise, efficient.

The schnitzel with noodles was juicy and delicious, as were the cabbage and potato dumplings. Dessert was great, as well.  Let's be honest here: German food isn't one of the world's most renowned cuisines, and for good reason. But Walzwerk at least proves that it can be fun and fulfilling.
author: Ben P.

description:
"I didn't know German people made such good food!" -nine years old picky eater from hell.

'nuff said, and that's all I've got after downing a large glass of 7-up/beer combo.
author: Kara P.

description:
Saturday, 8:30PM.

Party of 5, arriving in the midst of hectic dinner hour. We waited 45 minutes to be seated. Another 20 for the food, which wasn't bad. The food HAS to deliver for such a long wait.

Service [2 stars]:
+ Nice waitress
-  Long delays between filling our waters and other beverages

Grub [3 stars]:
+ Meat dishes were full of flavor, securing savory juices
-  Veggie dishes were bland (or maybe it's because I'm not used to the type of cuisine?)

Final Call:
I've been to a cramped joint before but for some reason, this place wasn't as well spaced or efficiently used. The whole time we felt squished while sweatin' like a mofo from the lack of ventilation. Food was decent, our return trip will certainly have reservations.

********************

Munchies:
1. Thuringer Salad (White Cabbage, Red Cabbage & Carrot Salad)
     -  All three veggies were bland, even with the sauce
2. Beef Roulade (Tri-Tip Stuffed with Bacon, Pickles, Mustard & Onions) with Spätzle and Red Cabbage
     + Cabbage was firm and had a sweet after-taste to it
     + Spatzle was chewy and in small unique shapes, good though!
     + Tri-tip was delicious, tasted more like pot roast though
3. Vegetarian Cabbage Roulade (Stuffed with Rice & Veggies) with Mashed Potatoes
     + Mash potatoes were liquid-y, but had a buttery and garlicky 
     goodness
     + Veggies and rice were moist and yummy
author: Chuck N.

description:
I'm usually not a friend of German food -- typically too heavy and not pleasing on my palate.  

So it was with some skepticism that we arrived at Walzwerk on a Friday night.  When you step in the first thing you notice the small size and relatively utilitarian appearance of things save for the cool East German paraphernalia all over the place.  We had a group of six so we waited for a bit near the "bar" area.  I thought we were in the way but the staff was so cheerful and friendly, definitely didn't make me feel so bad standing right in the hallway.

We ordered a few beers and a few minutes later were seated in the back room of the place.  We ordered the potato cakes to share as an app and I had the jager schnitzel.  

Food came and I was in heaven with this dish...it was a schnitzel topped with a mushroom gravy and spaetzel.  Let me tell you if I could have had seconds, I would have.  We finished the meal with some desserts.  I split an order of cold dog which was interesting - sponge cake, a layer or rum, and ice cream covered in bitter chocolate.  

Overall, I had such an amazing time at this place - great food, beer and great service.  The service is what really made our experience at Walzwerk.  Our waitress sat right down at our table and talked with us like we were friends.  

I wholeheartedly recommend this place to anyone looking for good solid food with great service.
author: Clifton T.

description: This place was fanrastic. Saw it also on Check Please. The three salads had wonderful, subtle dressing and the Jagger Schnitzel was out of this world. My wife had the Sour Botten and it was also wondeful. I liked the chocolate desert and she enjoyed the apple streudel. We drank  beer but next time I will try a mosel.
author: Mike M.

description:
I've finally come to the ultimate realization that service in San Francisco restaurants just plain sucks. This moment of clarity arrived in the middle of dinner at Walzwerk. Previously, I had thought that it was a particularly localized affliction, a North Beach thing. I am horribly mistaken.

I like German food, my father loves German food. So the old man was in town and I took him here for dinner. The imported waitress who looked old enough to know better, spent most of her time ignoring the customers, the service bell and anything except for some schmoe at the bar with whom she would make out with like a highschooler on a prom date - in full view of the front of the house. WtF? Getting a beverage, butter for the bread, water, the FOOD that's sitting in the order window, I might as well have done it myself, fer chrissakes. Not to mention when I finally got my entree, it was not what I ordered and much discussion ensued before I got my correct order fired. That said, I should mention another waitress came on duty as we were finishing dinner and took over our table and was very friendly. I hope she's working when I go back.

  The food was hit and miss. The soljanka soup was absolutely delicious and is quite possibly the one thing that will bring me back. The beef roulade was tougher than leather, bone dry and completely flavorless (not to mention ice cold in the middle), though the spatzel and red cabbage that accompanied it were very good. I tried a bit of the bratwurst and mashed potatoes and both were outstanding. I make some mean mashed potatoes myself so I never get excited about eating them in restaurants, but these were really good.

  The portions are ginormous and I'm certainly not one of those waifish metro types, but I couldn't come close to knocking out my plate.

  Overall, I'll give it another shot. It seems to be one of those places where you have to know what's good. If you get the right things, you'll have a great meal, if you get a clunker, you get stuck in a big way. I think avoiding the beef dishes is a good idea.
author: Thomas S.

description:
Very good German food.  I decided to come check this place out since the Schnitzelhaus on 9th and Folsom closed down :(

Great food; the salmon and beet appetizer was very good, but it was very small.  I liked my Jaegerschnitzel, however it was a little small; I always say that a real schnitzel should be hanging off your plate it's so big.  I have eaten schnitzel for every meal in Berlin, Budapest, and Vienna, and also at Schnitzelhaus and Suppenkuche here in the city, so I know what I'm talking about.  While it was good, it was not as good as the one at Schnitzelhaus (/whine).  Also, you have to make a choice between spaetzle and rottkraut, which I think is total BS.  You're already paying a high premium for this food, the least they could do is give you a little cheap pasta or cabbage for free.

I felt the beer list was lacking.  For this area, it should not be difficult whatsoever to expand their beer list drastically.  They could even buy it directly from City Beer Store a few blocks away on Folsom.

Great food, but I felt it was too expensive and not enough.  I was hoping this place would fill the hole that Schnitzelhaus left behind, but it doesn't quite cut it.  Schnitzelhaus was tiny and expensive like this place, except their beer list was tremendous and the food and helpings were much better.  Also, the staff was much friendlier and the owner would regularly engage you in conversation and drink a beer with you.

If you want German food and you're in this area, Walzwerk won't let you down, but be prepared to spend a lot.  If you want better food and more beer choices, I would choose Suppenkuche, except it does get pretty loud and busy in there, whereas this place is tiny and more intimate.
author: Matt L.

description:
We started off our meal with their smoked salmon.  It sucked.  We were a little apprehensive about the rest of our meal.

Fortunately, our entrees were fantastic.  I had the jagerschnitzel.  It's not fried.  It's like baked or something and covered in mushroom cream sauce.  Delicious.  And it's placed on pounds of spatzel.  I LOVE spatzel.  The size of this dish was huge, too.  I had about 2 more meals worth to take home.  

My boyfriend ordered their bratwurst.  Also, very good (I liked my jager schnitzel more, though!).  

I forget what beers we had, but the waitress seemed pretty knowledgeable and was able to pick out beers for us that we both liked.
author: S J.

description:
I had a fantastic night at Walzwerk.  What a great place -- reminded me so much of places I've been to in Germany, in a way that I haven't ever found here in America.  They don't bother to try to "look German," the way that so many German restaurants do, with all of the dark wood paneling and flags and bier steins everywhere.  Walzwerk just looks quite plain, in a rather accurately East German way, with wooden tables and chairs and some cool art on the wall.  The place is tiny, but it's cool. 

As for the food...uh, wow.  Just wow.  The potato cakes are stellar -- thick, moist, crispy on the outside, quite flavorful, and served with chive sour cream and applesauce.  Nom.  I disagree with Lisa C. below -- I liked the "vegetarian schnitzel."  I thought it was creative, and the parsley pesto was quite tasty.

The beer menu is extensive (of course), and they do have a wine menu, you just have to ask for it.

Also, the menu has a German side and an English side.  I got to practice my German a bit!
author: H. P.

description:
We've been here several times now, most recently in April.  I'm a fan of the chicken and apple dish, though everything I've tried has been pretty good. 

One thing: basically everything here involves a piece of a dead pig.  If that's not your thing, you're going to have a limited selection.

Also, they've got 2 widely spaced stairs in the front.
author: Avani W.

description:
small, not so comfy tables and chilly but bring on the beer and soon the windows were steamy from all the folks packed in by 7pm.

the potato pancakes were deelish
the cheese spatzel was good too but the cabbage outshined it!

the entrees wowed me:
the sauerbraten beef dish was soft marinated pieces of yumminess and came with heavy potato dumplings and cabbage.
the jager schnitzel was fantastic! tender pork with mushroom sauce and more spatzel.

no meal is complete without dessert so the chocolate tart was a supersized version of a choco truffle.  

two thumbs up for a melt in your mouth caloric affair!
author: Anh V.

description:
Ok, ok, it might be a really hipster joint, but it's a cute little place with yummy german food.  Everyone who works there is german, so if you are learning german, this is a place to go!  Plus, one of the waiters is super cute & will talk to you in german if you know any ;-)

I freaking love Potato Pancakes
author: Jen Z.

description:
Loved the vegetarian schnitzel, the beet soup (hated the sound of it--wound up loving it), the wine. 
First German restaurant I could go to, because of the vegetarian selections; in general, a really great place to have dinner. 

Downside: a few v. sides, but only one real vegetarian dish.
author: Joanna R.

description:
Pretty good food, the veggie schnitzel was very good. It comes with plenty of sauce, I'm not sure what it was made from but it's pretty good - and mashed potatoes. Nice hearty portions.

The dining room is very small, so be prepared to wait if you come on a busy night. The staff is very nice
author: Chili B.

description:
Let's run down the checklist in my not-patented, totally not-famous reviewing style:

Location: a little out of the way. 15th and South Van Ness is by no means a *bad* location -- 2 blocks from BART is easy -- but it's not the nicest part of the Mission and there's not yet a whole bunch else around there. I wouldn't feel great walking home alone from there late at night. No star.

Ambience: cheerful, authentic, not fancy but not shabby. A little loud towards the end of the evening -- probably not a great date venue, but then, sausages and beer aren't exactly ideal date food either. 1 star.

Food: hearty, high-quality, and tasty as all get out. It's big on meat and potatoes, but done exceptionally well. I advise skipping lunch, because portions are big. 1 star.

Prices: you get good food, and lots of it, and great beer, and lots of that, and then the bill comes and you're like: "oh, well, that's more than I was expecting, but that was totally worth it". 1 star.

Service: fast, friendly and polite. We went in a big group and spent a lot of time on our meal, and towards the end the waiter very politely said that another table had been waiting for 35 minutes, so could we possibly give up our table? I like that, both from our perspective and the incoming table. 1 star.

So again, not a great date venue, but a great place to go if you're hungry.
author: Laurie V.

description:
Beaming you back into East Germany's commie era with it's decor and the menu- and a great selection of both typical beers from East and West Germany, Walzwerk is easily the more authentic of the German restaurants in the city.
A 5th star is missing because of the place's noise level. Even though there is no hard music playing, it is most of the times not possible to hold or follow a conversation at normal volume. Which would be okay in any club or bar, but is a bit irritating at a restaurant. 
But if you want a great interpretation of traditional German dishes served with mostly authentic German charme, this is the right place for you.
author: Wolfgang S.

description:
I know I'm late on this one but who could've expected such fantastic food with such a good vibe from a self-proclaimed East German restaurant?

We were a threesome and started with the house-cured salmon which came with tasty fresh beets. Tasty and off to a good start.

The mains were the sauerbraten (?), the pan fried rainbow trout special, and the chicken breast stuffed with apple, bacon, and who knows what else. The salmon was good, these three exceeded all expectations. Serious food done very very well.

The decor is relatively spartan but the vibe is very laid back and warm.

I will return again. And again. And again.
author: Joe D.

description:
I'd give them a hearty 3 and 1/2 stars actually.  Rustic food and a small dining room, very homey kind of feeling.  Went here after a long day at work and sampled the special Ghoulash which was very flavorful, hot, hearty and served with lots of spaetzle.  Also tried the Jaegerschnitzel and it was hot and hearty but on the bland side.  Staff were friendly, helpful and made me feel welcome.  I was absolutely stuffed when I left and will be back again soon to try some of the other dishes.  This is rustic, hearty food.
Recommended.
author: Ron T.

description:
I admit I have not yet tried other German restaurants in the area -- which I now intend to -- but this place certainly handed me a good evening.

Me and my roommate went, seeing as she'd been there a couple of times before, and it was the perfect gloomy weather for comfort food! While I was surprised at how small it was, it was lovely. Very warm, comforting atmosphere. Even when the talk became more of a din -- all the merrier.
I'm surprised to read that the service has been bad before, because the two ladies working there tonight were absolutely lovely. They were busy but they handled everything perfectly, and I was completely satisfied with them.

For $30 I got the Pear Cider (which is a hard cider, little did I know when I ordered it,) the stuffed chicken breast with mashed potatoes and vegetables, and the apple strudel. Needless to say: DELICIOUS, DELICIOUS, AND DELICIOUS. Everything is flavorful, but not too overpowering. Just right. The mashed potatoes are possibly more butter than potato, but by the time it's in your mouth you could probably care less. Even the cooked veggies, which I'm not usually a fan of, were very tasty! I'm not even sure what it was. Could have been some collard greens, but my roommate spotted mostly beet leaves (?)
Yummy, whatever they were.
My roommate got the pork stuffed with garlic, i believe, and I liked that even better than my chicken. As for my chicken, it was good, don't get me wrong, but the cherry sauce on it wasn't my favorite. I think I would have preferred a more savory sauce on it, less a sweet one, if you get what I mean.

I intend on trying the other German stops nearby, but so far this place has left a good impression on me.
author: Holly F.

description: For lack of a better explanation, I think Walzwerk would be the cooler, nondescript cousin to Suppenkuche. Where one is a boisterous scene of uppity urbanites and non-locals, I felt Walzwerk stays truer to the Mission scene. Calmer and obviously way more hipster, the venue is much smaller and boasts East Berlin vibe over the later's Bavarian beer hall. Nonetheless, my meal here was awesome and in fact, some dishes had better flavors then my dear old Suppenkuche. The jaeggerschnitzel was probably the best I've had in years. Portions are also more manageable so you don't feel like a complete pig walking out. Their potato pancakes were also very good and from what I can remember, their goulash was equally tasty. While their beer selection is no where near as exciting as Suppenkuche, I will most definitely be back (probably more then I'd like to admit) to grub.
author: Jonny Bobby G.

description: Came here for a birthday dinner and had a pretty good experience. The cabin-like decor of the restaurant brought me back to the days of eating at Andechs, a small brewery I used to always eat at when working in Bavaria. The food is meat heavy and flavors very strong...in other words, authentic! There's also a good variety of German beers to choose from and if you're not a drinker, there's even non-alcoholic choices. It's not a German meal if it doesn't come with beer!
author: Eric L.

description:
3.5 stars

This is an overall good restaurant, but I'd say more "average" than "great".  Their prices are higher than at Suppenkuche but the food is not as good.
author: Steven V.

description:
I used to give this place 5 stars but that was 3 years ago. I have to say I was a little disappointed last time I ate here. The prices went up but I cannot say the same about the quality of food. I have eaten much better Rinderrouladen and Spaetzle at other German restaurants in SF. I went with 5 friends and they all shared my opinion. Unfortunately, something got lost here.... 


This is the best German restaurant in town! The food is a little expensive, but very tasty!! Every dish that I have tried so far was great! The waiters are German, which is a big plus for me. The service is excellent and you can experience true "Eastalgia" here. It is best to show up early since the place is pretty small. Beerwise: give "Aventinus" a try.
author: Iphigenie S.

description:
I was pretty buzzed from the amount of German beer I had before we got here (celebrating MOCKTOBERFEST)  but even still - this place is so cute!

The seating area is small and we had to wait but got a beer from the bar and looked at German books - which is a great little touch.

Once we were seated the menu was given in German and English and with a wide variety of options. I chose the Veggie Schnitzel - it was very good - and another German beer. Our waitress was FOB and nice but a little hard to understand.

The last reason I love this place: I won a bet with my co-worker here :)

FYI: the large photo on the wall on the left is  Karl Marx.
author: Jessica L.

description:
We just ate here tonight for my boyfriend's birthday.  We were here last year too - and all I have to say is VUNDERBAR!  This restaurant has many vunderful zinz going for it:
 
1) the owners (Christiane and Isabell are gracious and talented) 
2) the food (zimply amazing - try one of the specials) 
3) decor (fun - with a comfy humorous slant), 
4) a very cute waiter (those blue eyes!), and
5) a nice selection of beer!

Go, auktung!
author: Jim S.

description:
The restaurant feels as though you are in someones kitchen, which I like a lot. There are doilies on the tables & the drink menus are in small picture frames on every table which people then pick up and look at intently, which for some reason to me was visually kind of touching.

I felt all touched again when it got busy kind of all at once, and our waitress hustled around and doled out snacks- thoughtful, tasty, and not on the menu!

Our potato pancakes were great, the pork special had an awesome filling, and my schnitzel with spatzle was exactly what I'd been craving. We sat at an old enameled metal topped teacher's desk and while waiting for our check at the end of our dinner my bf'er found a drawer on his side which he subsequently opened, exposing-

2 teeny tiny German cook books
a checker board (also with the option of chess pieces)
a set of pick up sticks

Which would have been an awesome find while we waited for our food, but now that little treasure is for you.
Another neat thing would be the bathroom- it was decorated with a row of records along one wall and a glassed in medicine chest with all sorts of old German products on the other.
It probably is the fact that I watched the Science of Sleep after dinner and the images of piles of records all over the floor and rooms without walls, crispy saran wrap coming out of faucets making sounds of water, giant hands filling up rooms- merged with my sensory memories of Walzwerk - it's all warm, tasty, larger and more detailed than maybe any of it would have been in another situation, but the night was right and the memory has been made.
Walzwerk equals fun, homey, comforty, beautiful touching gladness. Fried in a pan.
author: jessica m.

description:
My wonderful East German friend (from Rostock) Nanette first brought me here. She said the food and the decorations made her homesick for the DDR that no longer exists, the country of her youth. She said as children, they were mostly unaware of all the political shenanagens, and she loved the Young Communist League campouts, the singalongs, the cheesey pop concerts and all the things for kids to do in a non-consumerist society. Watch the flick " Goodbye Lenin" before you go for some of that Ost Nostalgia.

I grew up in the Bundesrepublik Deutschland and the USA, and this restaurant reminds me very much of the Gasthofs we used to visit in the countryside as a child. 

The food is excellent, service can be spotty but they don't mind if you walk over to let them know. The back room is very fun for birthday parties!  

Great little place.
author: stephan k.

description:
Walzwerk is a nice German restaurant in an industrial, semi-run-down part of town. Since it has been ably reviewed by at least 224 Yelpers before me, I'll just add a lesson in contemporary German pop-culture:

The restaurant's East German theme constitutes a fine example of 'Ostalgie' -- a German word that conveys a certain affection for the old East Germany ... not to mention a certain 'forgetting' of how bad things in the communist DDR really were. The word comes from a combination of the German words for 'East' (Ost) and 'Nostalgia' (Nostalgie). Other examples of this phenomenon are the film "Goodbye Lenin!" (along with the lesser known, but arguably better "Sonnenallee"), renewed interest in the Trabant (or 'Trabi', a VERY cheap, 2-cylinder car created by the regime), as well as a veritable love affair with the Ampelmaennchen, which I can't really describe but you can probably find a picture of them if you google it. 

Oh, and the Weltenburg beer (I had the Helles ('light')) was REALLY good!
author: Ethan H.

description:
Loved it!  The decor is really cute.  Went with Madeleine and Ann, they've been there about 5 times n the last 3 months.

I had this sausage and mashed potoes and sauerkraut thing.  OH. MY. GOD. the best mashed potatoes ever.

Beet Soup = delish.

Potato Pancakes = also delish.

Not enough bars near the restaurant for a post-dinner drink, though.
author: Summer K.

description:
nice place to go for german food.

FOOD: ~my sauerbraten was really good, home-style, tender meat. 

~the potato dumplings were bland, so i traded for my friend's mashed potatoes that came w/his excellent bratwurst. i actually liked the braised red cabbage, which surprised me. 

~yummy rote grutze (red berry pudding) was nice.

DRINKS: beer is gut.

SERVICE: the owner couldn't have been any nicer, & our server was really nice & straightforward, too.

DECOR: the owner collected everything from east germany, from the s&p shakers to the flower vases to the bath products on display in the bathroom. very comfy & home-style, i can see why germans go here when they're feeling homesick. i love the tiny bar area! random yet cool. & how they spray painted the industrial stuff outside the window & lighted it, very artsy.

BATHROOM: i think there's only one. hilarious old east german albums on the walls. i don't like how the tp holder is on the ground & rusted.
