OVERALL: i'd go back if i was in the mood for bratwurst or some potato pancakes (mmm).
author: miss b.

description: I don't get the high scores for this place. I spent close to thirty dollars for about three dollars worth of food. The service was poor, had to ask for water and butter for some stalish pumpernickel. I have eaten authentic German food in Germany and this was mediocre by comparison. I ordered the beet soup which was just beets cooked in water and served with sprigs of dill and tasted like some vinegar dashed into the vegetable broth. Served with two slices of dry bread. The entree-bratwurst was good but the sauerkraut was over cooked and well, sour-just nothing special. The mashed potatos were Yukon gold and nicely seasoned. As one poster stated, the food was as austere as the ambience and the waitresses were too involved in chit chat to pay attention to their guests.
author: Eileen M.

description:
Decor was great, I wish they had another server.  

I prefer my potato pancakes traditional, not a hunk of potato which doesn't cook all the way thru.  My tenderloin with bacon was tasty, although the potatoes were cool.  My friend's chicken schnitzel was excellent.

My biggest complaint was that the heat was up and it was broiling inside.  We didn't even have alcohol, and we were perspiring when we left the restaurant.  Put it this way: on a cool SF evening (which is every night), we turned on the A/C on the drive home.  

I hope the fix the heat (or open a window) because I felt a little ill from the dramatic temperature change.
author: Steve F.

description: Great Potato cakes. Excellent atmosphere.  The Jager Snitzel was amazing. Great sauce and awesome flavors. Good German beer selection. I would rate this as a very authentic German food experience.
author: David S.

description: II was born in East Germany and really enjoyed going to Walzwerk.  The service was great and everybody spoke German.  The food was delicious.  I had Jaegerschnitzel and it definitely was smothered in mushroom sauce, and the apple strudel was wonderful.  I did feel like I was going back in time.
author: Gabriele M.

description:
All I can say is YUMMMMMMMMM.

My boyfriend went on Halloween night in our Hansel and Gretel costumes and were immediately welcomed by the staff and the patrons. The owner is very friendly and inviting and poured us some great beer, which I unfortunately can't pronounce or spell.

Dinner was delicious. It was a good thing the food is hearty since we were starving. Had an extremely tasty tomato-based soup with sausage, cabbage, zucchini and other vegetables. Again, wish I knew the name. We also had the potato pancakes and then as entrees had the jaeger schniztel and spaetzle and the pork goulash special over spaetzle. Finished up with some apple strudel for dessert. We loved everything about our meal (and beverages) and can't believe it took us so long to discover Walzwerk!
author: Dariana R.

description:
I went here last night. What an East Germanic experience. Hey, I'm half German! Danka Motherfucker. We ate schnitzel, bratwurst, and sauerkraut. Wow, homey and fun. It's totally a commie hangout, with tall, white, Aryan waiters to boot. I wanted to bring some of my Black Army friends here and try to out drink "RIGHT SAID FRED" with a Jessie Owens beer drinking challenge .  But the tall fucker look like he invented pilsner. Him and the other smaller bald white guy are great. They took care of me (food wise sickos!) and were the most pleasant communists I ever met. I love this place.....and the beer.
Beer - Great!
Food - Good!
Staff - Nice commies!
Restaurant - East German Propaganda Machine With Kitschy Posters.
Only thing missing was that nice tall Fraulein I'd make babies with!
author: Mark B.

description:
I have now been here about 5 times. Each time is different, in a good and bad way.

This past Friday night, we arrive about 830 to a 20 minute wait. That's fine. No prob. Both people seemed quite apologetic for the wait and I appreciated their sincerity.

We finally sat, in the coveted window table, and two out of three of us had the Jager schnitzel and the other had the regualr schnitzel. The spaetzle was delicious and warm (in the past, it was cold and old).

This was my best experience yet so I thought I would add to the glowing compliments on this restaurant. It was still hopping when we left around 1030. The Hef was warm due to a change in the keg so I got an unknown beer which was fantastic, though I dont recall the name.
author: Hilary H.

description: It took forever for the beers to show up and the meat was dry and bland (the pork tasted like turkey). This sort of disqualifies it as a good German restaurant. I've been three times, each time hoping that it would get better. It never got better. I don't understand why this place doesn't try a little harder.
author: Trevor S.

description:
Homey, warm and welcoming. It's not a formal place, but it feels casual, like you're eating at a friend's home. The  walls and ceilings are hard and smooth, and in the small back dining room the noise level can get high, making conversation challenging. 

The food was outstanding; I had the pork chop special, which was probably one of the best instantiations of pork chop in my lifetime, and tried some of the jaegerschnitzel. The spaetzle with mushroomy suace was awesome. I could eat whole plates of that by itself. 

Not a beer fan, but the schwarzbier did me just fine.

A screaming child at the table behind us (isn't 9 past his bedtime?!) but that's not their fault. I'd go back any day of the week.
author: dana l.

description: This little place is a fantastic little restaurant. The decor is entertaining with its pictures of East Germany icons and the major leaders of the bolshevik revolution. The food was really good though. This is not what you'd expect from a German restaurant. I had the Sauerbraten and the potato dumplings were as good as homemade. And most importantly they have some great German beers on tap. This place is small so don't go with a large group unless you can afford to wait, but put this on your regular eatery list if you enjoy German food.
author: Darin A.

description: Great drink and food selection. Best potato pancake and cabbage salad i have ever had!! Depending on what you get, the food can be relatively healthy... otherwise, expect a big plate of meat with plenty of creme and meat...
author: Emily Y.

description:
Had an enjoyable time here with some friends, and the food was good. We got the family-style menu with Jäger Schnitzel, Garlic Roast Pork, and Vegetarian Schnitzel. It was nice having a little taste of each of the appetizers - they were all pretty good. I wished the potato pancakes weren't so thick so you could taste the crispy goodness. What was really evident with the family style was that you could see each potato pancake was a different size and thickness. 

I wish we had gotten the regular schnitzel, although the Jäger Schnitzel was very good. The vegetarian schnitzel was a fried slice of yam, which was delicious - I liked it a lot. Even the vegetables (asparagus and carrot) were tasty even if they were just plain veggies. LOVED the Cheese Spätzle!

Service was a bit slow, even though we had made reservations and given them our orders for the family style ahead of time... so just enjoy the beer while you wait. I highly recommend the Hefeweizen!
author: Pamela L.

description: Good German food. A friend and I got the goulash, snichtzel and the red pudding to share. All heavy food for me. Too much meat...... but that's the highlight of German food so I shouldn't complain. And though it sounds like I don't like this place, I actually do. It's a guilty pleasure packing all those meat to your body but then, it's worth it
author: Cliff T.

description:
What a goofy little place. service was this bizarre mix of super friendly and totally annoyed (how very German). 

The food was just so-so. Schnitzel looked okay, but too mushroomey, potato pancakes were average and the herring appetizer tasted like fish in mayonaissey sour cream.

Wouldn't travel a long distance for it.
author: Andrew L.

description:
I take groups to Suppenkuche to impress them with swanky minimal style and great beer... I take friends to Walzwerk to impress them with how horribly bad I can ask for beers and make sad attempts at flirting with all wait staff. I have a thing for accents, and all the wait staff are rich with German accents. I like suppenkuche and their food, but not as much as I like Walzwerk's food that taste like some ones adorably plump eastern german granny is in the back  cooking for us... but its a skinny little white guy, I've seen him. 

Food is good, but the cold dog is great!
author: danny e.

description:
When I first found this place, I was completely and utterly in love. 

The food and drink is simple and delicious, the decor is delightful, and totally reminded me of my trip to Germany. When it's busy you can sit in that tiny communal corner and drink and peruse German design books. It's friendly in a non-confrontational sort of way. I don't like being bothered alot when I am dining out.

However, it does bother me that they don't take reservations, because I wait every time I go there, and not just for a short amount of time. It's always longer than they say it will be. And now that I'm short of cash, I have discovered how cheap and easy it is to make spätzle and vegetarian schnitzel, (Ahem, my vegetarian schnitzel is better, I dare say.) I have begun to stay home instead.

Still, I am fond of this place. It makes me happy to know it's there with stodgy goodness on those cold foggy San Francisco days.
author: Ima D.

description:
The morning after a meal at Walzwerk, my husband asked me how many stars I'd give it on Yelp.  4, I said.  He said he'd give five, because he was still thinking about the Jäger Schnitzel he had that was so delicious. 

Yes, the food is good at Walzwerk.  It's uber popular during dinner time.  We attempted once to spontaneously pay a visit at 8 on a Friday night and was told nicely but positively that we pretty much had no chance of getting a table.  

The place is small, but not THAT small.  So the second time, we were smart enough to call before leaving to see if a table was remotely possible (but not smart enough to plan ahead of time and make reservation of course).  It was 6pm and they gave us a glimpse of hope. 

Based on this very possible "maybe" we headed over.  The waiter excitedly told us that we were lucky, a group canceled and we were escorted to the back room.  

The back room is adorably decorated with nothing but East German posters on a bleak and simple wall.  It can be hard to hear people but wasn't too crowded with tables and chairs. 

I ordered the goulash special.  Meat was good and flavorful, and I loved the Spätzle and the cabbage.  Portion was large enough to take some left overs home.  

So 4 stars for now, if we are ever lucky enough to score a table again, and the food is as good as the first time, maybe (a very strong maybe) I will bump it up to 5.
author: Candice B.

description:
I'm copying and pasting this from an email I specially sent to a bunch of friends:

"an East German restaurant.  communist themed of course, and the menu is heavenly.  they have a wide array of drinks, too - German and others.  It seemed that maybe owners were also the servers, and they were German.  The place is pretty small, nice and cozy.  i loved it!   You need to look at the menu and GOOO!!! 

Lou heard about this place when someone said it was even better than Suppenkuchen.  Lou had a tasty bratwurst with mashed potatos that were absolutely rich.  I had marinated beef with potato dumpling and red cabbage...the beef was tender and melty, and the potato dumpling was spiced and flavorful.   We also had a yummy yummy "cold dog" (i'm picky with desserts)- it's a layer cake dessert.  It kind of had a tiramisu taste and it was laying on a bed of light cream/berry sauce."


Also just to add -- I loved the interior.  It had a German/Eastern Europe feeling.  The servers, decor, ambiance made you very much feel in a  peaceful home.  The posters and art were culturally enticing; in the restroom, the wall was lined with old German record covers.  There were communist-time knick knacks around, too.
author: Liz C.

description:
I had a good time here.  The place is small and homie.  When I went here, it was the first time I had a krostriker beer.  I believe thats what its called.  If you like newcastle then youll love this beer.  

I had the schnizel.  It was a great portion.  Its a bit pricey though.  I wouldnt mind going back.

DDR......
author: jon jon a.

description: I will definitely be back to Walzerk's.  Good addition to a developing neighborhood.  Walking across the threshold you almost feel like you're crossing the Berlin Wall (or something): SF on one side and Germany on the other.  The food and drinks are GOOD, albeit the food was quite salty.  Walzerk's does a nice job of providing authentic German dishes along with the dishes for finicky Californians, like myself.  As a vegetarian, I was delighted to order the vegetarian schnitzel, which was pretty good.  -It's a rare day when I can get my veggies schnitzeled.  Can't wait to try the brunch.
author: Tom F.

description:
Pretty tasty place. Arranged my friends bday dinner party here 'cause he's all about German food. 

Anyways, I have to say that the potato cakes by far were the tastiest things I had there.

I had the Sauerbraten... a liiiittle too sour for my taste buds. So I don't really recommend that dish. My friend got the Chicken stuffed with apples and stuff, now THAT was good. OMG... if I ever go there again i'll take one of those please. 

WE also requested a truck loaded full of these tiny liquor bottles... I had 2.

1 i shot straight down my throat. The 2nd went right out my nose...it's jagerish... so you can only imagine. 

Anyways, place is cool. Very cute. Ambience is something to admire. All the servers have nice little accents so I'm assuming it's pretty authentic. 

Oh, and beer is tasty... not as much of a selection I thought a German place would have though.
author: Eugenia Y.

description: My wife usually avoids German food because she rarely can get something without meat in it. She loved their vegetarian schnitzel! I ordered the wiener schnitzel and it was fantastic. We sat at the bar and ended chatting with one of the owner's cousins. The staff is very friendly and hospitable. We will be making Walzwerk one of our regular stops.
author: Nick Z.

description:
This place has a nice atmosphere, friendly staff, and the food is delicious. For me, it reminds me of what I used to eat as a kid in Russia. The potato latkes are always a good choice, same for the smoked salmon.  The entrees are huge, I would recommend sharing. They serve some good beers. The solianka is good too.

This place is really laid back and they don't try to be anything they are not. It's not a place to go and expect perfectly timed service at. It's more of a hang out spot.
author: Svet V.

description: I used to live 10 steps away from this place. It is the perfect cozy lovely wonderful place to have awesome dinner and awesome beer. I love the chicken stuffed with apples and bacon. Greatest combo ever. Its really small and the chairs dont match the tables, but I like it. Its the perfect hole i the wall restaurant! Much better than soup and chuchen (I don't know how to spell that but its in hayes valley)
author: Janel M.

description:
delicious. a little bit pricey but you get what you pay for. juicy schnitzel, creamy mashed potatoes.and Franziskaner seals the deal for me. good food, good beer and a good environment. life's necessities. 

make a reservation! they tend to be busy.
author: Joan S.

description:
VERY reasonably priced and the food and wine were fantastic.  We were a group of 4 and two out of the group hadn't had much German food - if any - before.  They truly enjoyed everything (except one who was afraid to try the fish).  I hear they are opening another place as well.  
Die Speise und der Dienst waren einwandfrei und ich könnte nicht aufhören, zu essen.
author: Kasi S.

description: Came here with my bf after some serious over-partying. The food was warm and comforting. The atmosphere cozy. Even though they were really busy, our waitress took good care of us. I'll definitely be back.
author: Judy L.

description: It's kind of a hole in the wall place. I wanted to try it for a long time. I liked the little appetizer sandwich in the beginning. I got the spaetzl with the mushroom sauce and schnizel. I discovered recently that I love spaetzl!! It was really rich and creamy. I'm afraid to ask about caloric intake that day. I got this German lychee drink but didnt' like it too much. Overall, I enjoyed my experience and would return for yummy German food. I'd definitely come back for more spaetzl.
author: Kathleen T.

description:
Ein Mass Bier Bitte!

god bless 'em for having both good beer -- and eschewing the 16oz pint glass a good german beer should never be served in :-)

first time for me at walzwerk tonight, and I'm damn pleased with the experience.  I had a thuringer salad (jullienne carrots, and two types of shredded cabbage)... followed by the jaeger schnitzel (schnitzel with a mushroom-cream sauce)... washed down with a couple of liters of really good pilsner.

faboo, *honestly* friendly service.

me likey.  comin' back.
author: Mark B.

description:
This place does German, the way German food is susposed to be: Hearty, Un-pretencious, and rib-sticking good.

This place is kinda small, but very homey feeling...as if you were in someones house...or kitchen...

Me and my lady ordered the Patatoe pancakes (a must), house salad, Beef Roulalade and a Jager Schintzel with mushroom sauce.  Everything was quite good, and tasty though we did not think much of the house salad (would not order that again as it was very average) but the other menu items more than made up for that and the food overall was surely above average.

Unfortunately, we were so full...we didn't order desserts but the next time, I would hope to be able to give the home made desserts such as the  interesting cold dog or apple strudel a try.
author: Jason C.

description:
I have never been a big fan of German food, but now I've changed my mind after eating at Walzwerk last night. Before now I had eaten German food at Suppenkuche (wasn't impressed), Pfeifer House (in Tahoe City) and a place in Oakland (can't remember name), but I was never all that thrilled about the food. Walzwerk is the shit, man.

I went with a couple of friends and had a great time drinking German beer and eating. To start we had the herring and potato pancakes. The potato pancakes (with sour cream and apple sauce) were really great and the herring (in dilled sour cream with green apples and brown bread) was also very good. For my entree I ordered a special on the menu, stuffed roasted pork roast with spaetzle and red cabbage (very yummy!!) My friends had the grilled bratwurst (with sauerkraut and mashed potatoes) and the jagerschnitzel (with spaetzle and mushroom gravy). All dishes were excellent and I would have been happy to eat any of them. I spied the entrees arriving to others in the dining room and they looked great too.

The only down-side was the desserts. I had read on Yelp that some people said to order the cold dog and the apple strudel. I thought the cold dog was boring and had a weird texture. The apple strudel was pretty good, but not my cup of tea. 

We all drank at least 2 beers each. I fell in love with the first beer I tried, a lager called (I think) Weltenburger Helles. A very satisfying beer on all levels. It was recommended by one of the waitresses.

I loved sitting in the back room which was filled with utiliterian furniture and had the vibe of a labor meeting hall. Very cold formica covered tables, etc, but with a sense of humor. 

The service was fine, and we were eventually brought some kind of after dinner herbal drink in tiny bottles (45% alcohol!) that were carried in a wooden truck. That stuff tasted like medicine and one would have to develop a taste for it. Pretty gross if you ask me.

I am definitely going back to eat at Walzwerk. Dunka.
author: Yvette K.

description:
Intimate and cozy. Just the place you want to be on a cold San Francisco night. German food has this strange "comfort food" effect on me. Not sure if it's the mashed potatoes or the beer- but when all was said and done, I left a happy [FULL] camper. 

Extra points for the red velvet bar area!
author: Cindy H.

description:
Walzwerk is like having dinner at your german aunt's house, but your aunt lives in the recreation room of an East German apartment tower.

Okay, what the fuck does Karsten mean by that?

What I mean is that the food has a home-cooked taste and presentation, which is good. The Rouladen I had was delicious - but it did not have the prettiness of a typical restaurant dish.

The apartment comment is because the decor here is spare - there is a little room in back of the dining area where you can sit at a couch and look through books on East German architecture while you sip a beer and wait for your table to be cleared.

This is a concept restaurant of a different stripe - the owners are trying to evoke a time when part of Germany had very different priorities and, to some, a simpler outlook.

What that means to you is that you can have a culinary treat from the Worker's Paradise of nostalgic memory, unspoiled by the forgotten and bitter aftertaste of the oppression that went hand in hand with it.
author: Karsten P.

description:
I would have loved to dined at Walwerk... but, after being seated and waiting 18 minutes with no one paying attention to us, it was time to go.  It's not even like it was busy, there were open tables in the joint and we smiled and waved to the staff numerous times after 10-12 minutes of being ignored.  Come on guys, you gotta do better.

I'm disappointed, as I'm getting into German food & beer, and made a real effort to get there Friday night.  Now, I'll not be back.
author: Scott S.

description:
Schnitzel and spatzle!  More than just fun to say, delicious to eat.  Being rather accustomed to light and healthy meals of sushi and CA fusion, I need a good hearty meal on occasion.  And Walzwerk delivers.  Ok, so not to my house...but God knows they'd have a lot of business from me if they did.

I was rather pleased with the specials, as with the spatzle.  The beer quality was good as one would expect in a German restaurant, but the selection was on the limited side.  I would skip the dessert (in the case that you actually still have room for it), unless they have the black forest cake, which is incredible and surprisingly light and fluffy.

Service can be really slow as they are often crowded and understaffed.  The ambiance is what one would hope for with a meal like that in front of you, boisterous and hearty.
author: Michelle P.

description:
I'm biased because a) I Iove German food and b) this place is *right* by my house, but I think it's damn good. 

I loved the cabbage, the bratwurst, the schnitzel and the East German atmosphere.

Ok, maybe the food at Supenkuche is a little bit better. But it also costs more than a little bit more. And, at Supenkuche they make you share a table (with, in my case, a couple that kept making out during dinner... at my table.... 10 inches away from my food).
author: Rebecca H.

description:
"It was a cold night. My girlfriend took the powerful light and pointed it squarely between my eyes...

"VEE HAVE 'VAYS OF MAKING YOU EAT 'ZA SCHNITZEL" she screamed. Finally I could take the pressure no more and I caved. We were on our way to Walzwerk. 

This was my second adventure into German cuisine, the first being Supenkuche about a week before. Personally I found the food here just as delicious & wonderful as Supenkuche but there's something about the atmosphere that's a little more cozy. 

The food had a home cooked feel to it that was paired nicely with the tight quarters & relaxed environment. I had the Jager Schnitzel and the flavors were all perfect. We left feeling happy & content. Again, just like Supenkuche, my only complaint is that its a little expensive for what you get, but still more than worth it if you're in the mood for some schnitzel/bratwurst & spatzle."
author: Jeff S.

description:
Good, hearty, simple German food - sehr gut! I used to live in Germany so I have a fairly decent basis for comparison - I went with the Schnitzel with mashed potatos and veggies and a fat stein o' beir... I can't believe I ate the whole thing, it was huuuge! For $14 an entree, it was right at the high end of what I was willing to pay for it, but the portion made up for the price, and the quality was good (although not excellent). The schnitzel itself was slightly on the thin side and breading a tad undercooked, but overall it was still worth it. 

Decor is ultra simple: momentos from East Germany now long past. Don't trip on the portraits of Marx, Engels and Lenin in the front dining room - nobody's trying to convert you. Head into the back room and you'll find album covers from Ost Deutscher groups now gone, and childhood momentos on the shelves... it's actually quite cool. Staff is so totally unpretentious and easy going, they made us feel at home the moment we walked in. I'm definitely going back. Note the do NOT make reservations for groups of two, so just head over and hope for the best... if you have to wait, they'll serve you up a pint.

If you need a fix of stout food sans fanfare and pretention to stick to your ribs and fill you up enough to skip breakfast the next morning, Walzwerk is your place.
author: Gregg G.

description:
I have never had German food until now.  (Dude, where have I been?)

This adorable hole in the wall has great food, big portions, friendly family service and the food is delicious.

I had the chicken stuffed with raisins and bacon, piled with mash potatoes and veggies.  Drowning my food was a beer/7-up!  Yum...and for dessert, a raspberry/strawberry sorbet-ish thing.  

Ok, I can't pronounce half the stuff on the menu but the food seems authentic and its just mouth watering.  

Go with friends, grab a few pints and just relax.  You can spend about $30 bucks here for booze, food and dessert!  Can't top that.
author: Alice H.

description:
I like the small, charming aspects of this place. Funky, kitchy and laid out in no particular order. The people were very nice and attentive but not overly so and they let us stay past closing time so we could chat and carry on.

The food was just OK. I have had better German food elsewhere.
author: Scott T.

description: 4.5 stars.  This place was pretty cool.... it's a small place with seats/tables in the front; kitchen, bar, waiting area, bathroom in the middle; and a room for relatively big groups in the back.  I would think it's casual-euro feeling... small space with good food and everything is informal and easy.  We got a bunch of beers and ordered a lot of food to share including:  potato pancakes, schnitzel, jager schnitzel (covered in mushroom cream sauce), stuffed chicken, beef roulade, and a short-rib special.  Everything tasted really good.  We were sharing everything, so things got mixed up so couldn't tell what was what, but everything was good.  Lots of heavy stuff, lots of creamy stuff, meats were really tender, the sides had good sour/tangy flavors to cut through the meats... spaetzle was light... I enjoyed it.  Service is good once you realize they're not going to greet you when you walk in b/c it's kind of hectic and lots of people standing around, but once we told them our reservations and during dinner, service was great!
author: Easter E.

description: Went back again and it was good but not fantastic. The mushroom gravy, in particular, was pretty weak. Suppenküche is definitely as good as Walzwerk -- maybe better. Either place is a solid choice though.
author: Aaron V.

description: Great German food. Very small place, has a nice atmosphere. Decorated with a lot of East German signs and pictures. Menu was not very large, but has very traditional German food. I had the bratwurst and my friend had schnitzel. Both were really good and filling. My bratwurst came with sauerkraut and mashed potatoes, which were delicious. Would definitely come again! Costs around $16 per entree.
author: Michael W.

description: I'm updating my old review to 5 stars b/c this place deserves it.
author: Jonathan B.

description:
Walzwerk reminds me of my German grandmother's kitchen back before the fall of the Berlin Wall. She even had the same Heino records and a predilection for stark DDR decoration. 
Get the potato pancakes.
author: Andreas T.

description:
Wonderful food, I was skeptical since I'm not too daring about cuisine.  Married to an East German myself, I had to make myself try the cuisine he was talking about.  The food was very good.  I had the stuffed chicken with raisins and some other things and it was well worth the wait.  The staff was overworked but held up with smiles and pleased us by letting us not be forgotten.  The artifacts inside hit close to home for my husband and brought smiles to his face of his youth.  We will definitely be back.

Its a very busy place so make reservations on the weekends and keep in mind
author: Van E.

description:
Trans_ Europ_ Express!     

From the ambience to wines to, most importantly, the food, I'd be hard pressed to find a more awesome restaurant than Walzwerk. Had an office party here and filled out the back room. Walls are delightfully detailed with German goodies including German LP covers. Two lovely German women were very accomodating. Potato pancakes started us off-- not a smidge remained. I had beef roulade-- beef stuffed with pickles, onions, and bacon. Terrific. Sampled the dishes around me-- the chicken stuffed with apples and bacon caught the attention of my palate. Portions were filling and perfect considering German food is a little heavy to begin with. I had an Austrian red to accompany my meal-- very well received. The desert led me to some mascarpone with a blueberry tart. MAN ALIVE was it good. Been to Suppenkuche-- this is lighter, more hip, and the food is a lot better.
author: Helen T.

description:
Very authentically German!  I felt as if I had been transported back to one of my old haunts in Germany.  The German waitresses are very attentive and friendly and the food totally hits the spot.  We had the potato pancakes to start , the schnitzel and spaetzle (perfect) as mains, and the apple strudel with ice cream for dessert.  Everything was delicious and although it may sound quite heavy, it was just right.  

A great meal and a blast from the past kind of experience.
author: Tina T.

description:
Do you remember that Pantene commercial from the 80's? (http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=phnbv19YLh8&mode=related&search=)

Well, don't hate on Walzwerk cause the food is fantabuloso.  Yeah, it is a popular spot. They'll take reservations for parties of 4 or more... but you're going to wait a while. That's ok... you're really not that important (sorry, i'm just being honest).

While waiting, order a Schneider Weiss.  No wonder Germans drink lots of beer... cause their beer tastes good!

The food is delectable... the waitress/owner pointed out that i couldn't provide the kitchen with a better compliment than licking my plate clean. (i didn't really lick it clean... but i did drag my fork sideways across the plate probably 15-20 times to lap up all the succulent marinade.)

The one slight shortcoming is that i was hoping for some obatzda--Bavarian yumminess mixing camembert cheese and butter and onions + paprika powder slathered onto a pretzel.
author: Kevin F.

description:
Im giving it 5 stars anyway - 

Yes, its small

Yes, its a little noisy

But I'll be damned if it isn't the best little German eatery in SF.  Sincerely traditional dinner menu, follwed by a cute array of very traditional appetizers.  This was an excellent meal.  both my friends loved theirs as well.  As the son of a German mother, I know good German food and this is excellent.  +1 for free range, hormone free pork.  +1 again for taking reservations despite their small size - unlike another popular Germany restaurant in Hayes Valley.  

They do have a back room for larger parties.  The staff is freindly and I really had no complaints about the whole experience.  Excellent selection of beers.  Looking forwward to my next trip to the DDR.
author: Rick R.

description:
I discovered this place thanks to Yelp...such a find!  Totally concur about the Jager - Schnitzel (which I was relieved to discover is not made with Jager-meister, but a creamy mushroom sauce).  Service is really friendly.

I was surprised at how many of the patrons were speaking German...always a good sign that a place is authentic!

Definitely share an entree though, portions are huge!
author: Kimberly G.

description:
ok, so I've been back to this place twice since I lwrote my previous review, and both times the service was much better. Once, I was with a girlfriend, who was going thru a very difficult divorce. We were sitting at the bar, and at one point when my friend broke in tears, the super sweet and gracious bartender offered us a shot of some kind of special (German?) bitters, which she said is supposed to make you feel better. 

The 2nd time I was with my hubby, sitting nearby our friend John Lee. Our 2 parties merged near the end of our meals and the staff was pretty cool about it. So, I now have a deeper appreciation for this place. The food is pretty darned tasty, the beer is great and it's closeby.
author: BR K.

description:
Their leave a message to make reservation system does not work. 

Their answering machine told me to leave a message to make a reservation and that they would call back to confirm.
I left a message, they did not call back.  I called again to be sure that my reservation was taken and was told that they were all booked. So I had to find another restaurant for my friends birthday party at the last minute.  

The Staff are German, aren't they supposed to be organized? 
Annoying.  : /
author: Puffy P.

description: Great home cooked authentic German food everything was fresh, tasty and served hot. We had the potato cakes as an appetizer I had the Bratwurst and my friend had the jagersnitzel (sp?) and wow really good generous portions. Then for dessert homemade german cheesecake YUM.  We will be back our server was really friendly and gave great recommendations. 5+ stars
author: julie c.

description: Woah. Great food.... great beer. Nice clean spot. Super friendly people. Not the cheapest food option, but awesome taste. I would totally recommend this joint.
author: Tania C.

description:
For me a good test of a restaurant is the quality of the side dishes that accompany a main dish.  At this charismatic dining experience the mashed potatoes, spätzle, mixed veggies, red cabbage and dumpling-thingy (don't know the name but you gotta try it) RULED.  Seriously.  These dishes can sometimes be doldrum place-fillers on one's plate - not here.

And then there was the brat, schnitzel, sauerbraten and beef roulade.  One word will do - YUM!!

Add fantastic German beer, intriguing German and sometimes East German decor (including a collection of small liquor bottles chosen from grandpa's collection of over 500 imported direct to next-to-the-bar, a Germanic medicine cabinet in the bathroom and a neon shower curtain keeping the cold weather out just inside the front door) and witty but cheery service and you get an A+.
author: Scott S.

description: A wonderfully kitsch homage to the former East Germany.  Solid beer selection and well-done northern German cuisine.  I recently dined family-style with a group of ten and, while all of the dishes were tasty...there's only so much one can do to make northern European food delicious.
author: Ted R.

description: Second visit - second GREAT MEAL.... The Special was a stuffed port chop....very moos, very satisfying.... Kicked off my Max Raabe, German weekend in style....
author: John A.

description: Herring and Heff is the way to go at Walzwerk.  Not only are their portions German sized, they are extremely delicious.  Moreover, I love the way the place is set up.  Nothing matches, from the plates to the chairs to the uneven legs on their tables.  And I find it endearing.  Even moreso than the awesome service.
author: Ivy R.

description:
Walzwerk's food is how I remember it from home. I love the Koestritzer Schwarzbier, which is a black beer but oh so delicious. The ambiance is like an east german school room, propaganda all over the walls and so much stuff from the whole GDR era - its very (n)ostalgic.

Try the salmon appetizer with the dark bread and have some of the Bratwurst with mashed potatoes and sauerkraut. Their cook is awesome...the service slightly moody. However, if you want the real german food experience - go there and you won't be disappointed.
author: Conny F.

description:
Do you love Schnitzel? Are you a vegetarian? Well you must have already been to Walzwerk.

The food is delicious, the atmosphere is kitsch and the wait staff is adorable.
author: Angela K.

description:
Went here for Sunday early dinner with family.  Our cousin-in-law is a transplant from Germany (with the obvious German accent) and he made reservations for our party of 6.  According to my cousin, the food is very authentic East German -- like something Axel's grandma would make when they went to her house for dinner -- from the cooking to the mismatched dinnerware to the old-school china that after dinner coffee was served in!

We started with potato pancakes and herring as our appetizers.  Entrees ordered were Salmon in caper sauce, Bratwurst, Jager Schnitzel (mushroom cream sauce) and Chicken Cordon Bleu (apparently commonly served in Germany.)  

For dessert we all had the apple streudel.  Perfectly diced apples with a sprinkling of raisins and spices wrapped in a thin pastry with a light coat of powdered sugar.  Yummy.

The decor was something out of East Germany, although I have never been there.  Maybe I have visions of what it would be like based on some Pink Floyd videos.  The dining tables were old, heavy steel desks that looked older than the ones I recall seeing in grade school in the late 70's.  Ditto for the chairs.  

Music: They played some kind of 80s techno (at a reasonable volume).  

Good food, reasonable prices.  Our dinner for 4 (4 adults and 2 kids) came out to $120 including tax and tip.
author: Spicy T.

description:
I just celebrated my 23rd birthday party here last night. Since I got my hair done at Glama-Rama (which is next door) I have wanted to check it out. And I was not disapointed!

I made my birhday reservation a couple hours before...and the waitress/hostess was SO NICE and accomidating. They even put my birthday cake in the fridge for us.

Looking at the menu, almost everything looked delicious. I LOVE german food so I was really excited. But I was most excited about the beer! So many goodies to choose from!
I am a curious girl and when I saw the DIESEL (1/2 coca cola 1/2 beer) I just had to try it. The waitress sensed my hesitation and gave me a little taster before I ordered the whole sha-bang. It was suprisingly WONDERFUL! And its only $4 !! nice!!!

When it came time to order food here is what everyone ordered and the overall reaction

My bf and I started out with the pototo pancakes that came with applesauce and sour cream with chives...the potoato pancakes were okay (suppenkucke has better CRISPIER ones) but they were in no way bad tasting...they were just a little hash-browny.

A couple people at the table ordered the onion soup (on special that day) with the parmesean crisps...I tried it and thought the soup was hearty and flavorful but needed MORE CHEESE! the ratio of cheese to soup was seriously lacking. 
My friend ordered the cured salmon appetizer and didnt eat half of it. The salmon was flabby and super greasy...thumbs down for salmon.

I had the Jaeger Shnitzel with creamy mushroom sauce and spatzle...OMG that is a gut buster! It was FUCKING DELICIOUS! and very filling and very rich! YUM!

my bf got the Vegetarian Shnitzel (basically breaded and fried veggies) that was accompanied by mashed 'taters, and a pickled cucumber salad. The deep fried beet was WONDERFUL!!! It was all great. 

The best part about the whole night was when the waitress arranged AND LIT all the candles on my cake and brought it out to me singing HAPPY BIRTHDAY!! i felt like I was part of her big german family! I loved it!!! She thought it was a little odd we were eating TRES LECHE cake at a German restaurant but we all thought it was quite amusing.

I will deifnitly be back.
author: Keila E.

description:
Delicious! I liked the herring appetizer, the stuffed (with some fruit and bacon, I think) chicken, and whatever I got the second time. I think I liked everything else I had too; I just wish I could remember what it was.

Wheelchair accessible -- only if you can get over a big step, twice (i.e. there are two spaced far enough apart to be tackled independently of each other).
author: Chris E.

description: I love this place.  Good food, good vibe, and a good value.  Just wish I came here more often!
author: Adam O.

description: Small restaurant but wonderful food. Definitely has an East Germany feel to it.
author: Johanna W.

description: This place was wunderbar.  I would definitely go here again.
author: Austin V.

description: Their pork loin was tasty and the beer was fine. It was not as good as I had imaged before I actually dine there, but it was still a lovely, nice little German restaurant.
author: I-An K.

description:
I stopped in with some friends to experience my first German meal. I was not expecting to like it very much, if at all, but I am definitely a fan now! I have never had such yummy potato pancakes, the entrees we all shared (I can't remember the names) were great as well, and the abundance and variety of beers is a plus! 

The service was good, and the ambiance was chill and homey. We were fortunate enough to get a table right when we arrived our first night without reservations, the next few times we stopped in there was a long wait (once we waited an hour).
author: Violet S.

description:
mmmmm .... happy belly

Good beer, really good food. Desserts are a little weaker than the other courses. Decor and theme is kitschy without being annoying.

Make sure to get there early, it's not a big place.
author: Uncle F.

description:
Uber - German!  Uber-ick!  Since when is "vegetarian schnitzel" deep-fried vegetables?  With weird green sauce that looked fattening but tasted like nothing.....And how can deep fried anything taste bad?  Like the oil was too cold and the veggies just soaked it up.  Makes for a good stomach ache.  Alright, maybe vegetarian anything isn't their strong suite.  But I say -- if you can't do it well, then don't put it on the menu.  Service is slow, but I suppose that's the European way.  Nevertheless I asked for a water refill that never came -- I gave up and left.  Plus the restaurant is full of super-loud drunk people, making it impossible to carry on a conversation without being one of the obnoxious loud people.

Redeeming factors that save this place from 1-star land?  The inside is adorable and full of German kitsch.  The cucumber salad and cooked cabbage were pretty good.
author: Lisa C.

description: I set up a small surprise Birthday dinner here for my Boyfriend and they were VERY accommodating. There is a little wait time involved with ordering and getting your food but there is just some charm about this place and the two young ladies working there that makes it all worth it. It's nothing fancy but it does appear to be very authentic in the areas of decor and also menu from what I can remember from my visit to Germany years ago. Schnitzel was GREAT! Stuffed Chicken was okay. Oh yeah and these ladies even brought out a complimentary sampling of some of their appetizers. We were there at 6pm on a Thursday and it was a nice intimate setting...by the time we left it was packed at about 8 so plan accordingly and just be patient..trust me, its all worth it.
author: Eric A.

description: if you want some german food, go here. the place isn't huge so a reservation may be a good idea.
author: Ameer N.

description: I need to get back here. It's been probably 3-4 years since I went. I friggin love this place. Authentic food served and cooked by actual German people. Go figure.
author: David G.

description:
Small Potato Pancakes, Jger Schnitzel with Sptzle and Creamy Mushrooom Sauce, & Kstritzer Schwarzbier. 
Oh so good.  Just go.
author: M E.

description:
Great atmosphere, wonderful service,delicious food reasonably priced and their desserts are to die for. Great selection of german beers and wines. Giant back room is great for birthdays and group dinners. My favorite secret spot in the mission!
If your looking for a great place for a memorable date this place is magical. Complete with cande-light and fun table settings!
author: Charlie B.

description:
This place is great. The dcor makes it even more authentic. It's a load of food, so I space out the visits, but otherwise I'd be here more often. I love the Thuringer salad & have enjoyed almost every dish at one point or another. There is a great selection of beer and the service is fast and friendly. When they are slow or backed up they apologize for it and might even buy you a beer to make up for it. It's good for groups or just a few people and the bars in the Mission are close enough so that you can walk over if you aren't quite ready to head home after your meal. 

My man is German and one of his friends is from E.Germany. We've all been here several times & everyone loves it. It's a nice alternative to Suppenkuche (German, but not East German), which has gotten really expensive and so noisy I barely hear myself think, let alone eat my spaetzle.
author: Amarar S.

description:
I was surprised that this seemingly hole in the wall spot had such incredible food.  I do love the cultural experience of food, but that is harder to get from western foods than eastern.

Walzwerk's does not fail to deliver, a German staff adds to the feel and with the variety of dishes my companions brought to the table they were all a hit.  At first, nobody wanted to share their food, but in the end they were big enough plates that the leftovers were up for grabs.
author: Ian E.

description:
The food definitely deserves 4-5 stars. We had the Jaegerschnitzel with the Spaetzle and the Bratwurst that came with Sauerkraut and mashed potatoes. Very, very tasty. 

The parts that were FAAAAR  from good were that our order got completely messed up and it took them almost an hour to get the wrong dishes to our table.  Our original order was the plain Schnitzel and the Bratwurst, but what we got after this freakin LONG wait was the Jaegerschnitzel and some chicken dish. Granted they looked good but those were not the plates we ordered.  The waitress admitted to having screwed up and apologetically offered that we keep one and that the Bratwurst would be prepared right away.  Hmm...being pregnant and hungry didn't leave us with much choice, so we kept the cutlet and started eating that it. Not bad. Very heavy because of the cream sauce but still yummy. The Bratwurst, when it finally arrived, was delicious.  Thank god...

They charged us only for the sausage in the end, which was very nice. If everything had gone well, this would have been a great experience. However, it's probably very worth another visit as we think that the food is tastier than Suppenkueche. As for the Wiener Schnitzel though, can't compare to Schnitzelhaus until we try Walzwerk's.
author: Hadley K.

description: I couldn't have been more pleased with the food, the service or the atmosphere.  The chicken with apple & bacon was amazing but that's not to say the rest wasn't also excellent.
author: Rebecca O.

description: Walzwerk was absolutely awful. We had a group dinner here in the back room. The service was inconsistent at times and downright rude at others. I ordered a dish specifically because it came with spaetzle which I had from the reviews was really good. Without telling me, they substituted the spaetzle with something else when the food came out. When I asked them about it, all they said was "We ran out." No apologies. If you're a German restaurant, you shouldn't run out of spaetzle. If you do, don't wait for the food to come for me to discover it myself. And when I ask you about it, don't act like I'm inconveniencing you to serve me what I ordered. Will NEVER eat there again. Suppenkuche will get my business from now on.
author: Sabrina K.

description:
Been here a couple of times and I had a pleasurable experience on both occasions. Had the potato pancakes again (yums) with applesauce, and the schnitzel. My favortite german dish is the cheese spaetzle, which I did not get, but regular spaetzle does come with a couple main courses.
A decent beer selection (duh) and a attentive staff does this body good.

 And I'll it a extra star for the heavy duty door outside has a nice weight to it!!!
author: wayne s.

description:
downhill.  is the high speed train this place is on.  the other night, they ran out of schnitzel.  and spatzle.  this affected every single one of our orders.  how can you run out of schnitzel?  and spatzle?  we stopped in for an early dinner at 7pm famished after a hike in muir woods.  and wait, they didn't tell us until 15 minutes *after* we placed our orders.  which was really annoying.  and not sure what's going on back there but she later comes back and says one of us can get the last schnitzel.  so the other tries to order sauerbraten, which comes with potato dumplings.  but guess what?  you guessed it, they're out of potato dumplings.  ??!?

i used to think this place was better than suppenkuche and i used to proselytize this fact widely.  but then somethings gone terribly wrong here, though you wouldn't know it from the continuing lines that build out onto the street for this place.  one thing i do know is that some of the waitstaff seems to have moved to suppenkuche in the last year or so.  perhaps he took all the recipes with him.  

granted the food wasn't exactly what we all had ordered, but we made the necessary adjustments in expectations they required.  we were famished, but we still have tastebuds.  i can still scrape the salt deposits off the roof of my mouth.  overly salted, oily fatty sauces.  the red cabbage was all sugary sweet, no sour.  dumping salt, sugar, and oil on everything tells me either your ingredients are turning and you don't want me to know, or you just don't give and crap about what you're putting on my plate.  one of the sides - seasonal vegetables was a bunch of overly salted and buttered frozen broccoli.  my tri-tip roulade was dry, which defies even my imagine, and tasted like squirrel, leaving me to assume it probably definitely wasn't tri-tip.  the potato pancakes were just their mashed potatoes shaped into a hockey puck and pan fried in oil.  not my kind of potato pancakes. 

i peaked back in to the kitchen to see what all was happening back there and it was authentic all right, authentic war-time berlin.  or like a dank abandoned house in east berlin where squatters have taken over.  food spattered on the walls, bits strewn everywhere, and puddles of sauce and chunks covering the floors.  dishes being hosed and scattered about.  now authentic is not the right word for it since most germans are a fastidiously, painstakingly clean folk. in short, this kitchen was unacceptable by even the dirtiest mission standards.  
as i walked back to my table, i must have been visibly peeved, since the owner gave me the most sad and apologetic smile she could muster without saying a word.  i wanted to ask her to come taste our food. but i didn't.  

the only thing good about this place is the beer and the friendly, if clueless, server.  one star each.  but that is never going to bring me back, especially at $90 bucks for 3 people.  what a waste.
author: Nikki F.

description: If I could give this restaurant 0 stars, I would. This review is just based on service, and not the food. We showed up for dinner on a Saturday night around 6:30pm. Host/owner told us it would be about a 45 minute wait, so we left our name and walked around the neighborhood to kill time. We returned promptly 45 minutes later, only to have the owner tell us the table intended for us had cleared out earlier than expected, and she waited a whole FIVE minutes for us to return, then gave our table to another group. I expressed my frustration openly to her, and she had the nerve to snap back at me, saying it was my fault and that this restaurant was probably not the place for us to have dinner. You know what Walzwerk, you're right. This isn't the place for me, and I will NEVER, EVER eat at your establishment again. The owner is rude and inconsiderate. So what if your food is good. Service counts for something in this business.
author: Tiffany L.

description: You are now entering East Berlin, seriously.  That's what the sign says and its true.  I just really enjoyed my experience.   I had 4 stars worth of fun but the food was 3 stars and that always wins out in hindsight.
author: Sarah A.

description: I pride myself knowing most of the great local eats in SF, so I was floored when I was introduced Walzwerk this week and found out this place has been around for 12 years.  I went there with a friend to catch up and it was the perfect locale.  This place is charmingly quaint, the German hosts are funny, welcoming and down to earth, and the food is pretty good. (Honestly, the food is more of a 3-star worthy rating.  However, all the elements of the place come together nicely...plus, the company was great too...so Walzwerk deserves a solid 4 starts.)
author: Ben M.

description:
I've come here on and off for years, but my last visit there was for my birthday celebration with friends and I have to say it was one of my favorite times there.  We pretty much took over the back room and had a great time.

The staff were so friendly and accommodating to our group of ten and always kept the beer flowing! The food was great, the portions huge and the atmosphere loads of fun.  It was a perfect place to share a nice meal with a group of good friends and not feel like you're annoying any hipsters nearby, because it seems that Walzwerk appeals to everyone and anyone and not just some trendspotters looking for the next big thing.  

We never felt rushed and seemed to all love the whole thing.  Big points for the potato pancakes, the jager schnitzel, the chicken and of course, the many beers we tried!!!  Definitely one of my favorite places and I will be back soon for sure.
author: Erik A.

description:
Correct me or not... but this place is all about the Jgerschnitzel (just in case if your computer isn't european-la-la-language-accent-marker compatible, the Jaegerschnitzel).  It was so damn good that I'm even afraid that I'd not find the equivalent in Berlin. The menu is mostly composed of East German dishes. 

Uber-cool atmosphere with all those East German souvenirs, especially in the toilet...faux-spooky! 

Waiters are quite nice and pretty punctual with bringing us our orders...sehr gemtlich!
author: Jesada P.

description:
Jager schnitzle floats my mushroom loving boat. The trio of salads is yummy, who knew you could do so much with cabbage? Portions are made for giants, but that makes for yummy leftovers. I wasn't really a fan of the veggie roulades, but their beers make up for that.

And a bonus point to these folks for actually giving my parents a memorable meal. Our waiter sat down at our table to chat with my folks about their experience on their visit to Germany and to discuss why their schnizle is not made from veal. My dad is super fussy, but our waiter charmed the socks off of him. I am *so* grateful!
author: Rabbit H.

description:
Yeah, this place is bomb. Wait staff was friendly, beer and food were great. Portions are a good size, food is hearty and flavorful, what more can you ask for?

Might not be a good stop for vegetarians...
author: IK U.

description:
Walzwerk is a good solid restaurant, but I wish the food quality was just a bit better. I think that Suppenkuche outshines Walzwerk on the food, but I like the homey atmosphere here.

We ordered the Diesel (Coke and Beer), herring salad, pork schnitzel in a mushroom sauce with spaetzle, with the kartofelpuffer.

The kartoffelpuffer needed a bit more crispness - the thickness made it a bit too soft for my taste. The spaetzle were a bit too dried out, maybe overcooked in the oven?

The service was very friendly and the meal was satisfying and filling. The portions are pretty big so you can consider sharing a dish.
author: Spoon G.

description:
I like the place and I like the people that work there. I also like their beer selection. They didn't even card me so that makes me very happy. I had the hef and it was pretty good. A bit light but good nevertheless.

The food. I had the stuff trout and it was a miss. My friend had the tenderloin and it was also a miss. In fact, it's a huge miss cause it was just so damn chewy and dry. However, the schnitzel was off the hook so I guess that one single dish that redeemed everything. My other friend had the salad and soup and she said that the soup tasted a lot like pickle juice. I don't know, since I didn't try it, I don't want to take her words in verbatim. The stuffed chicken breast with cherry sauce was AAAMAZING! The potato dumpling was also really good, although I still think it could be a little bit crispier. 

Overall, I would definitely take my friends back there.
author: Chen N.

description:
I was tempted to give this 1 star simply to bring the average rating down, because this place is already so hard to get a table at, but I realize it's pointless. My honest evaluation is that this is as good as it gets for German food (and I am German), and one of the best places overall for gloomy winter days. 

What sets the place apart from your typical German restaurant outside of Germany (which generally make you feel like you're at Oktoberfest) is that it specializes in East German cuisine (and decor!). The thing to keep in mind about East German food is that it's basically the same as West German food, except they had to get creative due to a lack of available ingredients, so there are plenty of variations on a basic theme. The menu at Walzwerk, accordingly, is small and creative, and judging by the authenticity of the food I was surprised to learn that the cook is Mexican.

Don't show up at this place without a reservation - or better yet, don't show up there at all, so you won't be taking my table.
author: Eric W.

description:
Went there as usual ordering the potato pancake and salad apps and the schnitzels for entree.
Easy enough, right?
No.
Apparently the owner (seriously, shouldn't the owner of a business be above mistakes like the following?) decides to bring out our entrees and apps ALL AT THE SAME TIME...when we looked at her puzzled, she said :no big deal, we'll keep them warm till you finish the appetizers. Before we could object, she ran off. When we were done with apps, they brought the same 2 plates back! You'd imagine for their mistake, they would refire our entrees considering they are fried and leaving them to go limp
 on the kitchen counter ain't cool...
The schnitzels as a result were tough as leather, veggies lame and the mashed potatoes congealed. They made a point to ignore us the rest of the night. And we go there pretty regularly. Well, not anymore!
Honey you lost our business for good! A little consideration and etiquette would have gone a long way.
author: Sara K.

description:
Something about German food that ALWAYS hits the spot for me. It must be all the carbs. 

Walzwerk is REALLY good, their Jäger Schnitzel, VERY good. It's a VERY VERY small place. so if you're claustrophobic, this wouldn't be the place for you, or just order Togo.

Genieen Sie!
author: S A.

description: It's like Suppenkuche, but a bit more intimate and much better for a date. So, its like Suppenkuche, minus the awkwardness of dining along with frat brothers who came to get wrecked and scream "DAS BOOT!" all loud and stuff in your ear, like everyone else hasn't seen Beerfest already anyway.
author: Chloe N.

description:
It pains me to write this review, I feel like a less than willing Abraham with a clever and so forth. However it may pain me to give this place a single star I think its important to air this grievance as its bugged me for several years now. 

I brought my mother and grandmothers here a few years ago along with my father. I had been here several times before and had wonderful experiences each and every single time. The herring salad kept bringing me back, that and the wonderful "brot". 

It was a lovely afternoon and we had a delightful meal of dishes that we all knew in one form or another, as we're all byproducts of the soviet regime. My mother insisted on paying the bill (there's just no arguing with a text-book classic Russian Jewish mother) so I let her. As we walked out of the restaurant a tall blond waitress chased us out and asked my mother "was there something wrong with the service?" My mother was completely taken aback, she said, no, not at all. The waitress went on to say "we live off our tips, yours was so small, we thought something was wrong." I went pale at this moment and I think my mother was just as pale if not sporting a more authentic countenance of death. She quickly dug into her purse and pulled out a twenty and handed it to the waitress just to end the uncomfortable scene. 

Perhaps my mother's arithmetic was off, maybe she did leave too little, maybe she felt that the food and service were substandard and as she was paying she has the right to tip to the level of the service. If you ever want someone to return you don't chase them out of the restaurant and demand a greater gratuity. 

Whatever the reason she left how much she left; we were a party of five and were not subject to the automatic x% for parties of 6/7 or more that are standard fare in restaurants. Whatever the case or the reason the waitress turned what was a fantastic day with our progenitors into something of a nightmare. For this reason I've never gone back and as such feel inclined to leave this single star in response to this woman ruining our afternoon and making my mother and grandmothers, to whom we had to translate the uncomfortable scene to, feel incredibly awkward. There really was no call for that, my mother is generally a good tipper, and whatever her reasons were to tip less than what this woman felt she deserved, were her own. For this waitress's heartless action I won't go back there... its too bad really cause I loved the food but I feel like the restaurant is partially to blame for allowing their wait staff to pull those kind of antics...
author: Len S.

description:
no beer boots, but all RAD.

my friend and I started with the potato pancakes, and like almost everyone writes about=they were epic.

I had the jager schnitzel, and even though I probably will not be able to pass it through my body for like 8 years , it's ok because it was off the hook amazing.

Awesome and friendly staff.Neat decor. I will be back as soon as I'm done digesting last night's dinner,which could take a while.Thank you Walzwerk!
author: Lauren V.

description: Great German food! Most of the items on the menu are meat and potatoes, but they do it very well. You are getting wholesome, hearty food here. Portions aren't super-huge, but they are definitely enough. I had a beef roulade, which was brushed on the inside with whole-grain mustard, lined with bacon, and stuffed with pickle. It also came with spatzle, red cabbage, and a tomatoey sauce. Everything was perfect. It was my first time having spatzle, and it was quite interesting--toasty and chewy (maybe a bit spongey). The red cabbage was pleasantly tart and tasted a bit like apple too. I'm thinking they used apple cider vinegar, which was a good choice! The meat was delicious.
author: Michael F.

description:
Went to this place for my friend's birthday, which heard about from his coworker.  It really is one of those hole in the walls other than it having a little overhang out front.  The inside was small, but it was pretty crowded too.

We ordered some drinks and it came up we were celebrating a birthday when they carded us.  So, they brought the drinks with some little tiny bottles of something called "Underberg."  It wasn't a drink, but an after-meal bitter that happens to be 44% alcohol by vol, lol.  They introduced us to this custom of toasting each other while looking them dead straight in the eyes and then downing it like a shot.  It tastes and smells like root beer along with a bunch of other spices.  It goes down smooth and not too bad of an aftertaste.  It made my girlfriend's ears feel warm.

We ordered the roast garlic pork, schnitzel (breaded porkloin), and the sauerbraten (marinated beef).  

The beef was the best in my opinion.  It was very tender like veal and the sauce tasted kind of like a wine reduction.  This dish also came with potato dumplings that were delicious and red cabbage, also good.

I liked the breaded pork loin next.  It was what you would expect from a breaded pork loin, although more tender.  The garlic pork had a wonderful sauce but the pork was a tiny bit overcooked, but still great with the sauce.

Desert was a terrific apple strudel and ice cream. The strudel has small, diced apples, raisins, and nuts, and is NOT filled with all that gooey junk from store bought strudels.

Service was excellent and authentically German (hard to understand accents sometimes).  And we definitely appreciated the birthday toast.  Food was great considering none of us knew what to expect from German food.   Perhaps a little pricey for the amount you get and somewhat out of the way.
author: Aaron F.

description: This place is good, not great.  We came here when the wait at Suppenkuche was too long.  The food was good, but nothing really spectacular.  For dessert we got a piece of cake that was absolutely terrible and our waitress could tell and gave it to us for free, which was really nice.  I will come back, but strongly prefer suppenkuche.
author: Aaron L.

description:
One of the first places my boyfriend took me on a date, and it was good. One of my closest friends is German and loves to cook, so I am accustomed to real traditional German food and wasn't sure this place would live up to my friend, but it did. The dishes are simple, but true to their origin, and of course the beer is good. It has a nice intimate atmosphere, and a nice place for a cozy meal. With respect to the service I can't say anything other than they were very nice to us!

So I went back again last night and I had the stuffed pork with cabbage and Spätzle, and my boyfriend had the stuffed chicken with cherry sauce that comes with good old peas and mash. ONce again, two big thumbs up for the food. It was so good and wholesome, and the beer went down a treat again too. I'm a definite fan!
author: Michelle C.

description: We actually found this place, which was a very small neighborhood restaurant.  But my, it was really good.  From the cream of potato with garlic soup, to the sauerbraten, to the chicken with a great sauce, all the way down to the apple streudel.  It seems German restaurants are few and far between where I live so it was a treat to find one while visiting San Francisco.  And this was a good one!
author: Dave C.

description:
Completely disagree with the previous post.

Went with a group of 7 and had a very good meal.  I tried everything on the table: beef remoulade, chicken breast, pork goulash, schnitzel, etc...pretty much 2/3 of the menu.  All was quite good.  Not exceptional, but quite a bit better than the competition--i.e. Suppenkuche.  The reason it gets four stars besides the solid food is the atmosphere.  I felt like I was walking into a German family's living room.  And that, to me, is one of the bigger compliments one can give.
author: Austin F.

description:
So the Yelp definition of 3-stars is "A-OK," and I think that's pretty accurate to describe Walzwerk.  I had a good time, but I'm not itching to go back.  

The pros:
Reservations for big groups - Whereas it's pretty tough to get a relatively last minute reservation for a group at Suppenkuche, this place could accommodate.
Parking - Super easy to park!  A rarity in this fine city of ours....
The name - It's just good fun to say Walzwerk in an overly accented German accent - "Vahlzverk...Let's go to Vahlzverk!" (Am I too easily amused?  Don't answer that!)

Only so-so:
Ambiance:  I liked the decor - very old regime, but the space was pretty small and felt a little cramped.  People are drinking large amounts of beer and eating way too much sausage, i.e., everyone is here to have a good time, but the space didn't really allow for collective rabblerousing.
Food:  I really enjoyed the potato pancakes and also had the stuffed chicken, which was actually quite good.  But the mashed potatoes definitely came out of a box, and the peas/carrots were definitely some frozen veggies.  Also, I didn't think their non-wurst options were as extensive (or maybe just as tasty) as Suppenkuche.
Service:  If you want water, you have to ask for it specifically (including refills).  But we did get an authentic German waitress for part of the time, so points for that!

Again, a good time was had by all!  But go more for the fun than for the food, in my opinion.
author: Sumona P.

description:
the wait can be long for the authentic german comfort foods. however, if you're into trying new things or a fan of the old favorites, this is a great place to be adventurous. the decor screams berlin circa 1980s and the service is not bad either. will go again.

We ordered:
--Vegetarian Schnitzel with the mashed potatoes and cucumber salad 
--Cheese Spätzle (Homemade Egg Noodle) with a Mixed Salad
--Cold Cut Platter (Pumpernickel & Whole Wheat Bread with Salami & Cheese)

all i have to say is that i am a fan!
author: Monlia W.

description:
I wanted so badly to like this place.  Really, truly.  The "W" in Alyssa W. should actually be prounounced like a "V" if we were to be linguistically accurate around my last name.  
The Beau, the Vegetarian and I went out dinner on Saturday night and were so excited after all the great reviews.

Reasons for 2 stars:
1.  They seated us in the back room then promptly forgot about us.  The Beau had to get up and grab menus for us (not from a waitress, just from a pile of menus at the bar).  The waitress came over 10 minutes later and actually said "Oh I'm so sorry, I forgot you!" but she had a charming German accent so we forgave her.
2.  Someone came over to bring us silverware after we had ordered apps and I asked her for another round of beers for the table.  "I'm NOT your waitress.  I'll get her to come over."  10 minutes later, still no waitress.  And no beer.
3.  The same woman brought out our appetizers.  We ordered the beer/onion/cheese soup, and she didn't have spoons with her.  Not wanted to be abandoned for another 10 minutes while our soup got cold, I asked for spoons "when you get a chance."  Her response?  "I KNOW.  I only have TWO hands." 
4.  Still no beers.
5.  The Beau gets his beer.  Still none for moi.  Not for another 5 minute or so.
6.  The food was average, I'd give them 3 stars for the food alone.  
7.  Not Our Waitress Woman seemed more like a waitress than our actual server.  She brought out all our food and handled the bill at the end of the meal.  The only thing she DIDN'T do was take our orders.  That kind of attitude is really unacceptable.  We just wanted some more booze, folks.  I would think Germans could understand that.

Potato pancakes were too thick for us; we were all used to thinner ones.  But they did taste good.  
Soup was nothing special.  
The Beau got the schnitzel and I got the jager schintzel.  Both were desperately under-seasoned.  The Vegetarian ordered the vegarian schnitzel and was really disappointed to find that they were really just deep-fried breaded vegetables.  They weren't even cooked all the way through - the potatoes were still crunchy.  Gross.

Sorry for the long review, but I'm still fuming.  There was quite a wait when we walked out of the restaurant.  If I'm going to be standing around waiting for German food, you'll find me at Suppenkuche.
author: Alyssa W.

description: Ok, first and foremost I would like to start off by saying  I go to Germany a lot on business. So I know what good german food tastes like. I had the soup and the schnitzel. #1 Schnitzel is best when it is veal. 2# my schnitzel was very tough pork and flavorless breading. I dont remember the last time I ever didn't finish a piece of schnitzel in my life. I didnt finish it their. The i had the apple strudel for dessert its looked dynamite when it arrived but when it hit my mouth it was uninspiring. Bottom line the food wasnt very good. The reason for the two stars was for the 2 cute german waitresses and good beer. Other than that had much better food in my time.
author: d m.

description: Good real German food. Good real German Beer. Served by real European people. Good.
author: Anthony S.

description:
Went here for the girlfriends birthday with her parents, food was alright but i really was not impressed with the service at all. Luckily we had a reservation and getting seated was not a problem. They were quick to take our drink orders but after that it seemed we were somewhat neglected. finally we got to order but it took forever to get our food. Granted it was fairly buys it seemed like other parties who came in later were getting fed before us. After finally getting our food it seemed even more difficult to get any service or attention from our waiter. I really was not so impressed.

i will end on a lighter note though. The food, i thought, was pretty good. Started things off with the potato cakes and salad. Very tasty. We also got the veggie schnitzel which was alright but not great. I wasn't too excited on the vegetables they put in it but it was still enjoyable. All in all, the food was pretty good but probably not good enough to make up for how unimpressed with the service. i might go back on a slower night but will probably want try out somewhere new if i'm having a german craving.
author: Derek Y.

description: Love it every time.  My fave?  The pickled herring, of course!
author: Alan B.

description: Awesome German food and the owner, who is likely to be your server, is very friendly and gracious.  It's small, but a great find!
author: Sandra M.

description: Food was excellent...servers and manager engaging, knowledgeable, and very authentic...decor appropriate and quaint...Ausgezeichnet!
author: Mike H.

description:
Want a German meal like Mom used to make - or at least someone's German Mom? Walzwerk is the spot. 

It's a straight up kind of place. You know you're in a German joint by the decor, tables, chairs, etc. Definitely some kul stuff to look at on the walls. Love the record albums in the back! 

Nice staff. Nice options - fare for vegans, vegetarians, pescetarians, and you meat eaters. 

Excellent portions- good prices, and most importantly, the food is authentic. I've had all of the fish and vegetarian dishes. Mashed potatoes, red cabbage, grilled salmon, stuffed cabbage, the soups, and the house-cured salmon are my faves. I've had better latkes. 

I'd give the place 5 stars if the upkeep of the floors, walls, and restrooms was better. 

All in all, they got real gut stuff over there at Walzwerk.
author: Carson R.

description: Walzwerk is just charming and the food is delicious. I've been to gatherings here both large and intimate and have always been pleased with the service and the food. I love the design of the place, it's like stepping into Eastern Germany. The bathroom is a highlight I love all the vintage records and toiletries. It's cozy and perfect.
author: Roxanne L.

description:
This is one of my favorite places in the city and the place I take people when I'm trying to show them how cool San Francisco is. A trip to Walzwerk is a trip back in time to a slightly psychedelic version of post-war East Germany and people usually enjoy the lounge-y environment. 

Wide selection of German beers, very reasonably priced and since you probably won't have heard of these fine imports, they are more than generous with their beer samples, which is rad! Great service every time I visit.

Seriously, eat there.
author: Luam M.

description: I enjoyed the beer, though the Schnitzel inspired in me a strange longing to tunnel under a heavily-fortified wall of some sort to escape to freedom.
author: Vic S.

description: This is a dismal, dark little hole with mediocre food. Having been to East Germany numerous times and having a German husband, we were both very disappointed with the whole experience. The decor is very East German feeling.... if by that you mean East Germany from the 1940's. It's all quite stereotypical and enjoyable for the first 10 minutes. Then you go blind from the dim light and leave hungry from the food that is not very good. There is more to German food than jaegerschnitzel and matjes. Really. We will not be returning because there are other places that are more welcoming, with better food.
author: Crystal S.

description: This is a really nice place with great food. Went there with a big group and got a group table in the back room. The food tasted very authentic and they had a good selection of drinks. As a bonus, parking is very easy.
author: Johannes G.

description: Delicious german food with a kitschy atmosphere. Wacky East German consumer goods (check out the album covers in the back room!), and posters. When they first opened the wait staff seemed to act rudely, in what I guess was a parody of american perceptions of east german communists? Unless our waitress was having a bad day! Either way, a fun place.
author: John A.

description: Walzwerk is a really small place and it is always busy, but the food is just fantastic.  They don't take reservations, so it's good to call ahead to see what the wait is like.  They have a small two seat bar that I am perfectly happy to sit at and chow down.
author: Mack S.

description: Simple in both authenticity and atmosphere, this restaurant mixes a little of East Germany with the family-friendly conditions of little neighborhod tratoria .  The owner waited on us, plopping down on the table three bottles of German white wines for me to try once she discovered I liked reisling.  The food was good German comfort food.  I had a lovely pork schnitzel.  Add my other favorite German s-word,  struedel, and I have to say it was perfect:  fresh, a little hint of tartness without the overlay of sugar you might expect elsewhere, and a superb crust.  As I write the food sits in "my belleeh," making me glad. I will be back!
author: Patrick B.

description: This place has really good food that reminded me of the food in Germany when I was last there. Found this place on yelp and it didn't let me, or my family, down!
