We have been looking for a good place to eat good schnitzel and now, we have one! The place is a little small, but it doesn't matter anymore when you fill your stomach with an amazing selection of beer and schnitzel!!!!! We ordered the potato pancakes, the herring, bratwurst, schnitzel, apple strudel and the cold dog desserts. Everything was amazing, and we left very satisfied. YUM! I highly suggest to try this place out if you ever feel like eating authentic East German food! Enjoy fellow yelpers!
author: Cristina D.

description:
vegetarian schnitzel, y'all.  

sprechen zi fucking delicious?
author: Laura B.

description: Excellent German food, great atmosphere.  Good beer selection.  Nice servers, no attitude.  Not in the most amazing area, but it's worth wherever you are coming from to have this food.  Made me want to go back to Germany.
author: betty b.

description:
I got a  gift certificate for my birthday so I wouldn't miss German food as much (I am originally from Germany). The place has a nice atmosphere and everyone was really nice. 
The only problem was the food:
Starters were ok, but nothing special. 
But the main dish was really really bad. The potato dumplings were so horrible I almost had to force myself to finish and most of the other food tasted like it came straight from a cheap can.
It's a pity because German food can be delicious - but if you are looking for good food, I really can't recommend this place.
author: Theresa K.

description: Great East German food!  Everyone at my table ordered the same thing, the fish special.  Whole fried rainbow trout, and yes I mean whole...eyes and all... served with spinach, potatoes and Brussels sprouts in a creamed spinach sauce.  After dinner, a shot of an alcohol/herb/digestive thing that came in a mini bottle.  I am not sure what it was..please let me know if you do...but I want more of it! Next time I am going back for the potato pancakes and some schnitzel!  Service was great and our waitress was super sweet.
author: Stacy R.

description: I hesitantly admit that I was afraid of German food. Afraid of the sauerkraut and bratwurst, and didn't know what a schnitzel was. I hate to be picky, but I didn't want to eat a big sausage and something too heavy. I was pleasantly surprised! I came here w/3 others and had one of the tastiest, kind of interesting meals. I had a chicken dish with a sauce that had dried cherries in it. It sounded like it would be decent, but it was amazingly good! Better than I expected and something I would go back to try again. Everything seemed very authentic and the staff were really proud of the restaurant (not sure if it's a family business).
author: Amy J.

description:
The food is still great, and if I return here, it will be purely to satisfy a craving. However, the brusque service I experienced last time turned into downright rude service on my most recent visit. I was part of a larger group with a reserved table. I didn't plan the reservation, but apparently a few of our party would be arriving late and perhaps not ordering dinner as a result. When the waitress heard this, she berated us for making the reservation for so many people if not all would be on time and eating, and said she'd need to decrease the size of the table since she had customers waiting. Fine - point taken - but isn't there a nice way to say this? She literally made us feel like we were in fourth grade and being scolded by the teacher. Plus, after moving the tables around, she made a point to come back and say, "Well, the party that was waiting just LEFT..." Our fault? What part of that is our problem? It really put a damper on the whole night. I try to be courteous when dining with a large group, and I know situations like ours are frustrating to deal with. But there's a difference between being stern/upholding restaurant policy, and being rude to customers.

After our food arrived she lightened up a bit, so maybe she felt bad (or maybe she didn't think she was rude). But it definitely made me think twice about coming back here, especially with a party larger than 2.
author: Beth T.

description:
If you are deciding on eating at Walzwerk at a prime dinner hour I encourage you to make a reservation.

I speak from experience.  Last week we waited a good hour for our table of 5.  (I couldn't make a reservation because I had no idea when my friends were going to finish their Christmas shopping.) However, we waited in good cheer, drinking our fair share of the .5L Radebergers.

I really enjoy the small spaces this restaurant offers.  The bar areas for two, a private room in the back for larger parties and the corner window tables in the front.

It really feels cozy wherever you are sitting and there are all sorts of authentic knick-knacks and memorabilia where if you use your imagination you might just feel like you are actually somewhere else. (I'm going to have to go with Germany on this one.)

As far as the food goes, I've had the Shnitzel, the Jager Shnitzel and the Bratwurst and everything has just been decadently amazing, satisifying taste and hunger in good portions.  The potato pancakes really do live up to their hype too, they are a must try.

I'd also like to note that the mustard that comes with the Bratwurst is so good I can only compare it to cocaine.
author: Adam C.

description:
Hmm, where should I start?...Well...what the fuck...here it goes. 

I'm not quite sure how I feel about this place. I have to admit, that I'm rather ambivalent when it comes to expressing the two experiences I've had on paper and in black & white for that matter. Therefore, what I'll do is start with the good aspects of this restaurant. First of all, they have some of the best German beer specimens this side of the Prime Meridian. In this respect, they are incomparable. Secondly, the food is hearty German fare, I've honestly learned to like the Teutonic tidbits featured on the Bauhuasesque menu. Why, even the lack of decor adds an almost stark nostalgia, that hearkens back to a Grimm Brothers fairy-tale. What, with the crocheted doily's and the Hansel & Gretel tulips and shit. 
Now for the bad. The service (or lack of) was something to be desired. Now, I've been in the "customer service" industry for years and granted, I know how it feels to get slammed. But come on...to be completely ignored on a "relatively" busy night is simply rude. And when you go up to say, order a beer (because you have been waiting for oh, about 20 minutes in the "lounge", for a table) and then have that shaved , sassy Wookie of a waiter, (literally) clap in your face to urge you to hurry up with your drink order, (like he has been waiting on you or something) is nothing short of an invitation to WAR! It only sours the whole dining experience. Due to this action alone, I will not be going back for a long while, maybe never. When I finally told it what I wanted to drink, (s)he then rolled her lidless eye and commented to another patron (who asked what it was pouring) "that he did not like it" and dismissed it, like (s)he only served it because it was it's job. Thanks for nothing Adolf. Not only did he commit a disservice to the other patron (discouraging a future order, perhaps) but disregarded my selection as well and with such disdain. I'm quite aware that we all have our own opinions but I was not there to hear him voice his. Perhaps this is the German way, but guess what? We are not in Germany. This is why I'm truly undecided in regards to my feelings about this place. I'm not sure the good food, great beer and quaint decor are worth it. 

One thing I do know for sure, is that the next German restaurant I'll spend my money at will be Suppenkuche.
author: Gabe T.

description: Will you still trust me if I keep giving out 5 stars? But really, Walzwerk is the best ever. Where else is it so much fun to wait a half-hour in a crowded space while people jostle the beer in your hand? But it's so cute and delicious (with pc meat for those who feel guilty eating it but can't quite stay on the veggie train). Suppenkuche is more severe fancypants German while Walzwerk is kooky east Berliner living under the specters of Marx and Lenin on the far wall. I love the bald waiter with the gold Pumas who said to my friend after dinner (in a broad German accent), "Actually, I really like your outfit." Actually, I really like your Walzwerk!
author: Katrina D.

description: Really cool vibe and yummy food. Good beer selection as well. The ambiance is charming, not one fork was from the same set at our table.
author: Mike I.

description: A very nice distraction from the norm, this cozy spot features an authentic menu (verified by my friend, also in attendance, who lived in Berlin for several years). The atmosphere was eclectic -- it's a dining room filled with middle school-ish art tables and discarded chairs from another era, but it works. The food was hearty and good, as were the many hefeweizens. And speaking of drinking too much, here's a tip: Don't get cheeky and say, "Ich liebe dich" to the server. She won't love you back, take my word.
author: Gregor G.

description:
There is a huge contrast between Schnitzelhaus and Walzwerk.  

Schnitzelhaus is LOUD w/ the SAME euro trash cd on EVERY TIME.
Walwerk is quiet w/ instrumental music and you can actually hear people speaking

Schnitzelhaus is much bigger now that they expanded next door
Walzwerk is tiny...main room only fits around 25 people? 

Schnitzelhaus breads and fries their schnitzel (i like the fried better)
Walzwerk only has two schnitzel...only one of them lightly breaded

Schnitzelhaus spatzle is thinner and smaller
Walzwerk spatzle is bigger and sauted a little (I like this one better)

Schnitzelhaus service can be very slow
Walzwerk service is much faster
author: LT B.

description:
My new friend from  East Germany is homesick and I was brought here to learn about German beer.  It was the rainiest day I have ever experienced in San Francisco, the entire city seemed to be a puddle and a cab was no-where to be found.  I BARTED to Mission and we decided to walk from there ( it is very walkable, maybe 3 blocks) .  When we arrived at the restaurant it felt so homey it was comforting and exciting all at once.  For such a rainy day when no one in their right mind would be out it seemed crowded, no open tables and no where to sit and wait, but they served us drinks none the less and spoke German to my friend which was neat to hear. Although I do not remember what the  beer I drank was called, it was really good, and was not served too warm and was not served too cold - just right for a freezing and soaking wet southern Californian.  All of the deco is done East German pre-fall-of -the-wall style. My friend went around to all of the walls and was wide eyed (almost teary -but in a manly way) as he explained what all of the brands/ pictures meant and once were when he was a child. At last we were seated and ate, he had a Beef Stoganoff ( I think) and what I ate I have no idea what it was called, but I will describe : thin beef rolled around mustard and pickles served with snitzle ? and this cabbage stuff.. I know it sounds gross but everything except for the cabbage was good, and the cabbage was probably good, but I just don't like cabbage.  I wanted to lick my plate clean, but I was on a date and I figure universally I should save licking my plate clean for date #4 or 5.  For dessert ( yeas he ordered dessert ! ) Was a cake that he said was very common for people to make in summer. It was a dry white cake/cookie with chocolate holding it together. It looked and tasted amazing ! 

It's Bart-able. It's fantastic authentic east German food. It's not snobby. Definitely a good one to try and frequent.
author: Camille A.

description: tasty! but the service was a little slow when i was there and the waitress added 20% tip on our bill for a party of two without informing us.
author: Paiyu G.

description:
Before Walzwerk, I'd never been to a restaurant where I was so appalled by how rude the hosts were, that I left (with my group of 3 friends) before we were even seated.
I showed up at 9pm and asked for a table for 4, explaining that my friends were on their way over; both the hostesses clearly did not believe me and made their disbelief obvious. When my friends arrived ~10 minutes later, we were rudely informed that we'd have to wait 20 minutes more. On inquiring whether we'd have enough time to order before the kitchen closed at 10pm (- the alternative would have been to look over the menus as we were waiting for our table -), the hostess very condescendingly replied that we would & that she wouldn't bother seating us otherwise. At that point, I'd had enough of their ridiculous attitude and we left.
I was disappointed since I'd been looking forward to trying German cuisine, and shocked that they would provide such unacceptable service.
author: Kavya J.

description: Had a great time at this cozy and homey neighborhood spot. As mentioned in other reviews the waitstaff was very attentive and helpful offering suggestions. Have a Hefeweizen at the bar and read facts about East Germany while waiting for a table. The yummy soup of the day, a spicy butternut squash was the perfect anecdote to the chilly night. Not a big fan of the "veggie schnitzel"--Just left too much to be desired. My dinning companion had the grilled bratwurst with mashed potatoes& sauerkraut which was so much tastier. 'Keep it real' with real meat & potatoes and you'll be much happier. . .
author: Kia B.

description: I love it.  It's around the corner from my office, so I can work a bit late, get here in time to slide on into a counter seat with a book and chill out, people watch, maybe sip on some sparkling wine, and listen to the servers chat in German.  The food hits the spot.
author: Melissa B.

description: I absolutely love German food, and SuppenKuche used to be my favorite German place to go in the city, but I think now Walzwerk has topped the list.  I'm pretty sure all the staff here speak German and I use that as an opportunity to practice my awful German. The restaurant is cozy, and there is a small waiting area in the back but a reservation is recommended.  The prices are pretty reasonable and the portions are MASSIVE! I can't remember the exact name of the dish I always order, but it's some kind of schnitzel with spaetzle and a yummy creamy mushroom sauce. I've also had the short ribs before too, but I think they are too heavy to eat alone and are a better dish shared between two people with a soup or salad. I really recommend this restaurant for anyone who likes East German cuisine and who has a very hearty appetite. Good for small groups of 4 or less.
author: Jade L.

description: Walzwerk offers up damn good German food and excellent German beer (you should have seen our eyes light up like little boys at Christmas when they brought out our beers).  In case you weren't able to discern this from the other reviews: the shnitzel here is great.  Service was affable and courteous, but it took a very long time for the food to come out.  Still, despite the long wait, I'd definitely recommend this for anyone who enjoys German food and places like Suppenkuche.
author: Matthew H.

description:
can't wait to bring the parents here, esp my dad (he's half german) because i know he will love it.  

so the one thing i have to warn you is that you should be very very hungry when you walk into this establishment.  i was so full when i left, and i barely ate half my entree!  i could tell they were disappointed in me.  

so we tried the potato pancakes, which were awesome, and also had onion soup.  i really like french onion soup, but after having this onion soup, i think i liked it more.  i don't really feel like i need all the cheese and bread on top... this was just perfectly cooked onions in a fragrant broth, with carrots too.  so good.  then for dinner shared the schnitzel and the stuffed chicken.  i ate half the stuffed chicken first, and it was fabulous, though incredibly filling.  thus i could only eat a few bites of my half of the schnitzel-- but it also was really good.  can't wait to go back actually, i saw some of the other entrees other people ordered and they ALL looked good.  and the service was super friendly and the atmosphere was just my style, very laid back.  definitely worth checking out.
author: Yvette H.

description: Let me start by saying, WHAT'S NOT TO LOVE?!?!!! The food is amazing, the setting is authentic and AWESOME, the staff is supreme, especially that drop dead gorgeous blond German girl with the sell you anything smile, and spunktacular spirit. I must say, I have never been so enthusiastic about dropping into a place for a bite and a beer as I am at Walzwerk. Plus the owner is pretty radical, hope you get to enjoy a drink with her when you visit as well!!! Keep it up, you lovely Krauts!
author: Sky G.

description:
I'd forgotten how much I love this place! I live near that Western German restaurant and it's ok, but Walzwerk is AMAZING! One of the things I miss most about Cleveland is sitting in one of my friend's kitchens listening to the foreign languages of their parents & grandparents, then having a huge plate of God knows what laid before me. There was always a pot of something on the stove and good times to be had in those balmy dining rooms.
Walzwerk is just like those kitchens, metal chairs, country-like 'decor' and just enormous plates of food made with love. Last night I was only able to catch & understand "Nina Hagen and Heidi Klum" in the jovial and hearty conversation that surrounded me.
My favorite is the schnitzel with cheese spaetzel accompanied by the most crisp & delicious veggies you'll find in the area! I have never been able to clean my plate, which fills me with a mixture of fear and shame. I always ask them to box it to go though, it's even better at midnight! Imagine that.
author: Colleen B.

description: This place is a nice authentic eaterie. It doesn't wreak of snobby SF food scene or trendy foodies and delivers a hearty German meal with great beers. If I took my my visiting family, they'd feel like they never left Germany.
author: H. Joseph E.

description: Having been to Walzwerk before, my boyfriend and I were looking forward to having another great experience.  HOWEVER, this last experience was just that...our LAST!  Though the food was good and their beer selection is great, there were cockroaches crawling down the walls while we ate!!!  YES, I SAID COCKROACHES!  They apologized and moved our table, were ANOTHER COCKROACH crawled down the walls next to us.  They cpmped our meal, but do you really want to eat at a place crawling with cockroaches?  I know I don't.  Bummer!  If they could've just kept proper health standards....
author: Stephanie K.

description: I was less impressed than others with Walzwerk's cuisine. Having spent some time in Germany may have turned me into a spaetzli snob...but what they're passing off as a plate of spaetzli is both an insult to the dish and perhaps even Germany. The schnitzel was better, but for the price I expected a better meal than I received.
author: Jennifer S.

description: first time eating german food and loved it, place has a cozy enviornment, took a bit of time to get the food but it was woth it.
author: Varun S.

description:
located near the corner of 15th and south van ness, walzwerk is a very cool spot in a very unexpected spot.  it's very tiny (only 10 tables) so getting there as early as dinnerly possible is advised.  when we got there we had less than a 30 minute wait.  after we were seated we noticed how quickly the queue for a table built up.  at one point we hear them tell some one that it would take an hour.  ouch...

the decor, as the hostess told us, is east german while the food is not from any particular region.  the staff is very friendly and are actually german folk speaking their great language from deutschland.  they had 5 german beers on tap and plenty more in bottles.  i tried the köstritzer schwarzbie and thought it was pretty darn good.  we were seated at the bar and we had a great time conversing w/ the hostess and wait staff while eating.

when were seated, we given these little pieces of bread w/ sour cream, cucumber and bacon (for me only).  nothing incredible but nice lil bites to start off with.  we split the small potato pancakes that came w/ apple sauce and chive sour cream.  this was a great starter with the potatoes being seasoned nicely the crust of the pancakes being nice and crispy w/ out being oily at all.  we really enjoyed them though we wondered how one person could actually finish them on their own.

for mains, i got the jäger schnitzel w/ spätzle and mushrooom sauce.  this was a pounded down porkloin and w/ the the accompaniments was a great dish.  only critique is that they could've used a bit more salt on the spätzle.  the sauce was very nice and the pork was cooked just right.  my wife got the vegetable "schnitzel" w/ mashed potatoes and a beet salad.  this was basically the german version of tempura but it was just as good.  the veggies that were schnitzel'd were carrots, cauliflowers and onions.  like the potato pancake they were cooked just right and were not oily.  the beet salad had picked onions and was might tasty treat.  the mashed potatoes though were a bit on the salty side.

for dessert we split the apple strudel and really enjoyed it.  the creme anglaise type sauce was a nicely presented w/ a raspberry sauce and the accompanying vanilla bean gelato worked well too.  the strudel itself was filled w/ nuts, golden raisins and, of course, apples.  the pastry was nice and light though not as warm as we would've wanted it to be.  overall though, it was a great dessert.

overall, i really enjoyed walzwerk.  there a few other items on this menu that's gonna definitely bring us back here!
author: Swarup B.

description:
I hate to say it, but until proved otherwise, Walzwerk has gone downhill.  It used to be fantastic - the food had a subtlety that really put it above most German restaurant fare, but the last time I went, it was off - dry chicken, everything just kind of...not what it was.  Another reviewer below mentioned loss of chef in September (last time I was there before Thanksgiving weekend would have been before that), so maybe this is what happened.  

I've also been rather forgiving of the pictures of communists on the wall (and, how sad that a reviewer that pointed this out thinks the middle picture is Stalin?!)(it's Engels).  I've taken the point of view that they were being ironic, maybe giving the finger (or whatever the German equivalent is) to those individuals...but I think I have to revise my position and not support a BUSINESS that features apparent homage to mass murderers so prominently.
author: Tim C.

description:
When we first moved to San Francisco in 1998, our dingy hovel of an apartment was located on 14th Street, just across from the Volvo dealership between South Van Ness and Shotwell. There's not much in the way of good eats in that corridor, so we made many trips to the 16th and Mission area. And then, one fateful evening in 1999, my roommate and I strolled by a newly opened restaurant with a black awning, we decided to duck in for a beer, and the rest is history... Walzwerk has changed out lives forever. If you haven't been by, you're doing yourself a great disservice. Christiane and Isabel (the founders) are two of the most funky and friendly East Germans I've ever met, and their food definitely reflects their European beauty and charm. 

Even when vegetarian friends come to town, we love taking them to Walzwerk (ever heard of veggie schnitzel? I hadn't.) Decidedly different than Suppenkuche (and in my opinion, so much better), the menu features a nice array of traditional German dishes from Thuringer Bratwurst (my personal favorite) to Marinated Beef (the close #2 to the Brat) to apple stuffed chicken, to nice fish (get Salmon!) and pork plates. For appetizers, don't miss the pickled herring plate in sour cream sauce and the potato pancakes... a must if you're revving up the night with a hearty stein of beer. And the beer... oh the beer... I'm wrapped up in a self-proclaimed love affair with the Walzwerk bar. They feature imported kegs of Dunkles Heffeweizen, Weltenburg Helles, Kostritzer Swarzbier, and so many more. Always perfectly chilled, always appearing in the proper labeled glassware, and always served with a disclaimer and smile, I love to catch a taxi to Walzwerk to just go wild sampling all the draughts. 

For dessert, don't miss the 'Cold Dog'---not at all what it sounds like, anyone will enjoy this layered pastry dipped in chocolate. And around the holidays, if you've never had a German-style duck plate, you better get your reservations in early. Hands down, Walzwerk is not only the best East German food in the city, it's, straight-up, the best German food in all of Northern California. Period.

And I can't forget the totally wild ambiance that Walzwerk pulls off... it's something like a mix of standing next to the Berlin Wall crossed with a 1950's German miscellanea museum, crossed with an SF family's Victorian home sitting room. Even the cutlery and plates are all mismatched, as if you turned over an old chest in some forgotten attic and had yourself a tea party--truly a unique and inspiring local experience.
author: Ankarino L.

description:
"San Francisco's premiere East German Restaurant."
menu: http://www.walzwerk.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=2&Itemid=3

as a vegetarian i generally avoid german food restaurants unless all i really want is chocolate and beer and not a good meal.  however, walzerk totally delivered in the veg food department - i had the vegi stuffed cabbage roulade and it was better than my mom used to make, and the accompanying mashed potatoes were so heavenly i could barely believe it.

the food was top notch but the restaurant wasn't stuffy or pretentious or trying too hard. the waitstaff and decor/atmosphere were also awesome - historical and kitchy - not your standard german restaurant theme and way mission-style. i loved that they just stapled stretch velvet to the walls instead of having them properly wallpapered.  it's what i'd do too.

i finally found a restaurant i think my midwestern germanic meat-and-potatoes parents will love in SF, and i'll probably be going back more than once just for the mashed potatoes.
author: amy l.

description: I really enjoyed my experience at Walzwerk. I had a stuffed chicken dish with Apple and Vegetables along with a few beers. I have a weakness for German beers. I didn't like this place as much as Schnitzelhaus in terms of the food since I like the schnitzel's Fried and their portions aren't as big (though it is cheaper). The atmosphere was much better than Schnitzelhaus that the music is relaxing instead of crazy and loud. I think the waiters/waitresses are pretty friendly too. The menu was pretty easy to read off of. I wish the place was a little bit bigger as I only saw like 8 tables there.
author: Nir B.

description: What an authentic, charming spot!  I love the food and genuine German memorabilia, and the waitresses are great!  Walzwerk is simple, casual, and fun--no frills or pretentiousness.
author: Alexa G.

description:
went here a few years ago and still remember being so pleased with the food, atmosphere and people. they were so sweet and almost demure- not what you expect from german folk. the food was suprisingly super tasty, not sure what spices they use. the whole experience was very relaxing. great beer served in the quinnessential stein. 

another  plus, excellent tea selection. they brought over a little stainless steel teapot on a little stainless steel tray with a basket full of loose leaf teas as well as some honey and lemon. its was a little tea party! although it still felt very german because of its industrial-like presentation. 

sit in the back room its cozy and romantic- another thing  i didn't expect from the german folk!
author: Adrienne P.

description:
Great place to dine out. 
Our family had the fathers day dinner there.
The place is small and cozy. Their food is delicious. I am not a big expert in food tasting but it was five of us there ordering different dishes and all of us were very much satisfied. As of some of the complains that were mentioned in the previous reviews, I can not confirm them. 1. We made our reservations in advance and were given a table promptly. 2. Our food was good as I already mentioned. 3. The waitress was quick and friendly.
The place is decorated perfectly. It's kitschy in the pop-art sort of sense.  Obviously the idea was to bring back memories of the soviet past of East Germany of late 1970th - early 80th. It was done well. Portraits of the founders of communism, Kissing Leonid Brezhnev and Erich Honecker, some old socialist posters, tables, plates etc... It all fits the profile. So, well done!
We'll definitely go back.
author: Alex B.

description: We were waiting outside suppenkuche realizing we would never get a seat and dealing with gruff staff and went over to Walzwerk which was busy but really accomodatibg. I love the east German feel and the food is always tasty reliable and filling with a good choice of beers. I can highly recommend the potato appetizers.  The staff can be intimidating but service is helpful and reliable.
author: Darren P.

description: Two words:  vegetarian schnitzel!  These ladies are serious, but they will serve you a great dinner.  You *will* enjoy!
author: Andi T.

description:
I had the best night last night. And it went a little something like this:
I raced out of work to meet my BFF for a 5:30 movie at the Lumiere. We're both obsessed with anything Indian, and will gladly sit through the most ridiculous Bollywood musical just so we can plan our outfits for our Bollywood party, in a constant state of planning. I arrived late, finding her out front holding my ticket and a mysterious paper bag filled with "treats."
We grabbed two fabulous indie theater seats, threw down our bags and as the credits rolled, I realized once again why Zoe is my BFF. 
My girl pulled out 4 cans of Sofia minis. 
We watched The Namesake. We laughed. We cried. We drank champagne out of a can. 
By 8 o'clock I had kissed Zoe goodbye, called Mikey and offered, "I can pick up food, we can order food or we can go out."
"I feel like going out."
"Oh thank god. Me too."
We drove around our hood looking for parking when I remembered. Walzwerk! That German joint. We should go there. After all, I was having dinner with the Aryan prince, a literal poster boy for SS recruiters. And parking at 14th and South Van Ness is a lot easier than 17th and Mission. 
We walked inside, found the perfect table by the window and ordered our respective wine and beer. (Note to my fellow wine drinkers, they have like 3 choices and all by the glass. I had the Chard. It was fine.)
The place was packed with loud hipstard types, the staff was all Euro-laid back and we had glittery, warm candles at our table. Dipping our spectacular potato pancakes in sour cream and chives, we settled in and perused our menu. Aryan prince wanted the special of the day, a mixed grill with sausage, salmon and beef, with mashed potatoes and sauerkraut. I had bites of all (except the salmon. I don't do salmon) and it was good. Not great. But good. 
I couldn't decide between the jaegersnitzel or the sauerbraten and our adorable server wisely suggested the sauerbraten, but with a side of spatzle instead of potato dumplings. It was great, especially the spatzle and red cabbage, but incredibly filling. I ordered more wine as we began our third round of Anne Frank jokes. 
Aryan prince leaned in. "I bet they're wondering what the hell I'm doing with a brown haired, brown eyed girl. Don't worry. You're Italian. Technically, we're on the same side." 
"Check out these portraits on the wall. Who the hell is that? Heinrich Himmler?"
"Hey, Ava Braun. Volume."
"What? Too soon?"
It's not a fun dinner unless it's a wildly inappropriate dinner. Any reference to my being a happy "camper" was taken beyond the realms of decency. It was fabulous. 
But after three drinks and enough food to stock the Fuhrerbunker, it was time to go home. Getting the check, however, proved to be impossible. That adorable server had settled in at a table, engrossed in conversation with the cast of Sprockets. And the only other staff member was scrambling to deal with everyone else, including a table of A-Ha fans playing cards nearby. It probably took 30 minutes from the time we wanted to leave to our actually pushing open the door. 
It pissed the Aryan prince off more than it did me. After all, I got canned champagne and a movie with the BFF, a cute, worldly, out-of-the-ordinary dinner with the Gestapo's dream candidate and a cache of appalling, send-you-straight-to-hell jokes that'll last me till my next plate of spatzle...
author: Beth S.

description: The food here was just OK, the clientele were friendly, but the staff? Horrible horrible rude people.Granted it's been a while since I was here, and it was with a party of co-workers, but we were all taken aback at the rude treatment. Not a repeat dining experience for me by any means.
author: Fancypants J.

description: What a treat this place is! Very casual but cosy ambience and the food is great! Had delicious beer-onion soup, herring in sour cream, potato pancakes and poached off bacon-wrapped pork loin and a very tasty schnitzel in mushroom cream sauce. Mmmm... Good beer, too. My new favorite neighborhood haunt!
author: Arwen O.

description: Very interesting. Had a bit of a wait, but enjoyed a couple beers (Weltenburg Amber, Weltenburg Pilsner) which were very refereshing and served in their proper glasses. Once we were seated we started with the potato pancakes. Even though I'm used to super thin and crispy latkes, these were the opposite, yet still tasty. I also had the special of the day which was meat loaf served with a huge mound of mashed potatoes and some peas. The meatloaf was very good and served with a nice mild sauce. Even though I was deemed un-gentlemanly by the waiter after not finishing off the pancakes, overall it was a pleasant experience...
author: Nicolas H.

description: I thought this place was good. Loved their food, I had the schnitzel with a mushroom sauce,Yummm! Inside they had these really cool posters. The service was little slow and not enough severs to get the packed place moving. Had their apple strudel with ice cream and that was delicious. Overall, good place to try some good, authentic German food.
author: Travis G.

description:
spezi (half coke - half 7up)
alsterwasser (half beer - half 7up)
diesel (half beer - half coke)

i am half german (the polish side is still in denial) and had no idea that german people drink this stuff until my trip to walzwerk!

the potato pancakes are the real deal.  i wasn't super impressed with my vegetarian schnitzel (the veggies were too hard to cut!) but everything else was great.  bring your appetite, for serious.

there are pictures of lenin and marx.  the lounge has velvet walls.  the bar looks like a bunker's insides.  how can you not love that?
author: Sarah B.

description:
i recently went to walzwerk with a large group. we made a reservation + decided to do the meal family style. we were told that it would be $25/person for our party of 19....but when the bill came it was $50/person + we only got 6 pitchers of beer (that's 2 small mugs/person). were the pitchers like $45 each? it was ridiculous.

to add to it, the servers barely saw us: just visited 2x to take the pitcher orders as drop off the 2 courses of meals. they did much less work since it was all family style, made a ton of money off of us and then acted like we were a huge burden. it was very disappointing to see how terribly they treated us. maybe because they knew they had a guaranteed tip waiting for them.

they ran someone's card 2x and then said that neither went through, even though it ended up both charges went through. they miscounted our money + accused us of short-changing them. they complained when we had a lot of cards to run, but that was due to us not having enough money since they grossly underestimated the cost of the meal/person.

i normally love this restaurant, but i sure got a sour taste in my mouth after this last visit.
author: Mary S.

description: When I think German food, I think great company and great beer.  Well, they got one of them right, the beer was cold.  Sadly, so was the help.  We had a waitress there that was not only rude as can be, but also possibly braindead.  Upon asking for my meal to be taken back and served hot, she became incredibly defensive and even tried to use physical harm against a female I was with.  I was utterly shocked and had to restrain myself from causing a further scene.  Let me be the first to tell you I am as laid back as they come, but I have never experience service like this.  I will never go back because of this waitress (whose name escapes me right now).  If you like people being nice to you, Walzerk is not the place for you.  I will never go again.  In fact, I'm debating writing a formal complaint to the management.  BE WARNED.
author: Sean T.

description: We were trying to go to Suppenkuche, which is in our neighborhood, but it was closed, so we wound up at Walzwerk instead.  Best choice we could have made!  The waitstaff was charming and helpful, they went out of their way to find a space for our large party - and took great care of us all night.  Food was fantastic, decor very authentically DDR-ish - the place is tasty and adorable.  Order the apfel strudel for dessert.
author: S C.

description: It's definitely kitschy like John wrote below. Walzwerk is a small homey restaurant serving up fresh East German comfort food.  I loved my borcht soup and the warm walnut bread was yummy too. The beer on tap was tasty. I look forward to returning soon and trying the other dishes.
author: joolia f.

description: Awesome, to die for, blah blah. once you been to one German restaurant you have been to them all. Food to die for,  keep eating that stuff and you will die soon.
author: Andrew B.

description: Their service was excellent! I dropped by without a reservation and almost got seated immediately. Their beer selection is quite impressive. They carry a lot of german beer that you cannot find at other bars. I had their schnitzel, and remember it being similar to Japanese tonkatsu over potatoes. Their sausage has a different taste. Overall, the ambience was great, service was great and the beer was excellent.
author: Helen L.

description:
wow...i felt like i was back in east berlin.  looking at stalin posters trying to show off and count for the waitress...haha, witht heir thick german accents, and ripped/buff/ just a little intimidating, but nice!

eins. fi. dry. fear. funf. six. seben. oct. nuin. tin...haha

anyway, i walked in hungering for a certain dish, and FOUND IT!!! what a great surprise.  it was the schnitzle noodle thing with mushroom cream sauce...DANKA! (thanks)

the beer was good too!
author: Carmen A.

description: I really enjoyed coming to this place. The people here are very nice. Of course they have great beer and even had one I had not had before, so that was nice to be able to try it. I had ordered the jagerschnitzel which I found to be very tasty but was very bland. Everything needed a lot of salt. After I had seasoned it, it became delicious. Overall a great place.
author: Sasha V.

description: The food was great, and the beer was great!  The environment was good too, it's out of the scummy area of the Mission but near enough to bart to hop over to easily.  The only downside was that it was oppressively hot inside, they could definitely do with opening the windows.  I'll be back for sure.
author: Tom T.

description: My experience at Walzwerk was disappointing.  The German draft beer was good (Spaten Amber ... mmm!) , but everything else was below expectation.  I ordered the Sauerbraten (tough, thick slices without much flavor)  with Potato Dumplings (dry and bland) and Braised Red Cabbage (the only food item that could really be classified as excellent).  My wife had one of the night's specials, Goulash (better than mine, but still only ok) with Spatzle (should have been lighter).  Also tried the Tomato - Cabage Soup and Thuringer Salad, of which neither were particularly appealing.  Service was lacking and the noise level was very high.  I really do like German food, but sorry, Walzwerk, you didn't do it for me.
author: Stephen M.

description:
i didn't really enjoy the food here.  i felt it like it was one of those meals where i HAD to eat it because i was being polite...

the potato pancakes are decent, but they really need to add more shredded onion and more pieces of shredded potato in the mix for texture.  

the smoked salmon and beet appetizer was good.  picked beets with onion and cold smoked salmon with capers were a good salty/sour combo.    

the beef roulade was not good.  it was beef tri-tip stuff with pickle and bacon.  i ate the pickle and stripped the bacon out and tried to just eat the tri-tip.  it was quite dry.  the sauce the roulade came with tasted like bbq sauce, it wasn't bad.  the spaetzle was OK.
author: Wendy S.

description:
it was time yet again to choose a place in the city to eat, and, one year after moving back from two years in germany, it was definitely time to have some german food. 

i think i enjoyed this place more than my friends. the food tasted completely authentic, even the mashed potatoes! i had the rinderroulade with red cabbage and spätzle. nom nom! the spätzle was a bit dry, imho, though. what memories it brought back! add on an apfelschorle and the open-faced sandwich-y hors d'œuvre...perfect! 

i would have given it 5 stars but i don't think my friends were all that impressed--one said her chicken was too dry. 

slightly over-priced, but i'm totally willing to pay for it.

if i'm in the city i'll totally go back again but i think speisekammer edges this place out (even though it doesn't have as much authenticity).
author: Jonathan K.

description:
As a quick summary Walzwerk rocks!  You walk in and immediately notice that this is not your usual Bavarian style German place.  Not that Bavarian is bad, but it gets a bit old and stereotypical after a while.  This place is East German.  There was a group of four of us.  We couldn't get reservations when we called ahead, so we showed up and decided to wait for a table.  I am so glad that we did.  We walked in and immediately noticed the decor, with pictures of Lenin and Marx hung on the walls.  The bathroom is even a homage to East German products (behind glass cases though).  We also quickly understood why we couldn't get a reservation.  The place is really small, it feels like you are in someone's living room.  The staff was incredibly cool and gracious. There was a blond German waitress with tattoos up her arm and a tall bald German waiter.  Both were great.  We were able to wait in a comfortable couch area by the bar and drink some awesome beer. I have to really recommend the Schwarzbier, really yummy!  We didn't have to wait too long for a table by the window to open up.
The food was great, the pitchers of beer kept coming and a good time was had by all.  Two of us had the Schnitzel, which was great.  My husband had the beer marinated pork special, really great.  One of us had the stuffed chicken breast, really incredible. We also all split the potato pancakes as an appetizer, highly recommended with sour cream and applesauce as toppings.  Meals run at about $13-15, but you get a large quantity of really good food, funky decor and fun wait staff.  I have a good friend who lives in the Midwest who is East German.  She keeps going to "German" festivals and restaurants only to be disappointed because they are all Bavarian.  Next time she visits out here, I will be taking her to Walzwerk, she won't be disappointed, and neither will anyone who gives this place a chance.  I think it may have to become my new hangout.
author: Kate B.

description: The latkes are PERFECTION. A touch of applesauce, a lil' dab of the chive sour cream. Make sure everyone gets one. I haven't been awfully impressed with the other things I've eaten here, but I'm notoriously picky. Points for good eavesdropping, German accents, and the artistic rendering of Nietzsche lurking over our table.
author: Melissa G.

description: Ok, let's cut to the chase.  We waited far too long for a table we already made reservations ahead of time for, service in general was very slow and all over the place, all our food came out at different times, and their makeshift extension of a restaurant sucks, so hopefully you're dining with people you actually enjoy spending time with.  Buuuuut, the food is amazing!  I love their Jager Schnitzel!  Somehow, that managed to make up for all that Walzwerk wasn't.  Happy dining :)
author: Kelly H.

description:
This place is amazing. It is so different from what I usually eat it's like taking a vacation. I ordered the vegetarian schnitzel and each piece of vegetable was perfectly prepared, so flavorful and so beautiful. Such a treat!!

Thank you for having such a wonderful option for vegetarians.
author: Sarah J.

description: A Mazing......loved every minute that I was there. From the tall German Beauty waitress's to the tall beautiful German beers.
author: David M.

description: I heard about this place months ago, but didn't get a chance to eat there until recently.  Coming from Pennsylvania, I'm no stranger to German food, but Walzwerk does it with style - cozy, slightly kitchy Socialist style.  Nothing fancy here, just genuine German dishes done well.  I started with a Köstritzer Schwarzbier (an excellent dark beer that stands up to the meat dishes, but easy drinking), and the potato pancakes.  My friend and I shared our entrees, beef remoulade and jager schnitzel, both were done to perfection. We finished with the Cold Dog, a layer cake made from fudge and cookies, about the perfect size for two people to share.  The prices were reasonable and we had no problem finding a table.  The service was a bit slow, but it was more than worth the wait.
author: Peter V.

description:
Any restaurant that gets me to not only willingly eat saurkraut but actually really enjoy it automatically gets 5 stars. The BF and I were fortunate enough to be invited out for dinner and since I've been on a self imposed healthy food, lots of veggies, small portions diet I was looking forward to a splurge of pork products and buttery potatoes. 
We arrived about 30 min after the rest of the group, just in time for the potato cakes! I smothered mine in sour cream and applesauce and it was FANTASTIC! When it came time to order, I was pretty much decided on the schnitzel and decided to change to the bratwurst at the last minute. I had been craving bratwurst since my recent trip to Rosemunde but I was afraid that I would be wasting valuable plate space with the saurkraut. When the food arrived all my worries went out the window. The saurkraut was by far the best I've ever had and was perfect when mixed with the potatoes and a piece of sausage. The portions are huge and we managed to leave with enough leftovers for lunch the next day! Everyone else's food looked great also especially the cheese spaetzl which I'll totally be trying next time. So delish! I think German is my new favorite comfort food!
author: Melanie V.

description:
This place is on the tried and true list for me. I love this place, and was introduced to it by my West German friend who whispered, "This place could never exist in Germany!", with all of the East German decor and references. 
The food is fantastic, and the service wonderful. Especially when my husband or my friend order in German! Though I am treated just as fine with my non-German speaking self! 
All dishes are wonderful, and the berry dessert is fantastic. 
I come to this place when I don't have the time to leave San Francisco, but want to feel as if I've gone out of town for a little bit. 
Oh, yes, this is a wonderful place for groups! I think there is a small steip to the front door, which is not impossible for someone in a wheelchair, but its nice to know. I think that some tables and chairs would need to be moved out of the way for wheelchair accessibility. This would not be a problem for the super friendly and capable staff.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Great food - the tomato soup with pickles & kraut sounds strange but is wonderful - had enough food for at least two more meals. Friendly service but attentiveness drops off when it gets busy. We arrived at 5:30 - promptly ordered and served. Checked on regularly until the restaurant filled up.
author: Richard M.

description: I loved it!!  Great food, great vibe, excellent service.  I am a big eater and they did not disappoint.  Nothing was over complicated and the decor on the inside was very East German(I don't know why, but it was).  I would definitely go back.
author: Matt S.

description: Friendly wait staff and good food make the Walzwerk a good choice for those looking to get some hearty small town German food.  Prices are slightly higher than I was expecting to pay, but if German food is your thing it may well be worth it.  I might stop by again if i'm in the area but won't go out of my way to eat there again.
author: Nick J.

description: Willkommen to the German Democratic Republic.  Greeted by a portrait of Vlady L...you will eat according to your ability and drink according to your need.  Great schnitzel!
author: L W.

description: I consider this commonly overlooked East German restaurant to be one of the best places to have German food in the city.  The beer selection isn't quite as good as Suppenkuche, but the food is a couple of notches better.  The Jagerschnitzle is always perfect, and I'm told the soljanka is worth a trip here by itself.  I've heard people complain about the service here, but I've had nothing but good experiences so far.  This place is more suited for smaller groups, with a focus on good german food.  If you're looking for a more raucous evening with a better beer selection, Suppenkuche is what you're looking for.  Either way you go, you're in for some great german food and beer.
author: Joshua W.

description: Good interesting plainish renditions of West German meets East German / Slavic food. I had a crowded (so seemingly huge) birthday at the table in the front room and it was fun. Nice gray interior accents. The vegetarian "schnitzel" was curiously unexciting.
author: matt c.

description: OMG  This place is sooo much better than Suppenkuche!  I guess it is the East German twist, their food just tastes better.  I am continuously craving the pickled Herring app, with tart and perfect pumpernickel bread.  I was with a large party, the back room was perfect for group dining.  Great German beers, cheap corkage and food so filling I have never had room for dessert (it looked amazing though).  This is now my go to place when I am craving something pickled like my great grandma used to make!
author: Alison D.

description:
the 4 stars are because the decor is fucking charming as hell and the beets and homemade lox appetizer was GREAT.  altho the vegetarian schnitzel wasn't good - the real deal was pretty good but a little dry.

cute place.
author: Erika Y.

description: Good atmosphere,They have a small lounge area ( the velvet room) where you can wait for your table and drink a beer with friends. Private room in the back which I believe you can reserve for parties greater than 8. Family style menu is amazing the beef and red cabbage with golden sultanas was a stand-out. The staff is small and they can be a bit terse     (don't take it personally) but they run a tight ship with the kitchen kicking out consistently  great dishes that warm the spirit.  Good service, reasonable pricing, good for groups, not good for vegetarians, excellent beer selection.
author: JJ C.

description: Dodge the crowds and parking issues of Suppenkuche for a place that has a charming DDR decor and food that is just as good. The beer selection leaves a little to be desired but that is really the only benefit to waiting for two hours in a Marina Bar like crowd at Suppenkuche. Is there anything better than enjoying a wiener-schnitzel in the shadow of Marx, Lenin and Engels? Yeah I know the guy in the middle photos name! Das ist ein sehr gut restaurant! PS: open the drawers in your table and enjoy the socialist literature or just do some coloring!
author: Ryan M.

description: I hesitated a little to give this place a five star because I really don't want it to get so popular that I can't go back and get another plate of schnitzel whenever I want to, but it's too good not to tell you how freaking awesome this place is.  I love that the waiter was totally straight out of Sprockets dance party, awww yeahhhh.....  a huge plate of schnitzel coming at me almost made me fall off my chair and say THANK YOU PORK GODS!!!  Seriously, the whole plate was covered by this delicious piece of breaded porky goodness, it was totally unreal, and the giant beers rocked too.  Definitely worth waiting for a meal to come out of the tiny kitchen.  Loved it!!
author: Barbra K.

description: Food is fantastic and the staff run around speaking german to each other so it feels very authentic.  It is tiny, but so far the best german food I've had in San Fran.
author: Parker W.

description: I find now living out here that I get the strangest cravings for certain cuisines. German happens to be a main one. The food was so good. I think I had a little of everything. I recommend calling ahead for reservations - the waiting area is very cramped.
author: Jessica S.

description: I didn't know East German restaurants even existed, since there is only 1 Germany now - or did I miss something? It feels very German here, from the heavily accented staff, to the great beer, to the Communist-era portraits of Lenin, etc. on the walls. The food is decent, but over-priced, which is just like Germany! Actually I don't remember the food in Germany.  I think I drank a lot when I was there.
author: Alexi S.

description: I spent half of my life in Tyrol so I'm picky about what people call German cuisine but Walzwerk delivers the goods with panache in a authentic manner. The food is excellent and their beer menu is great as well as they carry some of the more obscure Hefeweiz beers on tap and serve them in the correct glasses which, believe it or not, makes a huge difference. Geh ma vas trinken. Prost.
author: Armand C.

description:
We started out with the potato pancakes, which are served with sour cream and applesauce on the side.  While that may seem like a strange combo, they went together very well, so the meal started off on the right foot.  For the entree, I had jager schnitzel, served with spatzle and a creamy mushroom sauce -- delicious -- I loved every bite.  We topped the meal off with the Cold Dog dessert, which is a a layered cake made of chocolate, rum and butter cookies -- I highly recommend it.  This is a great restaurant, kind off the beaten path from most of the better known spots in the Mission.  

It's tough to say whether or not it's better than Suppenkuche.  If you're looking for something a little more laid-back -- definitely go with Walzwerk.  If you are showing friends a good time, Suppenkuche is probably the better, more fun option.  Walzwerk probably gets the upper hand strictly based upon food.
author: Luke P.

description:
Such a relief!
I was still in shock about the last time I tried to get some authentic German cuisine, back in August. Schnitzelhaus was still in business then but what I didn't know is that the ownership had changed. They are no longer. Long story short, it SUCKED.

Tonight was just lovely: fantastic service, great ( I mean DELICIOUS) food, and just all-around happiness.  I LOVE YOU WALZWERK, WILL YOU BE MY FRIEND?
author: Jazzmin N.

description: Better than Suppenkuche AND Schnitzelhaus!  Let me know if there is another German restaurant in SF and I'll try it, but as of now this is #1 German place to go!  Large portions, decent prices, family staffed (and very friendly), great beer selection :) Need anything else?  All I can say is yummmmm!
author: Nicole S.

description: Reasonable selection of German beer, though not especially extensive.  Really good food, especially the stuffed chicken.  Wow!  Generally a lot of food on the plates as well.  Definately one of the odder spaces I've been in - a random mix of different types of tables & chairs, some brick areas, one waiting lounge area covered in velvet... Certainly unique.  But tasty.
author: Don H.

description: My first experience with German food! Came across Walzwerk while we were looking for a place to eat dinner using the Yelp app on my sister's iPhone. The wait was long, and our order took even longer (they said it was because a big party in the back by the bar ordered a lot of appetizers). We didn't really mind, since we weren't super hungry until the food finally came. We ordered the potato pancakes, grilled bratwurst, and the schnitzel. All were delicious! I loved the bratwurst and sauerkraut together, and the mashed potatoes that came with that and the schnitzel was sooo good and creamy. It's a cozy little place, seating is limited. Definitely worth checking out.
author: S. D.

description: I had a delicious meat and potatoes meal, which was exactly what I was in the mood for.  Big portions, very tasty.  The service wasn't quite on top of everything, but they were friendly.
author: Wesley W.

description: I loved this place. I never had had german food before Walzwerk, but it was so yummy. I have been dying to go back and I will for sure.
author: Erin O.

description: Walzwerk is a fun place to check out the kitschy East German decor leftover from the Cold War.  I especially like the records covers and other assorted tschotchkes, in the back, near the restrooms.  The food is OK and a bit bland compared to Suppenkuche.  I've only been once to Walzwerk so perhaps I need to give it another try.
author: R L.

description: Have been recommending to my friends all week so might as well write a review too :) We had a group of 12, for which they recommended we order a fixed family menu because they have a small kitchen. I was already intrigued by this, and then when we got the food I was very impressed by how delicious it was (and at a very reasonable price). Favorites included schnitzel, spatzel and bratwurst. And the cold dog dessert - yum.... I won't tell you what it is so you'll have the surprise. Oh, and order the Diesel drink. Don't think I need to say more...
author: Susan T.

description: I wish I could give this place 10 stars.  I love this restaurant!  The food is delicious and interesting.  I'm vegetarian and am pleased to know there are several options on their menu - and I've tried them all although my favorite is the Cheese Spatzle.  Everything I've ever had there is heavenly.  Even dessert is oh so good.  Try the Red Berry Pudding.  Aaaaaah!  And to top it off, the staff is so friendly.  Oh yes, as mentioned here before, go hungry and have beer!  Enjoy!
author: Elena I.

description: I always leave full, happy, and completely satisfied. the wienerschnitzel is perfect! And I am so totally addicted to the soljanka (super hearty savory/sour veggie, salami, pickle soup). Great food, beer, service and atmosphere. Brush up on your German and try ordering auf Deutsch!
author: Jeremy H.

description: Walzwerk was a great restaurant and definitely a pleasant surprise.  A German restaurant, I was waited on by people who I think were actually German, which was a first.  Also, a nice cozy atmosphere in general at the restaurant.  The food was good.  I was nervous because I am a vegetarian, but they even had vegetarian schnitzel for me, which was quite tasty.
author: Joanna S.

description: Given the fact that we are talking about German food, combinations of 4 elements: meat+potato+red cabbage, this place is pretty good
author: Alex A.

description: Ok I can't believe I have never been here. People have talked about it and I guess I just don't find myself in the mood for German food very often, now I know where to go when I get the craving. I had the bratwurst, we started with the pickled herring and the house smoked salmon, they were all excellent. My friend had the jaegerschnitzel, which i was immediately jealous of and I can't wait to go back and try it. It is a pretty small place and I am sure fills up quickly, but the room in the back was great for our party of 5. The interior is full of an eclectic collection of old german and communist posters and other memorabilia. Great vibe, friendly service, and appropriately massive portions.
author: Kai H.

description: Dieser platz ist die bombe.
author: Clarissa S.

description: I love German food and this place delivered in every respect.  I felt like I was in East Berlin during the Cold War - so the ambiance was great.  The food was nice and heavy - exactly what I expected - the soup...I forget the name of it, it was awesome (salami and sauer kraut together - oh yeah), something I totally would concoct in my own kitchen, and my wiener schnitzel was yummy!
author: Tiberius A.

description: Between the kitschy DDR themed decor and the ridiculously good looking waiter, I wouldn't have cared if they served dog turds. This however, was not the case. The food was brilliant, the portions were huge and piping hot, and the beer was delicious. I cannot wait to go back!
author: Lizzie N.

description: This is my go to place for German food in SF.  I love it here.  The beer is great, and the food is even better.  Cozy place to be on a rainy day.  There is just something about mashed potatoes that makes you feel better when it's raining outside...
author: Olyn L.

description: Wow, my first official introduction to authentic German food!  I had the stuffed chicken, which came in a creamy sun-dried cherry sauce that is to die for!  Chased that delightful bird down with a very dark, very delicious chocolaty beer.  My only issue: my stomach could not keep up with my taste buds, so I was forced to miss out on dessert... alas!  My compliments to the chef, and to this fine establishment...
author: M.Scott C.

description: Hear me now and believe me later: this is the best German place in the city. With all the DDR kitsch and the dominatrix waitresses, this is a hipster's dream, but thanks to the abundance of the SF restaurant scene, Walzwerk is not overrun by wankers as it would be in a restaurant-poor city like, say, Boston. Very unusual dark beer selection.
author: Muckenfuss V.

description: being myself from eastern block, i really wanted to like this place  - but the food was terrible. spaetzle was cold and tasteless. beef roulade was overcooked and crusty. prices are high, food is terrible. this place is all kitsch, but little value.
author: Naz V.

description: The food as awful.  The service even worse.  If you care about how you are treated when you eat out, don't go here.  Go to Suppenkuche instead for better food and MUCH better service.
author: Charles K.

description: HATED IT!  Went with some people feeling nostalgic for Berlin.  They hadn't been to this place but had lived in Berlin and made sure we were prepared for a banal experience, which it turned out to be--that was the actual fun of going.  It was the most bland meal of my life.  And the pork chop was undercooked and tough.  I imagine those who claim to love this place either love it for memory's sake or are lying to themselves because they know it's supposed to be a cool place to hang out at.
author: K K.

description: Loved it, and I'm not even a big fan of German food. It tasted so much like home-cooked food; the kitschy atmosphere and the remarkable service made me give this 5 stars. Not to mention the schnitzel with mushroom gravy over spatzle was to die for. Yes, they are a bit disorganized, and it feels like you are being served in someone's home, but that's what made the experience so great!
author: Lisa F.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in the city. The staff is always friendly, and the food is amazing. While the schnitzel is what they are perhaps best known for (and with good reason), my favorite is the red beet soup. It's earthy aroma and hearty taste is to die for. The potato cakes are also a favorite.Cool interior, and a homely ambiance, walzwerk makes me feel like i'm visiting a relative in east germany who knows how to cook!
author: K D.

description: Fantastic food, funky interior, helpful waitstaff.  I speak very little German, so I pointed to the beer I wanted, and the waitress smiled and said in her cute German accent, "That says 'Beer List'"...
author: Joe L.

description: I love this place.  Best German restaurant this side of Checkpoint Charlie.  Great Bratwurst and Schnitzel.  Excellent beer, outstanding service.  Ausgezeichnet!
author: Noah Plays Bass M.

description:
The best German restaurant in Northern California.

I've tried almost everything on the menu and have enjoyed every one of them. I have never been disappointed with anything.

The mashed potatoes are the best I've ever had. The spatzle is always right and surprisingly it must be easy to mess this up.

Typical of a German reataurant, the beer comes right away and the food and the check take time. That's the way I like it.

Thank God they don't play the ompa pa pa music. In Muenchen, they play all sorts of music at different restaurants, but every one of them does not play tuba music. At Walzwerk, they tend toward jazz and not too loud. It's at that volume which affords some privacy without making the place into a bomb.

I tend to come at 5:30 without a reservation and choose one of the window seats which gives additional privacy. By 5:45, the place is packed.

Only the German place in Reno at 6th and Valley has better entries, but they play the ompa pa pa music there. I guess that's the way it goes. "ompa pa pa" music at German places and the "diddil le dee" music at Irish
author: Frank W.

description: I was in Alberto Y.'s birthday party and I second the motion...I accepted his invitation not expecting to enjoy the food as much as the company, and was pleasantly surprised to find that spaetzle and schnitzel were actually pretty tasty! In fact, for many of us, this was our first time having East German food, and after sharing a taste of each other's meals, it was unanimous...We like it!  We really liked it!  (Now, I ponder....when to return?...)
author: Gail O.

description: So Jeff S. and myself came here a while back with the GF's. I was surprised by this place after the disappointment i experienced @ Suppenkuche http://www.yelp.com/biz/DGyoVB9PdI9_jw0CNi_OPg The portions were well sized and the food tasted like it was home made. Actually the whole place gave off a whole mom and pop place you would encounter if you visited Germany. I tried the bacon wrapped chicken paired with a couple of Spaten. This is a nice place to take a cozy place to take a date.
author: Alfredo N.

description: Ever since I lived in Germany I've been looking for German food as good as I had there, and Walzwerk is even better than I ever had there.  My wife and I got there about 15 minutes after they opened and they were already almost full.  We sat at the bar and it was the best seat in the house.  The service was prompt and friendly.  Boy are they busy, but we were made to feel welcome.  A very welcoming atmosphere.  Sehr gemuetlich!  The Jaeger schnitzel is fantastic, and so is the chicken breast with apples, raisins and sun dried cherries.  We also had the "Kalt Hund" and berry pudding for dessert.  Definitely want to have them again!  Lots of items and on the walls giving it the DDR atmosphere, including portraits of the "Big 3", Marx, Engels and Lenin.  The only thing not authentic is I think the food is way better than than the typical East German restaurant!
author: Jim M.

description: Sehr gut.  There are a lot of great reviews on this place already, so here's my addition:  try the odd soda selections.  Hint: there's one that's half something.  It's sort of symbolic of East Germany itself, if you think about it...
author: Brian D.

description: as an addendum, I would recommend getting one of the specials of the day. they are extra yummy while sometimes the schnitzel (regular menu item) is a little dry. the specials, however, have not let me down yet, including the dessert specials if you actually have room for it! also, the potato pancakes are spot on.
author: Dorothy W.

description: Love this place. So homey and laid back. The waitstaff is friendly and personable, and the sauerbraten is to die for. Great after a hard week at work.
author: Marie G.

description: Went to Walzwerk on a Tuesday night. When we left the red-walled, cozy location, it was packed. Must have been the cold dog, or the schnitzel and spatzle in mushroom sauce, or the quick service, or the potato pancakes...yummy. I liked Walzwerk much better than Suppenkuche (I think SK is a bit more salt-crazed. I remember being super dehydrated after that meal.) The other aspect that sealed the deal for me is the ambience--its identity is neither overly hip nor culturally kitschy, but is eccentric enough to make you feel like you're having a unique experience. The only reason I'm holding out on that fifth star is because I'd like to try it again on a weekend and see if my first impressions still hold.
author: Kathy A.

description:
Where to start. GREAT BEER. The food is very good. It has that homey, comforty, I want to eat this on a cold foggy day feel to it. Especially the stuffed chicken breast, good enough to make me rat out my own brother to the Stasi. I also dig the industrial/DDR vibe inside. Good enough for 4 stars, right? It was my last visit, however, that earned Walzwerk the elusive fifth star.

Hop on the N down to Van Ness and walk the couple blocks down with the idea of having a couple (TWO) beers. Walk in and there is the woman I saw working  last time. Tall, Teutonic and gorgeous. Order beer in my non-existent German (go international playa!) and talk to her a bit. Mira (aforementioned hot thing) sits at the counter next to me to eat dinner before the rush and we talk about travel, how she's going back to Germany in a month and the Bundesliga. Bear in mind it's beer 4 or 5 now. More small talk and now she's running around with Marcel (other employee and all around cool mofo) handling orders. El Foxer (thats me, email if you want details on that handle) asks Mira if she 'd like to go out before she goes home. "No, boyfriend in Deutschland." to which I reply "That's horrible" (with a smile). FREEZE. At this time my ex-girlfriend, who had called earlier to see what I was up to and also loves this place, drops into the stool next to me. Mira then looks at me and says, "Don't pout." Ex then calls me out as being wasted so I classily glide/stumble to the bathroom. Now I'm sure she had a conversation with M.,  most likely on why we're exes (it's not me Jason, it IS you), and I re-emerge almost incoherent. To the best of my knowledge I tell Marcel he's the man, go jerk-mode on Mira and let X tell me that she's driving me home as she doesn't think I can walk to the train. X is forced to fill out the bill and help me sign my name as well as start running damage control for me. The last thing I remember saying on the way out was that I was going to have all the employees fired. All through this, I got great service and (too much) great beer. Thanks Walzwerk for not throwing me out on my ass or paying a homeless guy to beat me severely. I'll be back again, just not until after early August.
author: Robert K.

description: The owner's a friend of mine, so I have to say something about this one! Try the spatzle, or the dumplings, the red cabbage, and wash it down with an Underberg when you're done!
author: adrian c.

description: Solid German comfort food.  The wait can be a bit daunting on a weekend night.  Decor is sparse (duh, it's German), but cool.  Food is reasonably priced.  Service is spotty, but friendly.  The restaurant was sweltering hot, which was not ideal.  A fun place to check out.
author: Scott L.

description: I had a decent dinner here, but was kinda dissappointed. Our group got put back in the "Back Room" which turned out to be the kids room, full of screaming crying babies (probably the worst thing to do to a group who all are not fond of kids...) We were seated way before another table and had only one additional person and yet our meals came way after (for no reason we could figure out because the other table ordered exactly same dishes) With two servers paying attention to us it was still veeeery slow and lacking. They gave us a Brita pitcher for our water! The cheese spaetzil was good but not that exciting. And after being asked twice if we wanted dessert and waiting another 10 mins for bill, we all just wanted to leave the crying babies behind.
author: Alyssa C.

description:
this place is pretty good for comfort food...potatoes figure prominantly in some shape or form on the menu, whether they be mashed, boiled, or shaped in pancake form.  we had the potato pancakes w/ sour cream and applesauce to start, which was really good.  i got the cod filet w/ a dill sauce which was tasty.  my friend got the garlic roast pork which was a tad on the dry side.  we should have gotten the schnitzel instead, b/c i saw other people get it, and it looked really good.  i was so happy i could get a radler here, which is half beer/half seven up...it reminded me of my travels in germany.  

the decor in this restaurant is definitely interesting...the plates they use remind me of plates you use at home in the 1970s.  there is also a cabinet in the bathroom w/ funny german knick knacks.
author: Helen T.

description: I love Walzwerk, been going here for years - even if it's not authentic East-German food, and it can't because you can't get the same ingredients here in the U.S., no way.  They have really awesome dishes for Vegetarians, just fantastic.  Decor is fun, took me right back to the old days behind the (iron) curtain - yes, I remembered the awful plastic curtains when entering a DDR-establishment!  Too bad they can't serve the green Berliner Weisse any longer because the U.S. doesn't allow the green syrup to be imported anymore - typical American knuckleheads don't know what woodruff is.  I find the place in general too small, wish it would be in a bigger space, as it's always crowded.
author: L. A.

description: Love it!  Clever decor, good service, delicious kraut and brats.
author: T-Bone L.

description: Being a regular here has its pros and cons. Pros are that you can pretty much do everything except cooking and putting the money in the register. Cons are that you do exactly that. If it's super busy on our usual Thursday night, the staff can be a bit overwhelmed, but will always be friendly and edgy. Food-wise, try the Kaesespaetzle or be courageous and ask to get the Schnitzel with Spaetzle substituting the mashed potateos. Ed Y., I never saw green beer there. I'd recommend the Erdinger Weissbier. Oh, and it can be a bit noisy - and that's even without any music playing.
author: Roland A.

description: I've been here twice and loved it both times.  This is the grittier East German sister of Suppenkuche (which I also love).  It isn't really but it helps to put it into context.  The decor is incredibly charming in a cute, kitschy, commie, industrial kinda way (it's possible).  The staff is really German and super friendly.  Plus the food rocks.  I got the vegetarian schnitzel one time and the fish of the day another.  Both were yummy, weren't expensive and served as my lunch the next day.  It's a fun place to go and I highly reccomend it.
author: M M.

description: The food is really, really good.  It's a small, comfortable place, with a skeleton crew of friendly, attentive staff.
author: Eric W.

description: So we came here for a pre-Valentine's day dinner since my fiance was going to be out of town on the actual day. We also didn't want to blow a ton of money, but we wanted decent food and have been wanting to try this place for a while. We both wondered what East German food was going to be like since most German places serve Bavarian cuisine. We arrived hungry and pretty much already knew what we wanted even before we got there. So, Marc & I both had the Schnitzel (breaded and fried pork loin) with the delicious mushroom cream sauce except I had mine with the Spatzle (a type of homemade egg drop-noodle) and the boy had his with mashed potatoes. While the sauce and noodles were really good, the meat itself could have been more tender. The dark lager was decent but their beer selection definitely was nowhere near as big as Suppenkuche's. The organic Elderberry soda was quite refreshing though. The waiters & waitresses were nice and made substitutions without a problem. The decor was pretty interesting -- they really tried to make it look like a mid 20th C Eastern German place complete with framed posters of various Communist leaders & ads from that period. Being German, Marc was interested and took a walk around after dinner to check everything out. The dishes and flatware were also an eclectic mix of anything from homey looking stoneware and plain flatware to some random nicer pieces. The tables were eclectic too, and only the beer & soda glasses were consistent. It was a nice evening and we were served quickly by nice people. Basically, it was a good experience but no replacement for the Walter-run Schnizelhaus -- we really miss that place.
author: Samantha H.

description: Serving food your mother would make - if your mother was German and lived in Berlin 30 years ago. I came to this place once when a German TV crew was filming a segment for the anniversary of the fall of the Berlin wall. They made me describe my German food in front of microphone and camera. I can  imagine nice German families sitting in front of their TVs shaking their head in amusement.
author: Heather D.

description: After drinking those stiff drinks at Dillons, this is the place to go - how else would you decide to stuff your face with schnitzel, bratwurst and pickled herrings??  and don't forget the sweet stuff - and I don't mean the waiters.
author: Aga N.

description: Because you need some food to go with that Kostritzer Schwarzbier...  that's why you go...
author: Tim G.

description: The food was excellent.  I had eaten at a German restaurant only once before, and it was not that great.  So this place has completely changed my mind!  The atmosphere is quaint and quirky, the service was good and I enjoyed the fact that they played German music as well - even some of the hard stuff!
author: nicole h.

description:
You Vill Eat Das Fud!

And you vill like it!...

Really, you will.  The decor is pre-hassolhoff single handedly bringing down the wall days. 

You'll really get the feeling of sparse despair while enjoying your spatzle, but in a good way!

I agree though, ban the hipsters!
author: BH ..

description: We went here after every other place we tried in the neighborhood was closed (it was Sunday).
