Wasn't quite sure what to expect, but I guess the main point is don't go here unless you've really worked up an appetite and do not wear tight clothing--especially since wine doesn't really seem to go with German food. Beer is a better fit, so you don't want to be feeling constricted around the tummy! I found it difficult to choose between menu items, but ended up with the jaegerschnitzel and was in heaven. Definite comfort food. With the potato pancakes and our main courses, we were too stuffed to order dessert. My advice is go and share the main course so you can sample things. This is what I will do next time. Great atmosphere, laid back, friendly service. Thumbs up!
author: SheRat R.

description:
I am originally from Austria and even know how to cook a few original Viennese dishes (like Wiener Schnitzel), so I am generally a pretty discerning customer when it comes to German or Austrian food.
After dining at the Walzwerk last Saturday with two friends, I can honestly say that this is some of the best German / Austrian food I have EVER had. Between the three of us we tried the Sauerbraten, Jaegerschnitzel, and Goulash. 
Absolutely everything was phenomenal, including the very tasty Kartoffelpuffer appetizer and the Thueringer Salad. Add the great selection of tasty draft beers and the friendly service (this despite the fact that the place was packed to the rafters), this dinner is one for the record books. I am definitely coming back and bringing friends who are looking for an authentic German dining experience.
author: B A.

description: So this place was really yummy.  3 stars for sure.  The atmosphere was cool.  Very German.  I mean at least that's what I would imagine it to be like.  The 3 stars is totally personal review.  I'm not used to eating super heavy food like I did (I had the bratwurst and my boyfriend had the chicken).  And both of us were feeling it afterwards. The beer was amazing!!  I would come drink there again for sure.  Really I have nothing negative to say about the place, but come with an appetite and take a few tums afterwards :)
author: Angela S.

description:
Loved this restaurant. Tucked away on the edge of the Mission (about a block away from 16th Str Bart) the decor very much reminded me of the film "Goodbye Lenin" (which I loved btw). It's not so big, and people do make reservations, also not so good for large parties (max of 6 people really).

Good selection of German beer on tap, some bottle selections as well. I had the Franziskaner (hef), surprisingly our server told me "I thought you might like that one" to which I replied yes and laughed. Not sure if I give off a "I want Franziskaner" aura or something. We started with the kartoffelpuffer (potato pancakes) which were quite good, with applesauce and sour cream. Haven't had that much since I was in Germany 4 years ago, so I was quite happy if you can imagine. Dishes, I ordered the kaesespaetzle, which was much better than the ones at other German restaurants in the area. Honestly felt like this was quite authentic, with German servers and German people as part of the restaurants patrons. This is a place I would probably recommend to my German relatives, I think they would feel at home, sort of. To top off dessert was the rote gruetze, which I have never seen at any other German restaurant (also introduced to me in Germany of course... many many years ago). I don't quite remember the taste of it from Germany but I thought it was not so bad at the restaurant.

Overall service was not so bad as some people say, there were basically 2 servers and one lady who brought out some food and took away plates and cleaned tables but didn't take your order (she was the American). Cost is ok, maybe a little on the high end, but you don't come by authentic German food very often, so I let my wallet take a hit...
author: Yosie G.

description: I'd probably give 3 1/2 stars because the food was good.  However, we had a party of 4 and had to wait about an hour and 20 min when she told us it would probably be 20 - 30 minutes.  It is a small place but they seemed understaffed that night.  While waiting, we talked to some other patrons and learned that they have run out of certain foods before and some people were waiting a half hour for their dessert.  When we were finally sat the service was pretty good and our food came rather quickly because the restaurant was clearing out for the night.  They were out of schnitzel though so we were disappointed about that.   I would go back but probably just with one other person and earlier in the night.   The beer was great :)
author: Veronica M.

description: not ma style...sausage and mashed potatoes.  dont get me wrong, i love taters and sausage but i aint tryin to pay hella bread for that meal.  i can make that at home when i aint got no food. thats po folk nite.  the beer was ok...but gimme a anchor steam over that german beer anyday.  to each his own...
author: Bane V.

description:
Absolutely superb fare and service. REAL German cuisine. Excellent service.  Located on S. Van Ness (a nothing neighborhood according to our cab driver). We brought a party of 15 for a party and the owners suggested they serve us family style from a selection of their appetizers and entrees. I am very glad we took them up on their suggestion!

The decor is a homage to the old DDR (East Germany pre 1989). There is a definite nostalgia for the old days by many ex east Germans. The walls are hung with posters and memorabilia from the DDR era including photos of Karl Marx and Lenin along with East German rock and roll LP's. 

The space is small but not claustrophobic and the tables and chairs are simple, wooden and proletarian. Unpretentious to a fault.

We started with Small Potato Pancakes with Chive Sour Cream and Applesauce. They were perfectly seasoned with a brown crust outside, light and creamy inside. Next, Matjes Herring in Sour Cream with Apples, Onions and Pickles, served with Pumpernickel Bread. I love pickled herring and this version is a winner. (in fact, I overdid it on the herring!). This was followed by their House cured Salmon with Horseradish Cream & Marinated Beets. I am always suspicious of cured salmon served in restaurants since most times, it tastes like it came right from a package but this dish was the real deal and obviously prepared in house. Finally, we had the Thuringer Salad (White Cabbage, Red Cabbage & Carrot Salad) and Walzwerk's
House Green Salad (Butter Lettuce with a Light Oil & Vinegar Dressing). The cabbages and carrots were dressed like slaw but very lightly. Delicious! The salad was ok. Not spectacular. But definitely fresh and good.

Next the entrees, served heaped on huge platters. The Jäger Schnitzel (Porkloin) with Spätzle and Creamy Mushrooom Sauce was not like the Jäger Schnitzel I have had in Berlin which was always served breaded and doused in a heavy brown sauce. Walzwerk's version is served unbreaded and thinly sliced in a very light brown wild mushroom cream sauce and was superb. 

The second entree (all were served together); Garlic Roast Pork with Potatoes and Vegetables. The roast pork was cooked perfectly (I could cut it with a fork!) and not overpowered by the garlic. 

The third entry was my favorite (as well as with most of the table): Breast of Chicken stuffed with Apples & Bacon (with Sundried Cherry Sauce), Mashed Potatoes, and Seasonal Vegetables. I have never had anything quite like this. As with all stuffed chicken breast dishes, the danger is in overcooking the chicken so that it is tough and dry. Not at Walzwerks. The breast was succulent and juicy. The stuffing just the right amount of sweet and savory. The mashed potatoes were  as light as whipped cream and served with a big bowl of green peas which, though I love, were definitely of the frozen variety. Didn't matter. They were a perfect compliment to the meal.

Dessert? Nearly everyone got the Strudel, a few the Cold Dog and one person , the berry pudding. I didn't sample the pudding but I had the Strudel and it was the best strudel I have ever eaten, and that includes my own which is not bad. The Cold Dog was just ok, not bad. Reminded me of a mini ice box cake from the 50's.

Overall, it was a great meal for a great party. Generous servings of real comfort food prepared with care and skill. I will definitely go back to try the rest of the menu. Don't miss this out on this little gem of an eatery.
author: Jim G.

description:
Took my friend here for his birthday. Figured a German restaurant would have lots of meat but with a twist. Got there around 7:30 on a Saturday and told there was a 30 min wait. They don't accept reservations for parties of less than 4. We sat in the small waiting area and had drinks. The 7up/beer sounded good, but not sure so they gave me 2 VERY generous samples, one w/ pilsner other with wheat beer. Wheat was tasty. Also sampled the sparkling wine. That was really good. Would like more of that. 
When seated for dinner, I had several questions. Server was nice enough but a bit terse. Understandable though, as It was busy and there were only 2 servers. 
The soljanka soup sounded oddly good. Cabbage/tomato soup with pickles, salami and bacon? Love it. I love pickles and I love salami (nothing silly intended), so this soup was my kinda thing. Not that much cabbage. Lots of small cubes of salami. Would love a meal size version of this. 
For entree got the roasted garlic pork. Really wanted to try either the spaetzle or the potato dumplings but roast pork came w/potatoes. Was able to sub the spaetzle. Friend got the schnitzel. 
They ended up giving me potatoes and spaetzle. Server apologized and said they forgot, so gave me a side of spaetzle in separate bowl. I was told they wouldn't charge for two things, but spaetzle is extra. My pork was presented as two pinwheel type rounds with loads of garlic rolled inside. Alot of meat. Alot of food! The seasonal veggie was slices of cooked carrots. One pork wheel was a bit tough. The other was more tender but most of the outside of the round was a rind of fat. All needed salt. The spaetzle was lukewarm. I love chewy pasta-type foods, but wasn't so excited about the spaetzle. Not much flavor and no discernible sauce or seasoning. Probably better hot. 
My friend's schnitzel was tasty and tender. What's not to like about pounded thin pork that's been breaded and pan fried?! He liked my dish better. I liked his better. 
Most unusual, I was unable to finish my meal. That almost never happens unless I'm ill. I think it was the heaviness and meatiness that did me in. And boy, was there a lot of garlic! I was belching garlic fire all night. Kinda gross, really. 
In the end I'd say I LOVE the soup, but could pass on the rest. It was okay, not great. The service was nice, relatively friendly and i wasn't charged for the spaetzle nor one of my 7up/beer drinks. 
The samples they gave me of the drinks were large and also not charged. I left full, satisfied, but not ecstatic. 
I have been searching for a good Soljanka recipe today, though. Anyone have Walzwerk's? Do they sell that by the vat?
author: Allucaneat G.

description: I used to go here a lot when it opened.  At some point they made their veggie plate smaller with less fried cauliflower (Mmmmm...), so I took one star off their rating, but it's still really good food and great German beer!
author: Neal W.

description: Cool  East Germany commie joint, Lenin and Marx overlooking the affairs...   Commie style broken-down mismatched tables and chairs adds to the feel.  They have a good German beer selection and good schnitzel and mashed potatoes.  Usually a few real krauts milling around the small bar.
author: Brent H.

description:
some of the best cured salmon i've ever had, geniusly served alongside horseradish cream. 

you come here for the hearty german fare and the one-of-a-kind decor and ambiance.
a bit kitsch, a bit 90s industrial feel, a bit ephemera museum, but all disarmingly charming.
the back room, painted in bright orange and blue, had walls of toy cases displaying random fun things. 
the bathroom walls were plastered with old german record covers. i like. 

the spaetzle could've been better, but the schnitzel is just fine, as are the creamy mashed potatoes. 

there's a very special and unique feel here.
author: jennifer y.

description: My first time trying German food and I loved it. The Place has a cute charm to it. I remember all the tables and chairs didn't match. I also discovered PEAR CIDER, Yum!
author: Shelley S.

description: Tasty German food. The menu is not as large as Suppenkuche but all the usual suspects are there, and the cool DDR-themed decor is spiffy. Viva Deutschland!
author: Ben L.

description:
I went to Walzwerk for one of my "wine and whine" dinners with my former co-workers. This was my first time in a German restaurant and I am definitely coming back. Although we went on a Tuesday night the place was packed!!! We had to wait for about 20 minutes, but the food was worth the wait. We shared the Small Potato Pancakes with Chive Sour Cream and Applesauce. It was very good. I had the Jger Schnitzel with Sptzle and Creamy Mushrooom Sauce and it was very good. 

If you want to check out German food, this is the place to go
author: vernice l.

description: Very cool place.  The food was great, nothing fancy just straightforward good German food.  The service was excellent.
author: Bill B.

description: I like to think I know food! Well it was so nice to walk into Walzwerk and get the same service and food you would eat in Berlin. That's why I love this place, it made me feel I was back in Berlin. So get your ass down there and eat.
author: WildBill C.

description: I go for the Berliner Weisse...it's a meal unto itself.
author: Bridget W.

description: My mother, who only remembers her German when she's really sleepy or drunk, thinks this place is the bomb. So do the meat loving men in our lives. Very homey-cozy small. The women who run it are kind and efficient. Who serves an amuse bouche these days? I try to order something that come with spatzle every time I'm there. The specials never fail to please, but off the menu I love the potato pancakes and schnitzel best.
author: J. R.

description:
Like many of the other reviewers, I'm continually astonished that a place on such a desolate spot on South Van Ness serving German food, of all things, is consistently so packed. And the wait can be infuriating, especially if you're a party of 2 and there are plenty of larger tables open. 
But. You can't really beat the atmosphere. It feels like an (admittedly somewhat trendy) Ossi bar in Berlin (or Dresden or Jena, etc.), right down to the unassuming little plastic salt and pepper shakers and the unmistakable home-cooked taste of the food. All you need is a view of some ugly pre-fab housing and some sad old chainsmoking retirees and you'd be on Leipzigerstrasse. 
One gripe I do have is that a lot of the food is a bit too sweet, but I complain about the food in the way that you'd complain about your mom's food. It just tastes satisfyingly homey, and any misgivings can be washed away with a healthy dose of beer. 
I do wish they kept bar hours, did group-seating ala Suppenkueche and had Augustiner (granted, not an East German beer, but then, neither is Weltenburger, Franziskaner or a number of others they also serve), but whatever. They've got killer sauerbraten, bratwurst and potato dumplings. Those potato dumplings are awesome. Granted, I've never seen how they actually make them, but they taste just like authentic Thuringian potato dumplings made from grated raw potato (as opposed to cooked, mashed potatoes), which give them a unique texture and taste you'd be hard-pressed to find even in Germany.
author: Kei H.

description: For a german DDR experience, this is a great place.
author: Karl B.

description: What a beautiful gem to discover. We decided to head to San Francisco on a spontaneous evening and really wanted to find a good German restaurant to eat. We stumbled across some reviews for Walzwerk and decided to do it. We made reservations and were immediately greater by a friendly young lady and seated in a great dining room full of ambiance. We felt like we were eating at our grandmas house. It was busy and smelled delicious. We started with great beer and potato pancakes with sour cream and applesauce. They were delicious and crispy and had wonderful flavor. While it took awhile to get our meal, we very much enjoyed savoring the atmosphere and experience. Our kids loved it too! Once the food arrived let me tell you it was worth the wait. Authentic German Food just like my husbands family makes. He had the beef roulade with Spätzle and red cabbage. It was so tender and flavorful and the gravy was sooooooo good! I had the jäger schnitzel! So delicious. We have tried a handful of German restaurants and this was fantastic and blew the others away!! Our server was fantastic and even called us a cab which arrived right away out front to take us back to our hotel. Cannot say enough good things about this place!!
author: Sarah B.

description:
A friend introduced me to this fascinating place. We got there late (about 9:00pm) and the neighborhood was pretty gritty. I stepped through a thick wooden door and a plastic curtain and... I was back in my beloved Prague! I know it's an East German restaurant, but my first exposure to this type of food was on student exchange, and it hit the spot like nothing else in the last ten years. I had the marinated beef with potato dumplings and red cabbage, and it was SO GOOD! Dessert was a plum tart with creme and vanilla ice cream, split three ways: plenty!
Our waiter was so great, and at the end of the meal came by with little bottles of bitters, which he shared. Prost! Or, for nostalgia's sake, na zdravi!
author: Megan C.

description: Totally random decor, it's really unlike any other place.  I'm no expert on German food, but what I ate was fine, albeit a bit bland.  The waitress was a total bitch, hence the mediocre grade.   I've seriously never seen been so horrified.
author: marie m.

description: I loved this place! I thought it might be good but it was sooo much better than that! Great beer, amazing food. That was the best pickled herring I have ever tasted ( and enough for about 6 people!). The seasoning is subtle, unusual and just perfect. We got the spinach stuffed trout and the ham stuffed pork chop. Both were amazing. Both with enough leftovers for a whole second meal. The mashed potatoes were addictive. The beers were great. I was thinking about it for days after I left. I must go back with a larger group so I can try more stuff! Maybe enen make it to dessert....
author: brainflower A.

description: good decent unobjectionalble simple German food...a pleasant decor and ambience, if you like communist factory co-op lunch places.....lots of people complain about rude service, they just dont know Germans...they're not being rude, they're just efficient without a lot of fake friendliness...what you get here is fairly good value for your money (theyre maybe a bit overpriced, but this is SF after all) in a simple authentic seeming environment..the owners do try to make it as old style East German as possible, and theyre successful in that. For DDR factory workers, this is like coming home...comforting and scary at the same time.
author: Tom B.

description: Great food! We went as a big group and ordered one of everything. The host put us in the back room and it was perfect as I know this place gets crowded. So yes, one of everything, go for it.
author: Susan M.

description:
I am German. I know German food- and this place rocks.
In case you don't know, we eat bread that looks like wood and everything has butter on it... including the butter. I love they decor and I've seen the Govt. mandated housing there.. well you get it. As Hedwig would say long story short...
If my gf gets ever gets mad at me, I know I can bring her here and she will
forget, forgive, and flagellate me the way a good woman should.
Oh and I LOVE cabbage and potatoes. and BEER giant giant delicious beer.
author: Mr. Marie T.

description: Food was amazing!  Potato pancakes...heavenly!  However, the staff isn't so nice.  The woman there is freakin' scary...beware!  Tip o' the day:  Don't arrive w/o your whole party...you'll be sorry!
author: alisha h.

description: My mother grew up in East Germany and I remember being there to visit before the wall came down...Somehow, Walzwerk really embodies the place in the best possible sense.  I enjoy the authentic mid-century memorabilia and the conversation-worthy communist leader portraits on the walls.  As far as food goes, it is great, and it is certainly the closest to my mom's cooking.  She approves of the red cabbage there which is rare, believe me. I also enjoy the mellow atmosphere and I haven't yet had a problem getting a table.  We even brought our 3 and 5 year old niece and nephew, and yes they were well behaved, but it was still refreshing that we didn't get any dirty looks  from wait staff or guests which is usually only possible at like, Cheescake factory!
author: Jasmin P.

description:
This was the last German restaurant that I had left to try in the city and I should not have waited this long. Great DDR environment, fun/friendly server and good beer selections!

The food was just like I remembered. I never liked the herring salad growing up, but this was much better. Had the rindsroulade and the sauerbraten. Neither were drenched in thick gravy, which unfortunately has been the norm at other German restaurant, but instead in pan juices. Served with tasty pan-fried spaetzle and clove spiced red-cabbage. Even desserts were tasty. Go try the Rote Gruetze (berry pudding)...delicious. But the "cold dog" and the ever-present applestrudel are just as tasty!
author: chris k.

description:
Hello

First of all, you need to know that in two years Yelp became a really good reference to me. However i never rated any restaurant from the bay area. But after our experience of yesterday, i decided to register and rate this restaurant.

Yesterday was a farewell diner for my roommate and myself.
We did a reservation for about 20 persons. To make it easy, we order the "Family style" dinner. Which is an order of few plates that we shared
 I have to say that it wasn't exceptional. I would recommend other German restaurant for sure!
We shared some plates, but it wasn't worth 25$ per person

We were a big group so that waitress did have to care to much about us, and basically she really didn't care at all... She was also really rude (maybe because the tip was included ) Also the price didn't cover the alcohol, and seriously we drunk two tiny glass of beer per person which worth maybe less than 10$ max per person. But they charged us the double. 

I know that i can spend a lot of money for good food 
But almost 50 $ per person for the service and the quality of the food we got yesterday: I was really pissed!
author: caroline o.

description: Remember that mountain Richard Dreyfuss made out of mashed potatoes in 'Close Encounters of the Third Kind'?  Yeah, they've got that.
author: Nora S.

description: Walzwerk runs like a well-oiled machine.  The service runs a tight ship yet is very personable. The menu is a tad simple but the portions are right and are very well prepared.
author: Christian W.

description:
Who knew I liked East German Food?!  The Potato Pancakes were really lovely, not oily but perfectly crisp on the outside.  Just enough Sour Cream and apple sauce to go with. (I was pleased by the green onion in the sour cream - nice touch, and excellent flavor to boot)  The Jager Schnitzel (pardon the spelling) a cutlet of pork on top of spatzel covered in mushroom sauce was rich in mushroom flavor and not over heavy as you might expect the dish to be.  It was a nice balance and quite honestly almost refreshing to get a hearty meal that I didn't feel gross after eating. (you know that feeling after you've just eaten something that will show up on your cholesterol test in the future to haunt you?).  I had the 1/2 Coke 1/2 7 Up because I was feeling frisky, and the Apple strudel for dessert... it was lovely with the ciao bella vanilla, I felt the vanilla sauce was nice but didn't add anything to the dessert in flavor.

Awesome place to have a meal with friends, really great beer and nice staff and patrons.  This is a great place!  Walzwerk - I will be back!
author: Alicia W.

description: This is a good down home German place.  The schintzel was just right and I like the atmosphere.
author: Susan T.

description:
I love this place--I have had incredible meals there. The servings are huge (I dare anyone to try to eat a full appetizer, like the pickled herring, and an entree themselves), and the food is generally fantastic. The wait staff is friendly, although sometimes it's hard to get their attention if you're pressed for time.

My one complaint is the lack of consistency, which I see has been mentioned before. I've had the same dish more than once, and found it range from incredibly good to merely passable. It's really too bad, but it doesn't prevent me from coming back every couple months or so for a change of pace. If it were more consistent fantastic, it'd be one of my favorite places ever...
author: Jared B.

description: OMG a salivacious place to eat, especially when it's cold out.  the wiener is awesome.   it's hearty, tasty and will put you to bed.  the appetizers are also worth trying, but i have my old stand by's: potato pancakes or soljanka.   be sure to try the specials.
author: erica u.

description: Great food. A fun place for a small group to sit down and eat.
author: Scott F.

description: I love coming here!  The food's affordable, portions are plentiful, and the servers are GREAT!  They all have that wonderfully dry European sense of humour which I just can't seem to get enough of.  I've seen Sean Lennon and Vincent Gallo there, too!  How completely random is that?!?!  Love it, love it, love it and recommend it to everyone I know :D  Danke!
author: Jac C.

description: Best German food in SF without a question. This place is truly authentic. Everything from the beer to the decor is straight from Germany. Highly recommended.
author: Kris C.

description: We went to this restaurant after an art show and had my 86 year old father with us..He hates to eat out and always complains about the food..But he spent 7 years in Germany and met my mother there..it could have gone either way!! To begin with we shared an order of potato pancakes w sour cream and apple sauce,they were quite good..the old man ordered the snitzel with mashed potatoes/veggies and showed his approval by eating almost all of the substantial portion, it was crisp and delicious...I had the jager snitzel,a creamy combo of pork tenderloin, mushrooms,sauce smothering spazele.very rich and worth every high caloric bite..my daughters had the garlic pork loin(very good) and the cabbage roulade which looked delicious...We were too full for desert,but for once not a complaint from the old guy who pronounced the food "okay",high praise from the Grinch of restaurant dining....
author: Lily W.

description: I am never disappointed with Walzwerk. The food is always delicious (jaeger schnitzel...mmm), beer nice and cold, and I love the staff. Some people complain that the waitstaff is cold and unwelcoming, but I think it's because they can spot a deusche-bag a couple miles away. Get over it people. We're here for the food!
author: Courtney I.

description: Love this restaurant! The atmosphere, the food, the beer, and the waiting service are outstanding. My German friend recommended this place and it is simply the best compared to his mother's cooking. The schnitzel with the mashed potatoes is what I always get. I've tried the yager-shnitzel and it taste great. They have this spicy mustard that will knock your socks off. I always get a few Franziskaner Hefe-Weissbier that is fresh off the tap. If you are going with more than 4 people you should get reservations, it is always packed. My friend's and I always make an effort to go to this place every few months. It's just a block away from the 16th and Mission BART station. Anyone who likes food needs to go to this place.
author: Justin A.

description: Holy shit this place is great.  I went to a birthday dinner in the back room and it was so much fun!  The decor is bliss, the food is out of this country, and the service is divine.   I don't know if I would ever go back - but I am glad I got to experience this little gem.
author: gem s.

description: Excellent, hearty food & beer. It'll stick to your ribs... in a good way.
author: Matt W.

description: This place is great. Cozy, good food, and very friendly staff. The potato pancakes were really good, as was the chocolate almond cookie for dessert!
author: Sam H.

description: This was my first time eating at Walzwerk, a small East German restaurant, where I joined 6 friends for dinner, on a Monday evening.  The place was crowded and noisy, but conversation was certainly possible.  Among us, we shared an order of something akin to potato latkes, with apple sauce and sour cream.  They were perfect.  I ordered the schnitzel with mashed potatoes and baby zucchini.  Everything was delicious.  My friends ordered several different entrees, we finished everything, and I heard no complaints.  For dessert, we ordered one of each item on the menu and passed the dishes around the table.  Every one of the desserts was less than wonderful, with the cheese cake receiving poor marks from everyone.  It was simply mild  tasting fluff.  Service was good.  The price was quite reasonable.  I would definitely recommend it, but I would pass on the desserts.
author: Eddie W.

description:
stepping into walzwerk is a little like arriving at a youth hostel in munich -- cozy and spartan but funky and lively. the dining room is filled w all sorts of posters and artwork from 1960s and 70s east germany, and (perhaps due to the name) theres a distinctly utilitarian, almost industrial feel inside.

not surprisingly, the beer selection is good, though not as large or eclectic as i was hoping (you can get franziskaner pils in a lot of bars around the city). still, beers are served in their proper steins/mugs, which is nice. as was the tasty little pumpernickle bread points w ham and cheese we were served upon sitting down.

the service was quick and efficient (it IS a german restaurant) and the food hearty but not overwhelmingly flavorful (ditto). the pork chop w rosemary sauce -- a special -- was my fave, though our group also dug on the bratwurst served w a badass mustard and some delicious, homemade saurkraut. as simple as it sounds, that brat was richly spiced and perfectly cooked, squeaking w juices. 

the other entrees we had were good and big, tasty but nothing too special. desserts were also good but not great -- try the cold dog for the name alone.
author: jonathan z.

description: The Reisling to go is the Schnitzel :) Some times i just crave it from the bottom of my toes....I highly recommend it!
author: Nikki B.

description:
Every third Wednesday of the month a group of us, all expatriate Germans, meet at Walzwerk for dinner.  I am the only one in the bunch from Berlin; there are folks from Bavaria, from the Rheinland, and from the Ruhrpott, but we all agree that have dinner at Walzwerk is a bit like coming home to home-cooked meal.  It's, as we say in Germany, "wie bei Muttern"  (like at mom's).  

I must admit that back in Germany the "Ostalgia," a somewhat delusional infatuation with the lost days of the GDR, truly get on my nerves.  Though I grew up in West Berlin during the days of the wall, I still don't feel any desire for the good old days of East German "charme."  But I do get nostalgic for the Berlin of the 70s and have my regular bouts of homesickness.  And Walzwerk is a good way to celebrate both.  

Christiane, the owner and heart and mind behind the entire operation, is absolutely fantastic.  She is funny, warm and kind.  I fear that some of the folks who felt intimidated by her ways were probably misreading her suggestions for demands.  

If you are in the mood for good and AUTHENTIC German food in a really nice place, go to Walzwerk, have a beer, enjoy the Schnitzel or Sptzle or the Bratwurst and hang for a few hours.  It's absolutely worth it.  

Oh, and in case you show up on that third Wednesday of the month forgive us if we are too loud...  We try to be better next time.  (Sorry Christiane...)
author: Oliver P.

description:
One time in 1989, I found myself in East Berlin for an afternoon.  To get there, I had to change 25 West German Deutschmarks for 25 East German ones, which at first didn't bother me, but at the time, people were pretty excited about some wall coming down or something and East Berlin was basically a ghost town as all the East Germans were over in West Berlin buying Japanese electronics at inflated prices, drinking coca-cola and reveling a bit too much in the joys of capitalism.  The only place in East Berlin I could find to spend my East German Deutschmarks was a little ice-cream parlor that doled out cold war-sized wafer cones of strict ice milk in an assortment that was pedestrian at best.  Even with my Middle American appetite, I can't down 25 East German Deutschmarks worth of Gorbachev-era ice-milk, and on that day, with all the excitement of chipping away at the wall and meeting Checkpoint Charlie MP's from Port Washington, WI, I only managed to get rid of about 4 of East German Deutschmarks.  So now, somewhere in my vast collection of crap, probably in a bag next to the pieces of the wall that I chipped off using a hammer I stole from a little kid from Baden-Baden, I have 21 rather austere looking, completely obsolete East German Deutschmarks.

Ok, yeah, so Walzwerk...
35 stars for the spinach salmon spaetzle!  Sadly, I'll have to dock them 22 stars for not having it on the menu every day.  Actually, come to think of it, I'm going to dock them another 6 stars for not delivering to me personally a spinach salmon spaetzle dinner 5 out of 7 nights of the week.  Ok, where does that leave us...7 stars?  That sounds about right.

I love this place.  As you've probably gathered, I love the Spaetzle, with or without salmon and spinach.  In fact, at times it's hard for me to order anything else due to this mildly unhealthy infatuation.  But I have persevered in the face of such noodle-y adversity and have tried many other Teutonic treats as well.  The beet soup is good and comes in a really cool square red "bowl".  The Sauerbraten is great, not too sweet, not too sauer, sorry...sour and perfectly tender.  The Jagerschnitzle, also great, bratwurst great, potato pancakes, great, Thuringer salad great, red cabbage...see the trend?  The big potato dumplings could use a little extra something, as could the red berry pudding desert, but all is forgiven in light of the sauerkraut which can only be described as magnificent.  They have a great German beer selection, many on tap, as well as a pair of interesting beer and soda concoctions which are actually pretty refreshing.  They also have a perfect dessert called cold dog, which is cold but not canine in any way I can see.  I wish I could remember the name of the little bottles of aquavit-esque liquor they have on hand as a post-spaetzle digestif...kind of an acquired taste but an apt way to top off the meal.

The service is good, too.  They're working hard there, and can be, on occasion, a little gruff, but always good natured and quick to laugh.  It does always seem to be busy, so either make a reservation or be prepared to squeeze into the small waiting area and drink excellent beer until your number's up.  I love the mash-up dcor of industrial, graphic, East German chic.  Especially the bathroom collection of cold war toiletries and Deutschland 45's.

Now if only they'd let me pay for my spaetzle with those damn East German Deutschmarks...
author: Peter L.

description: Adorable charming German restaurant.  You feel as though you are on other side of the wall with all the Eastern memorabilia. Portions are good, and people come here to enjoy the food, not to get drunk drinking out of a boot.
author: sandy s.

description: mission location...quick trot from 16th mission bart....eclectic german decor...mix matching seating and plates....fitting mission vibe....alsterwasser $four...1 part beer to 1 part 7-up.....gulp and surprisingly cold, light, sweet and refreshing....new favorite beer "cocktail"?...possible....receiving trio of cheese and meat appetizer complimentary....ordering potato pancake trio $six fine...fried, soft and good with sweet applesauce and sour cream saucing....second, thuringer salad $seven subpar...trio of mild white cabbage, sour red cabbage and sweet carrot salad.... self main entree sauerbraten, marinated beef, with potato dumplings and sour red cabbage $sixteen decent....beef tender and sweet....warm sour red cabbage salad good sharp contrast....sweet and sour good balance?....sadly potato dumpling disappointing....worst in comparison to other german dumplings had.....to add...a comment of tastings...bite of cod bit overcooked and dry....bacon wrapped cabbage..infused with bacon fat taste good....chew of boiled beef fine and sauced....hearty meal for hungry soul....
author: Hen A.

description: The chicken with apple and bacon is so tasty, as well as the apple strudel. You can find a better bratwurst though. The decorations are interesting and charming.
author: Katherine S.

description: I don't get the fuss about this place. I went here based on the reviews, and completely understand why some people gave it a low rating. My entree was cold and I had to send it back to have it re-heated...  The  Jaegerschnitzel I had was barely o.k.. If you're paying these kind of prices for food, it should be excellent. Won't be returning here.
author: J M.

description: Walzwerk is a cozy German restaurant in the Mission. Very unassuming from the outside, but decidedly welcoming and charming on the inside. On a Friday night we arrived around 7 without a reservation- no problem as they invited us to sit down on a couch near the bar and order drinks. The waitress was extremely nice and allowed me to sample the Reisling- the sample size was an entire glass! Needless to say, the time passed quite quickly waiting for the table, and before we knew it we were seated at a slightly kitchy table decorated with fake flowers. I unintentionally knocked my glass of reisling over but the waitress was kind enough to refill the glass again. We shared the potato pancakes with sour cream, chives, and apple sauce for an appetizer. The pancakes were very thick- crispy on the outside yet soft and mushy on the inside. For dinner I had the vegetarian schnitzel which consisted of breaded and fried vegetables (carrots, beets, cauliflower) over a mountain of mashed potatoes and drizzled with a creamy tomato sauce. A very rich meal indeed, not to mention the portions are enormous. My meal would easily have fed three people. I also tried the mushroom spatzle, which was creamy and delicious.  I recommend this restaurant for anyone craving German food but unwilling to put up with trendy over hyped places- Walzwerk is definitely a down to earth satisfying experience and you will not leave hungry.
author: Kate A.

description:
a showdown with suppenkuche needed to happen.  and walzwerk fell a little short for me.
i found the decor to be the complete opposite of suppenkuche, which wasn't bad, just different.  the best part of dinner may have been the waitress, who is also the owner.  all i can say is that she fit every stereotype of germans i have.

friend: "how's the christmas goose?"
waitress: (intense stare) "what do you mean? it's goose!"
friend: "....."
waitress: "........" (more intense staring)
friend: "ummm.... i'll have the chicken...."

the drinks we ordered were awesome.  i tried a glass of both the beer + cola and the beer + 7-up.  total opposite drinks.  the beer mixed with coke was a darker, more bitter beer while the beer mixed with 7-up was light and refreshing.  both were equally tasty.  we started with two appetizers, the potato pancakes and the herring.  the herring, which is mixed with sour cream and various fruits and vegetables, was awesome.  the potato pancakes were so-so.  a little thick and undercooked.  the potato pancakes at suppenkuche were amazing so walzerks lost in that category.
as for the food, i ordered the chicken, which was stuffed with bacon and apples, with a creamy cherry sauce.  i don't usually eat meat but my friend told me it was awesome and the vegetarian dishes didn't call out to me.  my friend was right.  it was great except the parts of the chicken that were a bit thicker were dry.  the spatzle that it came with (they ran out of the mashed potatoes) was also delicious.

the best part of the night didn't happen until we tried spliting the bill with 4 credit cards.  the 4th person in our group felt bad about throwing his card in too cause he had enough cash so when the waitress came back, we asked.

friend: "it's ok to split the bill on 4 cards right?"
waitress: "........."
friend: "ummm........."
waitress" (long, single, slow blink)
friend: "........just split it with these three........"

awesome.  some people said that this place has bad service.  but i think it just reinforced my uneducated and naive stereotypes!
author: Thom Y.

description: I love German food and I love everything about the DDR, so I was uber excited to find out about this place. My excitement was quelched by the lousy food and rotten service. At first I chalked up the serivce to part of the East German ambience, later I realized it was just sheer attitude. Worst German meal ever!!! The potato dumpling was like eating a warm, wet, sponge - absolutely no flavor. My buddy had the spaetzle; weirdest I've ever seen. His chicken was good (roast chicken...go figure) but my sauerbraten was over-cooked and full of grissle. If the bad food and bad service were part of the East German theme I could laugh it off, but it clearly isn't. Save yourself the time and money and go to Schnitzel Haus or Suppenkuche.
author: Brad D.

description: Walzwerk is a little out of the way but definitely worth the trip. The waitress was super nice and seeing that we were a bit lost on what to order, she gave us some great recommendations. I ended up with the pork schnitzel, and boy did it taste good. I've never been to Germany, but I imagine in a tiny Bavarian village, you'd get the same amazing food. They also have a fairly decent offering of beer, and the restaurant is quiet enough that you can sit and chat with your friends over yummy food and beer.
author: Michele L.

description: really good food, nice people, highly recommend eating here especially if you like authentic german food.
author: Ribec F.

description: This is real-deal German food and quite imaginative too. I didn't expect the vegetarian schnitzel to be so interseting--instead of trying to recreate schnitzel with  tofu, they creatively deep fried red beets, carrots and cauliflower. the East German interior is also on target, and the competent ye straightforward staff is a dream!
author: nadines d.

description: Been wanting to go to Walzwerk for years; finally went tonight for the first time; loved it! Fairly crowded (Sat. night); you might have to wait a little to be seated, but it's entirely worth it. The staff is informal but very hospitable and accomodating; the food was great, and plenty of it- had the herring appetizer, my girlfriend had the grill plate with pork chop, sausages and fish, mashed potatoes, sauerkraut; I had the chicken breast- all delicious, good quality, and I had a very good Radeberger pilsner. Sehr lecker; gehen Sie! I'm anxious to go back.
author: JOHN S.

description: this place was pretty tasty, i tried my friends beer+sprite which was surprisingly good, got veggie strussel and enjoyed the kitchy atmosphere.
author: Jared Z.

description: I love this place!  Great food, reasonable prices, and the East German theme makes it not your typical Bavarian German restaurant.
author: Steve L.

description: My husband and I are return customers...and for one very good reason - yummy grub!  I had no idea what to expect the first time he brought me here, but being a closet foodie, I was very excited about trying German cuisine...as I had no prior experience with it.  I have found the atmosphere cozy, the staff fun, and the food very satisfying.  I never leave hungry and always have trouble deciding what to try next.  I have a good time at Walzwerk, and I look forward to our next visit.
author: Kristeen N.

description: so not what i expected...but was blown away by the great simple food and great beer....skip desert though..wasn't impressed with it.
author: A P.

description: Superb food, good hosts, old east German theme to the place. The beer is fantastic along with the food and the desert. Jäger Schnitzel which comes with the mushroom sauce is "out of this world". My wife had the "Beef Roulade" was good as well. We also tried the "cold dog" desert, truly a simple dish but satisfies the soul.  Been to this place several times, will be back several more times for sure.
author: Sreen T.

description: This place is actually b/t 3 and 4 stars but to have it at even stars with suppenkuche makes me want to bump it down a little.  solid food... potato pancakes were a little thick for my taste (i like mine crunchy).  the weiner schnitzel was good and the spaetzle was decent too but nothing blew my mind.  suppenkuche's not far from this place and the food is better in my opinion
author: jean m.

description:
if this is what East Germany is like, I must be living in the wrong country!

seriously I LOVED this place, and I am generally not the biggest fan of German food (had been wanting to try it for over 6 months before I actually made it there..)

The Schnitzel was really fulfilling, flavorful, crispy, comforting...and yet despite that I kept eyeing my boyfriend's dish because it was equally, if not more, delicious!
service was really polite, friendly and accommodating.. to the point that we were able to each have a mini wine-tasting session before deciding what to order.

the decor was interesting and fun without being overwhelming which is not always easy to find is SF... another win! 

I want to go back and try the herring now...
author: Victoria K.

description: I love the atmosphere of this place - it reminds me of my mom's kitchen from the 70s - it has some of the same furniture and dishes. Continuing on that comfort theme - the food is warm, delicious, and filling. If they ever have the beef goulash on the menu, definitley get it - it was the best beef-based soup/stew I've had outside my mom's kitchen. If you can, make reservations as there aren't many nearby bars or a large waiting area in the restaurant.
author: J K.

description: great food. but the place is spatially tight, especially the back room. but wait staff is very, very friendly and informed. overall, a nice option when suppenkuche is slammed.
author: casey c.

description: love this place. the servers are friendly, the beer is strong and if you're lucky you'll see a street fight on mission street on the way home like we did.  the crowd didnt feel over pretentious and the herring may not be like the way they do it in the Netherlands but it's pretty close.
author: S. K.

description: I never thought a german restaurant would have vegetarian options. Granted there are only 3 vege options but I could eat their Spatzle every day.
author: Susie O.

description: I went to dinner with enlightened folk and a genuine German, so we had what he was drinking and shared the dinners musical plate style. We had one appie - the potato pancakes which were under cooked and slightly crunchy not from the outside.  The Jaeger Schnitzel (creamy mushroomy sauce with decent dumplings) was the crowd favorite with the bratwurst a far second.  The stuffed chicken breast was adequate for those who can't eat the pork.  Avoid the beef roulade as under cooked (it needed to be braised for much longer) so did not have that melt in your mouth moment.  The cold dog was great and the apple strudel was disappointing.  While the waitress' were attentive with bringing more and more beer, water was definitely not in the offering, so if you want it, you'll have to ask for it.  Will I go back? Yes but will I pick carefully off the menu? You betcha.  They can seat up to 8 on one table and then it gets kind of tight.  Close to 16th St BART so easily accessible.
author: Gwyneth T.

description: I've been to most of the German restaurants in the Bay Area, but this is the one I liked the most. It was the first time I had a Soljanka soup (never heard of this in west Germany). It was totally awesome. I had the Rouladen, which were very good and my wife had the Jäger Schnitzel which was really super good. The place is really small inside and not very noticeable form the outside. Very gemueltich and antler free.
author: Marcus Z.

description: i totally dig the uber-industrial east german atmosphere of this place!  the food is great and served in plentiful portions.  i had the stuffed pork tenderloin served with red pickled cabbage and spatzle noodles - YUM!  also, the beer list is pretty decent. can't really beat german beer can you?
author: Jennifer D.

description: This place is an absolute gem!  In a kinda random location (i.e., not on the main Mission drag), it is definitely worth seeking out.  The first words out a the waitresses' mouth were, "So we want beers, ya?"  This came as no surprise as the seven of us were decked out in full douche bag, frat-bro, Marina gear (striped, collared shirts; I know don't hate me too much, I do own a few).  Still, looking as tooly as we may have, it was great to have some authentic German beers to start (I think they have Spaten, Franziskaner, and the usuals on tap, but some good dunkels and Aventinus on bottle!)  The food is amazing, stuffed chicken breast was delicious and the mashed potatoes are some of the best I've ever had.  The decor is old East German propaganda and posters of Lenin and Marx, which is a little unnerving, but adds to the experience.  A small and somewhat rowdy spot, not good for a quiet first date, but great for groups or a date that's down for a good time.  Find this place, you will like it, even my dorky Marina friends did (shit, maybe that's a bad thing).
author: Kevin M.

description: everything about this pace is awesome.  decor, staff, food, beer.  had the spaten amber, one of the best ambers i've ever had, the sauerbraten, and spiced red wine for dessert (christmas special).  quiet and chill on a sunday night with the place full of friends of the staff - it was like Cheers, but actually cool.  and the decor makes me want to live there.
author: James R.

description: I can't believe I haven't tried this place until now. Good food, cozy atmosphere. quirky staff. cool magazines and books to read. the potato pancakes are a fave and the goulash (special).
author: Missy D.

description: I love the Eastern European toiletries in the restroom, the mismatched furniture, and the velvet stapled to the walls.  I also think the food and the beer are pretty good, as are the prices.  What can I say, I can't get enough of the German food!  I'd go here more often if I had a car or lived close by.
author: jessica d.

description: Went back for an east german fix..... still just sucks.
author: sebastien r.

description: just a neutral 'remember to check this place out' review for now; a friend just recommended them to me.
author: Friedrich G.

description: We went to Walzwerk again last night. Their cheese spaetzle, as always, was DELISH  - the best in the bay area, if not California, if not the United States. Also. you should order the potato pancakes too - they're great.
author: barbara m.

description: super nice staff, and everything we ordered was delicious - sauer braten was really tender; schnitzel was perfectly fried (not too heavy); bratwurst and mashed potatoes were delicious; the pork chop was HUGE and moist. highly recommend, tho make a reservation if you don't want to wait for 1.5 hours.
author: Lisa M.

description: 96 on the DPH cleanliness score, teutonic comfort food, and great beer make this place a winner.  the service is a litte confused (salads came after entrees, soup was forgotten), but totally friendly and attentive.  would have been a five if the service was better.
author: N C.

description: When you first step into this place, your instincts may kick in and say, "let's get out of here, it is a dive".   Hopefully though you will think, "This place looks interesting" and have a seat at one of the few, but each one unique, tables.  You will then be greeted by one of the German owners most likely and if your smart, you will order a beer which they will bring to you in a unique beer stein.  Mix in the pickled herring for an appetizer and you will start to feel why this place is high on my list.  Order the Schnitzel for your entry and you will each get your own unique plate and silverware.  When your meal is finished and you have a table with drawers in it, open them up and pull out a German board game and make up your own rules of how to play it, all the while having what feels like your new friends, bringing you steins full of beer with big heads on them....the beer, not the waitresses.  This place no longer feels like a restaurant to me, but more like a friends house.
author: Pele N.

description: I must start this review by stating that my friend Markell is going to beat me down for having dined here with somebody else.  However, I feel it worked out to my advantage because I've never quite had a restaurant experience that's been so hard for me to pin down.  Thus, I'll need to return.  Here's what I know.  I had a really nice time with some friends in the back room and feel I just ordered the wrong dish (wasn't too impressed w/ the stuffed red peppers: very 7-11 microwavey).  I also think I prefer the front of the restaurant, which has a cuter, and slightly more civilized, vibe.  Now the strange part of the whole thing is that I really think I am going to love this place.  I love the yard sale sort of vibe w/ regard to the design (tables, utensils ect).  Very cute.  Also, it seemed really warm.  That is, the vibe between the owners/staff and what appeared to be a regular clientele.  Plus, any restaurant that serves mashed potatoes with practically every dish has it going on.  So, there you have it.  One of my favorite restaurants I haven't enjoyed yet ( did I mention I was outlandishly hung over that night).  Everyone says the food at Suppenkuche is better.  I'm not prepared to go there just yet.
author: Matt D.

description: low-key restaurant where everyone was laid back.  the service was attentive but not overly.  my  bf had the chicken and i ended up getting the swordfish (special of the day) - both really liked our meals.  we went on a thursday night and it was packed (it is pretty small). if you go on a friday or saturday, i'd suggest trying to make reservations.
author: michelle k.

description: EWWWWW.  Yuk.  I just know you will hate it, so go away.  You will just love soupkitchen or schnitzlepoot so go there...  Walzwerk is too busy for  you and is my personal eating eastablishment, so go away and make some other place busy, I'm sick of y'all messing up my eating agenda by getting in my way and making me wait for a table.  Enough Said!
author: Privacy P.

description: My family and friends have been going here for the past several years, but we have been here three times this year and each time was worse then the last. The first time the food was bland and the service poor. The second time the food was still poor, but looked horrible - like they simply threw it on the plate. The service was close to being rude, we had to wait for almost 30 minutes after our reservation. I let both slide as they were very busy and sometimes people sit and chat for way longer after they are done eating. However the third time we went is the last. We called and they said we didn't need reservations if we got there by 6:00. We got there at 5:50 and told there was an hour wait - I said we called and was told we didn't need reservations and the waitress had the nerve to say 'Well it got busy so stop complaining" and told us to stand there and wait.  We didn't wait, we left and will never be back. They are rude and the food has gone down hill.
author: LH N.

description: I went to Walzwerk for a birthday party and we were seated in the back room since there were over 10 of us. It's a cool little East German restaurant which got really hot inside (it was a really hot day in SF). I'm not a big fan of German food but I'd definitely think about Walzwerk if I ever had a craving.
author: See M.

description: fun, eclectic crowd...fabulous staff.  they were fun, relaxed, and served up some really delicious german food and beer.  the vibe is great...love eating to electronica.  try the stuffed chicken, and the vegetarian brat...yummy...big portions...left full...buzzed...and happy.
author: Teresa H.

description: Tasty and hearty portions, a laid-back environment and some damn good beers make this a lovely change from the usual grind of restaurants that all look and feel the same...
author: sinclair w.

description: really good german food! we usually at at spieskammer in Alameda but we were feeling adventurous and the yelpers reviews had me at schnitzel.(which by the way it  was delicious!) my husband had their special of honey and beer cooked spare ribs which was the biggest portion of meat I've ever seen and we shared the cold dog dessert. both were good but the desert could've been a larger portion.i think we were the only table that wasn't speaking german so you know it was authentic.
author: Erin T.

description: This is our go to East German restaurant, I know in SF there is a West German (yay happy Suppenkuke) and Walzwerk.  Their spatzle is delicious, brats are amazing, and wash everything down with a great beer, How good can it get!  There is quite a wait on weekends if you get there after 7:30, but the beer def helps!
author: Kristina K.

description: so much fun. we always come here and feel all hip and fassbinderish, and always wind up staying at the table long after eating. i never do that except here! it's because it's all cozy with thrift shop plateware and german pop artifacts and rad books to leaf through. the staff are sweethearts. if you have to wait for a table, just plop on a couch in the tiny red velvet waiting room and drink beer. the food is of the comfort variety, and vegetarians shouldn't be scared off because there's the spaztle, which is like mac and cheese, and the vegetarian schnitzle, which is kind of like 'german tempura.' once i had an undercooked salmon here, which was a sketchy situation but they were very nice about it and took it off the bill. that's the only reason i've dropped a star here: i fear the kitchen may be a little inconsistent.
author: jeremy l.

description: I had a group of 11 so went with the group menu...talk about value for money! We had lots of leftovers and everyone went away full and satisfied.  I think the food is as good as Suppenkuche although I like the Sauerbraten better at Suppenkuche I prefer the Spaetzel at Walzwerk.  With all the food, drinks and a few people had dessert it ended up at $40/pp including tip and tax, now that is a deal!  We had a large table in the back room and it was a great place for a large group.  Will be going back.
author: Liz B.

description: Best German food in San Francisco. The chicken, stuffed with apples and bacon is amazing, the potato pancakes are perfect. The staff is super friendly and the beer is excellent as well.
author: Del D.

description: amazing meal. i was uncomfortably full.  loved the saurbraten.  the schnitzel was tasty but a little plain.  thought the potato latkes were good but i'm not a fan of the mashed potato texture pancake.  loved the helles beer on draft.  our server was almost non-existent and when she was present, she was pretty aloof.  or is that part of the whole berlin experience?
author: dink f.

description: completely unsure how i lived in the mission for a year and had no idea this place existed. german restaurants are badly underrepresented in the city. we have an abundance of mexican, thai, indian, and sushi places to enjoy, but only four or five german ones that i can think of. and, of the three i've been to, walzwerk is the most authentic; at least in what appears to be an east german theme. i was pretty impressed by the fact all the waitresses we spoke to were either authentic germans or really good at faking an accent. i don't think i'd ever consumed herring before eating a family-style meal here for a friend's birthday recently. not sure if i'll ever eat herring again, either. the atmosphere, at least for a party, was fun and energetic. food was being passed around and new things being tried by almost everyone present. we had the entire backroom to ourselves which probably helped us have a better experience than had we been in the front surrounded by people waiting for tables. after receiving the bill, i'm not sure i'd return as the price was pretty hefty for a few beers and family-style dining of the type of food not generally associated with expensive tastes. one thing i'd have liked to have seen here was extremely large steins of beer. i associate "german" with "copious amounts of beer".
author: Jeremiah W.

description: I returned from Berlin a few weeks ago so my friends suggested we go to Walzwerk as a way to add some East German atmosphere to our conversation.  The food was perfect: very German, very hearty, and very delicious.  They had a vegetarian option that was very nice.  But the dining experience was disappointing.  We walked in and the restaurant was almost filled, and we had to stand there in the middle of the room wondering who we should talk to to get our name on a list or whatever.  It was extremely awkward.  We had two servers who were wonderful and friendly, but we were neglected badly.  After the meal they dropped off a menu for dessert and let us sit almost 15 minutes, and at the end another 15-minute wait for our check.  My two friends and I wanted to share a dessert because the dinner had been so filling, but the servers were reluctant to bring three plates so we could share cleanly.  We got this red berry thing in a glass with three spoons, and I didn't wish to eat my friends' saliva so I had to dump some of the dessert into my water glass so I could have my own portion.  The back room was very Spartan and noisy, and a crying infant made conversation impossible at our table. The bill was on the steep side, too, around $85 (including tip) for three people.  But the food was good. My suggestion is to go at an off-peak time when it's not crowded, try to sit in the front room, and bring your own plates if you want to share dessert.  Or just put up with everything and soak up what life in East Germany must have been like.
author: Daniel L.
